headline: ICL Loses $253 Million
abstract: Britain's biggest computer manufacturer, ICL, today reported a $253 million loss in its latest fiscal year. The loss in the year ended Sept. 30 was in contrast to a $19 million profit in the previous 12 months, the company said. The company did not release fiscal fourth-quarter or per-share results.

headline: SARGENT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: TEXT OF REAGAN'S ANNOUNCEMENT OF SANCTIONS   LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 (AP) - Following is the text of President Reagan's announcement today of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union:   LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 (AP) - Following is the text of President Reagan's announcement today of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union:   The Soviet Union bears a heavy and direct responsibility for the repression in Poland. For many months the Soviets publicly and privately demanded such a crackdown. They brought major pressures to bear through now-public letters to the Polish leadership, military maneuvers and other forms of intimidation. They now openly endorse the suppression which has ensued.

headline: ARMY OF PICASSO AFICIONADOS PAINTS A LITTLE SPANISH TOWN
abstract: Until recently, few people had heard of Caltojar, a village in the north-central province of Soria with one telephone and 207 inhabitants. Then Angel Nuno, the secretary of Caltojar's Town Hall, got the idea of painting imitation Picassos on its white walls and low adobe buildings.   ''At first we thought of paying homage to Velazquez,'' related the energetic Mr. Nuno. ''But then we realized that it was the year of Picasso and that 'Guernica' was about to be brought to Spain. And most of the older students in the village knew who Picasso was.''

headline: CARTER TO LOBBY SENATE ON AWACS
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter, saying the Reagan Administration should play a stronger role in the Middle East, told reporters today that he would lobby senators to support the sale of Awacs radar surveillance aircraft to Saudi Arabia.   Mr. Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, arrived by private plane at National Airport for a three-day visit, their first to Washington since Mr. Carter left office almost nine months ago.   The former President made public the text of a letter he had sent to senators urging them to support President Reagan's proposed military sale to the Saudis, which includes five Airborne Warning and Control System aircraft.

headline: Around the World; Rebels Reported Routed In 2 Salvadoran Battles
abstract: Government forces reported victories today in two major operations against guerrillas.

headline: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT SHRINKS
abstract: The nation's foreign trade deficit narrowed to $2.6 billion in September from $5.6 billion in August as the lagging United States economy depressed demand for imported goods, Commerce Department officials reported today.   Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has forecast a full-year merchandise trade deficit ''several billions'' higher than last year's $36.4 billion, but a department economist said the September figure indicated the final difference might be smaller.   ''I still expect an increase, but this shades it a little closer toward balance,'' said David Lund, the economist. He cautioned, however, against reading any major trend into one month's statistics.

headline: MOBIL HAS SETBACK ON MARATHON
abstract: A Federal District Court Judge dealt the Mobil Corporation a major blow yesterday in its bid to acquire the Marathon Oil Company by denying Mobil a preliminary injunction that would have blocked the United States Steel Corporation's rival bid.   The ruling by Judge Joseph P. Kinneary of the Federal District Court in Columbus, Ohio, came shortly after Mobil and the Amerada Hess Corporation announced jointly that they had reached an agreement under which Hess would purchase from Mobil Marathon's marketing, refining and transportation properties, if Mobil's takeover attempt were successful.   No details were given about the price Hess might pay, although the Marathon properties in question had a book value last year of $1.4 billion. Shareholders' Choices   Commenting on the judge's decision, Harvey J. Goldschmid, a professor specializing in antitrust law at the Columbia University School of Law, called it ''terribly important.''

headline: WALCO ENDS OFFER FOR GENERAL STEEL
abstract: Thwarted by questions raised about the ethics of its former chairman, Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brooklyn, the Walco National Corporation announced yesterday that it was abandoning its takeover of General Steel Industries. At the same time, General Steel agreed to be acquired by the Lukens Steel Company.   General Steel, based in St. Louis, had sued Walco to block the takeover attempt. In the course of ruling on the case, Judge H.  Kenneth Wangelin of United States District Court declared that Mr.  Richmond, who founded Walco and served as its chairman through 1978, had used his control ''improperly and unethically to appropriate Walco resources for his own personal financial and political benefit.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Burroughs Corp. said it had negotiated a $250 million revolving credit and term loan agreement with a group of 16 United States banks led by the Chase Manhattan Bank.   * I.C. Investors Inc. said that, according to a preliminary count, 2,652,000 of its common shares had been tendered or guaranteed for delivery before the expiration of the probation period on its cash tender offer to buy up to 3 million shares at $35 each.

headline: STRUGGLING FOKKER PLANS BIG PROJECT
abstract: The Fokker Aircraft Company has been feeling the pressure lately. Its civil aircraft production has not been large enough to increase profits, and its military output - Fokker makes F-16 fighters under license - is scheduled to taper off in the mid-1980's.   To complicate matters, a 12-year-old merger with Vereinigte Flugtechnische Werke, a small West German aircraft company, broke up earlier this year because of conflicting German and Dutch aviation policies.   But Fokker, trying to put its house in order, has embarked on a strategy that some industry analysts consider risky. In an effort to increase output and compensate for the maturing F-16 program, the company has joined forces with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to build a 150-seat aircraft.

headline: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BETTER HOMES: SELLING DREAMS
abstract: The magazine was called Fruit, Garden and Home when it was spawned in 1922, the same year that Reader's Digest sprang into being and a year before something called Time hit the racks. The first issue had a story about the Delicious apple, and another article went into what you could do with $50 in your backyard. In 1924, the name was rewritten to what it has been ever since - Better Homes and Gardens.   What has changed since those embryonic days is the home, as well as the people who dwell in it. But while many big circulation magazines, notably those geared for the homemaker, have been hobbled by circulation woes and identity crises, Better Homes struts along.   Feeding America's middle class a diet of insulation tips and Strawberry Banana Freeze recipes, it has never cut its circulation in its 59-year history, and, in fact, debates now whether to increase it.

headline: NATO FIRM ON SUPPORT FOR MISSILES
abstract: The Western allies said today that they were determined, despite dissenting political voices in Western Europe, to go ahead with plans to deploy new intermediate-range missiles in Europe unless the Soviet Union agreed in the next two years to ''a fair and effective arms-control agreement.''   At the end of their annual December meeting, the foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations issued a special statement dealing with the negotiations on limiting intermediaterange nuclear forces that began 12 days ago in Geneva.  They also released a communique that stressed their support for arms-control efforts.   Both documents praised the United States and were warmly received by Secretary of State of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. because they seemed to underline allied unity in relations with the Soviet Union at a time when the alliance is undergoing strains over Libya and other issues. The emphasis on proceeding with plans for nuclear modernization, while at the same time stressing a desire for arms control, was aimed both at the Soviet Union and at groups in Europe that have called for curtailment of allied plans for new nuclear forces.

headline: Correction
abstract: An article last week on chewing tobacco misidentified the company affiliation of Martin Solow. He is president of Durfee & Solow Advertising Inc. Mr. Solow's comments about trends in national sales of chewing tobacco vs. pipe tobacco were erroneously reported as those experienced by Lane Ltd., one of his firm's clients. Test marketing of Lane's Gold Star brand of chewing tobacco has been completed.

headline: Talking Business with Moore of Lang, Fisher & Stashower; For TV Ads, A New Era
abstract: As vice president and account supervisor at Lang, Fisher & Stashower, a Cleveland advertising agency, Thomas A. Moore handles advertising for a wide variety of products, ranging from soap to hardware to baby bottles, among the 49-year-old agency's $22 million a year in billings.   In addition, Mr. Moore, a graduate of Northwestern University and its Medill School of Journalism, has written articles in the business press about the image of advertising men and women in society as a whole and was co-author of an article in the Harvard Business Review about the new video technology. In a recent interview, he discussed what today's rapid technological change might mean for television advertising.   Q. What does the future hold for the television commercial?

headline: Investing; STOCKBROKERS AND THE NEW TEMPTATIONS
abstract: T HE traditional broker - the ''stock jockey'' who lives and dies on the ups and downs of various equities - is rapidly going the way of the stock ticker.   Evolving is a new sort of customer's man, one who offers a dizzying variety of financial services and products that were once primarily the purview of lawyers, accountants and tax advisers. ''The people who survive in this business are those who will be investment advisers, not stockbrokers,'' said a young Merrill Lynch account executive.   But whether this trend is an entirely benign development remains to be seen. With brokers now performing services that were once confined to banks, and exercising a potential cradle-to-grave control over family finances, the questions arise: Can the new type of broker offer the investor the same impartiality that is expected of the lawyer or tax adviser? Is the current commission structure, in which the broker has a vested interest in the investment decision, suitable? Will present safeguards be sufficient to prevent abuses of trust?

headline: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SECURITY COUNCIL AGAIN FAILS TO NAME A SECRETARY GENERAL
abstract: The Security Council went through eight more inconclusive rounds of balloting today in its attempt to choose a new Secretary General, and its members for the first time began considering how to bring other nominees into the race.   Kurt Waldheim, the Austrian diplomat who is seeking his third fiveyear term, won the minimum nine votes needed each time but was blocked by China's veto. Salim A. Salim, Tanzania's Foreign Minister, who has the support of African and other third world nations, reached that number twice before falling to eight votes. But he was blocked by an American veto.

headline: UGI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JARUZELSKI WARNS POLAND ON ENDING LABOR UNREST
abstract: Poland's official press agency, giving details of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's speech Saturday to the Communist Party Central Committee, said today that the Polish leader warned that strikes and anarchy must be halted or they would lead to a state of emergency.   ''The present situation cannot be maintained any longer,'' General Jaruzelski told the 200-member Central Committee, the press agency, P.A.P., said.   While the committee met, farmers, students and firefighter cadets continued wildcat strikes around the country.  ''The destructive process has to be stopped, or it will lead to a confrontation, to a state of war,'' General Jaruzelski said. A ''state of war'' is the expression in the Polish Constitution equivalent to a state of emergency.

headline: Soviet Oil Output Up
abstract: Soviet oil production in the first nine months of this year totaled 455 million tons, or about 3.5 billion barrels, an increase of 1 percent over the comparable period last year, Moscow radio said today.

headline: Patents; Thermal Storage Tanks For Daytime Cooling
abstract: A thermal storage system patented this week by Calvin D.MacCracken, president of Calmac Manufacturing Corporation, Englewood, N.J., is described as making it possible for the first time for ice to be frozen solid in a tank without damaging the tank.   The company, to which patent 4,294,078 is assigned, is manufacturing the equipment and plans to begin mass production soon in a new plant. Mr. MacCracken says the principal use will be to shift air-conditioning loads in buildings by making ice at night and using it for daytime cooling.

headline: CONROY INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business Conditions; A DEEPER TAX BITE
abstract: Despite calls for lower state taxes, 30 states have raised taxes by a total of $2.5 billion during the last 12 months, mainly through higher sales, excise and oil-severance taxes, according to economists at Morgan Guaranty Trust.   And last year, states collected more than $137 billion in general sales, income and other state taxes, or more than $607 a person, up 156 percent from 1970, the Tax Foundation Inc. said.

headline: GAF HEAD STEPS DOWN AFTER 10 MONTHS IN POST
abstract: The GAF Corporation announced yesterday that Jay R. Olson, president, chief executive officer and a director, had resigned those posts ''to pursue other interests.''   Last January, Richard Fleming also resigned as president, just five months after joining the company in that position. The same reason was cited for his departure. Mr. Olson was then named to the post.

headline: PEKING CALLS ITSELF PATIENT ON UNITY OFFER TO TAIWAN
abstract: A Communist official has cautioned Chinese not to expect immediate results from the overture to the Nationalists in Taiwan earlier this fall proposing reunification .   In an interview with the monthly political journal Outpost, the official, Liao Chengzhi, referred to a nine-point proposal made on Sept. 30 by Ye Jiany@ing, the chief of state, offering the Nationalists some sharing of power on the mainland while retaining their own economy and armed forces.   The offer was promptly rejected as a propaganda trick by the Nationalists, who have continued to denounce it.  Mr. Liao counseled patience and asked that the response from Taiwan not be taken too seriously.  ''They are now acting like fretful children,'' he said.  As head of the Office on Overseas Chinese Affairs, Mr. Liao is directly involved in helping the Communists compete with the Nationalists for the loyalties of the millions of Chinese living abroad. He is a member of the party's Central Committee and one of China's 20-odd vice presidents under Mr. Ye.

headline: SOUTHEAST
abstract: Employment figures in most of the Southeast, which had shone brightly in an otherwise gloomy national scene last year, are showing a decidedly darker picture this year. ''If it weren't for Florida, we would be worse off than the rest of the country,'' said Lewis R.  Jones, associate economist for the Trust Company of Georgia.   Even Florida is feeling the downturn in the economy. Last year the state registered a growth in the labor force of 5 1/2 percent. This year it will be lucky to hit 3 1/2 percent, according to labor experts. As of last June employment had grown only 1 percent.

headline: Toyo in Nigeria Talks
abstract: The Toyo Kogyo Company Ltd., Japan's third-largest car manufacturer, said today that it will start talks with the Nigerian Government on its plan to produce commerical vehicles there. A spokesman for the maker of Mazda cars said that the company is one of five candidates chosen by Nigeria. He said that Toyo Kogyo exp orted only 3,000 vehicles to Ni geria last year.

headline: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The Government will institute a trade action for the first time next week, accusing foreign governments of unfairly subsidizing steel exports to this country, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige announced. The move was viewed as increasing the dangers of a trade war. The countries that are expected to be cited are France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Rumania and South Africa. (Page A1.)   President Reagan is inclined to maintain his economic package unchanged, despite advice from aides and Republicans in Congress that he raise taxes to balance the budget. The debate within the Administration on the course of economic policy was said to be growing increasingly bitter. (D1.)

headline: RICHMOND TANK CAR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ATTACK IN ANGOLA RISKED CLOUD OF POISON GAS
abstract: Had the recent attack against Angola's sole oil refinery gone according to plan, a gigantic explosion would not only have devastated part of Luanda but could also have released a cloud of poisonous gas over the capital.   The full extent of the near disaster is just beginning to emerge as a column of black smoke still rises from the refinery on the outskirts of this city of 875,000 people.   The attack on Nov. 30 - said by the Angolans to have been carried out by mercenaries in the pay of South Africa - damaged only fuel tanks and some pipelines and did not seriously affect the refining complex itself, according to Western oil sources here.

headline: PLAYBOY SELLING 2 RESORT HOTELS FOR $42 MILLION
abstract: In an effort to shed unprofitable operations and raise much-needed cash, Playboy Enterprises Inc. announced today that it had agreed to sell its two resort hotels for $42 million to a joint venture involving Americana Hotel Inc. and Eugene Golub, the real estate investor.   The sale of the 340-room, 1,100-acre Playboy Resort and Country Club in Lake Geneva, Wis., and the 616-room, 530-acre Great Gorge Club in McAfee, N.J., is part of Playboy's broader divestiture strategy, adopted following difficulties with its gambling operations in Britain, according to the company.   ''The hotel business no longer fits Playboy's investment philosophy, except where they are part of our casino operations,'' Derick J. Daniels, Playboy's president, said. ''We are re-employing our assets in areas where we have a proven capability - communications and entertainment.''

headline: MAKING THE LIBERAL ARTS A PLUS
abstract: A LAN LUCAS stared dejectedly at the letter from Midwest Microprocessor. It was a nice enough letter, sprinkled with phrases like ''I enjoyed meeting you ... you have a fine background ... I wish you every success ....'' But the message was clear.  Midwest had no job for Alan Lucas. That rejection letter was particularly discouraging to Mr. Lucas because his roommate, Bob Abrams, had just received a job offer from Midwest, even though his grade-point average was lower than Mr. Lucas's and his campus activities were not as impressive.

headline: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allied Bancshares Inc., Houston, has elected W.C. Hatfield vice chairman of the holding company and vice chairman of its Allied Bank of Texas.   * Blasius Industries, Clifton, N.J., has elected Harold H. George, president, chief executive officer and chief operating officer, to the additional post of chairman.   * Consolidated Foods Corporation, Chicago, has elected Leo L.  Contois senior vice president-human resources.

headline: ANTICIPATING NEW UNIT, BELL SHIFTS TOP OFFICERS
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is shifting executive responsibilities as it prepares to enter new and unregulated lines of business through a separate subsidiary.   The subsidiary, authorized by the Federal Communications Commission and by the Federal District Court in Newark, still faces legal and political challenges, but would be established next year under an F.C.C. timetable.

headline: VATICAN PANEL GIVES APPROVAL TO NEW RULES ON ANNULMENTS
abstract: A Vatican commission approved a new code of universal church law today that substantially adopts the grounds for marriage annulment used in the United States for the last 11 years, according to church officials.   The new rules on marriage annulments are contained in a draft code of canon law approved by the commission of 74 cardinals and bishops at the conclusion of eight days of meetings.   An American member of the commission, Archbishop Joseph Bernardin of Cincinnati, said he was pleased with the new code's treatment of annulment, despite what he said was a minor change in annulment procedural rules.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Bankamerica Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $200 million of adjustable-rate notes due Nov. 1, 1989, to be sold through a Blyth Eastman Paine Webber group.

headline: Goldsmith Revises Offer to Diamond
abstract: The Diamond International Corporation, a diversified wood-products and paper producer, said it had received a revised merger proposal from Sir James Goldsmith, the London financier.

headline: MARMON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN OFFERS 4-POINT PLAN FOR U.S.-SOVIET MISSILE CURBS AND FORCE LIMITS IN EUROPE
abstract: President Reagan, urging that the United States and the Soviet Union take steps to avoid ''the dread threat of nuclear war,'' today proposed canceling plans to deploy new American intermediate-range missiles in Europe in return for the dismantling of comparable Soviet forces.   In a speech on arms control issues, Mr. Reagan said that he had sent Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, ''a sim- Transcript of address is on page A17. ple, straightforward, yet historic message'' setting forth a fourpoint agenda for reducing both sides' nuclear and conventional arsenals and for equalizing troop levels in Europe. Soviet-American negotiations on limiting nuclear forces in Europe are to open in Geneva in 12 days.   The emphasis in the speech, as it was in Mr. Reagan's most recent news conference, was on his desire for peace around the world. He sought to ease concerns abroad and at home about the possibility of war.

headline: VANDALS MAR ITALIAN CATHEDRAL
abstract: A close-up view of Orvieto Cathedral's 14th-century bas-relief after it was damaged by vandals.

headline: Around the World; 4 Bombings in Teheran Kill 2 and Wound 15
abstract: Four bombs exploded on Teheran's main shopping street today, killing at least 2 people and wounding 15. It was the second bomb attack this week in the Iranian capital.

headline: POLAND'S UNION ASKS FULL TURNOUT IN STRIKE TODAY
abstract: The Solidarity union called on its members today to honor a one-hour national strike tomorrow. The Polish Government continued its publicity against the job action.   At the same time the Communist Party scheduled a Central Committee meeting for tomorrow. It is expected to make more personnel changes in the leadership following the elevation of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Prime Minister and Defense Minister, to the post of the party's First Secretary.

headline: NATIONAL CAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.E. Says Theme Grows in Recognition
abstract: General Electric is probably more abreast of consumer attitudes than most corporations, and the person responsible for this is Herbert Krugman, the esteemed advertising researcher who as manager of public opinion research supervises the quarterly telephone interviews that reach 3,000 people each. G.E. has been feeling the public pulse for 17 years, not only on its own affairs and image but also on other corporations and world events.   Thanks to these surveys, Mr. Krugman could report in a speech yesterday before a research workshop of the Association of National Advertisers, speaking graphwise, that the newish G.E. theme, ''We bring good things to life,'' ''had a steeply rising slope of increased awareness and recognition never seen before in our history.''   He surmises that its strength comes from its being not just words alone but a combination of words, melody and, in the commercials, pictures.

headline: SAUNDERS LEASING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dry Dock Rate Cuts
abstract: New York's Dry Dock Savings Bank, the nation's 16th-largest mutual savings bank, said yesterday that it would cut its rate on adjustable home mortgages to 14 3/4 percent, effective immediately, and stop making conventional fixed-term mortgages entirely.   The reduction represents the first major drop in mortgage rates in more than a year from the record high levels that have kept activity in the housing market at a virtual standstill.

headline: 2-Hour Session Is Held In Geneva Missile Talks
abstract: United States and Soviet negotiators met again for two hours today to discuss reduction of medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe. No details were given in conformity with a news blackout agreed to by both sides.   Another session in the talks that began Nov. 30 was fixed for Friday.  Today's meeting took place in the Geneva office of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency in accord with the agreed rotation of sites between the two delegations.

headline: NEW PROTESTS MADE ON CANADIAN CONSTITUTION
abstract: Both opposition parties in Parliament raised new obstacles today to Government efforts to give Canada a new Constitution.   On the eve of what was expected to be the final debate on a longdiscussed and much-modified constitutional resolution, the Progressive Conservative and New Democratic Parties announced their rejection of some of the compromises reached two weeks ago in Ottawa by the federal Government and leaders of nine of the 10 provinces.  They said they would introduce amendments.   These statements came despite a warning by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau Wednesday that any further attempts to amend the resolution would imperil his accord with the provinces. Mr. Trudeau, who spoke at a news conference after introducing the modified resolution into the House of Commons, also expressed ''sadness'' at the compromises he had had to make.

headline: HOLDOVERS DOMINATE WEEK'S DEBT OFFERINGS
abstract: Investment bankers announced plans to sell more than $3.9 billion of notes and bonds this week, most of them holdovers from last week when prices gyrated so widely that issuers and investors backed away from the market.   Among the new names added to the list of those waiting to sell notes and bonds are South Central Bell Telephone Company, which plans to sell $175 million of 40-year debentures, and the World Bank, which plans to sell notes due 1986, 1988 and 1991. Last Friday, the 16 percent debentures of Southern Bell Telephone were offered in the secondary market at 103 1/8 to yield 15.51 percent.   The common ground for borrowers and lenders, this week as in November, seems to be maturities of three to 10 years and deep discount issues. According to Salomon Brothers data, intermediate issues accounted for two-thirds of the more than $5 billion of corporate debt sold in November, while nearly a third of the total was original issue, deep discount issues with either intermediate or long maturities.

headline: POLISH REGIME REPORTS END TO STRIKE AT SILESIA MILL
abstract: Polish security forces brought an end today to a strike at a steel mill in Silesia, but more than 1,000 coal miners carried their protest strike against the martial law regime into the 10th day, the Warsaw radio reported.   Government broadcasts monitored outside Poland said that 1,026 coal miners had come to the surface, but that about 1,000 remained underground in the shafts at the Ziemowit mine in Katowice Province in southern Poland.   An unspecified number of miners remained on strike at the nearby Piast coal mine, the authorities said. Other coal mines are generally operating normally, they said.

headline: AMERICAN ISRAEL PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IN SUDAN, 220 MILES CAN LAST FOREVER
abstract: A visitor was explaining to a Sudanese Army officer the other day how he had come to this place on Sudan's border with Chad whose name, in Arabic, means garden.   It had, the visitor said, taken him 13 hours in the back of a Land-Rover. Sand from the deep drifts of the desert had blown in his face, bellicose camels had bellowed from close quarters, goats at teahouses along the route had threatened to butt and, in the Marra Mountains, reckless swarms of locusts had massed in thorn trees and launched what seemed to be suicide attacks on the Land-Rover.   One insect, the visitor said mournfully, had swooped out of the dark and knocked his last cigarette from his hand. And one of his party, he recounted, had gone down with dysentry.

headline: FAR-REACHING EFFECTS FORESEEN IN FUTURE TIE
abstract: The Chicago Board of Trade's decision to join forces with the tiny and moribund New York Futures Exchange could have a far-reaching effect on the commodity futures industry, according to market participants.   The ''electronic linkage'' between the two exchanges announced Friday gives the Chicago board, which now handles about half the futures contracts traded, a vital foothold in New York.   ''If the recent spate of mergers between giant financial houses and commodity firms tells us anything,'' said Robert K. Wilmouth, the Chicago board's president, ''it is that commodities have become an integral part of the investment world, not merely peripheral marketplaces. We at C.B.T. want to become a supermarket for investments, all investments, not just commodities.''

headline: SYRIAN PRESIDENT VISITS SAUDIS
abstract: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria flew to Saudi Arabia today in the first stop of a tour of the Arabian Peninsula to work out a common Arab strategy in response to Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.   The Syrian President, who heads the hard-line Steadfastness Front, began his journey in Riyadh in what seemed to be an attempt at reconciliation with the leaders of the moderate Arab camp.

headline: TEXAS EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Nicaragua Threatens To Shut a Leading Paper
abstract: The Government has threatened to shut Nicaragua's leading opposition newspaper permanently unless its editors stop criticizing the leftist Government.   Agriculture Minister Jaime Wheelock said at a news conference here yesterday that the editors of La Prensa had been told that they must abandon their ''imperialist'' editorial policy.

headline: HELMERICH & PAYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HECLA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SENATOR BARS THRIFT UNIT BILL
abstract: Jake Garn, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, announced today that his panel would not consider Housepassed emergency legislation this year to give Federal regulators new powers to deal with financially troubled savings institutions.   But the Utah Republican said that because a ''significant consensus'' was developing between trade associations representing commercial banks and those representing the thrift institutions - savings banks and savings and loan associations - the committee would take up broader legislation early next year.   Mr. Garn's decision comes despite repeated requests by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation chairman, William M. Isaac, for emergency powers to merge financially troubled thrift institutions across state lines and to ease limitations on providing capital infusions.  Legislation passed in the House of Representatives addressed these requests.

headline: Market Place; Margin Calls: Market Threat
abstract: WITH the amount of stock in weak hands rising last month to levels approaching those of September 1974, the worst month on record, the stock market could be pushed into a painful fall. The most withering bear market in a generation ended in December 1974.   The New York Stock Exchange released its ''quality of credit'' figures for September on Wednesday. The figures clearly suggest that sustained market weakness could touch off heavy margin calls.

headline: Court Bars Offer by Armco
abstract: A Federal judge barred Armco Inc., a diversified company with a large interest in steel, from pursuing its takeover of the Ladish Company, a specialized metals foundry and forging concern based in Cudahy, Wis.   United States District Judge John F. Grady said that had he allowed the acquisition to proceed it would be ''very difficult or impossible'' later to allow competitive bidding for Ladish.

headline: Household to Sell Wien Air Alaska
abstract: Household International Inc., the former Household Finance Corporation, said that it had agreed to sell its Wien Air Alaska subsidiary to the Eagle International Corporation, a privately owned air cargo and oil exploration firm, for $50 million.

headline: BELFAST PRISONERS END HUNGER STRIKE THAT LEFT 10 DEAD
abstract: The hunger strike by Irish nationalist prisoners in Northern Ireland, in which 10 men have died since May, was called off tonight. The prisoners said they had ''reluctantly'' concluded that the families of the men now on the fast would refuse to let them die.   ''We have been robbed of the hunger strike as an effective protest weapon principally because of the successful campaign waged against our distressed relatives by the Catholic hierarchy,'' the Irish Republican Army prisoners at Maze Prison near Belfast said in a statement tonight.   Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who was awakened with the news inAustralia, where she was attending the Common wealth conference, was careful not to take a boastful stance tonight , but the collapse of the hunger strike was regarded by many as a v indication of her firm refusal to grant the prisoners the political status that they had demanded. Some I.R.A. Goals Achieved   On the other hand, the seven-month strike did achieve some of what the Irish Republican Army wanted, focusing world attention on its struggle to drive the British out of Ireland. As one young man after another starved himself to death, the Irish nationalist cause attracted sympathy and a flood of donations from around the world, especially the United States.

headline: Patents; A BICYCLE BUGGY
abstract: A buggy that can be attached to and pulled by a bicycle was patented this week by William E. Cox of Dallas.

headline: WEIDENBAUM SEES LOW GROWTH IN '82
abstract: President Reagan's chief economic adviser, Murray L. Weidenbaum, in an implicit acknowledgment that the recession will be neither mild nor brief, scaled back his forecast today for economic growth in 1982.   Instead of the 3.4 percent gain in 1982 that was forecast by the Administration in July, Mr. Weidenbaum said he expected growth of roughly 1 percent.   Mr. Weidenbaum, who is the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, reiterated a comment he made Sunday that unemployment might climb as high as 9 percent this winter. He said that he expected the peak to occur in March. The unemployment rate was 8 percent in October.

headline: WEAK ECONOMY WOULD LIMIT BUDGET CUTS, STOCKMAN SAYS
abstract: David A. Stockman, the budget director, said today that if a weak economy caused Federal revenues to fall short of forecasts, he would not seek additional spending cuts just to prevent the budget deficit from growing.   If the shortfall in revenues was essentially a result of the business cycle, Mr. Stockman said, an offsetting reduction in spending would be difficult to achieve ''and it wouldn't be wise in any event.'' An aide later confirmed that Mr. Stockman meant a further slash in spending might make the economy still weaker.   Answering questions at a press breakfast, Mr. Stockman seemed to take a dim view of putting the United States monetary system back on the gold standard. ''I don't see it as a panacea or a near-term fix,'' he said. This was his most explicit public statement on gold since a Presidential commission began reviewing the question in August.

headline: Lockheed's Stock Surges
abstract: The stock of the Lockheed Corporation surged 7 3/4 points, to 49 1/4, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as Wall Street hailed the aerospace company's decision on Monday to abandon its loss-ridden L-1011 Tristar jetliner program. More than 1 million shares were traded.

headline: 2 Japanese Climb Annapurna
abstract: Two Japanese men became the first climbers to scale the south face of Annapurna I in the Himalaya mountains and reach its 26,700-foot peak, the Nepalese Ministry of Tourism announced today. A spokesman said the two reached the summit Thursday without using oxygen. They were identified as Yukigiro Yanagisawa, 26 years old, and Hiroshi Aota, 23.

headline: NIGERIA SAID TO CUT OIL PRICE
abstract: Nigeria yesterday offered to sell crude oil to its customers at $34.50 a barrel, according to Platt's Oilgram Price Report, or $1.50 below Nigeria's discount price.   The reduction, Nigeria's second in two months, was viewed by market experts as evidence that reports that OPEC members were near a compromise on a unified base price of $34 might be premature. The reason is that the Nigerian price, because of quality and transportation surcharges of up to $5 a barrel that that country usually levies, would be too low to fit in with the accord.

headline: WHAT THE POOR WILL ASK OF THE RICH
abstract: PRESIDENTS Ronald Reagan, Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast, Abdus Sattar of Bangladesh and 19 other heads of state gather at the Mexican seaside resort of Cancun for two days of talk this week on how to improve the lot of the poor.   The leaders, eight from industrial nations and 14 from the socalled developing world, have already agreed to make no agreements, to take no actions that govern the way the world buys, sells and finances its goods and services.   Their discussions on Thursday and Friday, however, will be more than a seminar. The 22 confront a critical political decision that ultimately could affect everything from the price of jute in Bangladesh to control of the International Monetary Fund.   The leaders will decide whether to begin far-ranging negotiations on world aid and trade under the auspices of a United Nations organization - in which Vanuatu's vote would equal Japan's and where Belize and the United States count the same - or whether these issues shall remain inside the traditional postwar institutions, the I.M.F., the World Bank and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. These are institutions controlled by economic weight, thus by the rich, industrialized nations.

headline: Funds' Assets Up $2.68 Billion
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $2.68 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the 28th consecutive increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The funds' assets now stand at $185.53 billion after an average weekly increase this year of $2.3 billion.

headline: SWEARING-IN OF PAPANDREOU EXPECTED TO COME TOMORROW
abstract: Andreas Papandreou, whose Socialist party surprised even its most militant members with the extent of its election victory yesterday, is expected to be sworn in as Prime Minister on Wednesday.   With the defeat of the pro-Western New Democracy Party, Prime Minister George Rallis is due to submit the resignation of his Cabinet to President Constantine Caramanlis tomorrow morning. The formal request to Mr. Papandreou to form a new Government will follow.

headline: THE GAMES NEWSPAPERS PLAY
abstract: In hopes of holding or gaining circulation, newspapers across the country have been increasingly opening their pages to games, contests and other nonjournalistic features that seek to lure readers with thousands of dollars in cash prizes for everything from essays to crossword puzzles to variations on bingo.   Many newspaper executives say the games are highly valuable in introducing people to their pages. But the increased use of the contests in recent years is questioned by some industry analysts as being of limited value since the circulation gains they bring are largely temporary.   The games are often employed by newspapers that are fighting for the same readership - such as New York's two major tabloids, The Daily News and The Post. Large Cash Prizes Offered   Though they have been losing money, the two papers are currently trying to attract new readers with much-promoted, bingo-like games that feature large cash prizes. The Post's game, Wingo, and The News's Super Zingo both made their debuts last month. Super Zingo has lately been joined by a variation, Instant Zingo. The Post this week is offering a grand prize of $100,000.

headline: Around the World; Zimbabwean Police Seek Clues to Bombing
abstract: Police forensic experts examined the rubble of the Salisbury headquarters of Zimbabwe's governing party today for clues to who planted a bomb that killed 6 people and wounded 85 Friday.

headline: Bristol-Myers Names Phillips to Clairol Unit
abstract: Robert M. Phillips, who has been president of the health and beauty products division of Chesebrough-Ponds, is joining Bristol-Myers's Clairol Products division as executive vice president ''with primary responsibility for marketing and sales of retail hair color and toiletries.''

headline: Mutual Fund Sales Up
abstract: Sales of mutual funds other than short-term rose to $883.1 million in November from $866.5 million in October and compared with $863.6 million in November last year, according to a report by the Investment Company Institute of Washington, D.C. Redemptions, the report said yesterday, increased to $495.8 million in November from $452.1 million in the previous month. They amounted to $630.8 million in November last year. As a result, the mutual funds surveyed had net sales of $387.3 million in November, $414.4 million in October and $232.8 million in November last year, the report said.

headline: KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Canada Trade Surplus
abstract: Canada's September trade surplus fell to $65 million (Canadian) from August's upward-revised figure of $372 million and last September's $553 million, Statistics Canada said today. The federal agency said that seasonally adjusted September exports totaled $6.96 billion, up from $6.95 billion in August and $6.04 billion last September, while imports totaled $6.90 billion, up from $6.58 billion in August and $5.49 billion in September 1980.

headline: SOVIET WARNS FINNS TO SELECT PRESIDENT WITH CARE
abstract: The Soviet Union cautioned Finland yesterday against ''any miscalculation'' in the choice of a President to succeed 81-year-old Urho Kekkonen, who resigned last month for reasons of ill health.   In the first extensive comment on the Finnish leadership question, Pravda, the newspaper of the Soviet Communist Party, said that otherwise the result might be ''events that are at present difficult to forecast.'' There was no elaboration.

headline: Quaker May Sell Its Restaurants
abstract: The Quaker Oats Company said it was studying inquiries about the possible sale of all or part of its restaurant division. William D.  Smithburg, Quaker's president and chief executive officer, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Chicago that the company's restaurants are ''not a profitable business and we are continuing to review and reduce our investment by closing weaker stores.''

headline: Market Nations Decide Against Poland Talks
abstract: Britain said today that the Foreign Ministers of the European Economic Community had decided not to hold a special emergency meeting about Poland Wednesday, as had been considered.   Instead, senior diplomatic officials from the 10 member nations will come to London to discuss the Polish crisis.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Court Takes Japanese Job Suit
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether American subsidiaries of foreign corporations are required to abide by the Federal law that forbids discrimination in employment, despite trade treaties that appear to give the companies discretion in hiring.   The case involves a New York company, Sumitomo Shoji America, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of a Japanese import-export company. The New York company hired only male Japanese nationals for management positions, and was sued by a group of women secretarial employees on the ground that the policy violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.   The company argued that it was exempt from Title VII on the basis of the Treaty of Friendship, Commerce and Navigation between the United States and Japan. This 1953 treaty, similar to other trade treaties, allows companies of one country doing business in the other country to hire ''technical experts, executive personnel and other specialists of their choice.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * CBS Inc. has appointed Donald D. Wear Jr. vice president, Washington affairs, and J. Roger Moody vice president, development.   * Chelsea Industries has named Emil S. Bernstein vice president of finance and corporate development.

Glenn has been named vice president in charge of worldwide advertising, publicity and promotion for Avco Embassy Pictures Corporation, Los Angeles.

headline: Continental Air Reports Loss
abstract: Continental Air Lines today reported a third-quarter loss of $12.2 million on operating revenues of $305 million, bringing its loss for the first nine months of the year to $50 million.

headline: BANGLADESH LEADER SAID TO THWART ARMY PLOT
abstract: Abdus Sattar, the 75-year-old judge elected President of Bangladesh yesterday, reportedly thwarted a plan by army officers during the campaign to install him as the civilian head of a military regime.   Mr. Sattar, who won a sweeping victory in Sunday's election, which is being challenged as unfair by his leading opponent, had originally been persuaded to seek the presidency by leading army figures. At the time, just after the assassination of President Ziaur Rahman, Mr. Sattar, then the Vice President, was hospitalized with serious ailments. He told close aides that he feared he would be unable to campaign, but changed his mind in the face of arguments that the party built around the charismatic personality of President Zia could disintegrate without his candidacy.

headline: Cessna Aircraft
abstract: The Cessna Aircraft Company said that it had acquired, for an undisclosed price, the United Hydraulics Corporation in order to expand the product line of its Fluid Power Division, company officials said. Cessna's chairman, Russ Meyer, said that United Hydraulics, a unit of the Amerace Corporation, based in Hampton, Iowa, would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Cessna. United Hydraulics has about 200 workers and builds large hydraulic cylinders used in strip mining equipment and by heavy industries.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

headline: A Polish Cellist Applies For Asylum in the U.S.
abstract: A 31-year-old Polish cellist who has been studying at Yale University announced today that she had applied for political asylum in the United States.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Israel appears to be the biggest winner to emerge from the Arab League meeting that broke up in disarray here Wednesday night after only four acrimonious hours.   Among the clear losers seem to be Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization; Saudi Arabia; Lebanon; the United States, and the concept of Arab unity.   Israel, through no effort of its own, escaped the onus of being the obstacle to opening some form of new peace negotiations in the Middle East. Now the Israelis can point to the hard-line Arab countries and the Palestinian guerrillas as rejecting not just any peace overture, but one that originated with the Arabs themselves.  The turnabout could help to erase the memory of the bombing raids on Baghdad and Beirut last summer and restore Israel's image as a small, embattled land surrounded by implacable enemies.

headline: U.N. ASSEMBLY, FOR 3D TIME, BIDS 'FOREIGN TROOPS' QUIT AFGHANISTAN
abstract: The General Assembly renewed its demand today that ''foreign troops'' leave Afghanistan.  This was the third time since Moscow's military intervention in that country in December 1979 that the Assembly issued such a call, and the vote was again lopsided. Today, 116 nations supported the resolution, 23 were opposed and 12 abstained.   The document does not mention the Soviet Union by name and urges a pullout of ''foreign troops.'' But the three days of debate left no one in doubt that the 85,000 Soviet soldiers in Afghanistan were the object of the resolution.

headline: Court Upholds Penn Central
abstract: A three-judge Federal appeals panel denied a request by two Penn Central Corporation stockholders to delay the company's Thursday meeting at which shareholders are to vote on its proposed merger with Colt Industries.   The two-page decision, written by Judge Arlin M. Adams of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, said that Howard L. Terry of Houston and W. Herbert Hunt of Dallas failed to prove that they would win their appeal of a lower court judge's decision to dismiss the suit.

headline: I.R.A. PRISONERS IN ULSTER CALL NEW BRITISH RULES INADEQUATE
abstract: Irish Republican Army prisoners in Maze Prison outside Belfast reacted critically today to the British Government's new prison rules for Northern Ireland.   In a statement smuggled out of the prison, they said the decision to allow prisoners to wear their own clothing was ''a positive move in the right direction.''   But they descr ibed as vengeful and inadequate a proposal to count only half the time they have spent on protests toward their early release for g ood behavior. The prisoners had wanted to count all the time lost bec ause of protests.

headline: GULF UP
abstract: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income fell by 7.3 percent. The Gulf Oil Corporation, No.6, reported that its earnings climbed by 29.5 percent.   Wall Street analysts said that the results of both companies were better than expected, reflecting inventory profits, among other things. Constantine Fliakos of Merrill Lynch said that the ''underlying operations'' of both companies ''are a little weaker than I had thought.'' In particular, both Gulf's and Texaco's results were impaired by problems in their European refining business.

headline: 2 SAVINGS BANKS MAY TAKE OVER THE GREENWICH
abstract: The troubled Greenwich Savings Bank, with deposits of $2 billion, is expected to be merged into two Brooklyn-based savings banks that had announced plans last April to merge with each other.   The Greenwich merger would be accomplished with Federal help to keep the bank from failing.  Banking sources said yesterday that the two banks were the Metropolitan Savings Bank, the 12th-largest in New York City, and the Brooklyn Savings Bank, the 17th-largest. Greenwich is the 9th-largest in the city. If the three-way merger goes through, the combined institution would have deposits of about $6 billion, which would make it the largest savings bank in New York and the second-largest in the nation, behind the $7 billion Philadelphia Savings Fund Society.

headline: Hoechst Earnings Off
abstract: Worldwide profits before taxes of the Hoechst Group in the third quarter of 1981 slipped 13.8 percent, to $94 million, from $109 million, the company said yesterday.

headline: ROYAL INSURANCE MAKES U.S. CHANGES
abstract: The American subsidiary of Britain's Royal Insurance Company has named George W. Ansbro, 53 years old, as president and chief operating officer, effective next Jan. 1. He will succeed William C.  Simpson, 63, who will retire from the New York-based organization.  J. Roy Nicholas, a 59-year-old executive of the American company, continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: DISAFFECTED EXECUTIVES TURN TO VERMONT BUSINESS BROKER
abstract: For 14 years, Michael Balser worked his way up the corporate ladder to vice president at the Shipley Company, a family-owned, Boston-based chemical company.   But Mr. Balser, working under a young president who had no plans to leave, thought he had reached a dead end in his early 40's. He feared that he could spend another 14 years at the company performing the same tasks.   Eager to try to his hand at running his own company, Mr. Balser enlisted the help of Country Business Services, a Brattleboro, Vt., brokerage specializing in finding small businesses in New England and northern New York for the disaffected corporate employee ready to become self-employed.

headline: Patents; Fleischmann Award
abstract: Isaac Fleischmann, who retired this week as director of information services after serving the Patent and Trademark Office for 35 years, was presented by the Department of Commerce with a new public affairs award at a reception in his honor. Called the Isaac Fleischmann Award, it will be granted to others in the future. To get a copy of a patent, send number and 50 cents to the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

headline: LEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Bunker Hill Delay
abstract: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation said that it had extended until Jan. 15 an agreement for the possible sale of its Bunker Hill Company copper-mining subsidiary to three private Idaho-based investors. The agreement, which calls for the sale of Bunker Hill to Duane B. Hagadone, H.F. Magnuson and J. William Pfeiffer for $65 million in cash and notes, was due to expire tomorrow.

headline: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN OCTOBER BY A SLIGHT 0.4%
abstract: With housing prices falling and food inflation slowing, the Consumer Price Index rose by only four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the smallest increase in six months.   Spread over a year, such a monthly increase would add up to an annual inflation rate of only 4.8 percent, not compounded. That was a welcome slowdown from the pace of more than 10 percent in the summer months and economists said they expected the index to continue to show small rises for several more months.   A decline last month of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the sale price of houses was symptomatic of the way many economists hope that the current recession as well as high interest rates -which have been savaging the housing market - will squeeze down inflation.

headline: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LABOR PARTY IN BRITAIN VOTES TO QUIT THE COMMON MARKET
abstract: The Labor Party's annual conference voted overwhelmingly today in favor of British withdrawal from the European Economic Community without a referendum.   The size of the margin - more than 5 to 1 - means that a commitment to withdrawal will be in the Labor campaign platform, and that a future Labor government will be committed to leaving the Common Market. Michael Foot, the party leader, plans to go to Brussels before the end of the year to discuss with Socialists from other countries Labor's reasons for believing that it must withdraw as soon as possible.

headline: Dresser Net Rises
abstract: Dresser Industries reported a rise in net income in the fourth quarter, ended Oct. 31, to $94.8 million, or $1.21 a share, from $87.5 million, or $1.12, in the similar 1980 period.

headline: STEWART INFORMATION SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Change at Videofashion
abstract: Nicholas H. Charney, founder of Psychology Today and currently chairman and editor of Videofashion Monthly, will announce today that his video magazine will go next month from a program distributed as a tape or a disk to a 28-minute feature with the potential to reach 8 million cable TV subscribers via the Modern Satellite Network and the Satellite Programming Network.

headline: SYRIA, AN ANCIENT CROSSROADS, SEEKS TOURISTS
abstract: Syria, which has a 100-mile-long Mediterranean coastline, is planning to develop new beach resorts in an effort to attract foreign tourists.   Tourism Minister George Radwan said. "We have some spectacular coast with sandy beaches, and together with our historical sites - like the Roman ruins at Palmyra and the castles from Crusader times - we think that Syria could become a popular destination."   He added that by 1985 the Government hoped that the number of tourists visiting Syria would more than double, to about three million.

headline: POLISH RULERS TRY TO COAX STRIKERS OUT OF SILESIAN COAL MINES FOR
abstract: CHRISTMAS The following article is based on information reaching news agencies from Poland.   Intense efforts were under way in Poland to lure the striking Silesian coal miners to the surface. A radio report described the conditions of their protest and said ''families should spend Christmas together.''   The two mines, Ziemowit and Piast at Tychy, near Katowice, appear now to be the main continuing source of resistance to martial law, and the Government is eager to end the sit-in.

headline: MASTER OF NAMESMANSHIP
abstract: T HE Allied Chemical Corporation becomes the Allied Corporation.  United Aircraft becomes United Technologies. The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company becomes Chemical Bank. Who's responsible for all this?   Company executives don't impulsively decide to dump the name lovingly created by the founder. When a company suffers an identity crisis, real or imagined, there are consulting firms that lay the corporation on the couch, so to speak, and examine its psyche - why it has no friends, why it has perceptions of itself that don't correspond to reality.   One of the most successful practitioners of this psychology is Walter P. Margulies, the grandmaster of corporate namesmanship, who sits in a modern corner office high above Park Avenue presiding over the renaming of companies and the reshaping of their corporate image.

headline: SANTA FE DATA CITED
abstract: The president of the Pacific Stock Exchange said today that his organization had no hard evidence - but much suspicion - that insider information was used in the trading of Santa Fe International Corporation stock options.   Jim Gallagher, the exchange's president, told a Congressional committee that ''the information we have gathered seems to indicate a strong possibility that such illegal trading activity did occur.''

headline: Advertising; Addenda
abstract: * Bernard D. Kahn Associates now called Kahn/Larsen/Walsh Inc.   * Young & Rubicam International's office in Oslo, and Scaneco, a Norwegian advertising agency, will merge to form Scaneco-Young & Rubicam.

headline: CHAD REFUGEES IN CAMEROON BALK AT RETURNING TO HOMES
abstract: Tens of thousands of Chadian refugees live here in huts of plaited straw and plastic sheeting in sight of the homes they have decided to desert for good.   Relief workers say 100,000 Chadians have fled to this camp, which was built on a former swamp during a rebellion a year ago.  Libyan troops drove rebel forces of former Defense Minister Hissen Habre out of Chad's capital of Ndjamena, but 50,000 Chadian refugees remain in this camp. They have refused to return to Chad, the relief workers said, either because of associations with the Armies of the North, as Mr. Habre's forces are called, or simply out of fear that strife will erupt again in their capital just across the Shari River.

headline: Market Place; An Offering With Risks
abstract: ROONEY, PACE INC. marketed a million units of Inteleplex Corporation on Wednesday and in doing so may have brought back the concept of public offerings for unseasoned companies.   It is a coincidence perhaps, but Rooney, Pace took over the New York offices of John Muir & Company when Muir went out of business last August after dominating the market for new issues for high-risk companies.   In the second page of a preliminary offering plan, Inteleplex pictures a dazzling array of telephone and computer equipment. Apart from this, however, there seems little to inspire confidence in the 35-page document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Anta Corp. said it would purchase on the open market up to 100,000 shares of Anta common stock.   * Ashland Oil Inc. said its Ashland Oman Co. subsidiary had signed an agreement with the Government-controlled Oman Refinery co. to provide management and operating services on a 50,000-barrel-a-day refinery near the city of Muscat in Oman.   * City Investing Co. said that about 2,879,440 GDV Inc. common shares had been tendered for purchase under City Investing's tender offer for GDV shares.

headline: AUSTRIAN CHANCELLOR AND ECONOMY ARE AILING
abstract: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky and the Austrian economy are ailing these days - not gravely, but enough to prompt renewed speculation here about a governmental succession or change.   In the last few months Mr. Kreisky has suffered from an eye problem, an attack of pneumonia and gout. In the same period the economy has suffered from increasing trade and budget deficits and rising inflation.   Mr. Kreisky, who is 71 years old, has served longer than any other Western European head of government, with 11 years behind him in the Ballhaus Palace, where Prince Metternich once ruled. In a career as a Social Democratic politician spanning half a century, Mr. Kreisky has achieved a renown that reaches well beyond Austria.

headline: VORNADO TO INCREASE STORE CLOSINGS BY 18 UNITS
abstract: In a move that points to its intent to sharply limit its retailing activities, Vornado Inc., operator of the Two Guys discount store chain, said yesterday that its board had approved the closing soon of an additional 18 stores. The loss-ridden company two weeks ago said it planned to close 12 other stores.   The company, which only a year ago operated 49 Two Guys units, primarily in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, will have only 12 stores in operation after the 30 stores are closed, Vornado said. Three units have previously been closed this year.

headline: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELIS TAKE NO ACTION ON EUROPEANS
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin conferred today in his hospital room with key Cabinet members on the draft of a proposed American-Israeli statement designed to clear the way for European participation in a Sinai peacekeeping force.   No decision was reached on whether to accept the Europeans, Israeli Government officials said. But Mr. Begin, who is recovering from a broken thigh suffered in a fall three days ago, was described by an aide as willing to issue the joint statement, which would reaffirm the Camp David agreement as the only existing framework for Middle East peace and the sole basis for establishing the Sinai force.   The European reaction to this would then determine Israel's position, the officials said. It was not clear whether the Europeans would have to issue a positive statement of their own endorsing Camp David, or whether silence would satisfy the Government.

headline: AUSTRIAN SEES A DANGEROUS CRISIS
abstract: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky said today that the crisis in Poland could become the most serious threat to world peace since World War II.   Helping to create such a threat, he declared, is the news from Poland of violent resistance to the military crackdown. He also cited what he described as the risk that the Soviet Union might intervene.

headline: STOCKS FALL DESPITE PRIME CUT
abstract: The stock market, despite a reduction in the prime interest rate by a number of major banks, ended slightly lower yesterday in accelerated trading.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the session, closed down 3.90 points, to 865.58.  In the overall market, decliners on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advancers by the narrow margin of 744 to 720. The best performers were some of the takeover candidates.

headline: Article 102290 -- No Title
abstract: Forty-eight nations have pledged more than $122 million to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to continue its programs in 1982. The organization, which won the Nobel Peace Prize this year, has set a goal of $338 million.

headline: Joint Venture In U.S. Coal Set
abstract: The American Natural Resources Company and Petrofina S.A. of Brussels said they had agreed in principle to form an equally owned joint venture to mine and market Eastern United States coal, including those reserves now owned by a subsidiary of American Natural. The agreement provides that affiliated comp anies of the two groups will form a partnership to which American Nat ural's subsidiary, the ANR Coal Company, will contribute its assets, including 500 million tons of clean recoverable coal reserves and r elated mining, processing and loading facilities.

headline: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Financing Oil Hunt by China
abstract: China will need $20 billion to finance offshore oil exploration and production by 1990, a prominent Hong Kong banker said here today.   Michael Sandberg, chairman of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, told delegates to an oil conference here that ''if drilling is initiated early in 1982, at least $10 billion will be required to fund exploration and production by 1985, followed by another $10 billion by 1990.''

headline: F.T.C. NEAR DEADLINE ON MOBIL BID
abstract: Staff lawyers for the Federal Trade Commission may recommend a two-part plan that would enable the Mobil Corporation to go ahead with a $5 billion takeover bid for the Marathon Oil Company, sources close to the Government agency said yesterday.   The plan, these sources said, called for the F.T.C. to seek additional information from Mobil about the economic impact of its takeover. But instead of enabling Mobil to proceed 10 days after it supplied the data, as provided by law, Mobil would be permitted to go ahead immediately in exchange for assurance that the two companies would be kept separate for six months while the F.T.C studied the antitrust implications of a merger.   The F.T.C., which must act by midnight Saturday if it intends to prevent Mobil from proceeding with its takeover, will soon ask Mobil to supply the additional data, these sources said.

headline: Real Estate; Houston, First, Then On to Rye
abstract: RYE, N.Y.  JONATHAN MORSE tells this tale: An office construction site came on the market outside Houston in 1974 and nobody would touch it. It seems that the location was a bit off the beaten track, or perhaps beyond it.   But Mr. Morse and John C. Harvey, two architects who formed a partnership in Manhattan in 1970, were the new boys in town. They had designed for others but never built as investors. Mr. Morse went to Houston in 1977 specifically to find a site for their first venture.

headline: MINNESOTA FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

headline: GAS PRICE'S 'CATEGORY CREEP'
abstract: The price of natural gas is rising faster than had been contemplated under the 1978 legislation that partly decontrols gas prices, mainly because producers have become increasingly vigorous in adapting their operations to qualify for maximum prices from their wells.   This activity of gas producers has resulted in what has been dubbed ''category creep,'' a recently recognized phenomenon that distributors say could raise wellhead gas prices -and therefore the prices paid by consumers - by perhaps as much as $4 billion next year.   Category creep appears to be entirely legal. It is essentially the effort of producers to get their gas classified in higher-priced categories established under the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978.   ''Producers are creatively finding ways to increase their prices,'' declared Benjamin Schlesinger, a vice president of the American Gas Association, which represents gas pipelines and the utilities that buy gas from producers and sell it to consumers. He mentioned such practices as drilling old wells deeper or drilling new wells to tap old fields so that the gas produced qualifies for higher prices.

headline: Liggett Chief Elected
abstract: Jonathan W. Old Jr., the 57-year-old executive vice president of the Liggett Group, has been elected president and chief executive officer, effective Feb. 1, 1982. He will succeed Raymond J. Mulligan, who will retire at age 60 from Liggett, the American consumer products subsidiary of Britain's Grand Metropolitan.

headline: SOVIET BIDS U.S. MIND ITS OWN BUSINESS
abstract: The Soviet Union used a press commentary today to tell the Reagan Administration that the declaration of martial law in Poland was none of America's business.   Apart from a formal statement Monday by the official press agency Tass that declared events in Poland to be the ''internal affair'' of the Poles, the commentary today, also by Tass, was the closest thing to an official Soviet pronouncement since the Polish Communist leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, announced the crackdown on the independent trade union Solidarity three days ago.   Although the Reagan Administration has emphasized the need for restraint in statements on Poland so as not to provoke direct Soviet military intervention, the Tass commentary said that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and other senior officials had set ''imperialist terms'' for the resolution of Poland's domestic problems.   ''While interfering in the domestic affairs of the sovereign Polish state,'' the commentary said, ''the United States is trying to prove that the events in Poland in some way concern U.S. security interests. But Poland is a member of the Warsaw Pact treaty organization, a member of the Socialist community of states, and the United States should not look there for any 'security zone,' as Washington is doing practically in all other parts of the globe.''

headline: People
abstract: * Brian J. Gail has been appointed a senior vice president of Ted Bates Advertising/New York.   * Michael J. Ball of Sydney, Australia, named vice chairman of Ogilvy & Mather International.

headline: U.S. SCIENTISTS APPEAL TO BREZHNEV OVER SAKHAROV
abstract: American scientists have sent messages to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, and to President Reagan to try to avert a hunger strike by Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, which he has said he will begin Sunday to press for the emigration of his stepson's fiancee.   The messages were signed by 25 scientists, including 18 Nobel laureates, among them two winners this year for physics, Nicolaas Bloembergen of Harvard and Arthur Schawlow of Stanford.   At the same time, a number of scientists and specialists on the Soviet Union expressed concern that there was little that Americans could do to influence Moscow because of cutbacks over the last few years in academic exchanges.   The reductions are a result of earlier protests over Soviet human rights violations and the intervention in Afghanistan, as well as a decrease by the Reagan Administration in Federal financing for exchange programs.

headline: STATEMENT BY WHITE HOUSE
abstract: Following is the text of a statement by the deputy press secretary of the White House, Larry Speakes, which he read to reporters today:   After reviewing the article on David Stockman in the current Atlantic Monthly, the President today directed Mr. Stockman to meet with him. Mr. Stockman and the President met alone for lunch in the Oval Office from 12:45 to 1:30.   Mr. Stockman acknowledged that he had made a mistake and apologized for what he has now come to recognize as a grievous error.

abstract: Some of the thousands of demonstrators in Stockholm as they protested the declaration of martial law in Poland.

abstract: Following is the text of a draft resolution on Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights that was prepared for Security Council consideration:   THE SECURITY COUNCIL, HAVING CONSIDERED the letter of 14 December 1981 from the permanent representative of the Syrian Arab Republic contained in document S/14791,   REAFFIRMING that the acquistion of territory by force is inadmmissible, RECALLING the Geneva Convention Relative to the Protection of Civilian Persons in Time of War of 12 August 1949 and reaffirming its applicability to the occupied Syrian Golan Heights,   1. CONSIDERS that the Israeli decision to impose its laws, jurisdiction and administration in the occupied Golan Heights are null and void;   2.

headline: BOMB AT P.L.O. OFFICE KILLS AT LEAST 50
abstract: A car packed with more than a hundred pounds of explosives blew up today outside Palestinian guerrilla offices in a crowded street, killing at least 50 people and wounding more than 250, according to officials.   The explosion, the sixth and worst of its kind in two weeks, tore the facade from five buildings and squashed cars in the Fakhani neighborhood of Moslem West Beirut.   As ambulances fought their way through traffic and guerrillas fired submachine guns into the air, Palestinian forces reported finding three other booby-trapped cars in the area.   The blast came a day after a group calling itself the Front for the Liberation of Lebanon from Foreigners, which had claimed responsibility for the previous bombings, told the French-language newspaper L'Orient-Le Jour that it would direct its campaign against Syrian and Palestinian targets.

headline: SEARS WILL PURCHASE DEAN WITTER IN PLAN TO OFFER FINANCIAL SERVICES
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's biggest retail store chain, announced yesterday that it would buy Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., the fifth-largest brokerage house, for about $607 million in cash and stock.   The acquisition is a major step in the Chicago-based retailer's stated goal of becoming the ''largest consumer-oriented financial service entity'' in the country.   The developing Sears strategy would permit the huge retailer, with more than 800 stores, to sell a customer a house, get him a mortgage and handle his investments, as well as sell him furniture and apparel, service his car and write his insurance.   The agreement to acquire Dean Witter, which had been rumored for days, marks the third time this year that a major American corporation has undertaken to acquire a top brokerage house in the new competition among major corporations to provide comprehensive financial services.

headline: LIBYA TRIES TO PREVENT CONSENSUS FAVORING SAUDI'S PEACE PROPOSALS
abstract: Libya is trying to prevent the development of an Arab consensus in favor of a Saudi Arabian plan for a Middle East peace settlement.   Libya will be chairman of a meeting of the 22-member Arab League on Nov. 25 in Fez, Morocco, and is campaigning to keep the issue off the agenda. Saudi Arabia, however, with the support of other Persian Gulf Arab countries, is expected to win consideration of its plan.

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 12, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
abstract: Meets on the United Nations force in Cyprus at 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 3 P.M. and 7:30 P.M.

headline: Pravda Denounces Cancun Conference
abstract: The Soviet party newspaper Pravda today condemned the coming conference between industrialized and developing nations in Cancun, Mexico, as an attempt by the West to divide third world countries and subjugate them to satisfy its own economic interests.   ''The experience of the past shows that such meetings cannot produce positive results unless capitalist states radically change their approach to the developing countries,'' the Communist Party newspaper said.

headline: INVESTOR IN ST. JOE IDENTIFIED
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday identified Guiseppe Tome, an Italian citizen living in Switzerland and a close friend of Edgar M. Bronfman, head of the Seagram Company, as the purchaser of securities in the St. Joe Minerals Corporation in advance of an attempted takeover of St. Joe by Seagram last March.   In a related development, Judge Milton Pollack of the United States District Court in Manhattan yesterday ordered Banca Della Svizzera Italiana of Switzerland, through which the orders were placed, to identify clients involved in St. Joe stock and option purchases.  Judge Pollack had said last Friday that he would issue the order at the S.E.C.'s request.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Your Money; Reagan Cuts In Student Aid
abstract: IF the budget cutters in the Reagan Administration have their way, Federal aid to low- and middle-income families putting children through college will be drastically curtailed next year.   Proposed regulations, quietly published in the Federal Register last week, would greatly increase the amount of money that many parents are expected to contribute to their children's education before qualifying for Federal aid.   ''It's totally outrageous to issue the regulations at this point,'' said Robert Leider, publisher of several well-regarded guides on college financial aid. ''High school seniors are now in the process of applying to colleges, and they're doing so in the dark because they have no idea what kind of financial assistance will be available to them. Any changes should have been set in concrete at the beginning of the school year.''
