headline: POLAND WITHDRAWING TROOPS
abstract: The Polish Army announced tonight that it was withdrawing the hundreds of small military units sent to the countryside four weeks ago to help curb unrest.   The announcement, made on Polish television, said the soldiers would be recalled temporarily beginning tomorrow but would be ready to return.   The Government announced on Oct. 23 that it was sending special groups of officers to the countryside to resolve local disputes and insure the smooth distribution of supplies. A Government official said at the time that the units would operate in about 2,000 rural communes.

headline: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOVIET SAID TO JAM RADIO TO WARSAW
abstract: The United States, seeking to emphasize Moscow's support of the military crackdown in Poland, accused the Soviet Union today of ''heavily jamming'' the Voice of America's Polish-language broadcasts into Poland.   Alan D. Romberg, a State Department spokesman, noted that since August 1980 the Soviet Union has been jamming Voice of America broadcasts in Russian and other Soviet languages beamed to the Soviet Union.   He said of the latest jamming, which involves the broadcasts to Poland and began Monday night: ''The refusal by the Soviet authorities to permit their own citizens - and now the people of Poland as well - to know the facts about events in Poland and elsewhere is a renewed demonstration of the glaring weaknesses of the Soviets' own system and of the regime they have imposed on Poland.'' Effort Aimed at Allies   The Administration also stepped up its efforts to convince the allies and others that, although the crackdown is being carried out by Poles, the Soviet Union is largely responsible for it. Many European governments have persisted in limiting their criticism to the Polish military Government.

headline: Backer & Spielvogel Wins Lestoil Account
abstract: Again? Yes, Backer & Spielvogel has landed another account. This time its for the Lestoil products from the Noxell Corporation, which had been at Foote, Cone & Belding for seven years.

headline: SUDANESE, DISPERSING POWER, DISBAND PARLIAMENTS
abstract: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan dissolved his country's two parliaments today in a move that Sudanese officials described as a further step in Mr. Nimeiry's plan to decentralize power in the vast and troubled nation.   It was not immediately clear whether Mr. Nimeiry's step was related to the crisis between the Sudan and Libya. For several weeks now, there have been skirmishes on the Sudan's western border with Chad, where Libyan troops have been stationed since December and have aided one side in the Chadian civil war. There have also been charges from Sudanese officials that Libyan planes have been raiding Sudanese border towns.

headline: The Economy
abstract: The Treasury will give details this week of its financing plans for the rest of 1981. Heavy Government borrowing throughout the year has been a key ingredient in the behavior of the credit markets, and further debt sales could have an even larger impact. (Page D1.)

headline: EUROPEANS TO LAUNCH GE UNIT SATELLITE
abstract: In the emerging competition between European and American satellite launching services, a private European company, Arianespace, won a major marketing victory yesterday by signing its first contract to launch a communications satellite for an American customer.   The GTE Satellite Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, announced that the contract, valued at approximately $50 million, called for Arianespace to launch two satellites in 1984 by advanced Ariane rockets, which are being developed by the 11-nation European Space Agency. Arianespace, a French-dominated company, was formed last year to finance, produce, market and launch the Ariane rockets.

headline: Profits Up 25% At First Boston
abstract: First Boston Inc., the investment bank holding company, reported sharply higher earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30.  Its net income rose 25 percent, to $7.5 million from $6 million in the third quarter of 1980.

headline: SENATE VOTES TO END BAN ON AID TO ANGOLAN REBELS
abstract: The Senate voted today to repeal an amendment that bars the United States from aiding rebels fighting the Marxist regime in Angola.   Known as the Clark Amendment, after former Senator Dick Clark, an Iowa Democrat, the aid ban was removed from the foreign assistance bill by voice vote. An earlier attempt by liberal Democrats to make the repeal contingent on progress toward peace in southern Africa was defeated by a vote of 66 to 29.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: American Airlines To Cut 454 Jobs
abstract: American Airlines said that it had sent layoff notices to 320 management and 134 clerical employees whose jobs were being eliminated in its continuing effort to cut costs to cope with fare competition, a decline in air travel and flight reductions resulting from the air controllers' strike.   Earlier this week, the Dallas-based airline asked its 35,000 employees to accept a 5 percent pay cut for the first three months of 1982 and a wage freeze for the rest of the year.

headline: E.E.C. Textile Plan
abstract: The European Economic Community today proposed a new world textile agreement to restrain a surge in clothing imports from major third world producers. The draft for a new pact, to succeed the current multifiber arrangement when it expires at the end of the year, would drop provisions in the 1977 treaty allowing nations with threatened home industries to make ''reasonable departures'' from a guarantee of a 6 percent annual increase in textile imports from developing countries. Third world nations have attacked the ''departures'' clause as discriminatory.

headline: WALDHEIM'S PERSISTENCE STIRS CONCERN
abstract: Some senior diplomats from countries supporting Secretary General Kurt Waldheim fear that his pursuit of a third five-year term has damaged his prestige and that of his office.    The envoys, Asian and Western, who would not allow their names to be used, differ on the extent of the damage. Some argue that memories are short, that when the Security Council finally breaks the deadlock that has lasted through 16 rounds of balloting, no lasting consequences will ensue. Others, however, contend that the prolonged contest and Mr. Waldheim's active campaigning will have weakened the Secretary General's influence.

headline: Business People; OVERSEAS EXECUTIVE JOINING I.B.M. HUB
abstract: Jacques G. Maisonrouge, a 56-year-old senior vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation, has been named to the company's powerful corporate office as well as to the corporate management committee. When he moves to the I.B.M. corporate office at Armonk, N.Y., he will be succeeded in Paris as chairman and chief executive officer of the IBM World Trade-Europe/Middle East/Africa Corporation by Kaspar V. Cassani, 52, president of the unit since last year.   The corporate office, which is responsible for day-to-day operations, consists of the company's top executives. Mr. Maisonrouge will join John R. Opel, president and chief executive officer; Frank T. Cary, chairman and a former chief executive, and George B.  Beitzel, Dean R. McKay and Paul J. Rizzo, all senior vice presidents.

headline: SHIFT IS CONCEDED IN SAKHAROV CASE
abstract: The Soviet Union acknowledged obliquely today that it had bowed to the demand made by Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights advocate, when he began his 17-day hunger strike.   The acknowledgment came in the Government newspaper Izvestia, which said that Yelizaveta K. Alekseyeva, the 26-year-old woman on whose behalf Dr. Sakharov began the fast, would be allowed to emigrate ''by way of exception.'' Soviet citizens do not have the automatic right of emigration.   Although tonight's Izvestia item did not mention the fast, the newspaper told Soviet readers a week ago that the physicist and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, had started a hunger strike on behalf of Miss Alekseyeva's emigration efforts.

headline: METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. STEEL GIVES LOAN DETAILS
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation said today that it had more than $5.61 billion available for its proposed acquisition of the Marathon Oil Company, consisting of $3.01 billion in commitments from various American and foreign banks and $2.6 billion on hand in cash or its equivalent.   The company, according to a joint filing by U.S. Steel and Marathon at the Securities and Exchange Commission today, would pay interest on borrowings in this country at the prime rate of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, now 16 1/2 percent, while Eurodollar borrowings would be at three-eights of a percentage point over the London interbank offered rate (Libor).   These resources appeared to be sufficient for the acquisition of Marathon under an agreement that both companies announced Thursday.  The cost to U.S. Steel of its bid for Marathon was put at a total of $6.3 billion.

headline: FOR STRIKING STUDENTS IN WARSAW, NEW VISTAS
abstract: A leisurely game of badminton, without a net, was under way the other morning in the stately circular hall of the Warsaw Polytechnic, Poland's leading technical university.   On the benches of the steep amphitheater lecture halls, students were sleeping on mattresses. On the column of the entrance hall, large, mainly handwritten posters pledged support for various strikes and for Solidarity, the independent trade union. Others announced events such as commemorations of important persons or happenings in Polish history that have gone unproclaimed since 1939.

headline: Spanish Protest on NATO
abstract: Seven students held a sit-in for four hours today at the entrance hall of the United States consulate here to protest Spain's plans to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The students left voluntarily and were arrested by the police on undisclosed charges.

headline: Continental Air Default Possible
abstract: Continental Air Lines Inc., a Los Angeles-based airline, said it expected to go into technical default on some of its $322.2 million in debt by the end of the month unless it received waivers from its lenders. Continental added that it was confident that it would receive the necessary waivers.

abstract: The Bank of America said today it would act as agent for eight banks, including four in Japan, that will lend $135 million to Chile's electric utility, Empresa Nacional de Electricidad.

headline: Jordan Gets Loan
abstract: The World Bank said today that it had approved a $25 million loan to Jordan to support an educational and training project.

headline: ZUMWALT CRITICIZES LTV GRUMMAN BID
abstract: Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, the former Chief of Naval Operations, testified today that if the LTV Corporation was allowed to take over the Grumman Corporation, the resulting reduction in competition for military contracts would be ''very negative from the viewpoint of the Government and national defense.''   Admiral Zumwalt, who was the Navy's highest-ranking uniformed officer from 1970 to 1974, was the first witness in Grumman's legal battle to keep from being absorbed by LTV, a conglomerate based in Dallas. He testified in United States District Court here in support of Grumman's motion for a temporary restraining order against LTV.

headline: 2 Reach Everest Summit
abstract: A member of an American medical expedition and his Sherpa guide reached the top of Mount Everest yesterday and carried out the first medical tests ever at the summit, the Ministry of Tourism said today. Christopher Kopcjynski, a 33-year-old contractor from Spokane, Wash., and his Nepalese guide, Sundere, 20, conducted heart and lung tests and took weather readings.

headline: WARNER BROS. MAKING CHANGES AT THE TOP
abstract: Frank Wells, the last of the senior management triumvirate that ran Warner Bros. Inc., the motion picture unit of Warner Communications Inc., for about a decade, will take a much less active role at the company on Jan. 1. At that time, the two men at the top of Warner Bros., which is based in Burbank, Calif., will be Robert Daly, 43, chairman and chief executive officer, and Terry Semel, 38, president and chief operating officer.   The two other movie executives who left the Warner hierarchy in recent years were Ted Ashley and John Calley. The 49-year-old Mr.  Wells, a lawyer and Warner executive who had been president and cochief executive officer, will become vice chairman.

abstract: An engine invented for the Department of Energy converts heat from a liquid to mechanical energy by turning a wheel.

headline: Economic Scene; Ambivalence About Inflation
abstract: WASHINGTON THE unauthorized publication of preliminary Administration budget deficit projections has brought to light ambivalence among the President's most senior advisers about how rapidly the Government should try to cool inflation.   The leak, and subsequent comments by officials, also illuminate the highly political character of the President's economic forecast, or ''economic assumptions,'' as the Reagan people term them.   Officials emphasize that the leaked projections on the economy and budget were provisional -''unscrubbed,'' they like to say - and perforce will change by the time Mr. Reagan sends his fiscal year 1983 budget to Congress. Despite this fact, or perhaps because of it, the figures are valuable as a clue to the multiple considerations that influence - and change - the forecast.

headline: Jeff-Boat Layoffs
abstract: Jeff-Boat Inc., the nation's largest inland boat works, will lay off 600 employees at the end of November, company officials said.

headline: Market Place; Motor Maker Recommended
abstract: IN some regions of the land, aquifers have been drained to such a degree that it is difficult to recover the remaining water with surface pumps. That bad news for the nation is good news for the Franklin Electric Company, a major producer of submersible electric motors.   Franklin, founded in the late 1940's, grew rapidly after the company invented the first water-lubricated, hermetically sealed, stainless steel-encased submersible motor.   Franklin's motors have since powered growing numbers of submerged pumps capable of recoveries from depths of 1,000 feet. By contrast, surface pumps work best at depths of 100 feet or less.

headline: Venet to Be Turned Into Holding Company
abstract: Zal Venet, chief of Venet Advertising, home of such advertising clients as Pathmark supermarkets and Prince spaghetti, has decided to turn his agency into a holding company called the Venet Company.

headline: P.L.O. Recalls Envoy in Rome
abstract: The Palestine Liberation Organization recalled its representative in Rome today. The move was said to be a protest against the Italian Government's handling of an investigation into the death of a high P.L.O. official, Abu Sharar, on Oct. 9.

headline: CUMMINS ENGINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EGYPT'S PRESIDENT IS SAID TO INITIATE A NEW CRACKDOWN
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak, moving swiftly to consolidate his rule, ordered a nationwide roundup of Moslem fundamentalists today, according to Egyptian sources.   The sources said security forces had swept through towns across the country, arresting hundreds and possibly thousands of Moslem militants suspected of involvement in demonstrations and violence against the regime.   The Government would neither confirm nor deny reports of the crackdown, which comes 10 days after President Anwar el-Sadat was assassinated by four men whom the Government has linked with a Moslem fundamentalist group named Takfir Wahigra, or Atonement and Repentance. Other Arrests Since Killing   There have been many other arrests of both religious and political opponents of the regime since the assassination, but the Government has declined to give any names or numbers.

headline: GIVE THE MONEY TO THE REAL INNOVATORS
abstract: I N our opinion, a renaissance in innovation in America is possible, but a basic systemic change must first occur in governmental policies affecting small innovative businesses. -Presidential advisory committee on industrial innovation, the final report 1979.   A key element in the great industrial success of this country has been the individual - the entrepreneur, the small-business man. But in the past two decades business activity has steadily shifted away from individuals toward large, centralized organizations.

headline: OCCIDENTAL SAYS LIBYA EASES OIL-SALE TERMS
abstract: The Libyan Government has ''sweetened'' its oil sales arrangement with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, the company said yesterday. Other oil companies and analysts sugested that Tripoli wanted to keep Occidental as a customer at a time when many companies were refusing to buy Libyan crude.   Libya currently charges Occidental $39.15 a barrel, one of the world's highest prices, for much of the crude that Occidental takes.  The North African country has been one of the most adamant members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in refusing to lower prices in the face of sagging worldwide demand.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Study by CBS Counters 'Superstation' Proposal
abstract: Ted Bates/New York did not need to get its clients to put money into Ted Turner's superstation, WTBS, Atlanta, in order to get the kind of people the networks were losing to pay cable, according to the CBS Television Network. The network contends that commercial TV itself can supply the desired audiences.

headline: Unions Rebuff American Airlines
abstract: Leaders of three labor unions representing American Airlines' 21,000 unionized employees have rejected pay cuts and freezes sought by management in an attempt to save $7 million a month, a company spokesman said.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Air New Zealand Ltd., Los Angeles, has appointed Norman M.T.  Geary chief executive officer.   * Compuscan Inc., Teterboro, N.J., has named Gene Starr vice president, corporate development.

headline: UGANDA BRIGHTENS AS GUNFIRE YIELDS TO DISCO MUSIC
abstract: A visitor these days can walk through nighttime Kampala, hearing the beat of disco music rather than the rifle fire that was heard a few months ago. According to Government officials and Western diplomats, the change reflects the easing of tensions a year after President Milton Obote's return to office in Uganda.   Those foreigners and Ugandans seeking encouragement in this poor, violence-prone land also point to a tentative economic revival born of measures introduced in June in consultation with the International Monetary Fund. These measures have halted gasoline smuggling and undermined the black market.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Foreign News Reports Filed Through Censor   WARSAW, Dec. 18 (UPI) - Poland's military rulers allowed foreign journalists to resume filing reports today from Warsaw but only under strict conditions of censorship.   After five days without direct communications to the outside world, correpondents were told that a telex line was being made available at the Foreign Ministry press center.

headline: Around the World; Pope Bids Bishops Help Italy's Earthquake Zone
abstract: Pope John Paul II urged 35 bishops from southern Italy today to lead the way in the reconstruction of their region, which was devastated by a a major earthquake a year ago.

headline: Four-Week Navy Drill Is Begun in Caribbean
abstract: The United States Navy has begun four weeks of manuevers in the Caribbean, Pentagon officials said today.  However, they stressed that the manuevers, which began Oct. 30, were planned long ago and were only coincidentally related to a request from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the Defense Department to examine the military options growing out of Washington's concern about arms shipments to rebels in El Salvador.

headline: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Combustion Engineering
abstract: Combustion Engineering Inc., one of the city's largest private employers, said today that a depressed market is forcing the company's third employee layoff within two months.

headline: Photos From Poland Carried Out by Dane
abstract: A set of pictures of scenes in Poland after the imposition of martial law has been smuggled out by a Danish photographer and distributed by United Press International.   The photographer, Morten Lankilb, an employee of the Danish news agency Politiken, was on assignment in Poland when the crackdown came.

headline: GATT Seeks Trade Accord
abstract: The United States and three European countries - France, Belgium and the Netherlands - moved today to drop charges over export subsidies at a meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The two sides indicated they would accept a 1976 ruling by a GATT panel that said they had broken international trade rules by giving tax concessions to exporters.

headline: Petro-Lewis Sets Oil Acquisition
abstract: The Petro-Lewis Corporation said it had agreed to acquire nearly all of the American Express Company's oil and gas assets for about $76.9 million.

headline: SONY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRITONS RECOVER $76 MILLION IN GOLD
abstract: Deep-sea divers have recovered 95 percent of the gold bullion from the sunken British cruiser Edinburgh, netting bounty worth some $76 million.   British officials in this northern port said the British salvage consortium that carried out the operation had told them that only 20 of the 400 gold bars on board the cruiser remained in her hold.

headline: ABITIBI-PRICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STATEMENT BY REAGAN ON WAR
abstract: Following is a statement by President Reagan concerning United States nuclear strategy. The statement, which was distributed at the White House, was also read to reporters aboard Air Force One en route to Cancun, Mexico.

headline: TRAFALGAR SHIFTS POSTS
abstract: Trafalgar Industries realigned some top management posts over the weekend with the election of Peter W. May, its leading financial executive, as president and chief operating officer. As president, Mr. May assumes a post formerly held by Nelson Peltz, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOVIET ACCUSES PRESIDENT OF 'PLOY'
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain enthusiastically welcomed President Reagan's statement on arms control today, with Mr. Schmidt calling it ''the American peace strategy.''   The Chancellor and the Prime Minister greeted the President's speech with unusual warmth and expressions of satisfaction at a joint news conference here after previously scheduled talks.   Both leaders suggested that the foreign policy address showed great sensitivity for European considerations, and Mr. Schmidt made it clear that he felt it would make his work easier in dealing with public opinion in West Germany, where the United States has increasingly been associated with policies of confrontation. Televised Live to Europe   Mrs. Thatcher described the speech, which was televised live to Western Europe as ''supremely important'' and as the most significant message of Mr. Reagan's Presidency. And Mr. Schmidt said the speech confirmed what he said was his continual portrayal of Mr.  Reagan as a man of peace and that ''Ronald Reagan is a man who deep in his heart is searching for peace and is willing to negotiate, negotiate and negotiate.''

headline: P.& G., SMITHKLINE, PITTSTON, SINGER UP
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company announced yesterday that earnings in the first fiscal quarter of 1982 ended Sept.30 increased 12.9 percent, on a 3.4 percent sales increase. The company attributed the gains to higher unit sales but said results were lower than expected because of changes in foreign currency exchange rates.   The Cincinnati-based producer of household products, food and personal care items said that net income increased to $219 million, or $2.65 a share, from $194 million, or $2.34 a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Sales rose to $3 billion, from $2.9 billion.

headline: Around the World; Polisario Says It Downed A Moroccan Copter
abstract: Guerrillas fighting for independence for Moroccan-ruled Western Sahara today reported shooting down another Moroccan aircraft, killing the crew of three.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: HAIG ANKARA VISIT ENCOURAGES TURKS
abstract: The scheduled arrival here Sunday of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has been welcomed by Ankara as new evidence of a growing recognition in Washington of the importance of Turkey in this volatile region.   Turkish military and civilian leaders view Mr. Haig as an old friend who knows this country well, both its strengths and its limitations. It is often emphasized by Turkish officials that Mr.  Haig, as NATO's Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, was strongly opposed to the American embargo on arms sales to Turkey after Turkish troops occupied northern Cyprus in 1974.   The Haig visit, following that of the Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, who pledged more economic and military aid to Turkey last week, is generally seen as a move by the United States to strike a new and close relationship beyond the existing good ties within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

headline: DEPOSITORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Car Makers' Backlog Rises
abstract: Sluggish sales in September pushed inventories of new cars built in the United States to a 69-day supply on Oct. 1, up from a 64-day supply on Sept. 1, an industry journal reported today.   Auto makers generally prefer to keep a 60-day supply of cars on hand.

headline: Business Digest; The Economy
abstract: The Producer Price Index for finished goods rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in September, the smallest monthly rise in over three years, the Government reported. It cited lower prices for some foods and price-cutting on the last of the 1981 mod el cars. The report was seen as another sign that inflation is recedi ng. (Page 1.)   The nation's money supply fell $2.1 billion in the week ended Sept. 30, the Fed reported. It said the figure remained well below its target, despite its efforts to stimulate faster growth. The Fed reduced by a point its interest-rate surcharge, the second such cut in less than a month. In the credit markets, short-term interest rates fell, while prices for longer-term bonds rose sharply. (31.)

headline: Italy to Free 14,000 Convicts
abstract: About 14,000 prisoners will be freed from Italy's overcrowded jails under an amnesty pardoning minor crimes that was approved by the Senate's Justice Commission last night, an Italian official said today. About 36,000 people are being held in Italian jails, which were built to hold a maximum of 22,000 prisoners, the official said.

headline: DIANA GETS A RESPITE FROM THE PRESS
abstract: The monarchy-watchers of Fleet Street, under pressure from Queen Elizabeth, have agreed to become somewhat less diligent in watching the Princess of Wales.   The 20-year-old Princess, who is expecting a baby in June, deserves more privacy than she has been getting, most of the newspapers said in editorials this week, and they generally promised to start leaving her alone, except on public, ceremonial occasions.   The informal agreement goes to the heart of the perennial debate about the press and royal privacy. It grew out of a highly unusual meeting at Buckingham Palace on Tuesday between Michael Shea, the Queen's press secretary, and editors from newspapers and broadcasting networks.

headline: BANKERS TRUST GETS OFFER FOR VISA CARD
abstract: The First National Bank of Chicago, in a move that would nearly double its bank card business overnight, said yesterday that it was negotiating to buy the 1.1 million Visa accounts operated by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.   First Chicago currently charges its 1.7 million Visa cardholders a higher interest charge, 19.8 percent, and higher annual fee, $20, than the 18 percent and $15 in effect at Bankers Trust. An executive of the Chicago bank said it did not expect to extend the higher prices to the Bankers Trust accounts once the transaction was completed.

headline: AMERICAN AIR ASKS A 5% PAY CUT
abstract: American Airlines today announced a second cost-cutting move in as many weeks, this time asking its 35,000 employees to accept a 5 percent pay cut for the first three months of 1982, and a wage freeze for the rest of that year.   The airline had announced last week that an unspecified number of employees would be laid off or furloughed in December. That is in addition to the 750 workers and 200 pilots laid off by American after the air controllers' strike began in August.

headline: CHINESE WIDENING ROLE AT THE U.N.
abstract: Ten years ago today, the Communists in Peking were given the seat in the United Nations that had been held by the Nationalists in Taipei.   Over the decade, China has gradually exerted a widening influence at the United Nations.  Yet at the same time, the Peking Government has moved cautiously in participating in many of the activities of the world organization. In many instances it has refrained from voting in the Security Council and it still does not belong to many of the numerous committees that have sprung from resolutions of the General Assembly.

headline: Whittaker Net Gains 16.5%
abstract: The Whittaker Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended Oct. 31 rose 16.5 percent, to $19.1 million, or $1.21 a share, from $16.4 million, or $1.09 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues edged up 3.3 percent, to $412.7 million, from $399.6 million.

headline: ALLEN IS CLEARED BY INVESTIGATION ON GIFT OF $1,000
abstract: The Justice Department announced today that it had closed its investigation into Richard V. Allen's receipt of $1,000 from a Japanese magazine and that it had found no evidence of criminal wrongdoing.   The department's statement said Attorney General William French Smith had concluded that there was no reason to seek appointment of a special prosecutor in the matter.   At the same time, however, the department said it would continue its investigation into Mr. Allen's acceptance of two wristwatches from a Japanese associate and his filing of a financial disclosure form with the White House earlier this year that gave an incorrect date for the sale of his consulting firm. Return to Job Uncertain   Mr. Allen is taking a leave of absence from his post as President Reagan's national security adviser until the Justice Department completes its investigation. White House aides repeated today that there was no guarantee Mr. Allen would return to the job.

headline: India Receives Loan
abstract: The World Bank today announced a $300 million loan to help finance expansion of the Ramagundam thermal power station in India.

headline: SOUTHERN MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; Old Name Attempts Comeback
abstract: GUENTHER LAW, one of the oldest advertising agencies in the world, has gotten its name back. And the two men who are running the place and plan to buy it hope they can return some of its old luster as well.   The financial advertising specialty company, which was billing $35 million when it celebrated its centennial in 1972, is only billing $18 million today, which is an improvement from when Stephen J. Witt, chairman and chief operating officer, and Michael A. Taylor, president and chief executive officer, joined the agency last April.  Billings had dropped to $13 million.

headline: HUNT, PHILIP A, CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THE WORKERS' CHAMPION
abstract: From the moment he scaled the fence at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk on Aug. 14, 1980, to help striking workers negotiate the establishment of an independent labor union in Poland, Lech Walesa became a charismatic and seemingly invincible leader of a movement that promised to transform the country.   Wearing a Virgin Mary button in his lapel and speaking the language of the common man, he led the 9.5 million Solidarity union members through a series of confrontations and compromises that liberalized nearly all aspects of life in Communist Poland.   Mr. Walesa became one of the three most important figures in Poland, on a par with the primate of the Roman Catholic Church and the First Secretary of the Communist Party.   But yesterday Mr. Walesa's labor federation was in disarray after many of its leaders were arrested at a meeting in that same Gdansk shipyard. The Government declared a state of emergency and imposed a military Government on the country.

headline: U.S. OFFICIAL MEETS EUROPEANS ON POLICY TOWARD POLISH CRISIS
abstract: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, began consultations with the European allies of the United States today on a response to the situation in Poland.   Mr. Eagleburger talked in Rome this afternoon with Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo, and then flew to Bonn where he met with Foreign Minister Hans-Die@trich Genscher for an hour and a half tonight.   The trip, which will also include talks with Government leaders in Paris and London before Mr. Eagleburger returns to Washington, involves the issue of whether Western aid to Poland should be continued, as well as the Soviet Union's role in the Polish crisis.

headline: ATLAS VAN LINES INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Moran Inc.  In Business
abstract: William T. Moran, a well-known advertising and marketing researcher, has formally announced the existence of his two-year-old firm called Moran Inc., of Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Tremor Shakes Italian Area
abstract: An earth tremor registering four on the open-ended Richter scale shook a wide area of the Friuli region in northeast Italy early today, causing alarm among residents of several towns but no injuries, the police reported. The Friuli region was devastated by a quake that took 946 lives in May 1976.

headline: G.S.A. Defers Tin Sales
abstract: The General Services Administration said today that it would not resume its daily sales of tin from the National Defense stockpile until next Monday. The agency also said that no weekly silver auction would be held this week, and that the next sale would be held on Dec. 2.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM POLISH RADIO AND TV BROADCASTS
abstract: Following are excerpts from the Soviet press agency Tass and excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish here by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency Mine Strikes Go On 1 P.M. Tuesday, (7 A.M. Tuesday, E.S.T.)   Life is returning progressively to normal throughout the country.  Despite the numerous restrictions of martial law, both the economy and citizens' everyday life are steadily returning to normal in accordance with universal expectations.   Today is generally calm and industrious in Katowice Province.  Railway workers are particularly busy ferrying goods, transporting people and clearing snow from the rail tracks and trackside equipment.   More than 424,000 tons of various goods have been transported out of Katowice Province during the past 24 hours. Most industrial plants are operating.

headline: ASIA URGED TO END POPULATION SURGE
abstract: Legislators from 19 Asian countries have concluded a United Nations-sponsored conference on population problems by proposing that their governments work to hold Asia's annual population growth rate to 1 percent by the end of the century.   The target, less than half Asia's present growth rate of 2.1 percent a year, was set in a final document unanimously adopted by the delegates here on Friday. They also asked governments everywhere to increase contributions to international activities for population assistance to a record $1 billion a year by 1984.

headline: NIXON'S AWACS VIEW ASSAILED
abstract: Israel's Cabinet today approved a proposal by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon for a modest reorganization of the military governments in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.   Under the plan, which will take effect Dec. 1, a few middle-ranking military officers will be replaced by Israeli civilians in administering housing, health, welfare, tax and industrial programs in the occupied territories.   Cabinet Secretary Aryeh Naor explained that the civilian officials would be under the authority of the military governments, which would remain intact pending the implementation of limited Palestinian autonomy, or self-adminstration, under the Camp David accords.

headline: REVIVAL AT DYING G.M. PALNT
abstract: The shock waves struck early this year: The General Motors Corporation, operator of the Hyatt bearing plant here since 1938, planned to close the factory. G.M. said it would buy less costly parts elsewhere, including Japan, where wages and benefits run about half of the more than $20 an hour that workers here cost.   But leaders of the United Automobile Workers union local came back with a proposal to slash their pay by 30 percent and buy the plant.  Now, with G.M.'s eager commitment to $100 million in orders for each of the next three years, plus $20 million in funding, the factory is about to go it alone, albeit with only half its previous labor force. How the Takeover Works   The mechanism will be an Employee Stock Ownership Trust. Under such a trust, workers and managers together share ownership of a business. The workers at Hyatt, both manual and executive, have borrowed the money needed to buy Hyatt from General Motors for $60 million. Future profits will be used to repay the loan, and then the new owners will be able to build up their equity.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ASSOCIATES CORP OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Indonesian Oil Exports
abstract: Indonesia's oil exports in July rose to $1.26 billion from June's $1.12 billion, the Bank of Indonesia said today. Exports of natural gas increased to $212 million from $205 million.

headline: WORLD'S MONEY UP $207 BILLION
abstract: The world money supply rose by some $207 billion in 1981 - the smallest increase in 11 years - and worldwide inflation began falling as many countries pursued tightmoney policies, the Bank of America reported today.   Nonetheless, bank officials labeled as excessive the 9.7 percent increase this year, which pushed the total world money supply to $2,300 billion.   ''Even though it's slower growth, this year's increase alone, if laid end-to-end in $100 bills, would stretch 85 times to the moon,'' said H. Robert Heller, the bank's vice president for international economics. ''This shows the enormous magnitude of the monetary expansion and points to the necessity of continuing to curb this excessive monetary growth.''

headline: GENERAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japan Acts On Trade
abstract: The Japanese Government, in a concession to mounting international criticism of its trade practices, adopted a series of measures today aimed at expanding imports and reducing trade friction with the United States and Europe.   The package, approved by the Council of Economic Ministers, would reduce tariffs on 1,600 products ranging from automobile parts to machine tools, some liquors, biscuits and chocolates.

headline: People
abstract: * Frederick W. Rhines has been elected a senior vice president of McCann-Erickson, New York.   * Iris Shokoff has joined Grey Direct as senior vice president and director of media.   * Richard Kotz has joined the American Express Company as vice president, industry marketing and advertising in the Consumer Financial Services Group.

headline: Commercial Paper
abstract: Commercial paper outstanding in the United States rose a record $8.26 billion in September to a seasonally adjusted record $165.38 billion, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said. Last year, commercial paper outstanding totaled $119.78 billion. Financial company paper rose $4.94 billion in September, to $113.52 billion, while nonfinancial company paper rose $3.32 billion, to $51.86 billion.

headline: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN'S MISSILE OFFER IS SAID TO REFLECT WEINBERGER'S STAND
abstract: President Reagan's proposal to have both the Soviet Union and the United States do without intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe reflects a basic position advocated by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and Defense Department aides, senior Administration officials disclosed today.   High officials in both the State and Defense Departments, who spoke with the understanding that they would not be named, said that for a long time Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and his aides, feeling that Mr. Weinberger's approach was unrealistic, had opposed it and advocated a more modest proposal.   The officials said that the fundamental State Department position was for a reduction in Moscow's current inventory of more than 600 SS-4, SS-5, and SS-20 missiles to ''the lowest possible level,'' with the United States being allowed to match that with an equal inventory of intermediate-range missiles.   But Mr. Weinberger was reported to have argued against this approach on grounds that it was too ''fuzzy'' and to have pushed for Mr. Reagan to put forward an offer that was ''straight and simple'' - the offer to forego the planned deployment of 572 American Pershing-2 and cruise missiles if Moscow would dismantle the force of SS-4's, SS-5's, and SS-20's it had based in the western Soviet Union.

headline: Delhi Oil Flow Report
abstract: Delhi Petroleum Proprietary Ltd., the Australian unit of Delhi International Oil, said today that an appraisal well in the Cooper Basin had flowed oil at the rate of about 2,860 barrels a day. The flow is the second best ever recorded from an onshore Australian well, the company said.

headline: Amoco Lifts Oil Prices
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) yesterday became the first United States oil company to raise its prices in reaction to the price accord reached last week in Geneva by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.   The Amoco Production Company, the petroleum-producing arm of Indiana Standard, said it raised by $1 a barrel, effective last Sunday, the price it would pay for domestic crude oil.

headline: THORATEC LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Arizona Chemical Company, Wayne, N.J., has elected Don Stiling executive vice president.   * Chyron Corporation, Melville, L.I., has elected Joseph L.  Scheuer president and chief operating officer.   * Frederick's of Hollywood Inc., Los Angeles, has elected Colleen Menerey vice president-finance.

headline: S.E.C. WARNS ON BUDGET CUT
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission contends it would have to drop 20 percent of its employees, close as many as six offices and reduce sharply its enforcement and documentreviewing capability if the Administration and Congress force it to make a 12 percent budget cut.   Such a cut, the agency argued in a study sent to Congress yesterday, would undermine initiatives to reduce unnecessary regulation, a major goal of the Reagan Administration.   ''The implementation of a 12 percent budget cut at this time,'' the S.E.C.'s commissioners asserted, would ''substantially limit the operation of the commission in all areas and in some areas may make impossible the discharge of our statutory mandate.''

headline: The U.N. Today; Nov. 3, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   General Committee - 10 A.M.   Political and Security Committee - 11 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 8:30 P.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Pledging Conference for Develop- ment Activities - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: BULGARIANS TRY TO STEER CLEAR OF THE POLES' DIFFICULT ROUTE
abstract: Many Bulgarian officials and private citizens alike believe that the Poles have made some basic errors in industry and agriculture, and hope that moderation will prevail in resolving the crisis there.   The Bulgarian Government and officially controlled press express concern over the situation in Poland but refrain from making the sharp attacks against the independent union Solidarity that are so prevalent in most other Eastern bloc countries.   Many Bulgarians, who are thankful to the Russians for helping to liberate this country from Ottoman rule in the 19th century, say the Poles have been ungrateful to the Soviet Union for the economic help that it has given its partners in the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance.

headline: MCGRAW-HILL RYERSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Israeli's Trial Starts
abstract: Aharon Abuhazira, an Israeli Cabinet minister accused of larceny, pleaded not guilty today as his trial opened in District Court. Mr. Abuhazira, Minister of Labor, Welfare and Immigration, announced that he would take a leave of absence from his Cabinet post for the duration of the trial. Mr. Abuhazira is charged with using $4,300 in public money for household expenses while he was Mayor of Ramleh from 1975 to 1978.

headline: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COLORS DRAW THE YOUNG TO PEKING CLOTHES FAIR
abstract: A throng of young Chinese jostled around the outdoor stand where down-filled parkas, previously made for export, were selling for the equivalent of $22, a bargain.   Some young men frantically waved fistfuls of yuan notes to attract the attention of the clerks. A slender girl broke loose from the pack and tugged her purchase triumphantly out of its plastic bag as admiring friends watched.   From the stall across the way, other clerks looked on glumly. They were selling the sort of dark, blocky jackets popularized by Mao Zedong. The head clerk, asked how business was going, replied, ''It hasn't been profitable,'' and hunched into his gray overcoat.

headline: Madrid Intends to Dismantle Franco's Newspaper Empire
abstract: The Spanish Parliament yesterday approved a plan to sell 27 Government-owned newspapers, virtually dismantling the press network set up under Francisco Franco.

headline: South Africa Inmates in Fast
abstract: The South African prison on Robben Island, six miles northwest of Cape Town, has suspended once-a-month visits by relatives of political prisoners because some inmates have gone on a hunger strike. A statement today by the Commissioner of Prisons did not say how many prisoners were fasting or what they were demanding.

headline: MONEY SUPPLY JUMP AWAITED
abstract: The credit markets exhibited growing apprehension yesterday as both traders and investors braced for a sharp increase in the weekly money supply figures that the Federal Reserve is to issue this afternoon.  As a result, changes in values for most Treasury debt issues were minimal and trading remained light, according to dealers in Government securities.   Many investors were also discouraged by the behavior of the key Federal funds rate - that charged by banks to other banks for overnight funds needed to meet reserve requirements.

headline: Lockheed Corp.'s Tristar Review
abstract: The chairman of the Lockheed Corporation, Roy Anderson, said the company was not near a decision on whether to scrap its costly L-1011 Tristar commercial airliner project.

headline: BIG STEEL'S MOVES TO DIVERSIFY
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation's $6.3 billion offer for the Marathon Oil Company is more evidence of the steel industry's intensifying quest for growth outside its traditional business, analysts say.   U.S. Steel is a good example of this trend: In the 1950's, the company earned most of its money from steel operations. Last year these activities accounted for just 11 percent of total operating income; the rest came from chemicals, manufacturing, transportation and utilities and resource development.   ''The steel business has been a tough business to generate a return on,'' said Robert Nichols, an economist with Chase Econometrics.  ''It's a business that is hit hard by persistent cycles in the economy. People should not place all their chips in the steel industry, and they aren't.''

headline: Chase Challenges Income Tax Study
abstract: Chase Manhattan Bank has disputed a private analyst's conclusion that the bank paid no Federal income tax in 1980.   ''In fact, Chase Manhattan paid $9.2 million in Federal income tax, $16 million in state and local taxes and $117 million in foreign taxes,'' said Charles Frances, a Chase spokesman.

headline: Iranian Leftists Warned To Limit Activities
abstract: Iran's Prime Minister has declared that supporters of the pro-Soviet Tudeh Party and the majority branch of the Marxist People's Fedayeen had infiltrated the Revolutionary Guards and other fundamentalist organizations, and that they would be executed if they were found to have concealed their party affiliations.   ''If a member of the majority branch of the Fedayeen disguises himself as a Moslem and infiltrates Revolutionary Guards' corps, we will identify him and execute him,'' Mir Hussein Moussavi said in an interview published today in Teheran's Ettelaat newspaper.   Unlike most leftist groups, the Tudeh and the majority faction of the Fedayeen have supported the Islamic regime, which in turn has spared their members from the firing squads.

headline: PHOTOS SHOW CAIRO SECURITY BREAKDOWN, EXPERTS SAY
abstract: A seeming breakdown in security and the element of surprise at the Cairo parade grounds last week turned what should have been a suicide mission for the assassins into a successful attack on the life of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, in the view of three American security experts.   The experts, three former Secret Service agents who guarded Presidents before becoming private consultants, reached that conclusion after examining a series of photographs, some of which are appearing Tuesday in The New York Times.   The consultants - Charles F. Vance and Dario Marquez of DVM Inc., an international security firm based in Fairfax, Va., and Walter E.  Bothe, a private consultant - said that it was not possible to make a complete analysis from the photographs. Experts Make Observations   They did agree, however, that the pictures revealed enough of the scene and action to allow them to make these observations:   - The breakdown in security around Mr. Sadat, who was killed while sitting in a reviewing stand watching a military parade, was striking in several respects. Egyptian security forces evident in the pictures appeared confused, outgunned, poorly stationed and slow to respond to the assault.

headline: A FREE LUNCH? YES, INDEED
abstract: ''THERE'S no free lunch,'' James C. Miller 3d, the new chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, declared in Washington this week. Mr.  Miller was not merely voicing a cliche. He was explaining his strongly held view that the commission should stop trying to protect consumers from defective products and unsubstantiated advertising claims. Such protective efforts, he said, saddle business with costs that are then passed on to consumers.   The Reagan Administration is devoted to the no-free-lunch doctrine, one of the most ancient in the economics literature. ''Non exstat prandium gratuitum,'' wrote Fulminius Minor, an aristocratic Roman philosopher of the Augustan age, who was also known for the maxim, ''Post prandium, stabis; post coenam, ambulabis'' - ''After lunch, rest; after dinner, walk.''

headline: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INTERCOLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Fund Assets Rise Slightly
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $443.2 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $169.9 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. It was the 23d consecutive weekly increase but the slimmest gain since May.

headline: Around the World; Turkish Police Chief Jailed for Using Torture
abstract: A police chief was sentenced today to a 14-year prison term for his role in the death by torture of a leftist militant who had been caught putting up posters.

headline: Salvador Fighting Reported
abstract: An army drive in northern El Salvador is meeting heavy guerrilla resistance, contradicting Government reports that the drive had wiped out rebel activity in the area, officials said today. The army said earlier this week that 1,000 soldiers backed by artillery had secured the embattled town of Cinquera, 44 miles northeast of the capital, but a local commander said troops were still fighting rebels entrenched only miles away.

headline: TOBIN OF YALE WINS NOBEL IN ECONOMICS
abstract: James Tobin of Yale University was awarded the 1981 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science today for his analyses of financial markets and their effect on how businesses and families spend and save money.   The selection committee of the Royal Swedish Academy of Science said Mr. Tobin's work was a breakthrough in analyzing the relationship between financial markets, such as those for stocks and bonds, and ''real'' markets, such as those for real estate, factory machinery and consumer goods. Describing this relationship, the committee said, has been a ''classic problem in economic research.''   Mr. Tobin, who first gained national prominence as a member of President Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers, has stated that investments are affected by assessments of how risky they are and that investors differ in the degree of risk they are willing to accept.

headline: F.C.C. ASKS COMMENT ON EASING CABLE LIMITS
abstract: By a unanimous vote, the Federal Communications Commission put out for public comment today a staff report that recommends the removal of all restrictions on cable television ownership.   The debate before their 7-to-0 vote indicated that a majority appeared to favor the report's aim.  For years, the communications agency has protected the fledgling cable television industry by prohibiting ownership of cable networks by local television stations and by major networks. to prevent boradcaters from buying into cable and undercutting as a competitor.The commission had also limited the number of systems that could be held by a single owner.

headline: 4 Are Jailed in France For Slaying Giscard Aide
abstract: Four men were sentenced to prison tonight for the Christmas Eve slaying in 1976 of Jean de Broglie, a political associate of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing.

headline: China Questions U.S.  On Taiwan Arms Sale
abstract: China is asking the United States to clarify its decision to provide millions of dollars in military spare parts to Taiwan, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.   The spokesman also reiterated China's resolute opposition to the American sale of weapons to the Nationalist regime on Taiwan, according to the New China News Agency.

headline: JOHNSON, E F, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WESTCHESTER
abstract: Westchester County continues to grow at a steady rate, according to local planners and government experts, with the unemployment rate still the lowest in the state, at 4.4 percent last month, and the prospects quite good for qualified job seekers, especially in whitecollar fields.   Susan Glickman, director of the county's Office of Economic Development, said that ''Westchester has a great need for computer people and secretaries, as does the rest of the nation, which is moving in a service-oriented direction.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: SHARON VISITS ISRAELI SETTLEMENTS: Ariel Sharon, at left, the Israeli Defense Minister, being greeted by Jewish settlers yesterday in Bet Hadassah in central Hebron. Earlier during his visit to the Occupied West Bank, Mr. Sharon said, ''Our answer to the eight points of the Saudi plan is eight Israeli settlements.''

headline: SOVIET DRAFT SEEN OVERCOMING MANPOWER DIP
abstract: The Soviet armed forces are facing the prospect of substantial declines in available manpower in this decade, but Western analysts say there is little reason to believe that Soviet military strength will suffer as a result.   These conclusions are presented by Dr. Ellen Jones in an article in Strategic Review, a publication of the United States Strategic Institute, a nongovernmental organization. Dr. Jones, now an analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency, worked for the Defense Intelligence Agency in the past.   She says those who argue that Soviet military strength will be affected by manpower shortages overlook the ability of the Defense Ministry to maintain the yearly intake of conscripts at close to the current level.   Her conclusions are supported by intelligence analysts at Atlantic alliance headquarters in Belgium, where the comparative reductions in the manpower reservoirs of the Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have been closely studied. The studies predict that the United States, Britain and West Germany will encounter manpower problems in the rest of this decade.

headline: Saudis Reduce Oil Production
abstract: Abdul Hadi Taher, governor of Saudi Arabia's General Petroleum and Mineral Organization, was quoted yesterday as saying Saudi oil output would be cut by 800,000 barrels a day, to 8.5 million, following last week's OPEC conference.

headline: Market Place; Making Profit On Takeovers
abstract: ONE way to make money in takeovers is to strike before the iron is hot, namely, buy shares before a company becomes a target. This may be easier than it sounds, given that by some measures stock prices are near their lowest point in many years. For example, at about 875 the Dow Jones industrial average is at 6.7 times this year's expected earnings of $130 for the 30 corporations that make up the average - very near its 40-year low of six times earnings reached in 1974.   Obviously, then, shares of takeover candidates can be purchased today at prices well below those they would command in a bidding contest.

headline: EGYPTIANS VOTING TODAY ON MUBARAK PRESIDENCY
abstract: About 12 million Egyptians will vote in a national referendum tomorrow that is expected to elect Vice President Hosni Mubarak as Egypt's next President by an overwhelming margin.   After the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat last Tuesday, the ruling National Democratic Party nominated Mr. Mubarak to succeed him. Mr. Mubarak is the only candidate and is certain to begin a sixyear term on Wednesday, when he is sworn in at a ceremony in Parliament.   According to the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram, Mr. Mubarak, who is 53 years old, does not plan any changes in the Cabinet appointed by Mr. Sadat. Mayo, the weekly publication of the National Democratic Party, said that Mr. Mubarak would not name a new Vice President immediately.

headline: Business Digest; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously that the Federal Government is not legally required to make it easier for small oil companies to compete for offshore leases, reversing an appeals court decision.  Nearly all such leases are currently won by the major companies, which have the capital available to make the initial cash payments required under the bidding system in use now. In another ruling, the Justices held that Missouri taxpayers could not challenge local property assessments in a Federal court. (D1.)   A new floating rate on savings bonds will be proposed to Congress, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said. Under the plan, aimed at making the bonds more attractive in a time of high interest rates, bondholders would be guaranteed a fixed interest rate, but could earn a higher return if market interest rates rose above the fixed rate.  (D1.)

headline: HONDURAS TO PICK CIVILIAN CHIEF TODAY
abstract: Hondurans vote Sunday for their first civilian president in a decade, hopeful that a return to democracy will protect this country from the political violence convulsing the rest of Central America.   But the army, which has ruled Honduras for 17 of the past 18 years, has already placed restrictions on the authority of the next government and seems certain to remain the dominant political force in the country.   Further, during the election campaign the two leading candidates have largely ignored Honduras's acute economic and social problems and have instead opted to exchange insults. Their platforms, though, are barely distinguishable, both packed with promises but short in solutions.

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 21, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Committee on Conferences - 3 P.M.

headline: HARKEN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRITISH CAR BUYERS SAVE BY TRAVELING TO THE CONTINENT
abstract: One day last month, J.B. Fuller took a day off from work to save more than $1,100 on a new car by visiting Belgium, buying an auto there and driving it back to Britain via the car ferry. He did so on the advice of a friend who had done the same.   The men, both college principals, are among approximately 30,000 people living in Britain who have legally taken advantage of the sharp discrepancies between car prices in Britain and on the Continent.   The price disparities, which exist for most types of cars, even extend to those made in Britain and exported to the Continent. For example, a Mini Metro made by BL Ltd., which costs $5,065 in Britain before taxes, can be bought for $3,023 in West Germany and $3,866 in Italy. Similar differences exist with non-British cars.

headline: People
abstract: * James Aucone has joined David Deutsch Associates as executive vice president, director of account services, and Kevin Buckley has been named a senior vice president.   * John M. Pope appointed to vice president of marketing for the consumer products division of the Western Publishing Company, a subsidiary of Mattel Inc.   * John S. Robling has been named vice president for public affairs at Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc.

headline: BRITONS DISTURBED BY UNLISTED TRADING
abstract: When shares of Business Computer (Systems) started trading on the Unlisted Stock Market here, the money the company raised through its public sale of stock was distributed to the original shareholders.   ''We didn't really need the money for the business, but we felt that some of the original investors should get a modest payoff for the time and money spent,'' said Michael Munnelly, managing director of the company.   Although entrepreneurs may wish to cash in some of their chips, a perfectly legitimate aim, investors are beginning to fret that the companies now traded on the Unlisted Stock Market are more interested in a quick return than in fueling corporate growth. Such worries have grown stronger in recent weeks as stock prices have plunged.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GOLDEN NUGGET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BANKERS SAY RATES MAY EASE
abstract: Many of the nation's bankers believe that interest rates will decline one or two percentage points from current levels but that they will remain relatively high at least through early next year.   But few of the 10,000 bankers gathered here to attend the annual convention of the American Bankers Association claim any prescience.  Many have been badly burned in past months by basing investment decisions on expectations of a substantial decline in interest rates, only to see them rise rather than fall.   Underlying the uncertainty is substantial uneasiness about projections of large Federal budget defici ts and the possible effect that persistent high rates will have on custo mers.

headline: Power Failure in El Salvador Blacks Out a Third of Country
abstract: A power failure that the authorities suspect was a result of sabotage blacked out eastern El Salvador today.

headline: U.S. OFFICIAL CLEARED ON ROLE IN $230,000 CONTRACT AWARD
abstract: The Treasury Department said today that Norman B. Ture, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Tax and Economic Affairs, did not profit from a Treasury contract for an economic forecasting model that Mr. Ture had developed and partly owned.   The Inspector General of the Treasury said that, ''at most,'' Mr.  Ture had participated in an ''extremely debatable and highly technical'' violation of conflict-of-interest laws.   After reviewing the matter, the Justice Department has declined to prosecute, a Treasury spokesman said. Mr. Ture declined to comment on the findings, saying only, ''It's all in the report.''

headline: U.S. and Italy Agree On Red Brigades Policy
abstract: The American and Italian Governments are in agreement on a policy of not entering into negotiations with the Red Brigades kidnappers of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini said today.   Mr. Spadolini, at a news conference, said that with the kidnapping of the American general, Italian terrorists had made ''a qualitative jump'' from national to international operations.   Search operations continued in northern Italy and in parts of the south without producing any clues, the Italian police said.  Mr. Spadolini confirmed that allied experts, especially from West Germany and the United States, were helping Italy in the search for General Dozier.

headline: Israel to Continue Flights
abstract: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said tonight that Israel would continue its aerial reconnaissance patrols over Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia said that it had chased Israeli planes out of its northern airspace on Monday. Mr. Sharon, replying to questions on his return from Palestinian autonomy talks in Cairo, said the question of the overflights had not been discussed. He added it was clear to the countries of the region, as it was to the United States, that Israel would defend itself.

headline: Steel Production Falls
abstract: Steel production fell to 1.853 million tons in the week ending last Saturday, a decrease of 4.9 percent from the previous week's 1.949 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

headline: Soviet Mine Woes Cited WASHINGTON, Dec. 6
abstract: The Soviet Union's growing problems with its mining industry will lead to more Soviet mineral imports from the West in the 1980's, three American analysts said.   In a summary of a study to be released shortly, the analysts at the Interior Department's Bureau of Mines predicted Friday that Moscow would import more copper, lead and zinc, partly to supply Eastern Europe.   ''With the clear exception of a few precious and strategic metals, growth rates in Soviet output of most nonfuel minerals are anticipated to decline from past rates,'' the study said.

headline: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MONARCH MACHINE TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TORIES COME TO AID OF MRS. THATCHER
abstract: Former Prime Minister Edward Heath's assault on the economic policies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was all but lost today in waves of applause for her defenders.   In a speech at a luncheon meeting, Mr. Heath described Mrs.  Thatcher's monetarist approach as ''lunacy,'' and in the economic debate on the second day of the Conservative Party's annual conference he called repeatedly for a fresh start in combating the country's problems.   But the delegates to the conference gave Mr. Heath only tepid applause when he appeared. When he insisted that there were several alternatives to Mrs. Thatcher's approach, there were a few shouts of ''Rubbish!'' When he called for British participation in the European Monetary System, boos rang out in some parts of the Winter Gardens.  And when he was permitted to speak for seven minutes, while other participants were allotted only four minutes, delegates shouted ''Time! Time!''
