abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Justice Dept. Firm On Schlitz Merger
abstract: The Justice Department will not reconsider its Oct. 21 decision to oppose a $494 million merger between the Jos.

headline: Turkey Imprisons 25 As Suspected Terrorists
abstract: Martial law authorities announced today that they had jailed 25 suspected members of a left-wing terrorist group and seized 16 handguns, 128 dynamite sticks and other explosives.

headline: 20,000 Marchers in Frankfurt Protest New Airport Runway
abstract: About 20,000 people opposed to the construction of a new runway at Frankfurt's international airport staged a protest march at the site today.

headline: CHINESE ARE HOPING TO SIZE UP REAGAN AT CANCUN
abstract: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang left today for Mexico to represent China at the conference of 22 rich and poor nations, an event that will also give the Peking leadership its first opportunity to take personal measure of President Reagan.   The meeting in the Mexican resort of Cancun, starting Thursday, will be a gathering of leaders of the industrialized and the developing nations. This is believed to be the first time that China has joined such an international economic conference outside the framework of the United Nations, although Peking has supported the so-called Group of 77 developing countries pressing to correct their economic imbalance with the West.

headline: Coca-Cola to be Placed In the Midwest by MZB
abstract: Marvin Herb, who earlier this year acquired the Coca-Cola Bottling operations that cover Chicago, Indianapolis, Fort Wayne and Milwaukee and most of the areas in between from the Coca-Cola Company, has just selected MZB Advertising in Indianapolis to handle the merchandising and media ad placement. The advertising itself will continue to come from McCann-Erickson, Coke's traditional national agency and the one that had previously done the local work in this case.

headline: Electric Auto Plant
abstract: An auto maker that will begin producing luxury-priced electric cars next year may establish a plant in St.  Louis, a company official said today. John Shea, president of the Electric Auto Corporation of America, said, however, it would be at least two years before the company will be in a position to move into its own plant. City officials said they had hoped the company, based in Southfield, Mich., would move into the abandoned Corvette assembly plant.

headline: LIBYA PRESSSED TO REVISE TOUGH OIL-PRICE POLICY
abstract: This North African country, a hawk among OPEC members, is feeling increasing pressure to lower its oil prices to prevent an exodus of American oil companies, which control 70 percent of the oil-producing technology here.   The first shock to the Libyans came Nov. 12 when the Exxon Corporation announced that it was ending its operations in the country.   Then the Mobil Oil Corporation said in New York that its position was ''under review.'' This meant, according to an authoritative source in Tripoli who requested anonymity, that Mobil, too, was considering withdrawing because of Libya's tough pricing policies.  This source added that Mobil, which once produced about 110,000 barrels a day in Libya, currently ''is not producing anything.''

headline: PAPAL SECURITY INCREASED
abstract: PAPAL SECURITY INCREASED: Pope John II waving to crowds yesterday from the balcony of his residence at Castel Gandolfo, Italy.  He leans on a bulletproof glass shield that was recently installed on the balcony.

headline: 2 American Nuns Found Unharmed in Guatemala
abstract: Two Roman Catholic nuns from the United States, a Guatemalan priest and a seminary student who disappeared five days ago were found unharmed today in western Guatemala, a church official said.   He said there were indications they had been abducted.

headline: REAGAN REQUESTS AMERICANS TO QUIT LIBYA IMMEDIATELY
abstract: President Reagan appealed to Americans today to leave Libya immediately and invalidated American passports for travel to that country.   But he stopped short of embargoing Libyan oil, seeking additional sanctions against the Libyan Government or telling the estimated 1,500 Americans in Libya that they must return home.   A senior Administration official said Mr. Reagan was still considering a series of ''political, diplomatic, eco- Text of U.S. statement, page A12. nomic and other measures'' aimed at ending the ''current lawless behavior'' of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader. He said that it was ''obvious to all'' that an embargo on oil imports had been ''discussed,'' but that no new steps were imminent.

headline: 150,000 IN LONDON RALLY AGAINST BOMB
abstract: About 150,000 people marched through the heart of London today in a peaceful demonstration demanding nuclear disarmament.   Carrying placards depicting the horrors of nuclear war and chanting ''Ban the bomb!'' the marchers wound their way from the north bank of the Thames, near Trafalgar Square, to Hyde Park for a three-hour rally, blocking automobile traffic all along the route.   The rally, like a similar one in Bonn two weeks ago, reflected rising antinuclear feeling that is spreading across Europe, especially among the young. The Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, which sponsored the protest here, says that its membership in Britain has increased tenfold -from 3,000 to 30,000 - since early 1980.

headline: TAX BREAKS ON HOUSING STUDIED
abstract: Tax breaks for homeowners have had a mixed effect on the housing market and the United States economy as a whole, according to a new study by the Congressional Budget Office.   The advantages were originally granted to help bring to reality one of the great American dreams: homeownership for every desiring family. The new study, released today, comes at a time when the housing market is in a slump of historic dimension. It indicates that the breaks, although ''substantial'' in beneficial impact, have not been so effective as initially envisioned and have, in fact, been counterproductive in a number of instances.

headline: MARSH SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 10
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S.-JAPAN TRADE OBSTACLES
abstract: In three days of trade talks between the United States and Japan that began on Tuesday, Reagan Administration officials are presenting the Japanese Government with the grievances of people like Curt M. Rocca Jr.   Mr. Rocca is the president of the Numano Sake Company of Berkeley, Calif. Since 1979, when it first began to market sake in Japan, Numano has encountered some nettlesome obstacles while trying to sell the Japanese the rice wine that is Japan's national libation.   For one thing, Mr. Rocca said that the duty on bringing sake into Japan is six times what Japanese sake brewers pay to bring their product into the United States. Second, Numano makes a premium-grade sake, using more rice in the brewing process.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: Other Business; AS DETROIT GOES, SO GO MODEL CARS
abstract: Detroit's financial difficulties have been well documented but not, perhaps, the full impact of the ripple effect. Children, for example, are purchasing fewer toy plastic model cars than they did in the mid-1970's.   ''There has been a significant decline in our car sales in the last few years,'' said Harry Moorhouse, director of marketing of the plastic kit division of the Lesney Products Corporation. Of the 50 million plastic model kits sold to children and adults in America last year, toy industry analysts estimate that approximately onethird were cars, trucks or vans. Just two years ago, 40 percent of all models sold were road vehicles.

headline: BL Ltd. Workers End Latest Strike
abstract: Employees at Britain's stateowned auto maker returned to work after settlement of a monthlong strike over a proposal to cut 11 minutes from their 51-minute rest breaks. Officials said the shutdown by the 6,000 workers had cost BL Ltd. the equivalent of about $195 million.

headline: ECONOMIC REVIVAL CALLED POLISH AIM
abstract: A major goal of the military takeover in Poland, in the view of Western bankers and other experts, is a highly risky bid by the country's authorities to halt Poland's economic decline.   If it fails, it could touch off a major financial crisis, causing Poland to default on its multibillion-dollar foreign debt, undermining East-West trade and straining the West German banking system, these experts said today.   The declaration of martial law over the weekend and the ban on trade union activity, many Western bankers said, was inevitable so long as the country's economy continued to plunge, leaving factories partly idle and the population with inadequate food and fuel supplies.   ''There was no escaping the imposition of authority at some point so long as the chaos continued,'' said Richard Portes, an Americanborn economics professor at London University who published a major study on Poland's economic problems earlier this year.

headline: Ontario Hydro Bond
abstract: Ontario Hydro is raising $150 million through a 10-year Eurobond with a 16 percent interest-rate coupon and par pricing, bond market sources said here today. Deutsche Bank is the lead manager of the issue, which is callable after seven years at 101 1/2.

headline: The Sakharovs Plan A Hunger Strike
abstract: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human rights leader exiled to the city of Gorky, and his wife, Yelena Bonner, are planning to start a hunger strike on Nov. 22 to press for the emigration of a young woman engaged to marry Miss Bonner's son, friends of the family said today.   The sources said Dr. Sakharov sent a telegram Oct. 22 announcing his intentions to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader; to Anatoly P. Aleksandrov, president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, and to Yevgeny P. Velikhov, a vice president of the Academy. Dr. Sakharov remains a full member of the Academy.

headline: STEEL: TO DIVERSIFY OR REBUILD
abstract: A few years ago, when supporters of free trade would disagree with steelmakers on the need for import restrictions, the steelmakers would make a blatant appeal to patriotism and ask: ''Don't you think America needs a steel industry?''   But by their recent actions, it seems that steel producers have answered their own question with a ''Maybe.'' Domestic producers are modernizing many of their facilities, but apparently they have finally accepted with resignation their diminishing importance in the world steel industry.   The steel sector has shown its faith in the Reagan Administration's more attractive tax, environmental and regulatory policies by announcing a series of investment projects valued at more than $5.8 billion, a substantial sum by any measure. But with its bold, $6.4 billion bid last week for the Marathon Oil Company, the United States Steel Corporation vividly illustrated the sector's ambivalence toward its basic business.

headline: Western Air Stock
abstract: Eli Timoner, chairman of Air Florida, said yesterday that Air Florida recently purchased about 130,000 shares of Western Air stock, less than 1 percent of the outstanding. He added that he was still interested in buying control of Western Airlines.  For months, Air Florida held 11.6 percent of the Los Angeles-based carrier's stock but refrained from increasing this share.

headline: QUEEN OF LIGHTS
abstract: Accompanied by white-robed maids, Carolina Andersson, 17, wore a crown of candles as she was carried in procession in Vimmerby, Sweden. Miss Andersson was chosen as the town's 35th representative of St. Lucy for the celebration, next week on the feast day of the saint, of the Queen of Lights festival.

headline: Tax Forms Will Soon Be Arriving
abstract: Along with a few late Christmas cards, mail carriers will begin bringing another sign of the holiday season on Saturday: the 1981 Federal income tax forms.   About 91 million forms ''should begin to arrive no earlier than Saturday and no later than the first week in January,'' Rod Young, an Internal Revenue Service spokesman, said today.

headline: WORST DROUGHT IN CENTURY HITS SPAIN'S SOUTH
abstract: Fausto Lopez, who has a small farm in Spain's drought-stricken south, let his mule rest and picked up brown, dry earth. He watched it trickle between his fingers.  ''This is not soil,'' he said, ''it's dust.''

headline: COX BROADCASTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Argentine Chief Recovering
abstract: President Roberto Viola, recuperating from a cardiovascular illness, entered a hospital today for tests that will determine whether he is ready to return to work. An official bulletin said General Viola, 57 years old, would remain hospitalized until Friday. The presidential press office said Wednesday that the general ''has experienced an improvement in his clinical state.''

headline: Argentina Has New Air Chief
abstract: Brig. Gen. Arturo Lami Dozo assumed office today as commander of the Argentine Air Force and a member of the governing military junta. He replaces Brig. Gen. Omar Graffigna, who retired.

headline: Tremors Shake Soviet Town
abstract: Earth tremors have destroyed buildings in and around the town of Ismailly, just west of the Caspian Sea, but caused no casualties, the official press agency, Tass, reported today.

headline: Kuwaiti Oil Search Plan
abstract: The Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, which spent almost $100 million to acquire leases in nine countries this year, plans a substantial increase in international oil exploration activities, a petroleum newsletter said yesterday.   The corporation, which is Kuwait's national oil company, recently acquired the Santa Fe International Corporation, a large American drilling concern, for $2.5 billion.

headline: COBE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.N. Agency for Palestinians Says It Is in Financial Trouble
abstract: In the bleakest report since its formation 32 years ago, the United Nations relief agency for Palestinian refugees reported today that it was in ''a perilously critical state'' and might face bankruptcy.   The report projected that the agency's deficit for 1981 would be $44.8 million and would nearly double to $80.3 million in 1982.

headline: A.T.&T. TO BUY REST OF PACIFIC UNIT
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would acquire the minority-held shares of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, its financially troubled California subsidiary, in a stock swap valued at nearly $400 million.   The move would allow A.T.&T., which now owns 91 percent of Pacific Telephone, to transfer some of its assets to a new unregulated subsidiary without having to worry about compensating independent shareholders. ''It's just the matter of having the flexibility of a 100 percent-owned corporation,'' said Arthur Latno Jr., executive vice president of Pacific Telephone.   The Federal Communications Commission has authorized the reorganization of A.T.&T. and the Senate has passed a bill that would permit the phone company to divide into a regulated division for phone services and an unregulated division for new competitive services. While the final structure of A.T.&T. has not been determined, the company is already moving to reorganize itself.

headline: The Times of London Has $15 Million Loss
abstract: The Times of London has lost $15.5 million since July 1, the newspaper's managing director, Gerald Long, was quoted today as saying.   Answering questions from one of his own reporters on the future of Times Newspapers Ltd., Mr. Long said he knew of no plan to sell the concern but he said he had had ''quite a few conversations'' on the possibility of closing if economies were not achieved.

headline: U.N. CALLS ON EL SALVADOR TO NEGOIATE WITH REBELS
abstract: The General Assembly approved a resolution tonight calling on the United States-backed junta in El Salvador to negotiate with its leftist opponents before next year's scheduled elections.   The vote was 68 to 22, with the United States voting against.

headline: POLISH POLICE BATTLE 5,000 PROTESTING ARRESTS
abstract: In the worst outbreak of street violence in 14 months of labor unrest, the police in Katowice today battled 5,000 protesters who had been angered by the arrest of three Solidarity activists for distributing leaflets.   According to a Solidarity statement, the demonstrators took to the streets in the southern mining city after the police arrested the three unionists for selling underground newspapers and Solidarity leaflets from a van.   Two of the men escaped into the crowd and one, Tadeusz Buranowski, a local union board member, was detained by the police.  Official reports said the crowd attacked the police and hurled stones at the police station, breaking windows. One police van was overturned. Polish television showed photographs of a huge crowd and people standing atop the overturned van. There were no reported injuries.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: FED ADDS TO BANK RESERVES
abstract: The Federal Reserve was active yesterday adding reserves to the banking system on two occasions, but many analysts concluded that the nation's central bank was acting for technical reasons and was not trying to significantly increase the supply of credit in the banking system.   By late in the day, short-term interest rates were slightly higher, while note and bond yields were about unchanged. Dealers said that the heavy supply of new corporate notes and bonds had been well received, but that the continuing influx of new issues was putting some pressure on the market.   ''Some investors see more issues coming, and have decided to back away from the market,'' one investment banker said.  Many economists have been scrutinizing Federal Reserve actions for signs that the Fed will encourage the often-predicted rate decline by pumping more credit into the banking system. Yesterday the Fed added credit for four and eight days, via temporary purchases of securities, and then permanently added reserves though purchases of agency securities for Monday delivery.

headline: Dissident Soviet Couple Believed to Begin Fast
abstract: Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet scientist, and his wife, Yelena Bonner, are believed to have begun a hunger strike in Gorky today to protest the Soviet authorities' refusal to grant an exit visa to their daughter-in-law. Dr. Sakharov has accused the authorities of penalizing the young woman for his activities.   Miss Bonner said she and Dr. Sakharov intended to fast until authorities let the young woman leave the country.

headline: JAPANESE PRIME MINISTER REORGANIZES CABINET
abstract: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki replaced his Foreign Minister and other Cabinet members today and announced other appointments to top posts in the governing party.   Mr. Suzuki, who has been Prime Minister since July 1980, carried out the first reorganization of the Cabinet and the governing Liberal Democratic Party under his leadership. Fifteen of the 20 Cabinet ministers were replaced.

headline: OREGON PORTLAND CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FEW ISSUES SET SO FAR THIS WEEK
abstract: Few corporations have scheduled new note or bond issues this week, but investment bankers say many more will come to market if yields continue to decline or even stay at their levels of late Friday.   Because the terms of most new issues are negotiated between the company and the underwriters, it is possible for a new debt issue to wait in the wings and not be announced until the underwriting group has lined up buyers for most or all of the securities. This can happen rapidly, as shown last Friday when Caterpillar Tractor's Aarated notes due in 1988 were offered to yield 14.75 percent and Nova Scotia's A-1 notes due in 1991 were offered to yield 15.75 percent.

headline: BLAME THE POLITICIANS, NOT ECONOMISTS
abstract: R ONALD COASE, though not a household name, is a superstar in the economics profession. When he talks, economists listen. And when he recently delivered the Nutter Lecture at the American Enterprise Institute, he addressed the most important issue facing economists.  He asked, how should economists choose between competing theories about how the world works?   Milton Friedman has argued that a theory should not be judged by the accuracy of its assumptions. The only important question is whether it predicts events accurately.

headline: How to Figure Certificate's Yield
abstract: Here is how to figure the yield on a tax-exempt savings certificate, starting with the discount rate for one-year Treasury bills.   Using the results of yesterday's one-year bill auction as an example, follow these steps.   - Take the average discount rate of 14.58 percent and multiply by 364. Then divide by 360. The result should be 14.742.

headline: NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Kuwait Sets Oil Price Cut
abstract: Kuwait announced today, as expected, that its oil price will fall by 70 cents a barrel on Jan.1 as called for in agreements reached at last week's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.   Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifi al-Sabah, said that the price would fall to $32.30 a barrel.

headline: HOOVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: COLD AND MADNESS IN SIBERIA
abstract: Whatever the temperature, Siberians are loath to admit it's cold. But here they have no choice - there simply aren't many colder places on earth.   Dawn is still far off at 9 A.M.; it's 60 degrees below zero. The cold hits the nostrils first, an anesthetizing stab that stiffens the lining of the nose. The eyes begin to sting, and soon the cheeks start to tingle and turn pallid. Rub them quickly, say the anxious hosts, but then the diverted breath coats eyeglasses with an unyielding crust of frost.

headline: U.S. ENVOY UNHURT IN ATTACK IN PARIS
abstract: A gunman fired six shots at the top-ranking American diplomat in Paris as he was leaving his home this morning, but the envoy escaped unhurt.   Christian A. Chapman, the charge d'affaires at the American Embassy, ran to shelter behind his car as soon as the shooting began. Mr. Chapman's driver escaped injury, as did several passers-by on the quiet, tree-lined street near the Champs de Mars. The unidentified gunman, who was described by witnesses as ''Middle Eastern in appearance,'' walked off briskly after emptying his pistol.   In Washington, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  expressed the suspicion that Libya might have been responsible for the assassination attempt, but said he had no proof. Mr. Haig said the United States had reports that Libya was involved in planned terrorism against American diplomats. Libya promptly denied the accusations.

headline: O.E.C.D. Forecast On Growth Dimmer
abstract: Most industrialized countries should experience modest economic growth next year, while the United States remains mired in recession, according to the semiannual economic report of the organization that gathers statistics on the industrialized nations.   The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicted that unemployment in the United States would rise to a rate of 9 1/4 percent in the first half of 1982 and hold at 9 percent in the second six months, a sustained level of joblessness unknown in America since the Great Depression. Last month, the unemployment rate was at 8.4 percent of the work force.   Elsewhere in the industrialized world, unemployment is also expected to rise because economic growth will be too low to accommodate those entering the labor force for the first time as well as those laid off because of improvements in production efficiency.

headline: THOUSANDS PROTEST IN WARSAW STREETS
abstract: The following article is based on information arriving from Poland.   The hostility of Poles to the imposition of martial law erupted into street demonstrations in Warsaw yesterday on the 11th anniversary of riots along the Baltic Coast. There were reports of street fighting and shooting incidents in other cities.

headline: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Sales by the Big Three domestic auto makers fell 27.8 percent during the first 10 days of December. Ford's sales fell 37.7 percent, General Motors' sales slid 26.4 percent and Chrysler's fell 14.6 percent. (Page D1.)   A delay of action that could have ended interest rate limits on many Americans' savings accounts will be sought by Treasury Secretary Regan. The position represents a shift. (D1.)

headline: Patents; A Radioactive Tracer For Probing Arteries
abstract: A cardiac probe with the trademark name The Nuclear Stethoscope was patented this week for Bios Inc., Valhalla, N.Y., which develops and manufactures medical equipment. Robert I. Gray, president, says he believes the invention is making a profound contribution to diagnosis of coronary artery disease, as demonstrated at various research centers.

headline: CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THRIFT UNITS EXPECTING LITTLE RELIEF
abstract: The recent drop in interest rates will bring little near-term relief to many of the nation's beleaguered savings and loan associations, according to delegates attending the annual convention of the United States League of Savings Associations.   This is because many savings institutions have accumulated large amounts of deposits at high rates in certificates that will not mature for months, or even years, they said.   ''We're going to have to stick with it for another 30 months,'' said Russell L. Stewart, chairman of the Home Federal Savings and Loan Association in St. Petersburg, Fla., which has assets of more than $1 billion. ''Everybody has been moving into the 30-month smallsavers certificates, and they've been getting yields of up to 15 1/2 percent,'' added Mr. Stewart, who is among 4,000 savings executives gathered at the New York Hilton.

headline: 2 KILLED BY BOMB AT ANTWERP SYNAGOGUE
abstract: A car bomb exploded outside a synagogue in the predominantly Jewish diamond-trading district here today, killing 2 women and wounding 95 other people, 12 of them seriously.   The bomb, concealed in a parked van with one wheel removed, went off shortly after 9 A.M., a few minutes before services were to begin in the synagogue celebrating the feast of Simhath Torah.   The explosion smashed in the double doors and stained glass windows of the narrow white-stone building, which is on Hoverniersstaat, in the heart of the @diamond-trading area near the Antwerp railroad station.   It ripped the facade off one of Antwerp's four diamond exchanges, the Diamond Club, which stands next door, and it smashed shop fronts and windows within 500 yards. Cars and trucks were hurled across the street and set on fire. All that remained of the van carrying the bomb were parts of its axles.

headline: Soviet Lodges a Protest In Attack at Residence
abstract: In a note made public today, the Soviet Union lodged a strong protest with the United States over an incident last Saturday in which shots were fired into a Soviet residence at Glen Cove, L.I.   It called the attack, in which no one was injured, very serious and demanded that ''those guilty of the terrorist act'' be found and brought to account.   The note said a number of Soviet diplomats and family members were in the building at the time of the incident.

headline: POPE ISSUES A CALL TO PEOPLE 'HUMILIATED' BY AUTHORITIES
abstract: Pope John Paul II made an impromptu appearance at his window overlooking St. Peter's Square today and, in an apparent reference to his native Poland, said many people were being ''humiliated'' by their governments this Christmas season.   The Roman Catholic leader spoke to several thousand people in the square on the feast of St. Stephen, the first Christian martyr. John Paul had never before spoken at his window to mark the day.

headline: STA-RITE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Flemish Social Christian Forms Belgian Cabinet
abstract: A Flemish Social Christian named Wilfried Martens announced the formation today of a center-right Belgian Cabinet, ending a three-month old political crisis.   Mr. Martens, four times Prime Minister in the past three years, said the French- and Flemish-speaking Liberal and Social Christian parties had agreed to form a coalition to save Belgium from its worst economic problems in 3O years.

headline: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: French Senate Votes To End Death Penalty
abstract: The Government bill to abolish the death penalty cleared its last hurdle today when the oppositiondominated Senate passed the measure by a vote of 161 to 126.   The bill will become law after it is published in the official gazette, probably in the next week.

headline: ALLIED CORP. GAINS 78.8%
abstract: W.R. Grace & Company, a diversified chemical concern with interests in natural resources and consumer businesses, reported yesterday that profits for the third quarter rose 40.7 percent, to $97.1 million, or $2.04 a share, from $69 million, or $1.47 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.   Sales increased by 6 percent, to $1.59 billion from $1.5 billion in the third quarter of 1980.  The company said that its third-quarter results included after-tax divestment gains of $33.7 million from the public stock offering in Omnicare Inc., a health-care services company, and $13.8 million from a claim settlement against the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company.

headline: THE SURGE IN BUSINESS FAILURES
abstract: FINALLY, the high cost of money is sending tens of thousands of the businesses that borrowed it down the road that so many of the experts said it would to a cleaner called bankruptcy court. All it took to send them there was a recession.   The last big decline was the one in 1974 and 1975. That was the inventory recession. Companies, anticipating ever-rising sales, had crammed their warehouses with materials and supplies and products, only to watch them languish there when the economy stopped buying.  Those that couldn't cope shut down or sold out.   This is the interest-rate recession. Before it began showing up in the data that depicted a slide in the overall economy, it had crippled two of the most rate-sensitive industries, automobiles and housing. Now it is sweeping into many other industries.

headline: Patents; Monitor for Valves
abstract: A position indicator invented for the Department of Energy will show an operator in a control room whether a valve in a gas-cooled nuclear reactor is closed or open. The invention, patent 4,304,630, was made under a contract with the General Atomic Company, San Diego, by David E. Tanner. The position of a valve or other movable element is detected by reflected light and the information is transmitted through fiber optics to a readout point.

headline: Foreign Steel Investigation
abstract: The Reagan Administration today added Canada and Spain to its list of foreign steel producers under investigation for unfair trade practices.   The Commerce Department said it was starting an ''antidumping'' investigation of sheet piling from Canada and a countervailing duty investigation of structural steel shapes from Spain.

headline: TO HUNGARIANS, THE POLES ARE ON THE WRONG TRACK
abstract: There is a growing sense of confidence here that the Hungarian model of gradually loosening controls is ''the right way'' and that the crisis in Poland proves it.   Communist Party officials here do not express concern over Hungary's catching the freedom fever from Poland but rather see the situation there as a ''failure'' for both the Communist Party leadership and the defiant labor unions.   The main fear among Communists here is that a deterioration of the security situation in Poland could lead to military intervention by the Soviet Union and its allies. This would undoubtedly block general East-West relations and close Hungary's doors to the West.  And half of Budapest's trade is with the West.

headline: SUN TO SELL ASSETS OF SHIP UNIT
abstract: The Sun Company announced today that it would sell the assets of its 65-year-old shipbuilding subsidiary to Levingston Shipbuilding Company, a privately held company that operates two shipyards in Texas and a marine engineering facility in Annapolis, Md.   The subsidiary, Sun Ship Inc., has been one of the nation's major shipyards and the leading employer in Chester, Pa., near Philadelphia. Repairs to Be Continued   The parent company had announced last January that it would phase out new vessel construction and sharply reduce the work force of 4,200 but would continue to repair ships and maintain other Sun Ship operations.   The Sun Company, which signed a letter of intent with Levingston, did not disclose terms of the transaction. A Sun spokesman, Kurt VanVlandren, said the sale, which would be final by March 1982, is conditional upon reaching a definitive agreement, obtaining Government approval and renegotiating labor agreements with Sun Ship's labor unions.

headline: GREENMAN BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAPAN SAID TO INFILTRATE CONSUMER GROUP
abstract: A few years ago, it was a struggling little public interest group seeking to promote the concept of free trade.  Now, with its membership rolls swollen by the American employees of the Japanese automobile industry, Consumers for World Trade finds itself both increasingly influential -and controversial - with one United States Senator terming its activities ''an underhanded and dishonorable way for the Japanese to try to influence public opinion.''   Consumers for World Trade, which promotes an open trading system through lobbying and educational programs, is considered by its critics to be a part of an increasingly energetic effort by the Japanese to sway the course of policies affecting bilateral relations.   This year, Japan is expected to sell some $15 billion more goods to the United States than it will buy from this country. There is nothing irregular in the Japanese pursuit of friends in Washington.  Indeed, most foreign governments and companies spend a lot of time and money doing just that.

headline: ALONG ZIMBABWE'S BORDER, A WAR IS STILL GOING ON
abstract: Although the war ended last year between the forces of the former Rhodesia and the insurgents who now govern Zimbabwe, the sound of firing has never been stilled in the rich farming country here along the Mozambique border.   Now it comes regularly from the other side, where an obscure insurgency called the Mozambique National Resistance Movement has been operating.   The fighting seems to be intermittent and seldom sustained, but it has been enough to provoke a movement of refugees from Mozambique to this recently embattled, now peaceful area of Zimbabwe. Many find work on white commercial farms in the area. Some end up squatting on the commercial farms.

headline: Polish Bond: Japan Is Cool
abstract: Officials at the Japanese Finance Ministry and commercial banks here said today they doubted that the Communist bloc would be able to raise money on the Japanese capital market to support Poland.   They could not confirm a report in the Japanese financial daily, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, that quoted banking sources saying the Comecon Bank, which is the settlement bank for the Soviet Union and East European countries, had sounded out some Japanese banks about the possibility of floating a $90 million bond in Japan.   The officials said the proceeds of such proposed fund raising could be expected to be used as financial support for Poland, but the market response here might be poor because Japanese banks and securities firms would be very cautious in view of the current crisis and the United States' economic sanctions against Poland.

headline: Funding of State Dept.  Approved by the House
abstract: The House of Representatives passed a $5.7 billion State Department authorization bill today and sent it to a House-Senate conference with a message that it should be amended.   At issue are cuts made by the International Communication Agency to meet the Administration's 12 percent across-the-board budget reduction.

headline: POPE URGES POLES TO SET OWN COURSE
abstract: Pope John Paul II, addressing 300 Polish priests and lay people at the Vatican today, asked them to pray that Poles alone be allowed to determine their future.   He said that ''the nation's right to self-determination'' as well as other basic human values were now at stake.  In one of the clearest references he has made to Soviet pressure on Poland and to the danger of Soviet intervention, the Pope offered ''a prayer that we alone may be able to be the craftsmen and the builders of our destiny, the responsible creators of our future, so that no one shall interfere from the outside and so that all this shall not be imposed on us from the outside.''

headline: POLES IN ACCORD ON BANK DEBT
abstract: Handlowy, Poland's state bank, reached an agreement this week to reschedule $2.4 billion in debt owed this year to 460 commercial banks in Western countries and Japan, the Dresdner Bank announced today.   The agreement marks the first formal rescheduling of Polish debt to Western banks. Earlier, the banks had agreed to postpone repayment deadlines on more than $5 billion in debt while negotiators attempted to reach agreement on rescheduling.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LIBERTY FABRICS OF NEW YORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IN ITALY, THE BOMB'S A POLITICAL ISSUE FOR FIRST TIME
abstract: In all, perhaps a half-million demonstrators have marched this fall in Rome, Milan, Venice and many smaller cities against the stationing of nuclear weapons in Italy.   The dimension and nature of the marches came as a surprise to the political parties that normally direct and control every facet of Italy's political life.   The parties found themselves bypassed and overtaken by an amorphous coming together of antiwar activists, opponents of nuclear weapons, ecologists, feminists, conscientious objectors, religious groups, youth organizations and leftists with conflicting political affiliations.   This was something new on the Italian political scene - a mass expression of genuine pacifism that seemed to be different from the anti-Americanism of the protests during the Vietnam War and cold war.

headline: New Trading In Eurodollars
abstract: The Chicago Board of Trade and the New York Futures Exchange were given Government permission today to begin trading in Eurodollar futures contracts.   The action by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission brings to three the number of exchanges designated as a contract market to trade futures contracts in Eurodollar time deposit rates.

headline: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PACIFIC ISLE ANGRY AT U.S. STAND ON MISSILE SITE
abstract: Landowners of Kwajalein Atoll, whose property has been used by the United States for missile tests for nearly 20 years, have been told by a Washington consultant that the Department of Defense may continue using the test site for the next decade or two.   The consultant reported to the Kwajalein Atoll Corporation, which represents the landowners, that information provided in Washington by military and Congressional sources showed the operations at the atoll yielded vital data on the accuracy of missiles and on weapons deployment. An American adviser to the islanders said here that their leaders were surprised by the report on the site, a high security area.   The landowners, who number about 5,500, are engaged in litigation against the United States for redress of what they consider inadequate compensation for the military use of their lands in the past. Under the custom prevailing in the Marshall Islands, of which the atoll is a part, land is communally owned and is administered by hereditary chiefs.

headline: News Analysis; MUBARAK'S EGYPT: JUST A CARBON COPY OF SADAT'S, OR WILL IT BE AN ORIGINAL?
abstract: Egypt's new leader, Hosni Mubarak, faces a bewildering array of foreign and domestic issues at a time when he will be under intense scrutiny at home and abroad.   Mr. Mubarak, who had served as Anwar el-Sadat's Vice President since 1975, was thrust into Egypt's highest office when the President was assassinated at a military parade Tuesday. He had been handpicked for the vice presidential post and for a long time had been regarded as Mr. Sadat's heir apparent.   Last night he was easily nominated for the presidency by the ruling National Democratic Party. The choice will be ratified by the Egyptian electorate in a referendum on Tuesday since he is the only candidate on the ballot.

headline: BANKERS TRUST CO (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLISH PARTY MEETING IS CRITICAL OF LEADERSHIP
abstract: Members of the Central Committee criticized Poland's Communist leadership today, many of them calling for stronger action to overcome the economic crisis and a tougher line against the Solidarity union.   A resolution to be voted on tomorrow would call on the Government to declare a state of emergency if the need arises. This would allow summary arrests, military trials and other steps to deal with social unrest.

headline: SPANISH CHIEF SHUFFLES TEAM WITH OBJECT TO UNITING PARTY
abstract: Spain's newly shuffled Cabinet took its oath of office before King Juan Carlos today.  For the first time since 1937 a woman was appointed to a Cabinet job, but aside from that the new Cabinet contains few novelties or surprises. Its composition appears dictated almost entirely by the need of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo to appease factions in his Union of the Democratic Center.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Chemical Bank has named John M. Eggemeyer 3d a senior vice president.   * Hospital Corp. of America, Nashville, has named Ronald C. Marston president of the Europe/Middle East/ Africa region.

headline: Budd Co. Layoffs
abstract: The Budd Company said that 1,500 employees at its Red Lion plant in Philadelphia will be laid off from Dec. 4 through mid-January because of a shortage of brake system parts caused by a strike against a supplier. A Budd spokesman said that the workers will be called back in mid-January but no specific date has been set.

headline: WESTINGHOUSE NET UP 14.4% IN THIRD QUARTER
abstract: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's second-largest maker of electrical equipment after the General Electric Company, reported yesterday that gains by all three of its component groups caused earnings in the third quarter to rise 14.4 percent as sales increased 10.1 percent.   Westinghouse said that net income in the latest quarter moved up to $104.6 million, or $1.21 a share, from $91.4 million, or $1.06 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenues widened to $2.28 billion from $2.07 billion.

headline: COMMERCE SOUTHWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.9 BILLION
abstract: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday a larger-than-expected $1.9 billion decline in the nation's money supply, which strengthened the conviction of some analysts that short-term interest rates would drop soon.   The late-afternoon announcement meant that growth in the supply of money circulating through the economy had fallen further behind the Fed's growth targets for 1981.   The M-1B measure of money supply, consisting of currency plus deposits in all kinds of checking accounts, totaled $431.7 billion in the week ended Sept. 23, and is now more than $6 billion below the level that would be consistent with the Federal Reserve's 6.5 percent minimum growth target for this year.   ''The economy is the weakest it has been in 15 months, and money supply growth continues to be sluggish, so I expect to see a lower Federal funds rate in the very near future,'' said Albert Gross, an economist at Refco Partners, a Government securities firm.

headline: FINANCIAL TIMES ENDS WEEKLY
abstract: World Business Weekly, the three-year-old digest of international business and financial news aimed at the American business executive, is ceasing publication after its current issue, the Financial Times Group announced yesterday.   The troubled Financial Times, London's daily business newspaper, started the magazine in October 1978 as one prong of a drive to gain an audience beyond British shores. In 1979, it also began an international edition of The Financial Times that is distributed elsewhere in Europe and in the United States.

headline: ALZA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Iran Says 13 Leftists Have Been Executed
abstract: Iranian officials said today that 13 leftist guerrillas fighting Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Moslem regime were executed by firing squads.   The Teheran office of the general prosecutor said, by telephone, that 13 members of the People's Mujahedeen and other underground groups were executed Tuesday in the northern city of Gorgan and in Ahvaz, capital of the province of Khuzistan in southwestern Iran.   They were found guilty of participating in armed demonstrations and attempting to assassinate government supporters.

headline: IRAN PICKS U.S.-TRAINED DOCTOR TO BE PREMIER
abstract: Iran said today that a 36-year-old Islamic fundamentalist who received medical training in the United States had been chosen the new Prime Minister.   When formally endorsed by Parliament, the new leader, Ali Akbar Vellayati, will succeed Ayatollah Mohammed Riza Mahdavi-Kani, who resigned last Thursday to give the newly elected President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, a free hand to choose the Cabinet. Prime Minister Mahdavi-Kani had been accused of not moving strongly enough to suppress opposition to the Islamic Government.

headline: BONN AND MOSCOW SET OWN CONTACTS ON ARMS CONTROL
abstract: Leonid I. Brezhnev and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt today ended three days of talks during which they agreed to set up separate Soviet-West German contacts on arms control parallel to the Soviet-American talks starting Monday in Geneva.   A West German spokesman, Kurt Becker, disclosed the plan at a news conference, saying that the separate exchanges were considered necessary because ''we are the people most deeply concerned'' by the outcome of the Soviet-American talks, which will seek to limit or reduce medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe.   The State Department, commenting in Washington on various arms proposals made by Mr. Brezhnev in Bonn, said that with the Geneva talks about to begin, it was now ''time for serious discussions and a cessation of public posturing.'' (Page A10.)

headline: Moscow Denies Charge On Chemical Warfare
abstract: The Soviet Union today denied an accusation by a United States official that Soviet-backed governments in Asia were using lethal chemical weapons.   ''Washington officials have neither direct nor indirect evidence of the use of chemical and biological weapons by the Soviet Union,'' the official press agency Tass said.

headline: U.S. PLANS DIRECT COMPLAINTS TO NATIONS SUBSIDIZING STEEL
abstract: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige announced today that the Government, for the first time, would bring official complaints accusing foreign governments of unfairly subsidizing steel exports to this country.   The action, which Mr. Baldrige said would be taken early next week after the exporting nations were informed, increased the dangers of a trade war, especially with European nations.   It could also lead to sharply higher tariffs on imported s-el, reducing shipments here and thereby causing layoffs abroad in a sector already hit by overcapacity and high unemployment.   Although Mr. Baldrige insisted the United States would be acting only against ''unfair'' practices, the consequences could include retaliation against American exports of food, machinery and other products by foreign governments angered by the reduction in their American steel markets.

headline: LA POINTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Parts Spinoff Urged for RCA
abstract: RCA may be too unweildy for its own good, or, as James Magid puts it, ''RCA may be worth more dead than alive.'' Mr. Magid, an analyst who follows RCA for L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, means that parts of the empire would be more valuable if sold than if the ailing conglomerate continues to operate them.   Mr. Magid would like RCA to sell CIT and Hertz, redeploy the assets, retire some debt and thus become a much stronger company.  He said that RCA's chairman, Thornton F. Bradshaw, had been hinting in the press that the two divisions were for sale, although he had not been talking to analysts.   Meanwhile, Mr. Bradshaw, the former president of Atlantic Richfield, is attempting to turn RCA around, a big job.  Interest-rate-sensitive CIT and Hertz are both off stride, although CIT profits in the first nine months helped keep RCA in the black.  But the sale of the two divisions could be highly rewarding.

headline: BEGIN EASES STAND ON AUTONOMY UNIT
abstract: An aide to Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Israel had agreed to a slight enlargement of the proposed administrative council that would conduct the Palestinians' affairs in the West Bank and Gaza Strip under the Camp David accords.   The aide said in an interview that contrary to an impression created by a report published in The New York Times Wednesday, the change represented no basic shift in the Israeli position but rather a modification on a technical question.   The Times report said Mr. Begin, in conversations with Americans at the funeral of Anwar el-Sadat in Cairo last week and with former President Jimmy Carter in the United States last month, had expressed readiness to accept principles for Palestinian self-rule proposed a year ago by the Carter Administration.  The article said, however, that Mr. Begin did not explain precisely what he had in mind.

headline: SYBRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. Issues Dominate Financing
abstract: The United States Treasury will dominate new-issue activity in the credit markets this week with sales of one-year bills and four-year notes, as well as the regular weekly sale of new three- and six-month notes.   Investment bankers said that some corporate issues could still come to market in this holiday-shortened week if market conditions improve, but, as of Friday, no sales were scheduled.

headline: GULF NUCLEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Supply-Side
abstract: To the Business Editor: Carl Alan Batlin's analysis in ''Those Tax Cuts Could Miss the Target'' (Oct. 4), seems seriously flawed. He argues that since the reduction in the tax rates increases the after-tax rate of return for all securities, regardless of risk, ''safe securities are now relatively more attractive than risky ones, because investors can now earn the same expected return as before but without bearing as much risk.''

headline: Business Conditions; A BIG YEAR FOR OPIC
abstract: These are heady days for the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Government entity that sells political risk insurance and financial services to American companies entering markets in developing countries. Backed by a pro-investment Administration and a more aggressive marketing approach, it is writing more policies than ever.

headline: WHITE HOUSE SAYS REAGAN KNEW IN SEPTEMBER ABOUT ALLEN INQUIRY
abstract: President Reagan has known since mid-September that his national security adviser, Richard V. Allen, received a $1,000 cash payment from a Japanese journalist, a White House spokesman said today.   The spokesman, David R. Gergen, had said previously that it was not until last Friday that the President learned both about the payment, made after a Japanese magazine interviewed Nancy Reagan, and about a Justice Department investigation into the matter.   Just before his disclosure today at a regular news briefing, Mr.  Gergen had said that there would be a strict policy of no comment while the Justice Department's investigation continued.   ''I do want to correct the record on one point,'' Mr. Gergen added, and revealed then that not even he, as the White House Director of Communications, had known about the President's knowledge when he briefed reporters on Friday.   ''I subsequently learned that he knew of the fact that the matter had been referred to the Justice Department prior to that time,'' Mr. Gergen said. ''He learned this at approximately the time the money was discovered and the matter was referred to the Justice Department.''

headline: IRANIANS STAGE ANKARA PROTEST
abstract: Revolutionary guards reportedly executed 61 more leftist Mujahedeen dissidents in Teheran today, and anti-Khomeini forces shot up and ransacked the Iranian consulate in Istanbul to protest the mounting toll of executions.   A Turkish and an Iranian guard and a consulate employee were wounded in shooting in the seizure of the consulate, the Turkish police said.

headline: PRODUCTIVITY DOWN AT 1.9% YEARLY RATE
abstract: American business productivity declined at an annual rate of 1.9 percent in the quarter ended Sept. 30, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. It was the worst showing since the first quarter of 1978, when a 2.3 percent annual rate of decline was registered.   Reversing two consecutive quarters of improvement, the output of private industry declined 1.2 percent in the latest quarter while working hours rose seven-tenths of 1 percent on a seasonally adjusted annual basis. The figures were based on preliminary readings of the performance of all private business, including farming, in July, August and September.

headline: BARD, C R, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Canada Loan Guarantee
abstract: The British Export Credits Guarantee Department said today that it would guarantee a $82.52 million (Canadian) loan to the Transalta Utilities Corporation of Alberta, its first such Canadian loan guarantee. The five-year loan, to help finance two turbine generators from GEC Turbine Generators Ltd. and GEC Canada Ltd., will carry a subsidized interest rate of 8.5 percent.

headline: International Loans Up
abstract: Borrowing on international capital markets increased 53.5 percent, to $183.16 billion, from $119.35 billion in 1980, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported today.

headline: COMBINED COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INDUSTRIAL-AMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Wife Reports That Sakharov Has Suffered Heart Flutters
abstract: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident who recently carried out, with his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, a 17-day hunger strike to obtain an exit visa for a relative, has since suffered palpitations similar to a heart attack, Miss Bonner said today.   Miss Bonner told reporters by telephone from the city of Gorky that her husband suffered the palpitations last Tuesday and Saturday.

headline: Lockheed Net Up 25.6%
abstract: The Lockheed Corporation said today that its third-quarter profit rose 25.6 percent, to $20.6 million, or $1.18 a share, from $16.4 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier.  Sales rose 8.1 percent, to $1.46 billion from $1.35 billion in 1980.

headline: NAPLES FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Sympathy Strike in Bavaria
abstract: About 100,000 workers in Bavaria were reported today to have staged a five-minute work stoppage in sympathy with ''suppressed Polish colleagues.'' The action, called by the Bavarian wing of the national trade union council, was carried out in a number of factories including the B.M.W. and Audi auto plants in Munich and Ingolstadt.

headline: VISA RESTRICTIONS HARD TO ENFORCE
abstract: The passport restrictions on travel to Libya announced today by the Reagan Administration would be difficult to enforce against anyone determined to go to that country, or to remain there, according to legal experts.   But Administration officials said that President Reagan was prepared to take other available legal measures if necessary to insure that Americans leave Libya. Whether such additional steps would, or legally could, include criminal prosecutions of people who travel to Libya without permission is unclear.

headline: Hardee's to Buy Burger Chef
abstract: The General Foods Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Burger Chef Systems unit, a fast-food retailer, to Hardee's Food Systems Inc. for about $44 million. Other terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

headline: Economic Affairs; RELAX, SOCIAL SECURITY IS DOING ITS JOB
abstract: I F one believes the detractors of Social Security, the public pension system of this country is almost bankrupt, gives out benefits that are improvidently generous and has reduced savings among our citizens, thus robbing our economy of vital capital. This adds up to a harsh indictment. The truth is, however, that not one of these accusations deserves to be taken seriously.   All the talk about bankruptcy and insolvency has caused considerable mental anguish. People already retired, and those looking forward to retirement in the near future, have been made to feel painfully insecure. Virtually all of these people expect to use Social Security benefit checks to meet their basic needs, and many of them have been seized by the fear that the checks will either be drastically reduced or will not be there at all.

headline: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEINBERGER ASSAILS NEUTRALISM
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger warned today against ''the dangers of neutralism'' in Europe posed by those who advocate ''unilateral disarmament.'' But he said he distinquished between such neutralism and the neutrality of Sweden, which is strongly armed.

headline: Coal Terminal May Be Built
abstract: The Patrick Petroleum Corporation said that it would build a coal terminal in Hampton Roads, Va., the country's No.1 port for coal exports, if it could secure financing.   The terminal, capable of handling 9 million tons of coal, would lie on 60 acres along a newly dredged branch of the Elizabeth River in Chesapeake, Va.

headline: Reader Comment; FOR THE BELL BILL
abstract: P AUL MacAVOY'S opposition to the Telecommunications Competition and Deregulation Act of 1981 (''Why Reagan Should Veto the Bell Bill,'' Oct. 25) should be entitled ''Stop the World, I Want to Get Off.''   Mr. MacAvoy seems to argue that Congress can and should stop the dramatic advances in technology that have characterized the telecommunications industry in recent years, halt competition made possible by this technology and return to the era of monopoly supply. This argument reflects a misunderstanding of the Senate's purpose in drafting and overwhelmingly passing this legislation.

headline: Technology; Playing Games Electronically
abstract: THE first electronic computer, Eniac, which weighed 30 tons and filled a sizable room, was built during World War II to compute artillery shell trajectories for the Army. Perhaps it is only natural that 35 years later, some of Eniac's descendants, which fit on a table and have such names as Odyssey, are being used to shoot down imaginary enemy spaceships and invading aliens.   Odyssey, of course, is a brand of video game, one of the hot products this Christmas. The computer and the video game, the Eniac and the Odyssey, have evolved side by side.

headline: Careers; A Need for Polymer Experts
abstract: COURSES in polymer chemistry might be a way for many young chemists who graduate in the next few years to win a job in industry. And for chemists with a Ph.D degree, knowledge of polymers may also open the door to a faculty job.   Industry has become concerned -and so have some educators - at the scarcity of polymer studies in colleges and universities. Often when courses in polymers are available, they are offered in engineering school rather than the chemistry department.

headline: FOUR VETERANS DEFEND VISIT TO VIETNAM
abstract: Four American veterans of the Indochina war, back in New York from a six-day visit to Vietnam, defended their trip yesterday against charges that they had served Vietnamese propaganda purposes.   The accusations came at a news conference held by the four veterans to report that they had succeeded in opening channels of communication with Hanoi.   In responding to the charges, Robert O. Muller, executive director of the Vietnam Veterans of America, said they did not feel that they had been ''used by Vietnamese'' to promote contacts with the United States that might lead to diplomatic relations and economic aid.   Mr. Muller, a former Marine paralyzed from the waist down by a bullet wound suffered in fighting in 1969 in what was then South Vietnam, said Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, had promised them that the Vietnamese Government would undertake ''renewed efforts'' to account for Americans listed as missing in action.

headline: W.R. Grace Stake
abstract: Friedrick Flick Industries of Dusseldorf, West Germany, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it now owned 12.9 million shares, or 27 percent, of the common stock of W.R. Grace & Company. Flick, the largest holder of Grace shares, said the total included 447,100 shares acquired between Oct. 30 and Dec. 21 at about $45 a share.

headline: TORIES ATTACK MRS. THATCHER'S ECONOMIC POLICIES
abstract: Just three weeks after shuffling her Cabinet to quell unrest within the Conservative Party, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is facing an even fiercer barrage of attacks from Tory ranks over her economic policies.   Former Prime Minister Edward Heath, a leadi ng Conservative, demanded today that Mrs. Thatcher's austere e conomic program be reversed and all but called on voters to back another candidate if change is not forthcoming.   Other Tory voices are also being raised as the prospect of economic recovery has receded in the wake of sharp increases in interest rates. The increases, to 16 percent from 12 percent, have resulted from efforts to stem the decline of the pound on foreign exchange markets.

headline: VISA'S MOVE WORRIES GERMAN BANKS
abstract: West German banks are regrouping to fend off a wave of American-style credit cards after a marketing coup by the last of the big consumer cards to penetrate this closely guarded market.   Major American credit cards such as Visa and Mastercard have been spreading across Europe in recent years. But German banks have been able to keep such cards out of their domestic market by refusing them sponsors and by throwing their considerable weight behind a powerful competitor - the Eurocheque network.   In August, however, Visa International and the BankAmerica Corporation's West German branch announced an agreement with Bayerische Motoren Werke, the auto maker, to issue Visa credit cards, linked to BankAmerica acounts, through BMW's list of German dealers.

headline: ISRAEL IS CULTIVATING SOME UNLIKELY NEW FRIENDS
abstract: A most unlikely visitor is scheduled to arrive in Israel on Tuesday under the auspieces of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith: the Rev. Bailey E. Smith, president of the Southern Baptist Convention, who said last year that ''God Almighty does not hear the prayer of a Jew.''   The trip, initiated by the Anti-Defamation League with the full endorsement of the Government - Prime Minister Menachem Begin has agreed to meet with Mr. Smith - is the latest and most vivid example of a growing effort by Israel to seek out supporters in unexpected segments of American society. The effort has been intensified as relations with the American Government have deteriorated, as customary liberal support in the United States has fallen away and as the conservative organization Moral Majority has become a political force.   Israel is now giving special attention to cultivating evangelical Christians, many of whom defend the Israeli nation for biblical reasons. Prime Minister Begin has formed a friendly relationship with the Rev. Jerry Falwell, head of Moral Majority. But the tactic has deeply distressed some American Jewish supporters of Israel, who regard the fundamentalist movement as antidemocratic and potentially anti-Semitic.

headline: Marsteller Gains
abstract: Wendy's of Pittsburgh Inc. has named Marsteller Inc.'s Pittsburgh office as its regional advertising agency for 40 Wendy's restaurants in the Pittsburgh and Johnstown/Altoona areas. The account's current billings are about $1 million, and had been handled by Jay Reich Advertising, also in Pittsburgh.

headline: RETAIL SALES UP 0.8% IN NOVEMBER
abstract: Retail sales rebounded a slight but encouraging eight-tenths of 1 percent in November after having dropped sharply in October. The rise apparently resulted from the decline in interest rates last month that encouraged consumers to finance ''big-ticket'' purchases.   The report, from the Commerce Department, gives a ''reason for retailers to be aggressive - there's a spark of life in the consumer,'' said Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist for the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia.

headline: Article 064092 -- No Title
abstract: The Seagram Company Ltd., the big Canadian distilling concern, has borrowed $300 million (in United States currency) from a consortium of Canadian banks to buy back as much as 14.25 percent of its common stock, the Bank of Montreal, one of five banks in the consortium, announced.   Seagram, which had sales last year of $2.5 billion (United States currency), said the loan would be a five-year, unsecured one.

headline: No Headline
abstract: 2 OF AYATOLLAH'S BACKERS SLAIN   BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 23 (AP) - Iran reported today that two supporters of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's regime were assassinated in a grenade attack in the northeastern city of Meshed.   The state-run Teheran radio, monitored here, identified the victims as Mojtaba Ozbaki, a Member of Parliament from Shahr-I-Kourd in central Iran, and Gholamali Jaaffarzadeh, the Governor of Meshed.

headline: SYRIA, IN U.N., URGES SANCTIONS ON ISRAEL
abstract: Syria urged the Security Council today to impose sanctions if Israel refused to revoke its annexation of the Golan Heights.   In response, Israel argued that Syria had harassed Israel from the heights, had refused to accept any boundary between the two nations and had declared it would make no peace with Israel.   The clash opened the Council's debate on a draft resolution that would declare the takeover announced on Monday to be illegal and demand that Israel undo its action in a week. Diplomats generally believe that 14 of the Council's members will support this call, but the United States' attitude is not clear.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELI SEEMS TO RETREAT ON SAUDIS
abstract: An Israeli official who was quoted yesterday as saying that Saudi Arabia had gone ''a little way in our direction'' with certain aspects of its peace plan appeared to repudiate his remarks today.   The remarks by the official, Moshe Arens, who is expected to be Israel's next Ambassador to the United States, differed sharply from the position of Prime Minister Menachem Begin, who has dismissed the entire Saudi proposal as an ''annihilation plan'' for Israel.

headline: ZIEGLER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Israeli Chief to Visit Egypt
abstract: President Yitzhak Navon of Israel will visit Egypt within the next month to pay his condolences on the death of President Anwar el-Sadat.

headline: South Africa Orders Reporter To Leave Country in 14 Days
abstract: The South African Government today ordered an Associated Press correspondent, Cynthia Stevens, to leave the country within 14 days.

headline: UAL Inc. Net Down 53.8%
abstract: United Airlines, the nation's largest airline, said yesterday that it had a loss of $400,000 in the third quarter, although its parent company, UAL Inc., showed a profit of $7.2 million which came primarily from earnings of its hotel business.   The earnings for UAL of $7.2 million, or 24 cents a share, however, were down 53.8 percent in the third quarter from earnings of $15.6 million, or 53 cents a share last year.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Beneficial Corp., Wilmington, Del., announced that George R.  Evans, vice chairman, was retiring, and that David J. Farris had been named president and chief executive officer of the Beneficial Management Corp. subsidiary.   * Bristol-Myers Co. has elected Michael E. Autera, J. Richard Edmondson, Charles A. Heimbold Jr. and Marvin H. Koslow senior vice presidents.   * Blue Bell Inc., Greensboro, N.C., has appointed Michael C. Hand president of its Maverick division.

headline: KEY POLISH FACTORIES STAY CLOSED DESPITE EFFORT TO RESTORE INDUSTRY
abstract: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.   Despite attempts by Poland's military authorities to restore a sense of normality, key factories around Poland remained closed yesterday or were working at far below normal production. It was the first working day after the Christmas holidays.   Workers at the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk, Solidarity's birthplace, were told to remain at home until next Monday. The order, which countermanded an earlier one that they report today, appeared to reflect official concern that had the workers gone back they might again have staged a sit-in at the factory.

headline: French Bank Head Out Over Nationalization
abstract: Pierre L. Moussa, 59, resigned yesterday as chairman of the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas, France's leading private bank, which is known as Paribas, after the French National Assembly voted to nationalize his company and the Compagnie Financiere Indosuez. The Assembly's approval of the nationalization, part of a Government bill for the nationalization of five major industrial companies and most French-owned private banks, came after one of its most acrimonious debates in recent years.

headline: Moran Energy Discovers Gas
abstract: Moran Energy Inc. said it had discovered gas at its Darrington State Farm No. 1-A well in Brazoria County, Tex.

headline: MIDLAND GLASS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Big Publisher
abstract: To the Business Editor: I would like to correct a statement about Nat Wartels in ''Tight Grip on a Rich Empire'' (Oct. 18). I was a Crown employee from September 1978 to August 1980, and during that time saw a lot of Nat and Crown.
