headline: JUDGE RULES BROKERAGE MUST BE LIQUIDATED
abstract: A Federal judge ruled today that a stock brokerage firm where securities worth an estimated total of $36 million were reported missing was insolvent and ordered the company liquidated.   Chief United States District Judge H. Kenneth Wangelin agreed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company, Stix & Company, had a deficit of more than $14 million, and placed the company in permanent receivership.

headline: BRITAIN PLANNING TO END ITS STATE GAS MONOPOLY
abstract: The British Government, announcing expanded plans to reduce the role of state-owned companies in the energy industry, said today that it would end the monopoly of the British Gas Corporation in supplying natural gas.   This decision apparently stemmed from recent difficulties in negotiating a North Sea gas pipeline plan with privately held companies.   In addition, the Government reiterated that it would sell a 51 percent interest in the exploration and production arms of the British National Oil Company, a plan that had appeared stalled.

headline: TURKS TO SEEK DEATH FOR UNIONISTS
abstract: A martial law prosecutor will demand death sentences for 52 leftist union leaders scheduled to go on trial in Istanbul on Dec. 24, it was announced today.   The leaders of the Confederation of Revolutionary Trade Unions will be brought to trial on charges of trying to change the Constitution and establish a proletarian dictatorship, according to sources who have had access to the 865-page indictment.   This will be the first time since the armed forces came to power on Sept. 12, 1980, that a military court has demanded capital punishment for suspects not directly linked to terrorist activities, according to Turkish lawyers.

headline: Newmont Stake
abstract: Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd., which is based in London, said it had raised its stake in the Newmont Mining Corporation to 16.5 percent and now held 4.3 million common shares, including 415,100 shares purchased for $19.1 million between Oct. 23 and Oct. 28.

headline: Ally & Gargano
abstract: Ally & Gargano has been assigned the corporate advertising account of the Bank of New York, the country's 18th largest bank with 191 branches in this state and overseas. The assignment was previously at Doremus & Company. Retail advertising for the bank will continue to be done by Cunningham & Walsh.

headline: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Zimbabwe Leader Honored
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe today became an honorary citizen of Mozambique, the country which was a base for his guerrillas during the war that led to Zimbabwe's independence in April, 1980.

headline: BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BOEING NET OFF 33.8% IN QUARTER
abstract: The Boeing Company reported yesterday a 33.8 percent decline in third-quarter profits, to $92.5 million, or 96 cents a share, from $139.8 million, or $1.45, in the third quarter of 1980. Sales for the quarter were $2.2 million, the same as last year.   Citing reduced aircraft deliveries as a cause of the profits downturn, Boeing said airline industry problems had curbed orders for its 747 and 727 jetliners. It also reported that research and development costs had reduced its earnings.

headline: Crash Kills 11 in Spain
abstract: A train and a truck collided at a rail crossing near this city in northeast Spain today and rescue officials said at least 11 people were killed and 30 injured. All the victims were passengers of the train.

headline: No Headline
abstract: REAGAN APPLAUDS THE AFGHAN GUERRILLAS   WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) - President Reagan praised the ''courageous people of Afghanistan'' today and said that two years after the intervention by Soviet troops, the Afghan resistance movement had ''effectively'' denied the Russians control of most of the southwest-Asian nation.   Mr. Reagan said the Soviet effort to ''establish a puppet government'' had failed and that Soviet control ''extends little beyond the major cities.''   ''Even there,'' Mr. Reagan said, ''the Afghan freedom fighters often hold sway by night and sometimes even by day.'' The written statement, issued by the White House as Mr. Reagan left for California and a weeklong vacation, came two years after Soviet forces entered Afghanistan on Dec. 27, 1979 to support President Babrak Karmal and his pro-Moscow Government.

headline: KEY SUSPECT: MOSLEM GANG OF TERRORISTS
abstract: A small, violent Moslem fundamentalist group has become the main target of the investigation into the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat.   The Egyptian Government has not yet officially said anything about the assassins of Mr. Sadat. Nor has it commented on how many of the men who sprayed a parade reviewing stand with bullets it has in custody. But sources here, both Egyptians and foreign diplomats, said today that a group called Takfir Wahigra, or Repentance and Atonement, was the focus of suspicion so far.

headline: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PEACE CORPS SEEKS A REVIEW OF CUTS
abstract: The Peace Corps, with its modest $105 million budget cut this year to $83.6 million, has appealed to the Administration for reconsideration.   Loret Miller Ruppe, the organization's director, said yesterday in her office just before setting out on a month-long tour of volunteer outposts in North and West Africa, that she had met with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. about the budgetary problem and had found him ''very supportive.''   ''He said what we were doing was right in line with the Administration's foreign policy,'' she said. ''But we haven't heard anything yet about our appeal.''

headline: INVENTOR'S I.B.M. DEAL
abstract: Jerome H. Lemelson, a 58-year-old inventor who last week announced the licensing of a group of his patents for information-handling equipment to the International Business Machines Corporation, believes that ''my persistence'' has been one of his major assets. It was this persistence, he said, that helped him receive more than 350 patents as well as large royalties over the years for inventions in such fields as industrial robots, communications and magnetic recording.   But his deal with I.B.M., which licensed on a nonexclusive basis some 20 patents related to data processing terminals, word processing and similar fields, was one of his biggest accomplishments. ''I first wrote to Thomas Watson Jr., then the chairman of I.B.M., in 1963,'' Mr. Lemelson said. ''Would you believe it? He answered me within a few days. It was a big thrill.''

headline: Berlin Squatters Evicted
abstract: The police evicted squatters from three West Berlin buildings yesterday soon after they were occupied. A police spokesman said today that 186 people were detained for identity checks but that only one person was arrested. Squatters protesting the shortage of housing in West Berlin occupy about 150 vacant buildings here in defiance of owners and city authorities.

headline: Jordan, Case & McGrath Offers Marketing Study
abstract: Did you know that half this country's population is over 55 years of age? About 46 million people? More than all of the kids in grammar and high schools? Well you do now, and it is brought to you courtesy of Jordan, Case & McGrath, whose Norman Goldstein, director of marketing services, supervised the preparation of a six-page brochure on the subject of our crowd entitled, ''The 55+ Market: The Marketing Opportunity of the 1980's.''   The people at the agency, who, surprisingly enough are also quite skilled at advertising acne remedies, are prepared to share their new-found knowledge. A letter will find them at 445 Park Avenue.

headline: Toll in Japan Mine Now 44
abstract: Mine company officials said rescue workers recovered another body today from a coal mine at Yubari in Hokkaido, bringing the number of known dead in the mine disaster to 44.  Fortynine other miners and 10 rescue workers still are trapped and presumed dead, four days after methane gas seeped into the mine.  Officials said there was ''practically no hope'' for them, and rescue workers abandoned their search for more bodies today.

headline: ALLIED'S NUCLEAR WRITE-OFF
abstract: The Allied Corporation has decided to take an $87 million write-off on a partially completed, nuclear-reprocessing plant in Barnwell, S.C. But the company may have to dismantle the plant to qualify for the applicable tax credit, industry sources here suggest.   The facility, begun in 1971, is one of three commercial nuclearreprocessing plants undertaken in the United States. Only one, in West Valley, N.Y., has ever been put into service, and it too is now closed. The other, a General Electric Company unit at Morris, Ill., has never been activated.

headline: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sep
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SSC&B Said to Win Steak & Ale Account
abstract: Reports from the field have it that SSC&B, one of the more active components of the Interpublic Group of Companies, will become the agency for the Steak & Ale Restaurants of America, which the Leo Burnett Company resigned in October to take the McDonald's account.

headline: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TAIWAN JET SALE NEAR APPROVAL, OFFICIALS REPORT
abstract: The Reagan Administration is near to approving the sale of advanced fighter planes to Taiwan, according to officials in the White House, the Defense Department and the State Department.   For the record, a spokesman for the State Department, which is responsible for foreign military sales, said tonight that there had been ''no decision even in principle to sell improved fighter aircraft to Taiwan.''   But Administration officials in three agencies of the executive branch and Republican officials in Congress said planning for the sale was proceeding. They said that the high-powered F-16 fighter had been eliminated and that the two main candidates were an F-5E Tiger with improved electronics and armament and the F-5G Tigershark, a substantially new plane with higher performance. Taiwan now produces the old version of the F-5E.

headline: JAPAN'S BARRIER ON ALUMINUM
abstract: Japan, which has been strongly criticized for its growing exports and big trade surplus with Europe and the United States, would presumably be the last to use barriers against imports from abroad.   But Japan is apparently planning to help its ailing aluminum industry by establishing a program of tariffs that American officials say is protectionist and likely to add further to the United States trade gap with Japan.   ''Japan's timing on this issue is terrible, almost unconscionable,'' Lionel H. Olmer, United States Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said in an interview.   Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, who led a mission to Tokyo, mostly to discuss ways of increasing American imports, said at at a recent news conference that he brought up the aluminum issue at each of his several sessions with top Government representatives.

headline: Panasonic Offers Hand Computer
abstract: Panasonic, the consumer electronics unit of Japan's giant Matsushita Electric Industrial Company Ltd., introduced a hand-held computer that the company said could be packed into a briefcase.   The computer, which is known as an HHC and will be marketed under the name ''The Link,'' was developed by Panasonic and Friends Amis, a San Francisco-based software technology concern.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: 9 Die as Korean Bridge Falls
abstract: Nine workers were killed today when a steel suspension bridge under construction collapsed and they plunged about 100 feet into a chasm on the South Korean resort island of Cheju, the police said.

headline: Steel Company To Modernize
abstract: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, said that it would spend $187 million in the next year and a half on a modernization program in a bid to ''move ahead and be competitive in the world market,'' .   The steelmaker said that it planned to spend $110 million to build a continuous slab caster at its Mingo Junction, Ohio, plant; $19 million to complete waste water treatment plants at its Steubenville and Mingo Junction facilities; $17 million to im-prove air emissions at the same plants, and $40 million to improve operations at its Monessen, Pa., plant.

headline: Canadian Mail Rates To Increase on Jan. 1
abstract: Canadian internal and overseas mail rates will nearly double on Jan. 1, the Government announced today.  A first-class letter will cost 30 cents, against 17 cents at present, while a letter to the United States goes up from 17 cents to 35 cents. It will cost 60 cents to mail a letter to any other foreign country, against 35 cents at present.

headline: Tape Shows Private Side of F.C.C.
abstract: By the time they went behind closed doors last April, members of the Federal Communications Commission were unanimous in their view that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was entitled to a significantly higher profit margin than that approved by an administrative law judge or recommended by its staff, a videotape of that meeting shows.   In fact, two members of the commission, Joseph R. Fogarty and Anne P. Jones, actually wanted to grant the telephone company a rate of return on its investment higher than the 13 percent it had requested.    The commission eventually settled on a 12.75 percent rate of return, with a provision allowing a variation of a quarter of a percentage point - in essence, allowing A.T.& T to earn the 13 percent return it asserted was necessary to raise capital in the equity and debt markets for construction and modernization.

headline: VARIABLE MORTGAGE RATE CUT ON COAST
abstract: The country's two largest savings and loan associations, both in California, said yesterday that they had lowered their mortgage rates to 16 percent.   The new rates at both the Home Savings and Loan Association and the Great Western Savings and Loan Association apply only to variable rate mortgages, which are practically the only home loans the institutions are issuing.   The rate reductions at the two West Coast savings and loan associations continue a trend to somewhat lower mortgage rates that began within the last couple of weeks. Late last week, both Citibank and the Chase Manhattan Bank lowered their mortgage rates by about a percentage point.

headline: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARAFAT WELCOMES SAUDI PROPOSAL FOR 'COEXISTENCE' WITH THE ISRAELIS
abstract: Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said here today that he welcomed the peace plan proposed by Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia because it calls for ''coexistence'' between Israel and the Arabs.   The P.L.O. leader's remarks in an interview published here came amid a resurgence of interest in the Saudi plan, presented last August, which calls for the creation of a Palestinian state and appears to recognize Israel.  But Mr. Arafat again would not say directly that he would acknowledge the existence of Israel.

headline: ISRAEL REJECTS MOSQUE PLAN OPPOSED BY ARABS
abstract: A dispute over an Israeli project to incorporate the ruins of a mosque into a tourist shopping complex here ended this week with the announcement that the proposal was invalid because the land involved was Government-owned.   The announcement was made in Jerusalem on Tuesday by Finance Ministry officials at a meeting of Parliament's Interior Committee that was attended by Moslem and Government figures involved in the dispute.   Protests erupted among Arabs in Israel and abroad after it became known that the Tel Aviv Municipal Planning Committee had approved plans by private Jewish contractors to build a tourist shopping center at the site, which had belonged to the mosque's religious trust. The contractors, headed by Gideon Peres, brother of the Israeli Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres, leased the property six years ago from a local Moslem religious trust committee that has since been ousted.

headline: SSC&B Adds Scannon To Its Mennen Billings
abstract: SSC&B, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is adding to its billings from the Mennen Company.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Aileen Inc. has appointed Robert Siegelin vice president of sales and Judy Smith president of the Redi division for juniors.   * Alexander & Alexander Inc. has named Herbert H. Berkeley executive vice president of its newly created department of strategic business development.   * Biochem International Inc., Milwaukee, has elected to its board Reuben Gutoff, president of Strategy Associates, and James S.  Kennedy Jr., president of the Wilken Investment Co.

headline: Norman Lear Seeks Avco Unit
abstract: Norman Lear Productions, which produces many of television's popular series, said that it and Perenchio, Inc., would purchase the assets of Avco Embassy, a movie production subsidiary of the Avco Corporation, for an undisclosed price.

headline: NEW JERSEY
abstract: Skilled jobs in high-technology industry appear to hold the most promise for development and growth in New Jersey, state economists and personnel experts say. To spur this growth, they say the state would be wise to join with the private sector and colleges in inducing high-technology industry to locate in the Garden State.

headline: GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHINA SEES NO ADDED GRAIN NEED
abstract: With a good harvest in sight, China does not expect to buy any more American grain this year beyond the six million to nine million metric tons already agreed upon for the year, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.   Encouraging the Chinese to purchase more of this year's American crop had been one of the aims of Mr. Block when he arrived Friday for a visit that included talks with China's Agricultural Minister, Lin Hujia, and the Minister of Light Industry, Song Jiwen.   Speaking with reporters before his departure today, Mr. Block said that, ''at each of the meetings with each of the officials that we talked to, I did bring up that we have a large crop in the United States of very high quality at very attractive prices and would encourage the Chinese to look toward additional purchases if they have any needs.'' But he added that the Chinese had said that there was no indication that they would need more than the agreed-upon amount.

headline: Around the World; Turkish Assembly Starts Drafting a Constitution
abstract: Turkey's ruling junta today opened the first meeting of a 160-member consultative assembly that will prepare a new constitution and laws relating to elections and political parties.

headline: Canada Signs Nuclear Pact
abstract: Canada and the European Economic Community have signed a long-term agreement that governs Common Market purchases of nuclear fuel.   The pact, which replaces an interim agreement reached in 1978, sets out terms for reprocessing or enriching uranium sold by Canada to Common Market members and safeguards for storing enriched uranium and plutonium, a statement by the Common Market Commission said.

headline: DOW JUMPS ON HOPE OF RATE DROP
abstract: Stock prices swept sharply higher yesterday in response to forecasts of easing interest rates by a prominent Wall Street economist and a revival of takeover fever in oil issues.   The Dow Jones industrial average, scoring its most spirited advance in seven months, jumped 19.60 points, to 852.55.  Volume surged to 58.6 million shares from Thursday's 40.1 million, marking the heaviest trading since 61.3 million shares were traded on Sept. 28, when the Dow rose more than 18 points.   It added up to what Barry Sahgal, energy analyst for Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., called ''a confluence of favorable events'' for a beleaguered market that, only two days ago, was nearing a 16-month low.

headline: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Yr-to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Newmont Gold Reserves Rise
abstract: The Newmont Mining Corporation, a major producer of copper, gold, silver, oil, coal, cement and lithium, said that three new gold discoveries at properties in Nevada and southern California had raised its total proven reserves of the metal to 7 million ounces from 4.1 million.   Based on the latest price of gold of about $430 an ounce, reserves of 7 million ounces would have a gross market value of more than $3 billion.

headline: Brazil Coffee Crop
abstract: The United States Department of Agriculture said today that its latest estimate puts Brazil's 1982-83 coffee crop at 16 million bags, a sharp decline as a result of the July frost. The preliminary United States estimate of the Brazilian crop following the frost had predicted the crop to be between 15 million and 18 million bags, the department said.

headline: SENATE APPROVES '82 FOREIGN ASSISTANCE BILL, 40-33
abstract: The Senate tonight passed the 1982 Foreign Assistance Bill by a 40-33 vote. The final roll call on the $5.7 billion package came after a 13-hour day of debate during which the Senate voted to link the resumption of military aid to Chile to a Presidential report demonstrating that nation's progress on human rights.   The Senate also voted to separate the Peace Corps from Action and make it an independent agency. The Peace Corps and Vista, a domestic voluntary program, had been combined to form Action in 1971 under the Nixon Administration.

headline: Jack Anderson to Try Another Magazine
abstract: It looks as if The Investigator magazine, which Jack Anderson, the columnist, started in September with three associates, may not be long for this world.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ANALYSTS DIFFER OVER OUTLOOK
abstract: IN describing a bull that is sensed but not seen, Wall Street analysts are sketching outlines of a hoped-for rising market that differ in several important respects.   Most analysts look for a strong advance sometime soon but are urging investors to pick companies that can move upward in the difficult economic environment that is widely foreseen until then.  T hat could me an that Wall Street, optimistic by nature and occupational bias, harbors doubts that a bull market is on the way.   Whether stock prices advance, the clouded economic outlook causes Stefan D. Abrams of Oppenheimer & Company to favor shares of larger, quality companies, a theme that recurred often in a number of interviews.

headline: HIGH HOPES FOR HIGH SCHOOLERS
abstract: DAVID P. dropped out of school a few months before graduation.  "Academic pursuits," a counselor at David's school said, "were just not for him, but he had the best attitude about work I've ever seen in a young person." David worked as a groundskeeper at his high school until he had earned enough to get an apartment in an area of New Jersey where he wanted to live.  He moved and, through persistence, got a job as a plumber's apprentice.   That was three years ago.  Today David earns $15,000 and expects to get his plumber's license in the near future.  With it, he will earn much more.

headline: ARMENIAN LINKED TO SYNAGOGUE RAID
abstract: French investigators have linked an Armenian terrorist who was arrested, released and rear@rested here last week with the bombing of a Paris synagogue in October 1980 in which four persons died.   The police said that a man who calls himself Dimitriu Giorgiu was carrying a false Cypriot passport from the same series as the false passport carried by the suspect in the synagogue blast 13 months ago, and numerically close to it. This is the first known break in the synagogue case since the trail of the suspect was lost last year.   The man in custody here was arrested last Wednesday as he was about to board a plane for Beirut, Lebanon, at Orly Airport. He was taken to police headquarters in central Paris, questioned for 48 hours and then released on Friday. He was rearrested as he tried to board another flight for Beirut on Saturday.

headline: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WASHINGTON SAYS IT IS OPTIMISTIC THAT ACCORD WON'T BE CANCELED
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that despite Prime Minister Menachem Begin's vehement denunciation of the United States, it still hoped that the strategic cooperation agreement with Israel would not be canceled.   ''I'm very optimistic that today's storm clouds will pass,'' Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said when asked about Mr.  Begin's declaration today that the three-week old agreement was now canceled in his eyes as a result of the American decision to suspend further talks on carrying it out.   It was unclear in Washington tonight whether in fact the strategic cooperation accord was legally nullified or not. In his statement, Mr. Begin said that he regarded the American action on the accord ''as its cancellation.'' Harsh Language From Begin   When asked if the State Department regarded the Begin statement as a cancellation, Anita Stockman, a department spokesman, said, ''We are studying the Israeli communique.''

headline: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1981; Markets
abstract: Short-term interest rates fell sharply amid widespread prospects of further drops. In Treasury bill auctions, new three-month and sixmonth issues averaged 10.693 percent and 10.972 percent, respectively. Long-term bond prices rose as yields eased. (Page D1.)   The stock market tumbled amid growing apprehension over the deepening recession. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 10.85 points, to 845.03, its biggest loss since Oct. 14. (D12.) The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies. Gold prices dropped $13.60 an ounce, to $400.20, on the Comex. (D18.) Futures prices fell sharply for metals, corn, soybeans and cotton. (D18.)

headline: Chicago Visa Cost
abstract: First National Bank of Chicago said it would raise its finance charge on Visa accounts to an annual rate of 19.8 percent, from 18 percent, or to 1.85 percent, from 1.5 percent, on a monthly basis. The bank noted that a bill lifting usury ceilings in Illinois was enacted last month and said the high cost of funds and increasing operating expenses had resulted in losses for most bank credit card programs. First National, which has about 1.8 million Visa accounts, said the increase would take effect Dec. 18 in 46 states and next March in Iowa, Texas, New Jersey and Wyoming.

headline: ACF INDUSTRIES ELECTION
abstract: Ivan A. Burns, 46, has been elected president and chief operating officer of ACF Industries, a diversified New York-based company, effective next Tuesday. He will succeed Henry A. Correa, 64, who will become vice chairman.

headline: Patents; New Ejection System For Naval Air Crews
abstract: A vertical ejection system for aircraft crews has been developed by the Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, Calif. Patent 4,303,212 was obtained for the Navy this week by W. James Stone and Ronald G.  Stoutmeyer, project engineers.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OHIO PASSES LAW BLOCKING BID BY MOBIL
abstract: The Ohio Legislature gave final approval today to a bill that would block the Mobil Corporation's $5.1 billion takeover bid for Marathon Oil Corporation.   The Ohio House of Representatives voted by 88 to 1 in favor of legislation already approved by the Senate that would change state antitrust laws to prohibit the takeover of any Ohio company if the acquisition would ''substantially lessen competition in any market for petroleum products'' in the state. Marathon has its headquarters in Findlay, Ohio.

headline: BREZHNEV BIDS REAGAN HELP BAN A NUCLEAR ATTACK
abstract: In a rebuttal to President Reagan's comments on American and Soviet nuclear strategy, Leonid I. Brezhnev today called on Mr. Reagan to join in ''rejecting the very idea of nuclear attack as criminal.''   Mr. Brezhnev's comments were published by Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency, in the form of a reply to a question from Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper. The forum appeared to have been chosen because Mr. Reagan made his comments on Friday in an interview with newspaper editors.   Mr. Reagan, asked whether an exchange of tactical nuclear weapons would inevitably lead to a strategic exchange, said: ''I could see where you could have the exchange of tactical weapons against troops in the field without it bringing either one of the major powers to pushing the button.''

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Avco Financial Services filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a sale of $125 million of zero-coupon junior subordinated notes due in 1990, through a group of underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody.   * Iowa Electric Light and Power is offering $30 million first mortgage bonds, series T, 14 3/4 percent, due in 1991, priced at 99.50, yielding 14.84 percent, to be sold through a Goldman, Sachs group.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Teamster Vote Voided
abstract: An election by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in the nation's largest teamster local has been voided by regional directors, who decided that the members may have avoided voting because ballots were not secret. Ballots for the September election in the 12,000-member Local 748 were numbered and the same number and the member's name appeared on return envelopes.

headline: Comment; WHERE RED INK IS A FALSE ALARM
abstract: P RESIDENT REAGAN'S doomsday prophecies about the budget deficits and the national debt are grossly exaggerated, but they are capable of immense damage to our economy by associated futile policies.   The President, like a participant in a bar debate, looks at our $1 trillion debt and figuratively says: ''Gee, that's a lot of money.'' It is, but it is dwarfed by the $3 trillion gross national product.  We need to put some things into perspective.

headline: SENIOR SOVIET AIDE CALLS REAGAN PLAN A WELCOME CHANGE
abstract: A senior Soviet official said today that President Reagan's proposal for a mutual renunciation of mediumrange missiles in Europe was a welcome change from Mr. Reagan's ''bellicose'' pronouncements in recent months.   However, Vadim V. Zagladin, a member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, implied at a news conference that the Kremlin would give a chilly response to the proposal when negotiations on the missiles open in Geneva on Nov. 30.   Mr. Zagladin, believed to be an influential foreign policy adviser to the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, was the first senior Kremlin figure to comment on the missile plan set forth by Mr. Reagan in a speech at the National Press Club in Washington two days ago.  Mr. Zagladin made his remarks at a news conference where he presented a 74-page booklet on Soviet military doctrine.   And in Washington, the Soviet Embassy released the text of a letter in which Mr. Brezhnev challenged President Reagan's view of Soviet-American relations but urged that they meet because ''private conversation is better.'' (Page 25.)

headline: 470 Fishermen Missing As Hurricane Hits India
abstract: At least 470 fishermen were missing today in a hurricane that lashed the western Indian coast with tidal waves and 90 miles per hour winds, the United News of India reported.   At least 11 boats sank in the Arabian Sea and five trawlers are missing, the news agency said.

headline: STOCKS UP IN SLOWEST '81 SESSION
abstract: Stock prices, holding to a fairly typical pre-Christmas pattern, edged higher yesterday amid the slowest trading of 1981.  Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange plunged to 23.9 million shares from Wednesday's 42.9 million. This marked the lowest volume since 16.1 million shares changed hands last Dec. 26, a Friday session that fell between Christmas Day and the weekend.

headline: The U.N. Today; Oct. 19, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. headline: BONN RELEASED SPY IN '74 BRANDT CASE
abstract: West Germany, in an exchange with East Germany, today released the master spy whose activities led to the 1974 resignation of Willy Brandt as Chancellor.   Gunter Guillaume, a 54-year-old East German Army officer and agent of East Berlin's security service, became a close personal aide of Mr. Brandt in the early 1970's. He was arrested and sentenced to 13 years in prison for treason in 1975.

headline: Inventors Hall of Fame To Induct Four Feb. 7
abstract: Four inventors are to be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame at the Patent and Trademark Office, Arlington, Va., on Feb.  7.   Nominations have been received by Frederick B. Ziesenheim, a Pittsburgh patent attorney who is the president of the National Inventors Hall of Fame Foundation.

headline: UNION BID FOR KAISER
abstract: The United Steelworkers of America announced yesterday that the union had proposed the formation of a nonprofit corporation to acquire all the common stock of the Kaiser Steel Corporation, or at least a controlling interest in the company.   James Dembowski, a representative of Local 2869 of the steelworkers, said in a statement that the proposed company, to be named Kaiser Esop Inc., would set up an employee stock ownership plan to buy out Kaiser's current stockholders at a price yet to be determined and satisfy Kaiser Steel's creditors on terms for the repayment of Kaiser debt.   Kaiser Esop has hired Kelso & Company of San Francisco, a national investment banking firm, to develop the plan and help interest Kaiser Steel's management in it. ''Kaiser's management has expressed a willingness to discuss the plan with its employees,'' said Louis O.  Kelso, chairman of the board of Kelso, in a telephone interview yesterday.

headline: Holiday Trading Curb
abstract: Because of the Veterans Day holiday, there was no trading yesterday in foreign exchange or in Treasury notes, bills and bonds.

headline: SUDAN LEADER CONTENDS LIBYANS HAVE POSTPONED PLAN FOR INVASION
abstract: A senior Sudanese official said today that he believed Libya had postponed plans for an immediate invasion of the Sudan but still harbored designs to bring down President Gaafar al-Nimeiry by force.   The official, Maj. Gen. Omar Mohammed el-Tayeb, who is Second Vice President and Minister for State Security, was speaking in an interview with four Western reporters.   His remarks seemed designed to counter skepticism about the likelihood of an invasion and to keep Western attention focused on the Sudan's sense of vulnerability after the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, a close ally. Nimeiry Predicted Early Move   President Nimeiry used the occasion of Mr. Sadat's funeral in Cairo last week to reiterate that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, planned to attack the Sudan from Chad, where Libyan forces are supporting the Government against an insurgency.

headline: Protesters March in Lisbon
abstract: Hundreds of students marched through Lisbon today demanding the abolition of nuclear arms by both East and West.

headline: GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Partial Close At BL Nearer
abstract: BL Ltd., Britain's ailing state-owned auto maker, came closer to a partial shutdown when its board decided not to submit next year's production program to the Government for approval and additional aid because of a threatened strike.   In a last-ditch attempt to save BL autos - the company's bus and truck divisions are not, so far, affected - both sides were invited for talks with the Government's Arbitration and Conciliation Advisory service.

headline: THE SELLING GETS TOUGHER FOR LIQUID SOAPS
abstract: ''R EJOICE,'' declares the advertisement. What has commerce wrought to inspire this summons to celebrate? ''Rejoice,'' it seems, is the name of the newest liquid soap. ''It's what soap should have been in the first place,'' the advertisement states.   It seems a doubly curious assertion, given the source: the Procter & Gamble Company, manufacturer of Ivory Soap, the best-selling bar of soap in the nation. But last summer, P.&G. joined the ranks of 50 or so manufacturers in offering a liquid soap, packaged in a plastic pump-type dispenser.

headline: PRESIDENT STILL RESISTS TAX RISES
abstract: President Reagan was described today as leaning against making any significant revisions in his economic package, despite continuing advice from some aides and Republicans in Congress that he accept the idea of tax increases to balance the Federal budget.   The President's tentative position appeared to insure two outcomes, White House aides said: a retreat from Mr. Reagan's pledge to balance the budget by 1984, and the prospect that the President would veto Congressional appropriations bills, even some supported by allies on Capitol Hill, as he attempted to cut spending.   In another round of meetings on the economic situation, the President once more struggled with conflicting advice from members of his own Administra-   The economic policy debate has raised doubts within the Administration over whether the economic program can work. Page D2. tion as he prepared for more meetings tomorrow with Republican Congressional leaders at the White House. Some Administration members favor increasing taxes to balance the budget, while others insist that the President should stick to his original program of spending cuts and tax cuts to achieve growth. The second group is not so concerned about a deficit.

headline: MRS. KIRKPATRICK ASKS 40 NATIONS TO EXPLAIN THEIR ANTI-U.S. STAND
abstract: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American delegate, has privately asked 40 nations to explain their support for a document of ''base lies and malicious attacks upon the good name of the United States.''   The letter, addressed to third-world nations that identify themselves as nonaligned, was sent on Oct. 6, Mrs. Kirkpatrick said.  It complained of the ''vicious and erroneous language'' in a communique issued after a meeting Sept. 28 of foreign ministers and delegation heads from 93 third-world nations.   Mrs. Kirkpatrick also says that many of those to whom she wrote have responded favorably. She would not name them, on the ground that it ''would be inappropriate.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: TASS ASSAILS REAGAN'S SANCTIONS AS A RETURN TO THE COLD WAR ERA
abstract: The Soviet press agency Tass accused President Reagan today of attempting ''to hurl the world back to the dark times of the cold war'' with his decision to restrict Soviet-American trade and other contacts because of the Polish military crackdown.   In a report from Washington, Tass contended that Mr. Reagan knew it was futile to adopt ''new acts of blackmail and pressure'' against the Kremlin in an effort to get the Russians to roll back the actions of the Polish military authorities.   The press agency said that the United States Administration was in a ''blind fury'' at the failure of ''counterrevolutionary scum'' in Poland and that Washington's real purpose in ordering the sanctions was to make a final attack on the roots of detente. 'A Campaign of Hatred'   Faced with the collapse of an American plot to restore ''capitalism'' in Poland, Tass said, ''Washington's rulers are in a hurry to whip up to the limit a campaign of hatred in respect of socialist countries, above all the U.S.S.R.''   The press agency said the Reagan Administration wanted ''to undermine the foundations of Soviet-American relations worked out as a result of huge efforts, and to curtail them to a minimum.'' But Tass said the President's ''crude diktat'' to the Kremlin would fail.

headline: OTHER DEVELOPMENTS
abstract: Warsaw mood - Every hour on the hour beginning at 6 A.M., Poles listening to their radios heard Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski speak in solemn tones about having placed the country under martial law. The interludes were filled with music. More cars were on the streets than is usual for a Sunday, particularly in a period of acute gasoline shortage. All telephones had stopped functioning, presumably to keep those who might wish to resist from coordinating actions. Page A17. Washington concern - The Reagan Administration called in the Polish Ambassador and the Soviet Deputy Chief of Mission for discussions. Several allied diplomats were also called to the State Department. President Reagan returned ahead of schedule from a weekend at Camp David to be briefed on Poland by Administation officials. Page A15. Soviet silence - The Soviet Union made no official comment on the declaration of martial law in Poland. The Polish developments were reported in a series of brief and largely factual dispatches by the official news agency Tass. Page A19. Papal appeal - Pope Paul John II asked his fellow Poles to pray for peace and to do everything in their power ''to peacefully build a peaceful future.'' Page A14. German reaction - Chancellor Helmut

headline: U.S. Official Resigning
abstract: Lawrence Connell Jr. is resigning effective Jan. 1 as a member of the National Credit Union Administration to become head of a mutual savings bank in Seattle, the agency announced today. Mr. Connell, who served for two years as chairman of the three-member agency board that oversees the nation's 12,300 federally chartered credit unions, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Washington Mutual Savings Bank, the agency said. Mr. Connell, a lawyer and an economist, was bank commissioner in Connecticut before being named in 1977 by President Carter to be administrator of the agency.

headline: Polish Debt Meeting Set
abstract: Representatives of Poland and its 15 main Western creditors are to meet in Paris on Wednesday and Thursday to discuss the rescheduling of debts falling due in 1982, banking sources said today. Without a revised schedule, Poland would have to come up with $5.7 billion next year to meet its debts.

headline: TOPPS CHEWING GUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 43 STORE CLOSINGS AT A. & P. EXPECTED
abstract: The loss-ridden Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company is reported to be planning another major round of store closings, but its plan to use surplus funds from its pension program to offset the costs has drawn a lawsuit from a former senior company executive.   Trade sources said yesterday that A.& P. is designating an estimated 43 stores, most of them in the New York metropolitan area, for closing by Thanksgiving Day.   An A.& P. spokesman, questioned about the reports, would only say that ''we have made some decisions on selective store closings in the metropolitan area.'' Michael Rourke, vice president for communications and corporate affairs, added that it was likely that those stores would be closed by Thanksgiving Day. He said, however, that he could not identify the locations, except to say that most of the stores were on Long Island and in Queens, Brooklyn and New Jersey.

headline: SAKHAROVS REPORT PROTEST HAS ENDED
abstract: Andrei D. Sakharov sent a telegram to Moscow today telling the young woman on whose behalf he staged a 17-day hunger strike that he and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, were recovering from their fast and were ''happy beyond words'' at the Kremlin's decision to let the young woman emigrate to the United States.   The telegram included a prearranged code that the recipient, Yelizaveta Alekseyeva, said authenticated it as coming from Dr.  Sakharov, the 60-year-old physicist and Nobel Peace Prize winner who is a key figure in the human rights movement here. She said the key words - ''on the evening of the eighth we stopped drinking Borzhomi,'' a local variety of mineral water - had been agreed on before the fast in case the Soviet authorities tried to send false messages in the physicist's name.

headline: MARSH & MCLENNAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Polaroid Expects Drop in Earnings
abstract: The Polaroid Corporation said that its third-quarter earnings are likely to be down sharply from the $13.4 million, or 31 cents a share, that it earned in the second quarter and the $20.6 million, or 63 cents a share, that it earned in the third quarter a year ago.   The strong United States dollar, resulting in foreign earnings shrinkages, weak markets and inflation, has hit earnings, the company said.
