headline: Silhouette Books Names President
abstract: Silhouette Books, a combatant with Harlequin Books in the paperbacks' so-called romance wars, has named John C. Gfeller, 44 years old, as president. The position at the company, part of the Simon & Schuster subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, had been vacant.

headline: Exodus of Jews From Soviet Running at Third of '80 Level
abstract: The Intergovernmental Committee for Migration today reported a continued drop in emigration of Jews from the Soviet Union, expected to be only about a third of the 1980 total by year's end.   The agency said 363 Jews arrived at the Vienna transit center in November, bringing the year's total to a little over 9,000. The Jewish emigration rate has shown a steady decline from 51,000 in 1979 and 29,000 last year.

headline: CHRISTIAN MILITIA IN SOUTH LEBANON CONTINUING TO BESIEGE U.N. BASE
abstract: The Lebanese Christian militia led by Maj.  Saad Haddad kept up its siege around United Nations headquarters in southern Lebanon for the third day today as fresh water at the base began to run low.   The spokesman for the United Nations peacekeeping force, Timur Goksel, said by telephone from the headquarters at Naqura that about 250 civilians who normally commute daily from Israel were trapped inside, along with the 900 United Nations soldiers stationed there.   Major Haddad, whose Israeli-backed forces numbering about 1,500 men control a buffer zone along the Lebanese side of the Israeli border about 5 miles wide and 60 miles long, has demanded guarantees from the United Nations that its peacekeeping troops would prevent Palestinian guerrillas from infiltrating into the border area.

headline: MUBARAK TERMS U.S. RESPONSE ENCOURAGING
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak called the United States response to Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights ''encouraging'' today and said he hoped that ''we can reach reasonable solutions regarding this problem so there will be no further escalation of differences.''   On Friday the Reagan Administration, in reaction to legislation approved by the Israeli Parliament extending Israeli rule to the Golan Heights, suspended its newly signed agreement on strategic cooperation with Israel and froze plans for arms purchases from the Israelis. Israeli officials said that Washington's action called into question United States treaty commitments, including those in the Camp David agreements of 1978.

headline: WALKER-SCOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Arab League Meeting Is Demanded by Syria
abstract: The Government said today that Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights was taking the Middle East to the ''edge of war'' and it called for an emergency session of the Arab League.   A Government statement asked the 21-nation league headquarters in Tunisia to convene a meeting to discuss what it termed Israel's ''grave aggression'' against Syria.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Turkish Leader Goes To Pakistan for Talks   ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 22 (Reuters) - Turkey's head of state, Gen. Kenan Evren, arrived here today on his first foreign trip since coming to power 14 months ago and said he hoped the visit would strengthen bonds between Pakistan and Turkey.   President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq welcomed the Turkish leader in an elaborate ceremony at Islamabad Airport at the start of the six-day visit.

headline: Flemish Liberals Accept Bid to Form Government
abstract: Willy de Clerq, leader of the Flemish Liberals, accepted King Baudouin's request today to form a new Belgian cabinet and said he would try to set up a center-right coalition of Liberals and Social Christians.

headline: Record Cold in England
abstract: England shivered through its coldest night since records started 93 years ago. The lowest temperature was recorded in Shropshire, western England, at 9 below.

headline: AGRA INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: F.H.A. Lowers Ceiling on Rate
abstract: The Government is lowering the interestrate ceiling for another federally insured home loan program, bringing the limit on graduated-payment mortgages into line with other loans for single-family homes.   The change, effective tomorrow, will lower the ceiling to 16 1/2 percent from 17 percent for graduated-payment mortgages guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration, according to a statement Friday by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

headline: Auto Makers Iding 100,000
abstract: The five big American auto makers, with sales at their lowest in 22 years, will lay off nearly 100,000 workers after the first of the year.   The car manufacturers have scheduled production cutbacks for 1982 and are extending the traditional end-of-the-year factory closings into the new year.

headline: TOP POST AT GOTTLIEB FILLED BY A NEWCOMER
abstract: Boyd W. Browne, 51, has joined D. Gottlieb & Company, manufacturer of coin-operated amusement machines with headquarters in Northlake, Ill., as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Robert W. Bloom, 39, who resigned from the Columbia Pictures Industries subsidiary ''to pursue other long-term interests.''

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Berry Industries announced that it had arranged bank lines of credit totaling $12 million with the Bank of America and the Bank of the Southwest.   * Gandalf Technologies said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 2.07 million common shares, to be sold through an Alex Brown & Sons group.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Prime Minister Bulent Ulusu spoke of fostering the atmosphere of understanding, respect and love between Turkey and the United States, while the American Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, reciprocated with words of understanding, friendship and cooperation and promises of more economic and military aid.   Not since the heyday of the Baghdad Pact nearly a quarter of a century ago has there been such a public effusion of warmth and understanding between Washington and Ankara.   Visits by Secretary Weinberger and Secretary of State Alexander M.  Haig Jr. within 10 days this month are widely seen as the makings of a strategic partnership beyond the two countries' membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.   At the close of Secretary Weinberger's talks here Saturday, agreement was announced to set up a Joint Defense Group to enlarge and improve military cooperation between the countries.

headline: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Japan Timber Unit Bankrupt
abstract: A major Japanese timber importing company was declared bankrupt today, another victim of a slowdown in some sectors of the economy that is expected to make 1981 the third-worst year on record for business failures in Japan.   The timber company, Shin Asahigawa, had $302 million in debts, making its failure the second-biggest corporate bankruptcy this year after that of Osaka Shoken Shinyo, a securities financing concern that had debts of $462 million.

headline: ANTWERP GEM DEALERS TRY TO RECOVER FROM BLAST
abstract: ''It will be business as usual when we reopen next Monday, that's for sure,'' said Jaak Nutkewitz, president of the Diamond Bourse, the largest of the four diamond exchanges near the central station that make Antwerp the hub of the world's diamond trade.   Downstairs, workmen were fitting new sheets of bulletproof glass into the windows of the trading room, blown out Tuesday by the parcel bomb that went off outside a neighboring synagogue, killing 3 and injuring nearly 100.   In small groups escorted by the police, diamond dealers, mostly Orthodox Jews in long coats, were picking their way back to their offices to see what remained and to gather up the millions of dollars worth of diamonds they abandonded when they fled.   ''I know the business is dominated by Jews and they look conspicuous to visitors because of their ringlets, their hats and beards,'' Mr. Nutkewitz said, ''but the people here are quite used to them. They belong here. They are part of Antwerp folklore.''

headline: First Penn Sets Shift From Foreign Lending
abstract: The First Pennsylvania Bank, the cornerstone holding of the financially troubled First Pennsylvania Corporation, said today that it would move away from foreign lending activity over the next five years in favor of providing international banking services for corporations.   The new five-year strategy, outlined in a news conference today, recognizes that foreign direct lending has become an increasingly risky area in recent years, said George A. Butler, the bank's chairman and president.   The main thrust of the bank's new strategy will be to generate income from such services as exchanges of currency and by providing letters of credit abroad and handling the deposits of regional companies doing substantial business abroad, he said.

headline: CHRISTMAS SALES TOP PREDICTIONS
abstract: Christmas retail business, the most important of the year for the nation's stores, is winding up better than expected. But sharp price discounting has held down profits, which normally swell in the outburst of seasonal buying.   A spot-check of stores in 10 major cities this week showed an erratic pattern, with high volume in some cities and low volume in others.   The shift from the earlier lagging pace to the traditional climactic surge of year-end buying across the country - a surge that seems to come later each year - was spurred by additional rounds of price-cutting and heavy store promotions. But customers continued to be very selective.

headline: IS RAELI ATTACKS SAUDIS' LEADERS AS FOES OF JEWS
abstract: The Israeli Government accused Saudi Arabia yesterday of ''a fanatic hatred of Jews and Israel,'' of keeping the Palestine Liberation Organization alive with oil money, of pressuring countries to break relations with Israel and of supporting a scheme to dismember the country.   The attack came in a speech to the Foreign Policy Association at the Hilton Hotel by Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir. He did not directly mention the proposed United States sale of Awacs Excerpts from speech, page A10. radar surveillance aircraft to the Saudis but devoted virtually all of his 2,000-word address to a bitter assault on the Saudis as a ''major obstacle'' to a Middle East peace.

headline: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SSC&B Wins; Homelite
abstract: SSC&B, a subsidiary of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has become the first ad agency to be assigned both the Homelite and Jacobsen product lines by the Homelite division of Textron. And the promotion budget for the coming year, according to the company, is $11 million, more than $4 million of which will be for media advertising.

headline: S.P.C.C. in Deal With RCA Astro
abstract: The Southern Pacific Communications Company has contracted with RCA Astro-Electronics for construction of three satellites, including one devoted to video transmissions for cable and broadcast markets.

headline: Japan to Discuss Plane With Boeing
abstract: Japanese aerospace officials plan to travel to Seattle next week to discuss a possible joint venture with the Boeing Company for development of a 150-seat aircraft, Boeing officials said.   A recent Tokyo newspaper report said that Japan had selected Boeing as a partner in the $1 billion plane development project.

headline: SIBERIANS FIGHTING TO PRESERVE LAKE
abstract: To the Buryat Mongols who lived around Lake Baikal before the Russians came, the lake was home to Burkhan, an angry and jealous god to be treated with deference and care. So great was their respect for his kingdom that they apologized to a tree before chopping it down.   According to legend, when Burkhan's daughter Angara eloped to marry Yenisei, the furious god threw a huge rock that stands to this day at the outlet of the Angara River, which flows from Lake Baikal to the Yenisei River.   The stories were recounted recently by Valentina I. Galkina, with little to suggest that the ancient legends had lost their power. Mrs. Galkina and her husband have spent their lifetimes studying and protecting Burkhan's world at the Limnological Institute here near the point where the Angara leaves Lake Baikal.

headline: TECHNOLOGY
abstract: BOTH the telephone system and cable television are vying to provide electronic home information services that will allow consumers to read news reports on their television screens or to shop or bank at home. Now, in a new twist, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is trying to interest cable companies in a joint venture that would use both sets of wires.   Dennis Sullivan, assistant vice president for product management and development at A.T.& T., said that he had discussed such a possibility in both public forums and private meetings with cable companies. While the phone company is not actively negotiating with any cable companies now, Mr. Sullivan said he hopes that negotiations will start and that such a system will be operating ''within a year.''

headline: DU PONT AND SEAGRAM REACH DIRECTOR ACCORD
abstract: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the Seagram Company, which were intense rivals in the bidding war for Conoco Inc. last summer, said yesterday that they had signed an agreement whereby the chairman of each company will become a director of the other.   In a joint announcement, the companies also said that Seagram, which now holds 20 percent of Du Pont's common stock, will not exceed a 25 percent stake in the voting stock of the nation's largest chemical company and that Du Pont will have the right of first refusal if Seagram wants to sell its holdings.   Seagram aquired its stake in Du Pont after that company beat out Seagram for the control of Conoco, which was formally merged with Du Pont last week.

headline: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 21 Killed, 60 Wounded In North Lebanon Unrest
abstract: Lebanon's continuing wave of violence spread today to the northern part of the country, where a bombing and a raid by gunmen left 21 people dead and 60 wounded.   Ten people lost their lives in a car bomb explosion during the afternoon rush hour in the northern port of Tripoli.

headline: BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Record Maruzen Loss
abstract: The Maruzen Oil Company posted a loss of 73.8 billion yen ($327 million) in the first half of its fiscal year, ended Sept. 30, the largest six-month loss ever reported by a company listed on Japan's stock exchanges. The refiner, which relies heavily on relatively higher-priced non-Saudi Arabian crude oil, had a 23.7 billion yen loss in the year ended last March.

headline: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A NEW BONUS: COMPANY AID ON RETIREMENT
abstract: T HROUGHOUT the country, large corporations and smaller businesses are thinking less about what kind of gold watch to give their prospective retirees and more about what kind of preretirement program to offer them. Rough estimates are that 500 companies now have some kind of retirement program, ranging from one-hour meetings with a local bank officer to several days of carefully structured seminars.   ''I think this trend will grow, what we're doing now,'' said Joan Showalter, CBS vice president for personnel, referring to her company's Pre-Retirement Education Program (PREP). ''I think out there 10 years from now it will be the rare major corporation that doesn't have something like this. It's a responsible step for industry.''

headline: COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ENERGY WATCH
abstract: CRUDE OIL INVENTORIES Crude oil stocks dropped to 362.9 million barrels, down 7 million.

headline: GROWTH BRINGS PAIN TO DRESDNER BANK
abstract: Behind the aging squat sandstone building housing Dresdner Bank's executive offices stands a new 32-story glass-andaluminum office building, neatly reflecting the bank's recent explosive growth.   Dresdner, West Germany's second-largest bank, after Deutsche Bank, christened the building last year with a big public relations campaign aimed at local critics who said the expansion marred Frankfurt's traditional architectural unity.   Though the bank rejects the esthetic criticism, its executives would probably agree these days that financially, at least, growth can have its drawbacks. First Time Since War   Indeed, last year Dresdner cut its dividend for the first time since World War II as earnings shrank under the impact of high lending rates, a sluggish economy, mounting risks in countries such as Poland and the cost of bailing out ailing industrial customers such as AEG-Telefunken, the tottering electrical giant.

headline: DIETRICH RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: About Real Estate; MANAGEMENT OF CITY-HELD PROPERTIES
abstract: New York City's Department of Housing Preservation and Development is saddled with an immense stock of residential property that has fallen into its hands through tax foreclosure.   Much of the property is managed by the department itself. But an increasing amount is managed by assorted entities under the department's Division of Alternate Management.   There are various alternate management programs, and this year two of them were merged - the Community Management Program and the Management in Partnership Program.

headline: Jet Production Altered at Lear
abstract: Plans for an acceleration in the production schedules of two types of executive aircraft produced by the Gates Learjet Corporation have been postponed because of lagging orders, a company spokesman said.

headline: MEXICANS GO ALL OUT FOR TALKS IN CANCUN
abstract: Decorators are still sprucing up the Cancun airport and the hot lines to capitals as far apart as Abidjan and Peking have yet to be tested, but preparations for next week's conference of industrialized and developing nations are now virtually complete.   Already, security agents with walkie-talkies outnumber tourists in swimsuits and, by the time President Reagan and other world leaders gather here next Wednesday, this normally soporific resort will have been taken over by 1,500 foreign delegates and over 2,000 journalists.   A narrow 14-mile-long island sprinkled with luxurious hotels that attend only to the affluent, Cancun seems an unlikely setting for a conference on world poverty. But it offers the informality, seclusion and security thought necessary to encourage some breakthrough in years of fruitless negotiations.

headline: K Mart Offers New Security
abstract: The K Mart Corporation and Merrill Lynch yesterday introduced a new kind of debt security that would allow the retailer to raise funds by selling its leases to 25 stores in 12 states.   The securities are called Merrill Lynch Corporate Pass-Through Certificates, First K Mart series, and $80 million of them were offered yesterday at a price of 100 with a 15 3/4 percent coupon.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Pan American World Airways said it had sold its tax benefits on McDonnell Douglas DC-10-30 aircraft for about $12.5 million to an unnamed buyer.   * Warner Amex Cable Communications said it had been awarded the cable television franchise for the community of Jackson Township, Ohio, near Canton, and will begin construction of a 35-channel system to provide cable communications services for about 10,000 homes.  Warner Amex is a joint venture of Warner Communications Inc. and the American Express Company.

headline: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: American Fletcher Plans Dual Presidency
abstract: At the American Fletcher Corporation, the largest bank holding company in Indiana, two presidents will take office on Jan.1, 1982.  Larry J. Hannah, 39, will become president of the $2.8 billion corporation and Joseph D. Barnette Jr., 42, will become president of the 60-plus branch Indianapolis bank.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Circle K Corp. said it intended to purchase up to $3 million of common stock of Nucorp Energy Inc. on the open market but that changing market conditions had resulted in the cancellation of an agreement to purchase 150,000 shares of Nucorp stock at $20 a share.   * Control Data Corp. has received a two-year contract valued at $5 million to supply its model 9409T flexible disk drives to Altos Computer Sytems of San Jose, Calif.   * General Signal Corp.'s Cardion Electronics division has received a $13.7 million Air Force contract for a new generation of aircraft navigational equipment.

headline: President Is Elected At AMF Inc.
abstract: William P. Sovey, 48, has been elected president and chief operating officer of AMF Inc., effective next March 1. He will succeed Ray A. Tritten, who will retire, at the age of 63, from the diversified company, which is based in White Plains.

headline: MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Debt Securities Little Changed
abstract: Prices of corporate and tax-exempt debt securities were firm but little changed in very light trading yesterday, dealers said.  ''It really was not much of a trading day,'' one analyst said, ''since many potential buyers were on vacation and nobody wants to trade actively without some feedback from the government securities market.''

headline: MEESE WARNS ANEW ON SALVADOR ARMS
abstract: Edwin Meese 3d, the President's counselor, reinforced the Administration's warnings on Central America today by asserting that President Reagan has not ruled out a blockade or other strong actions aimed at halting the flow of arms into El Salvador.   The stern tenor of his remarks to reporters, added to a developing series of public statements and other moves concerning possible action in the Caribbean region, made it clear he was siding with the assertive posture taken by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  over the more cautious posture of the Defense Department.   Although Mr. Meese said that President Reagan had ruled out sending American ground troops into Nicaragua or other countries, he denied any inconsistency between that position and Mr. Haig's new warnings about Cuban activities. And he challenged a reporter's suggestion that the Administration's sharp statements might make it ''look like a paper tiger'' if there were not a forceful follow-up.

headline: QUASAR MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Market Place; Life Insurance For Investors
abstract: THE New York Stock Exchange is informing member firms of an improved life insurance plan for investors. Unlike a year-old plan limiting coverage to a mere $15,000, the new one offers unlimited coverage.   Moreover, the burden of administering the plan is shifted from the broker to the insurer. The new plan, like the old one, is underwritten by the Federal Home Life Insurance Company of Battle Creek, Mich.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Brunswick Corp. and G.D. Searle & Co. announced a joint agreement for Brunswick to purchase Searle's Dover Urological Products division in a cash transaction. Terms were not disclosed.   * Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. said that the Federal Reserve Board had approved its proposed acquisition of Alliance Corp.    * Grumman Aerospace Corp. was awarded a $71.3 million Air Force contract for an experimental aircraft in a forward-swept-wing flight program.

headline: Sambo's Closings In 8 States
abstract: Sambo's Restaurants Inc., confirming earlier reports, said that it had closed down some of its outlets in eight states in a ''store-by-store evaluation'' to weed out unprofitable operations.

headline: NOVEMBER ECONOMIC INDEX OFF 0.3%
abstract: The Government index intended to forecast broad economic trends fell three-tenths of 1 percent in November, a significantly smaller decline than in preceding months, the Commerce Department reported today.   The figure, though not a major surprise, was somewhat better than many economists had expected and was taken as evidence that the recession is approaching its bottom.   ''Things are getting less worse,'' commented Edward H. Boss, vice president of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, which, like many others, has predicted that an upturn in business activity will take effect some time in the second quarter of 1982.   The Reagan Administration also seemed somewhat cheered by today's report. ''The modest decline in the leading indicators for November, following much steeper setbacks in the previous two months, indicates that the business downturn may be slowing,'' Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige commented.

headline: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: energywatch
abstract: OCT. 9, 1981 Crude oil supplies surged to 375.5 million barrels, as refining output dipped and imports increased.

headline: CBS AND BELL PLAN VIDEO-TEXT TEST
abstract: CBS Inc. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that they would jointly test a home information system with consumers in Ridgewood, N.J., beginning next autumn.   The companies, which said in September that they were planning a marketing test of so-called video-text technology, said the trial would involve 200 Ridgewood households and be conducted in two threemonth phases starting next September. Consumers will participate for free.   Video-text systems permit two-way communication between consumers and data bases of information stored in computers. In the Ridgewood experiment, households will be able to select from a variety of continually updated news, weather, sports, education and entertainment material culled from the broadcast and publications units of CBS. Furthermore, the test is expected to permit consumers to bank and shop electronically. Local and national advertising will also be displayed.

headline: Business Conditions; HOW COLLEGE PAYS
abstract: In order to get a job in today's market, it helps to hit the books. According to a recent survey by the Labor Department, the American worker is better educated than ever before.   Paced by the movement of the ''baby boom'' generation into the work force, and aided by the trend toward earlier retirement among older workers, the Labor Department found in March that 40 percent of the labor force aged 25 to 64 had completed a year or more of college. As recently as 1970, only 23 percent of such workers had reached a similar academic level. In 1981, the Labor Department said, more than 32 million working Americans, or 41 percent of the labor force, had graduated from high school, up from 38 percent in 1970.

headline: XEROX PROFIT DOWN 2.7% ON 1.9% REVENUE GAIN
abstract: The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday that third-quarter profits fell 2.7 percent compared with last year's third quarter, a drop it attributed largely to unfavorable currency translation.   The copier and office equipment company said its net income for the quarter was $149.6 million, or $1.77 a share, down from $153.8 million, or $1.82 a share, in the third quarter of 1980. Revenues rose 1.9 percent, to $2.12 billion from $2.08 billion.

headline: FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP 4.8 MILLION SHARES
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose by 4.8 million shares, to 78.9 million, in the month ended Nov.  13.

headline: 9 MORE SENATORS SUPPORT PRESIDENT ON SALE OF AWACS
abstract: Eight Senators who previously took no position on the sale of Awacs planes and other air combat equipment to Saudi Arabia said today that they would support the sale. Another Senator, an opponent, switched to Mr. Reagan's side.   The day's developments raised the strong possibility that the President might win when the Senate votes on the $8.5 billion sale tomorrow at 5 P.M.   The Senators will vote on a resolution of disapproval aimed at preventing the President from carrying out the sale of five Airborne Warning and Control System aircraft, air-to-air fighter plane missiles and other equipment. The House has previously passed such a resolution. 'Changed My Mind,' Jepsen Says   One of the most surprising developments of the day, especially to his former comrades in the group opposing the sale, was the announcement by Senator Roger W. Jepsen, Republican of Iowa, that, after months in the role of a leader of the anti-sale group, he would now vote to support the President.

headline: Sohio Buys Coal From U.S. Steel
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of Ohio announced that they have completed the sale of 700 million tons of the steel concern's coal reserves to the oil company for about $600 million.

headline: Esmark Earnings Up
abstract: Esmark Inc. today reported record net earnings from continuing operations for the fiscal year of $99.6 million, or $7.49 a share, up from $54.3 million, or $1.90 a share, last year. In the fourth quarter, Esmark said, net income from continuing operations was $27.4 million, or $2.10 a share, up from $16 million, or 63 cents a share, on revenue of $849.9 million, up from $758.9 million.

headline: French-Soviet Trade Talks
abstract: As French trade officials prepared for talks aimed at reducing France's growing trade deficit with the Soviet Union, the French External Relations Ministry said it would not seek Western advice about a $300 million computer deal with the Russians.   A communique issued Friday said Minister of External Trade Michel Jobert would seek ''to come to grips with the possibility of balancing trade exchanges between the two countries'' during the regular meeting of the French-Soviet Economic Cooperation Commission, which begins Monday.

headline: Other Business; AIRLINES: GOODBYE TO THE FREEBIES
abstract: Soaring fuel costs, no-frills competitors, cost-conscious customers, deregulation, controllers' strike - some days it hardly seems worth it to run an airline. The day of the promotional freebee, therefore, is over.   Gone is the free steak dinner and all the champagne you could drink if you take a Delta Airlines flight from New York to Miami. Gone is the free fifth of Jack Daniels from a Texas International flight from Dallas/Fort Worth to Atlanta. And just this month, United Airlines pulled the rug out from under a really old standard - the free hotel room and meals if a plane is grounded for meteorological or mechanical reasons. This, it is feared, may set a trend. ''The other airlines are just watching to see if we could get away with it,'' said Charles Novak, a United spokesman.

headline: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EVEN FOR TEXANS, THE BASSES ARE RICH
abstract: AMONG oil rich Texans, almost none have a lower profile than the Bass family of Fort Worth, itself a quiet, folksy city of 385,000 some 30 miles west of Dallas. The Basses themselves are unknown even to most Texans, although they are probably among the five or 10 wealthiest families in the United States.   Several prominent Texas businessmen interviewed said that they doubted that the Basses were as big as the Hunts of Dallas. But both are so big - with each clan's total worth easily more than $1 billion - that neither family really knows how wealthy it is. But a former executive with Morgan Stanley, the investment banking firm, offered one indication of the Basses' wealth: ''We looked at their operations a while back,'' he said, ''and they were so well-heeled it was hard to find anything we could do for them.''   ''They are very, very quiet, and very, very powerful,'' added the former Morgan officer, who asked not to be identified.  The extremely private clan, which shuns the press and refuses all interviews, came to national attention last month, when it was disclosed that the family was the second-largest shareholder of Marathon Oil with 5.1 percent of the stock, after another Texas investor, Sedco Inc., which has 7.7 percent.

headline: Dow Advances 5.23; Defense Issues Gain
abstract: The stock market, buoyed by strength in the defense and high-technology issues, posted a moderate advance yesterday in accelerated trading.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, closed up 5.23 points, to 875.76. For the week, the blue-chip barometer lost 10.75 points because of early declines attributed to investors' concern over the deepening recession and the crisis in Poland.   Yesterday, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declining stocks by almost a 9-to-5 ratio. Turnover on the Big Board rose to 50.9 million shares from 47.2 million shares on Thursday.

headline: Jersey Bond Yields at Records
abstract: A new issue of New Jersey bonds, rated triple-A, was offered yesterday with record yields peaking at 12.7 percent for bonds due in 2000-01.   At a time when most long-term interest rates have increased sharply, New Jersey had the misfortune to be the third issuer of high-grade state bonds in a week. The supply of triple-A state bonds helped push yields higher just as the upcoming supply of Treasury notes and bonds has led to higher yields in that market.   With yields ranging from 9 percent for bonds due in 1982 to 12.7 percent for those due 2000-01, investors in the New Jersey issue were offered returns that were a quarter to one percentage point higher than similarly rated Illinois bonds sold a week ago.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Separate Bomb Threats Force Halt of Trading
abstract: Trading on the Chicago Board of Trade and the Phildelphia Stock Exchange was halted at midsession yesterday after anonymous callers said bombs had been placed in the buildings.   Hundreds of employees at both exchanges were evacuated while bomb squads searched the buildings but officials said later that nothing was found in either city.

headline: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 1,000 Stage Ottawa Protest On Arrest of Polish Unionists
abstract: About 1,000 demonstrators marched outside the Canadian Parliament and the Polish and Soviet Embassies here today to protest the imposition of martial law in Poland and the arrest of the leaders of the Solidarity union movement.   They burned a Soviet flag outside the Soviet Embassy, but the police refused to let them enter the building with a coffin that they said represented the death of Polish freedom, witnesses said.

headline: Argentina Gets Loan
abstract: The Bank of America said today that 77 international banks had signed a seven-year, $600 million loan agreement with Argentina.

headline: Real Estate; SoHo Loft For Use as Galleries
abstract: EDUARD NAKHAMKIN came from Russia with more love than money six years ago. An important object of his love was contemporary Russian painting, a taste he cultivated during a five-month stopover in Rome. Rome is a center of expatriate artists from the Soviet Union.   Unlikely as it may seem for a former mathematics professor at the polytechnical institute of Riga who barely spoke English at first, Mr. Nakhamkin (pronounced nuh-HAHM-kin) opened an art gallery specializing in contemporary Russian painting at 50 East 53d Street in 1976, using a $2,000 security deposit for the rented space.

headline: No Headline
abstract: President Reagan authorized the donation of $30 million worth of food staples to Poland today to help ease shortages. The grant brings total food aid over the last year to $820 million.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MILLER, HENRY S, REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: About Real Estate; NEW TACK ON HOUSING AID FOR THE POOR
abstract: The Reagan Administration is starting to disclose its ideas on housing assistance for lower-income families amid fears that years of effort to make Federal subsidies work successfully against neighborhood blight may be unraveling.   That is not the intent, nor will it be the effect, said Philip D.  Winn, the Assistant Secretary for Housing in the Department of Housing and Urban Development, who was here this week to address the New York Society of Security Analysts. He described the ''truly poor'' as H.U.D.'s ''clients.'' Other clients are first-time home buyers, he said.

headline: POLAND'S NEW LEADER PLEDGES LOYALTY TO BREZHNEV
abstract: The Soviet press gave front-page display today to assurances from the new Polish party leader that Poles considered the defense of Communism and of the Soviet alliance their ''highest duty.''   In a message thanking Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, for his telegram of congratulations, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski also expressed gratitude for the Soviet Union's ''constant assistance and understanding of the unusually difficult problems faced by our country.''   Mr. Brezhnev, in his message last week, called on General Jaruzelski to use his ''great prestige'' to rally Polish Communists against ''counterrevolution,'' a term commonly used for the activities of the Solidarity union.

headline: ACCOUNTANTS FIND GOVERNMENT FAVOR
abstract: The nation's accountants, blamed by Federal officials for some of the corporate scandals of the 1970's, are enjoying better days.   Pressure for Federal regulation has waned. The Securities and Exchange Commission has shredded its letters warning of the importance of auditor independence from the companies they audit.  And, perhaps most surprising, certified public accountants now occupy powerful positions in Washington.

headline: Texaco to Halt Its Gasohol Sales
abstract: Texaco Inc., the nation's largest gasohol dealer, said it would stop selling gasohol at most of its service stations because of flagging motorist interest and high costs.  Texaco has been the oil industry's most vocal advocate of the alcohol-and-gasoline mixture and has marketed it at 1,600 stations in 19 states.

headline: THE AFGHAN WARRIORS: MANY OUTLOOKS, ONE CAUSE
abstract: Photographs of the turbaned guerrilla fighters of Afghanistan have been widely seen in the last two years and in general they reflect images of fierce, even fanatical men who are willing to make heavy sacrifices and may even be eager for martyrdom as they fight the Soviet soldiers and struggle against alien beliefs.    Like all stereotypes these portraits have an element of truth. But six weeks spent in the field in Afghanistan with a number of guerrilla groups refined this general impression to a number of very different personalities. They shared in the fight but they had different motives, different passions and different dreams. All endured rigors. Many were brave. Some were frightened. Some of the frightened were brave.

headline: G.& W. to Buy Burlington Unit
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries has signed a letter of intent to buy Burlington Industries' hosiery and sock divisions for an undisclosed price, the companies said.

headline: GIBSON-HOMANS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: McDonnell Douglas Up
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, builder of fighter aircraft, announced net income for the third quarter of $51.7 million, or $1.30 a share. The comparable figures for the third quarter last year, reduced by a write-off of $32 million related to the DC-9 program, were $11.7 million, or 30 cents a share. Sales advanced 20 percent, to $1.8 billion, from $1.5 billion.

headline: Nissan Predicts U.S. Sales Rise
abstract: Officials of Nissan Motors U.S.A.  predicted that the company's sales in the 1982 model year would improve to 500,000 cars and 130,000 trucks, equal to its record 1980 performance.

headline: New Nation Seeks U.N. Seat
abstract: Antigua and Barbuda, which gained its independence from Britain yesterday, applied for membership in the United Nations today. It would become the 157th member.

headline: ATLAS VAN LINES INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PRICE NEWS, 15 3/4% PRIME SEND STOCKS UP BY 18.45
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average surged 18.45 points yesterday, to 870.24, against a backdrop of falling interest rates and rising hopes for improvement on the inflation front next year.   The prime rate was at its lowest level in a year as more than a dozen of the nation's leading banks cut the basic lending charge to 16 percent, while Chase Manhattan went to 15 3/4 percent. (Page D11.)    The busy session marked a dramatic turnabout in sentiment for a stock market that had moved in a narrow channel for more than two weeks, as investors fretted about an economic downturn and lower corporate profits.

headline: A World to Feed 11th article of a series ap-; pearing periodically.
abstract: The two farmers faced real dangers on opposite sides of the war that turned Rhodesia into Zimbabwe. Both have now had a piece of the first big postwar harvest, which has made this the only black-ruled country in Africa that has to worry about overproduction of food. Yet, although they are separated by only 25 miles and a range of hills, the two farmers - Nichodamas Manomano and Hermanus Conradie Jr. - exist in different worlds. One of these worlds knows bumper crops as a matter of course; the other still shares in the crisis of rural Africa, where population pressure and ruinous cultivation practices are part of a cycle that ends in malnutrition and the depletion of the soil itself.   Although Zimbabwe may rank as black Africa's major example of a country with a food surplus, it is too soon to say that it has found a way to unlock the productive potential of Africa's farmers. Of the 76 million bushels of corn that will eventually find its way to market from Zimbabwe's farms this year, 67 million were grown by only 4,000 white commercial farmers.

headline: THOMAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Olin Earnings Up 46.2%
abstract: The Olin Corporation said today that gains on chemical and brass operations enabled it to earn 74 cents a share in the third quarter, up from 51 cents a year ago. Net income was $17.7 million on sales of $489.9 million, compared with $12.2 million a year ago on sales of $432.1 million, an increase of 46.2 percent. For nine months, Olin earned $79.1 million, or $3.29 a share, on sales of $1.56 billion, compared with $61.4 million, or $2.56 a share, a year ago on sales of $1.4 billion.

headline: U.S. SEEKS SCHLITZ MERGER BAN
abstract: In the Reagan Administration's first comment on a major corporate merger, the Justice Department announced today that it would oppose the $494 million acquisition of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company by the G. Heileman Brewing Company as a violation of antitrust law.   The combination of the two Wisconsin-based companies would be challenged on the ground that it would substantially lessen competition, asserted William F. Baxter, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the department's antitrust division. He said that if the two companies pursued the transaction, his department will file a civil antitrust suit seeking to block it.

headline: SIGNAL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PEKING IS RE-EXAMINING ROLE OF THE ARTS
abstract: A writer whose filmscript touched off an ideological debate this year over the Communist Party's relationship to post-Maoist Chinese literature, has publicly apologized for the ''flaws'' in his work and thanked his critics for having pointed them out.   The self-criticism by the writer, Bai Hua, which evoked the kind of servility demanded of intellectuals under Mao Zedong, first appeared on Dec. 23 in The Liberation Army Daily, the military newspaper that launched the attack against him last spring.   The newspaper assailed him because Mr. Bai was serving in a cultural unit of the People's Liberation Army based in Wuhan. The military newspaper is not available to foreigners, but Mr. Bai's apology was published in full on Dec. 24 in the party newspaper, The People's Daily, which once implicitly defended him.

headline: BAD NEWS AT THE FINANCIAL TIMES
abstract: LONDON L ESS than a month ago, the Financial Times, perhaps best known for its distinctive salmon-pink paper, closed World Business Weekly, an American offshoot introduced on a shoestring in 1978 that had nonetheless piled up losses estimated in the millions.   It was the latest reversal for a publishing company that once seemed to do most things right. A European edition, printed in Frankfurt and still undergoing editorial metamorphosis after nearly three years, is struggling to pay its way. And the newspaper itself, still more widely read in British corporate circles than any competitor, has slipped into the red for the first time since 1945.   Last year, the Financial Times Group posted a loss of $320,000 before taxes and interest income. With aggressive belt-tightening, the group might move back into the black this year, but the results are not expected to approach the $5.5 million earned in 1979 before taxes, a level more typical of the company's performance.

headline: Prudential Unit Sold to Jardine
abstract: The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell the insurance business of its Bache Group Inc. subsidiary to Jardine Matheson & Company.   Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: VW to Raise Prices
abstract: Prices for Volkswagen of America's 1982 vehicles will be an average of 3.4 percent higher than prices for comparable 1981 models, the auto maker said. The increases of $250 per vehicle, reflect ''rising costs of materials, production and distribution'' as well as upgraded equipment on some models, VW said. Base prices for the 1982 models include $5,99 0 for the Rabbit, $6,775for the VW pi ckup, $8,375 for the two-door Jetta and $11,360 for the Vanagan L. Th e 1982 vehicles are to be introduced late this month.

headline: U.S. Bond Prices Move Lower; 6-Month Bills Up to 11.838%
abstract: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds declined slightly - and yields inched upward - in quiet trading early yesterday. Prices then dropped further late in the day after the Treasury announced plans to raise $5 billion of cash through sales of new seven- and 20-year issues.   Interest rates also increased for outstanding securities in the short-term market even though participants in that sector said they were not troubled by the supply of new issues that is haunting the note and bond markets. The Treasury's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills resulted in average rates of 11.037 percent and 11.838 percent, respectively. Last week, the three-month bill sold at an average rate of 11.10 percent and the six-month bill sold at 11.60 percent.

headline: Bonn Is Acting On Budget Gap
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt met today with Helmut Kohl, the opposition leader, for the first time in more than six months to seek support enabling his Government to pass legislation needed for its 1982 budget.   The package Mr. Schmidt proposed was hammered out in more than 12 hours of stubborn debate yesterday in an agreement that means essentially the Government will keep a larger share of central bank profits, raise unemployment payments and make further Government spending cuts to offset an expected $3.4 billion shortfall in next year's budget.

headline: Satellite Contract
abstract: The Western Union Corporation said it had awarded Arianespace, a French-based consortium of European space companies and agencies, a $22 million contract to launch Westar 6, Western Union's sixth domestic communications satellite. The company said the satellite, being built by the Hughes Aircraft Company, would be available for launching by Arianespace from Kourou, French Guiana, in December 1983.

headline: Stocks Gain; Dow Adds 1.90
abstract: Stock prices edged higher yesterday after two sessions of spectacular gains in response to falling interest rates.  After showing small losses earlier, the Dow Jones industrial average finished at 868.72, up 1.90 points. Its combined advance on Friday and Monday came to nearly 34 points.

headline: ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Loss at Schlitz
abstract: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, the nation's fourth-largest brewer, reported a loss in the third quarter of $36.1 million, attributed mainly to the $43.2 million cost of closing a Milwaukee brewery.

headline: U.S. Rejects Silver Bids
abstract: For the third consecutive week, the General Services Administration today rejected all bids for silver at its seventh weekly auction of the metal from the National Defense Stockpile.   The agency will again offer for sale 1.25 million ounces of silver from the stockpile at its next auction on Wednesday, Dec. 9.

headline: First Texas Savings Appoints Chairman
abstract: J. Michael Cornwall, the 46-year-old chief executive officer of the First Texas Savings Association, has been appointed chairman of the $2 billion Dallas-based savings and loan association. Robin R.  Glackin, 36, will succeed him as president of the company, a subsidiary of the Beneficial Corporation with more than 70 offices in 40 Texas cities.   The changes will follow the retirement tomorrow of Roger J. Keane as chairman at the age of 64 after 27 years with the corporation.  Mr. Cornwall said that among his new duties he will work closely with the First Texas real estate operation, a common practice among Texas savings and loan associations, whereby they develop properties for sale to residential builders.

headline: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 13
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PARKS SAUSAGES IS BACK FOR MORE
abstract: H.G. PARKS INC. was one of those companies whose renown stretched far beyond its relatively small size. Its more-Parks-sausages commercials were one reason. Another was its uncommon place among American corporations. It was black-owned and black-run, one of the biggest such companies in the country. Parks, however, became one of the thousands of companies in recent years that were devoured by conglomerates; and its conglomerate owner in turn was devoured by another conglomerate. And in 1980 for the first time, Parks lost money.   Today, Parks, a manufacturer many meat products besides sausage, is back on its own. It is being run by managers who were there when the company was taken over and were there to retrieve it when the conglomerates had had enough. And once again, a year since its liberation, sales are rising and Parks is making money. Raymond V.  Haysbert Sr., chief executive, and other Parks associates purchased the business from a division of Canadian Pacific that had acquired the Norin Corporation, the conglomerate that had initially acquired Parks.   From its beginning in 1951, when the founder, Henry G. Parks Jr., had but two helpers, the company grew until, with sales of $13.6 million in 1976, it stood seventh among the top 100 black-owned businesses as compiled by Black Enterprise magazine.

headline: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NOBEL PEACE AWARD GOES TO U.N. AGENCY FOR ITS REFUGEE WORK
abstract: The 1981 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded today to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for aiding the growing numbers of homeless and displaced people around the world.   The organization was described by the Norwegian Nobel Committee, which chooses the Peace Prize recipient, as having done major work, in spite of substantial political difficulties, in dealing with ''a veritable flood of human catastrophe and suffering, both physical and psychological.'' And in dealing with strained relations between nations that are affected, the award statement said, the agency served the interests of peace.   The committee spoke of the ''tremendous and increasing number of refugees'' in the world, mentioning those who had left their homes in Afghanistan, Ethiopia and Vietnam but not referring to the causes of their flight. It estimated that there are between 14 million and 18 million refugees in the world.

headline: GOLDMAN, SACHS BUYS BIG COMMODITY DEALER
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Company, one of the world's leading investment banking houses, said yesterday that it had acquired J. Aron & Company, the nation's biggest supplier of green coffee beans to roasters and a major factor in the international precious and base metals trade.   Officers of Goldman, Sachs and J. Aron, both private partnerships, declined to put a dollar value on the merger. However, industry sources said the price was slightly more than $100 million. The capital of Goldman, Sachs, $239 million as of last June 30, makes it the largest financial institution operating as a partnership. The industry sources estimated the revenues of J. Aron at more than $1 billion last year.

headline: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Budget director David A. Stockman is embroiled in a major controversy. In an interview in the December issue of The Atlantic Monthly, Mr. Stockman said he had never had much faith in the Reagan Administration's economic theories and projections. The admission was called ''devastating'' by Democrats and caused anger and dismay among senior White House aides. But the aides said Mr. Stockman was too valuable to be dismissed. A spokesman for Mr. Stockman did not disavow the quotations but said that Mr. Stockman thought his remarks were off the record. (Page A1.)   Corporations intent on reducing their tax bills are rushing to meet tomorrow's deadline for completing special tax deals on leasing.  Under the new tax law, companies with certain tax benefits they cannot use may, in effect, sell them to profitable companies that can use them to reduce taxes. Overall, experts estimate, the arrangements could cost the Treasury billions of dollars in lost revenues. (D1.)

headline: No Headline
abstract: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN SPEECH ON U.S. POLICY TOWARD DEVELOPING NATIONS   PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (AP) - Following are excerpts from a speech by President Reagan prepared for delivery today to the World Affairs Council of Philadelphia:   PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (AP) - Following are excerpts from a speech by President Reagan prepared for delivery today to the World Affairs Council of Philadelphia:   I will be traveling next week to Cancun, Mexico, to participate in a summit that will bring together leaders of two-thirds of the world's population.   The subject of our talks will be the relationships among developed and developing nations and specifically, I hope, how we can work together to strengthen the world economy and promote greater economic growth and prosperity for all our peoples.   We will take with us sound and constructive ideas designed to help spark a cooperative strategy for global growth to benefit both developed and developing nations.   Such a strategy rests upon three solid pillars: First, an understanding of the real meaning of development, based on our own historical experience and that of other successful countries.   Second, a demonstrated record of achievement in promoting growth and development throughout the world, both through our bilateral economic relations, and through cooperation with our partners in the specialized international institutions, such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Kaiser Aluminum Closing 4th Line
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the nation's third-largest aluminum producer, announced today that it was shutting the last of four aluminum-producing lines at its Ravenswood faclity in West Virginia.   The Oakland-based company said that the shutdown was the result of an inability to reach agreement with its employees on proposed changes in work practices and seniority provisions.

headline: DESPITE KILLINGS, IRANIAN SEES A 'KIND OF STABILITY'
abstract: Despite waves of assassinations and executions, Iran's revolution has achieved a ''kind of stability,'' according to the country's Foreign Minister.   The revolution enjoys ''the mass support of the people'' and ''has been changing their mentality, culture and value systems,'' the Minister, Mir Hussein Moussavi, said. ''Stability in the political system of our revolution has a different meaning than in the West.''   Mr. Moussavi, in New York for the United Nations General Assembly, spoke this week at the vacant residence of Iran's United Nations mission chief, a mansion at 1033 Fifth Avenue. An Iranian official said it was the first time in months that a high-ranking Government official had been interviewed by a Western correspondent.

headline: NORTHWESTERN SECURITY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TAIWAN SAYS IT WILL NEVER NEGOTIATE WITH CHINA
abstract: President Chiang Ching-kuo said todaythat Taiwan w ould never negotiate with the Chinese Communists.  Mr. Chiang made the remarks at a Central Standing Committee meetingof the ruling Kuomintang.  It was the first top-level affirmation of Taiwan's longstanding policy since Peking began its reunification drive last week and the first public statement from the President on the offer to share powerwith the Nati onalists in ruling a reunified nation.   According to the text of Mr. Chiang's speech, he said: ''To talk peace with the Chinese Communists is to invite death. This is an agonizing, bloodstained lesson that we and many other Asian countries have learned.''

headline: EXCERPTS FROM TALK WITH EGYPT'S PRESIDENT
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview today with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt:   Q. Is there a conspiracy ?  A. The investigation didn't finish but I could give just a very brief idea. Some extremists here, some fanatics, maybe Moslem fanatics with their principles far away from Islam, these people are just trying to imitate something like what happened in Iran. Our position here in Egypt differs completely from Iran. The character of the people, our nature differs completely from Iran. They planned to assassinate the President, maybe the whole leadership, at the celebration of the sixth of October and then to declare something like the so-called Islamic revolution. But they couldnt fulfill such a plan. Who it is - better to wait until the investigation is finished.   Q. Do you think President Sadat went too far in his crackdown on opponents in September?  A. Not at all. Not at all. If he didn't do it it would have been much more serious the day of the assassination. It is true that some of those arrested on the fifth of September were partners in this act.

headline: Market Place; Major Stocks: Some Off 40%
abstract: BEAR markets are insensitive to value. Good stocks slide, along with the not-so-good. Dramatic casualties are often found among secondary companies, and even the shares of quality companies that are temporarily off stride are frequently hard hit.   Generally the stock market is down about 20 percent as measured by the Standard & Poor's index of 400 industrial stocks. A new computer screening by Oppenheimer & Company has disclosed 76 important stocks that are at least 40 percent below their peak.

headline: PRODUCTS RESEARCH & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. CALLS ISRAELI MOVE A PERIL TO CAMP DAVID
abstract: The Reagan Administration today opposed Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights as inconsistent with the Camp David peace accords.   Both White House and State Department officials said the United States had been given no warning by Prime Minister Menachem Begin that he would sponsor legislation declaring that Israel has permanent jurisdiction over the land captured from Syria in 1967.   The initial White House criticism, delivered this morning by Larry Speakes, the deputy press secretary, was based on news reports received in Washington shortly before Israel's Parliament approved the measure, 63 to 21.

headline: MOBIL SHORT OF GOAL ON MARATHON
abstract: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had been tendered only 38 percent of the Marathon Oil Company's stock - well short of its goal. In the absence of an increase in Mobil's $5.1 billion takeover proposal, Marathon shares slid in value on the New York Stock Exchange.   Mobil is seeking at least 50 percent, or 30 million shares, of Marathon's 60 million shares outstanding, at $85 a share. It said, however, that only 23 million shares had been tendered since its takeover proposal was announced on Oct. 30. Most of the stock was thought to have been tendered before the United States Steel Corporation entered the bidding last Thursday with an offer for Marathon currently valued at an average price of $103 a share.

headline: Canada Bank Rate Falls
abstract: The Bank of Canada's closely watched bank rate declined today by 1.49 percent, to 16.13 percent, its lowest level in 11 months. The central bank rate -the benchmark in determining the rate chartered banks charge their most creditworthy customers - fell to 17.62 percent last week. This week's decline extended a steady drop since August, when the rate peaked at a record 21.24 percent.

headline: CHANGES AT TEXASGULF
abstract: Now that France's state-controlled oil company, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, is the owner of about 65 percent of Texasgulf Inc., the American company has merged its minerals exploration division with the Elf Aquitaine Mining Corporation in the United States to form the Texasgulf Minerals Exploration Company.   Kenneth J. Kutz, a 54-year-old vice president of Texasgulf, will be president of the new exploration company. George W. Mannard, 49, who had headed the minerals exploration division of Texasgulf as a vice president, will go to the Canadian Development Corporation, which has in turn acquired Texasgulf's Canadian operations. He will become president of a subsidiary there to be called Kidd Creek Mines Ltd.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Walter V. Shipley, 46 years old, has been named president of the Chemical Bank, the nation's seventh largest, effective Jan.1. Mr.  Shipley, who has been senior executive vice president in charge of Chemical's wholesale banking activities worldwide, will succeed Norborne Berkeley Jr., 59.   Donald C. Platten, 63, will remain as chairman and chief executive officer, a position he has held since 1973.  According to industry analysts, Mr. Shipley is now heir apparent to Mr. Platten, who is scheduled to retire in October 1983. Although Mr. Shipley had been widely viewed as the likely successor, surprise was expressed at the bank's speed in appointing a member of the next generation of senior management to the post.

headline: St. Regis Paper
abstract: The St. Regis Paper Company will close its Kraft mill for two weeks on Dec. 17, affecting 570 hourly wage employees, company officials said. The shutdown, the second at the mill in recent weeks, was attributed to a slowdown in demand for paper products, The mill makes heavy Kraft paper for paper bags and cardboard-box liners.

headline: ISRAEL TELLS JAPAN IT REGRETS ARAFAT WILL VISIT
abstract: In an unusual diplomatic move, Israel publicly expressed regret today through its Ambassador here that Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, had been invited to visit Tokyo next week and ''will be received by political leaders.''   ''We regret very much that a terrorist leader such as Arafat was invited to Japan,'' Ambassador Amnon Ben-Yohanan said at a news conference.   Mr. Arafat is due to arrive here next Monday with a party of about 20 people.  Technically, the invitation to him came from an unofficial group, the League for Japan-Palestine Friendship, which has about 100 supporters in Japan's Parliament, according to Japanese diplomats.  But the Japanese press termed the invitation official in all but name. Japanese diplomats reportedly worked quietly for the invitation for several years.

headline: ROAN CONSOLIDATED MINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Do Nothingism
abstract: To the Business Editor: In ''When Nothing Works, Do Nothing'' (Sept. 27), Mr. MacAvoy ends with a testimonial from ''a distinguished French civil servant'' who resignedly concludes that ''Reagan economics is right because all else seems to be wrong.''   It is more accurate to say that most economic policies of the American administrations since World War II, with the exception of the brief period when President Carter tried to persuade Americans to conserve and reduce waste, have been wrong, but that Mr. Reagan's innovations are patently even more harmful because they will aggravate all the factors that cause progressively higher prices, interest rates and unemployment.

headline: 2 AUTHORS REVIVE DISPUTE OVER PEARL HARBOR
abstract: Forty years after the Japanese air attack on Pearl Harbor, on Dec.  7, 1941, writers and researchers are still arguing over whether Washington had advance knowledge of that Sunday morning attack, which plunged the United States into World War II.   ''At Dawn We Slept,'' by the historian Gordon W. Prange, to be published posthumously later this month by McGraw-Hill, argues that neither the evidence nor common sense justifies any other conclusion than the one reached in nine official investigations between Dec. 11, 1941, and July 15, 1946. That conclusion is that the Administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt did not know in advance about the attack, which left more than 2,300 Americans dead and many warships and planes destroyed or damaged.   But two other books due to appear soon argue the opposite.  John Toland, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1971 for ''The Rising Sun,'' a book about the war in the Pacific, asserts in ''Infamy,'' which Doubleday is to publish in March, that well before the Japanese attack, Washington knew that Japanese carriers were heading for Pearl Harbor. This is a shift from Mr. Toland's view in ''The Rising Sun,'' in which he expressed doubt that Roosevelt knew that the Japanese were coming.

headline: Pemex-Britain Oil Pact Set
abstract: Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, Mexico's state oil monopoly, said today that it has signed two contracts to export 70,000 barrels a day of oil to Britain until the end of the ye ar.   A statement issued here said the contracts for the first Mexican oil exports to Britain were signed in London by Julio Moctezuma Cid, Pemex head, with Shell International and British Petroleum.

Grosso has been named executive vice president, operations, and a director of Ingalls Associates.  * Wayne Gastman has been named a senior vice president at J. Richard Smith Advertising, Old Bethpage, L.I.

headline: Patents; A Computer to Help Motorists Navigate
abstract: A computer patented this week is designed to guide a motorist without the need of maps or travel instructions. Daniel J. Turco, owner of several retail stores in Billerica, Mass., was granted patent 4,301,506 for the ''router.''
