headline: Around the World; Gaza City Begins Strike Over Tax on Doctors
abstract: Gaza City began a second two-day commercial strike today in support of doctors who refuse to pay the Israeli Government a 12 percent tax on their income.

headline: COOPER-JARRETT FILES IN BANKRUPTCY COURT
abstract: Trucking deregulation and two recessions have finally taken their toll on Cooper-Jarrett Inc., a small New Jersey-based trucking company.   Cooper-Jarrett, which has lost money in each of the last four years, filed for protection yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company's officers cited deregulation and a weakened economy as the main reasons for its inablity to stay profitable.   The increase in the number of truckers brought about by deregulation in 1980 came just when tonnage for the trucking industry was declining because of a recession, said William Hanlon, vice president and general counsel.

headline: Bomb Hits Salvador Bridge
abstract: A bomb destroyed a bridge today on a main road linking El Salvador's capital with provincial towns, th police said. No one was injured.

headline: TITLES SWITCH AT CLABIR
abstract: The chairman and the president of the Clabir Corporation, a holding company for two operating companies, have changed titles.  Henry D. Clarke Jr., 47, who had been president, will become chairman, while Ralph R.M. Ehrmann, 56, who had been chairman, will become president. Mr. Clarke, however, continues as chief executive officer.

headline: SAGE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Amin Aide Goes on Trial
abstract: Bob Astles, a British-born former aide of the ousted Ugandan dictator Idi Amin, pleaded not guilty at the start of his murder trial in Kampala today. Mr. Astles, who amassed considerable wealth and power during Mr. Amin's brutal rule, is charged with murdering a fisherman, Henry Musisi, near Lake Victoria in an antismuggling operation four years ago.

headline: UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Ulster Policeman Wounded by Car Bomb
abstract: Irish guerrillas kept up their attacks on the British province's security forces today, critically wounding a policeman with a bomb that they placed in his car.   The bomb destroyed the police reservist's car in Banbridge, 25 miles southwest of Belfast.  Three people were killed and one injured this week in attacks by the Irish Republican Army.

headline: Economic Analysis
abstract: For the second time in two years, a recession has become the cutting edge in the battle to reduce inflation and interest rates. It is a painful medicine, and it comes with no promise of lasting recovery.   The Carter Administration, inadvertently or not, induced the 1980 recession with its controls on credit. And the Reagan Administration, although it did not prescribe it, now has the recession of 1981. It is expected to be a broader, longer and generally more severe downturn than in 1980, if only because of the Federal Reserve Board's tight monetary policy, which the Administration has endorsed.

headline: GULF UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Key Oppenheimer Aide
abstract: Oppenheimer & Company, the Wall Street partnership, owns and operates a brokerage firm and two money-management companies as well as a variety of companies in other industries. Now the investment house has named Lester Pollack, 48, as a partner to direct a key aspect of the organization's investment banking activities.

headline: TRUDEAU OFFERS COMPROMISE ON CONSTITUTION
abstract: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has offered what he calls a substantial compromise on his proposals for a new constitution for Canada, and he has proposed a meeting with the 10 provincial premiers on Tuesday for a final attempt to reach a consensus.   The offer, the details of which were not disclosed, was made last night in a meeting with Premier William Bennett of British Columbia.  Mr. Bennett represented eight provinces that have been fighting Mr.  Trudeau's constitutional proposals for more than a year because of the restrictions on provincial powers that they would entail.   Mr. Bennett said today that a decision would be made by his group in Ottawa on Monday. It appeared, however, that the answer would be no.

headline: Power System Bonds Delayed
abstract: A $150 million plan to suspend development of two nuclear powers plants ran into another snag when the Washington Public Power Supply System was forced to postpone preparations for a $200 million bond sale to build three other power plants.   Bond underwriters on Friday advised the power system to wait until problems with the suspension plan were resolved before going to the bond market for construction money for the other plants, said Nick Cain, the power system's executive board chairman.

headline: ELECTRONICS EXPERTS HAVE SYSTEM WIRED
abstract: A YOUNG electronics engineer looking for a job in the San Francisco Bay area might be offered a host of unusual inducements. While still in school he might be provided with lucrative summer jobs by companies hoping to lure him back when he graduates. Upon graduation he might be given a bonus to sign with a company, or stock options, profit-sharing plans, sabbaticals and other fringe benefits.   Once at his new job, he can expect flexible hours and loose dress codes, use of the company jogging track and Friday afternoon beer busts at the company swimming pool. And offers to work for the company across the street.   Almost anything goes in recruitment in ''Silicon Valley,'' the area south of San Francisco that is the heartland of the nation's electronics industry. While not all jobs in electronics are that glamorous or lucrative, the recruiting practices attest to the fact that technical talent, which is crucial to success in an innovationoriented industry like electronics, is in short supply.

headline: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
abstract: A United States Government delegation began talks in Moscow today on the sale of millions of tons of grain to the Soviet Union, now facing its third poor harvest in a row.   The seven-man team, headed by Agriculture Department Under Secretary Seeley Lodwick, met Soviet negotiators at the Foreign Trade Ministry for what are expected to be two days of hard bargaining.

headline: SPANISH GOVERNING PARTY DEFEATED IN VOTE FOR A REGIONAL LEGISLATURE
abstract: A small right-wing party has inflicted a stunning defeat on both the Government party and the opposition Socialists in Spain's first elections since the attempted military coup of last February.   In voting yesterday for a regional parliament in Galicia, in the northwest, the right-wing Popular Alliance led by former Interior Minister Manuel Fraga Iribarne won 26 of the legislature's 71 seats.   Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo's center-right Government party, which has dominated the region's politics for five years, took only 24 seats. The Socialists, who had expected major advances, were limited to 17 seats, and small regionalist groups gained 4. The Communist Party was shut out.

headline: Oil Refining Is Sluggish
abstract: Domestic refineries operated at only two-thirds total capacity in the week ending Oct. 2, matching last April's two-and-a-half-year low point caused by sluggish demand and a growing oil glut, the Government reported.   The Energy Department, in its weekly petroleum status report, said American refineries operated at 66.2 percent of capacity on average daily crude oil inputs of 12.3 million barrels.

headline: FIRST COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Svensk Exportkredit, a Swedish export group, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of $100 million of 10-year notes.   * Commercial Credit Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of $100 million of notes due Dec. 1, 1985.

headline: RCA SATELLITE SALE AT SOTHEBY
abstract: In a hushed Sotheby Park Bernet auction hall, as tense cable television executives signaled with paddles, a sale of communications satellite facilities for their booming industry brought $90.1 million in winning bids yesterday.   The high total, a record for a Sotheby auction, reflected keen competition for use of the facilities, which are to be carried by an RCA satellite to be launched on Jan. 12.   Auctioned off, at Sotheby's York Avenue galleries, were seven-year leases for seven devices called transponders, which are used for relaying signals from the earth's surface back down to earth and, indirectly, to television screens and other recipients. Demand for transponders is intense, largely because cable television programming has been proliferating.

headline: ALCAN, ARMCO DECLINE
abstract: The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest steel producer, reported an earnings turnabout yesterday, saying that it had a $92.7 million profit in the third quarter, in contrast to a loss of $14.5 million for the comparable 1980 quarter.   The company attributed the increase to improvements in operating performance and increased steel demand. Nevertheless, it said, the industry is experiencing a slowdown attributable to high interest rates, a consequent reduction of steel inventories by steel users and rising steel imports.

headline: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Posts Change At Texas Air
abstract: Texas International Airlines Inc. reported late yesterday that Robert J. Carney, 41 years old, the company's chairman, had assumed the additional responsibilities of president from Harry T. Chandis, 47.   Texas International said Mr. Chandis ''has resigned to pursue other business interests.'' The Houston-based Texas International, a regional airline operating a route system of more than 25,000 miles and serving about 40 cities in the United States and Mexico, would not comment further on the reasons for Mr. Chandis's departure, nor could he be reached for comment.

headline: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: United Technologies, Apple, Natomas Gain
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that net income in the third quarter rose 14.8 percent on a sales increase of 11.6 percent.   The Hartford-based concern said that net income in the latest three months increased to $112.5 million, or $1.83 a share, from $98 million, or $1.81 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues advanced to $3.26 billion, from $2.92 billion.   ''The earnings were in line with our estimates,'' said Alan Benasuli, who follows United Technologies for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

headline: Chris-Craft Takeover
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the assumption of majority control of United Television Inc. by Chris-Craft Industries, giving Chris-Craft the maximum number of VHF telelvision stations - five - that a company may own. The F.C.C. said yesterday that it had approved the transfer of United Television and its three stations - KTVX-TV in Salt Lake City, KMOL-TV in San Antonio, Tex., and KMSP-TV in Minneapolis -from the stockholders of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation.

headline: VIDEO RECORDER SALES GO ON
abstract: Retailers of video cassette recorders said yesterday that they expected little immediate impact on sales from Monday's court ruling that taping television programs violated copyright laws.   ''We are going to continue with business as usual,'' said James L.  Vandeberg, corporate secretary of Carter Hawley Hale Stores in Los Angeles, one of the defendants in the suit and owner of such retail chains as Neiman-Marcus, Broadway and Wanamaker. ''There's nothing in the court decision that says we have to stop selling them.''   A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals in San Francisco ruled Monday that users of videotape machines, their manufacturers, retailers and advertising agencies that promote them could be sued for damages if the machines are used to tape copyrighted material off the air, even for home use. The suit was filed by MCA Inc. (owner of Universal City Studios) and Walt Disney Productions against the Sony Corporation, which makes video cassette recorders, as well as four retailers, Sony's ad agency and one owner of a video cassette machine.

headline: Interpublic Group Has 1.6% Drop in Net
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies released yesterday their thirdquarter financial results, showing a 1.6 percent decline in net income, to $2.19 million, or 47 cents a share, from $2.2 million, or 50 cents, last year.

headline: SPACE FOR FASHION INDUSTRY BEING CREATED ON 7TH AVE.
abstract: Despite its reputation as the fashion center of the world, the area of Seventh Avenue between Penn Station and Times Square is practically bereft of first-class apparel showrooms, having only two buildings offering such space.   So said Bruce Berger, president of Bruce Berger Realty, the other day. Mr. Berger was recounting how he and two overseas partners have set about correcting that lack.   Mr. Berger is a principal in Fashion Atrium Associates, the concern renovating the 15-story building at 485 Seventh Avenue, at the intersection of 36th Street, into a 200,000-square-foot industry showroom center. It is called The Fashion Atrium. Renovation of the structure was begun in mid-1980. The building is expected to be ready for occupancy at the end of next summer.

headline: Economic Scene; Urgent Search For a New Mix
abstract: THE onset of a recession, which the Reagan Administration now expects to be severe, has focused national attention on the need for a new mix of economic policies that will check and reverse the slump without causing inflation and interest rates to soar again once the current recession ends. The American economy has been on a roller coaster. This is the second recession in two years, and if interest rates go shooting up again when the current slump ends, there could be a third recession close behind.   Although it has been partly obscured by the fog of technical concepts and jargon, a conflict exists between the Administration and the Federal Reserve Board over how monetary policy should be conducted. Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Fed, regards bringing down the rate of inflation as his top priority, and has been telling both the Administration and the public that he does not intend to relax restrictive monetary policy. He told a group of real estate brokers in Florida earlier this week that ''we can't effectively deal with your problems by pumping up the money supply.'' Even if this were to produce short-term relief, he said, it would only aggravate problems for the longer run.

headline: Talking Business with Westergaard of Equity Research; Selecting New Growth Stocks
abstract: Emerging growth companies, especially those involved in high technology, are increasingly attracting the attention of those buyers of stocks willing to invest time as well as money. The leading tracker of these often dynamic issues is John Westergaard, editor and publisher of the Equity Research Associates investment service.   Mr. Westergaard, also president of Equity Research Associates Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company., has had an enviable record over the last few years in picking emerging growth stocks that will improve over the long term. Mr. Westergaard, in most cases, advises investors to hold onto his recommendations for at least two or three years in order to realize their full potential growth. Here, Mr. Westergaard assays the special equity sector as 1982 approaches.

headline: Oil Data Delayed
abstract: The weekly American Petroleum Institute figures do not appear today because of a Christmas holiday delay. The figures will appear in tomorrow's paper.

headline: Other Business; AT MORGAN STANLEY, BANKERS WEAR BEEPERS
abstract: It isn't just doctors and repairmen who wear them now. Beepers, those one-way paging devices that beckon their bearers from golf courses and meetings, are showing up on the pinstriped suits of Wall Street.   Morgan Stanley, for example, has provided beepers to the more than 60 professionals in its mergers and acquisitions department for the last couple of years. According to other firms, the devices had a role in the takeovers of Texasgulf and Conoco.

headline: EATON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REDUCED FARES IN LONDON REJECTED BY LORDS
abstract: A committee of the House of Lords, in a decision with wide political repercussions, today overturned the Greater London Council's program of subsidized fares for the city's buses and subways.   The Law Lords, who are roughly comparable to the United States Supreme Court, ruled that the council had acted improperly two months ago when it cut the fares by an average of 25 percent, making up the deficit by sharp increases in real estate taxes, or rates as they are known here.   Ken Livingstone, the left-wing Socialist who is the leader of the council, called the ruling ''devastating,'' and predicted that some fares might now have to be increased by 100 percent or more. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher welcomed the ruling, saying that the council's fare cut had been ''in breach of their duty to ratepayers, and wrong in law.''

headline: Oil Data Delayed
abstract: Because of a delay in gathering statistics, the weekly American Petroleum Institute figures do not appear today. The figures are expected to appear tomorrow.

headline: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THE BIG APPLE SHOWS SOME BRUISED SPOTS
abstract: I F one word could describe the situation in New York City's work force, that word would be mixed. For the first half of the year, employment in the city declined while it went up in the nation as a whole - the first time that has happened in two years.  But though the job market has been bleak for semi-skilled bluecollar workers, it has been quite the opposite for the skilled, educated, white-collar worker.   ''Historically, New York has had an exploited underclass,'' said George Sternlieb, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University. ''Now it has a redundant underclass. There's no role for them.''

headline: M-G-M Suing Transamerica
abstract: The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company has accused the Transamerica Corporation of fraud and deception in the $380 million sale of Transamerica's United Artists unit to M-G-M earlier this year.   In a suit filed in Superior Court yesterday, M-G-M asked for $100 million in damages, saying that Transamerica unfairly withheld payments to it for certain tax credits belonging to United Artists.

headline: PESTICIDES ARE ENDANGERING WILDLIFE IN AN AFRICAN VALLEY
abstract: When David Livingstone and others passed this way a century ago, through the heat-seared valley of the Zambezi River, malaria-carrying mosquitoes infected them with often-fatal fevers and tsetse flies killed their animals.   These days, mankind has learned to combat the insects that decimated the early explorers, but the chemicals used are threatening the wildlife that proliferated here in the 19th century.   Ecologists draw a parallel between the decline in the bald eagle before DDT was banned in the United States in 1972 and similar perils facing the majestic fish eagle as a result of the pesticide being used for crop-spraying and insect control in the Zambezi basin area.   Here, on the Zimbabwe-Zambia border, the Zambezi swirls below an iron girder bridge that marks the frontier. Crocodiles and hippopotamuses abound in its waters, and fish eagles, two and a half feet long with six-foot wing spans, issue haunting mocking calls from treetop aeries.

headline: U.S. ADDING TROOPS TO WAR GAMES IN EGYPT
abstract: Defense Department officials said today that there would be no increase in the number of American troops scheduled to take part in a military exercise in Egypt and the Sudan that was planned before the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat. They said, however, that the range of the maneuvers would be extended.   The chief spokesman for the Pentagon, Assistant Secretary Henry E.  Catto Jr., said the exercise, called Bright Star, had long been planned but was being modified in consultation with other governments as a consequence of President Sadat's death.   Mr. Catto told reporters at a briefing this morning, ''I don't think it has been enhanced as a result of recent events.'' His remarks were prompted by questions about a statement by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in a television interview Sunday in which he said that there would be ''a highly increased U.S. presence for those exercises.'' Some officials had interpreted Mr.  Haig's statement to mean that the number of Americans participating would be increased significantly.

headline: U.N. TEAM IN DOUBT ON 'YELLOW RAIN'
abstract: A group of United Nations experts says that it can neither verify nor refute charges that Communist forces have used poisonous chemicals in Southeast Asia.   Secretary General Kurt Waldheim is due to report Tuesday that his team of five specialists ''found itself unable to reach a final conclusion as to whether or not chemical warfare agents had been used.''   The study says that refugees from Laos and Cambodia, who were interviewed in Thailand, ''related stories similar to those appearing'' in documents submitted by the the United States. The United States contended that chemical attacks, which villagers described as clouds of ''yellow rain,'' caused nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and death. American authorities say that they have collected samples of leaves, stems, water and rocks from the sites of the attacks and that the samples bear traces of deadly toxins.

headline: VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ITT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Protestant Inmates Stage 36-Hour Siege in Ulster
abstract: About 50 Protestant prisoners who said they held 4 guards and 13 Catholic inmates as hostages on the roof of Belfast's Crumlin Road jail ended their protest early today after 36 hours, a mediator said.   The mediator, John McQuade, a Member of Parliament for the Rev. Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party, said the protesters promised to release their hostages later in the day.   The prisoners, members of Protestant paramilitary organizations awaiting trial, said they were demanding better jail conditions and segregation from Irish Republican Army suspects held in the same wing.

headline: Lloyds Stock Purchase
abstract: Lloyds Bank Ltd. said today that it held 71.6 million, or 60.3 percent, of the ordinary issued shares of Lloyds and Scottish Ltd. following the close of its offer for the finance and leasing group. Acceptances totaled 11.99 million shares, or 10.09 percent, of the issued shares, Lloyds said, adding that it already held 59.64 million shares before the posting of the offer.

headline: WYMAN-GORDON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PANDA TOTAL IS STABILIZED, CHINESE SAYS
abstract: The number of giant pandas, whose survival was once jeopardized by a dearth of its favorite bamboo, has stopped declining, according to a Chinese specialist on the endangered species.   In an interview with the New China News Agency, Hu Jinchu, an associate professor at Nanchong Teachers College in Sichuan Province, was quoted as reporting that China's panda population had been stabilized though a combination of Government protective measures, the discovery of food substitutes and the study of diseases afflicting the panda.   He did not say how many pandas are believed to be alive today.  After a survey of known panda habitats in 1974 and 1975, the Ministry of Forestry estimated that China had slightly more than 1,000 of the elusive creatures, which are called ''bearcats'' by the Chinese.

headline: SIGMA-ALDRICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Saturday Review Begins Cultural Cable Listings
abstract: With the March issue, Saturday Review will tip its hat in recognition of the new electronic technology by beginning to include a monthly department called Cultural Cable and Television Calendar.

headline: MASSMUTUAL MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Corning Venture
abstract: Corning Glass Works said it had formed a joint venture company in France with Compagnie de Saint-Gobain-Pont-a-Mousson and Thomson-CSF, a unit of Thomson-Brandt, to produce optical fibers. The company, to be called Fibres Optiques Industries, will be 40 percent owned by Corning and 60 percent by the two French companies, Corning said.

headline: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Stock Outlook in Technology
abstract: THE sun may or may not be setting on the bear market, but a few analysts are already looking for a brighter day in technology stocks.  These stocks were particularly hard hit this year, partly because they had done unusually well in the prior bull market.   While stocks in general dropped 20 percent, most technology issues dropped by a third.  And some of them, such as Rohm and Sperry, were down to half their previous value when they reached their lowest levels.

headline: Expansion Planned For Light Wines Amid Surging Sales
abstract: The tennis-playing couple lay down their racquets and pick up a bottle. ''What a perfect time for your other wine,'' says the voiceover in the television commercial for Taylor California Cellars Light Chablis.   It is one of the new light wines, a product that is low in calories and alcohol, but evidently soaring in sales. Retail sales of light wine may reach $20 million for 1981, after less than a year on the market. By the end of the decade, industry members say, the category could account for 10 to 15 percent of total wine sales.

headline: MIDWAY AIRLINES ANGERS BIG CARRIERS
abstract: An aggressive advertising campaign by a small airline in Chicago has touched off a feud that could end the peaceful coexistence between the nation's large, established airlines and the smaller carriers that have proliferated since the industry was deregulated three years ago.   At stake for many of the small airlines are the once-free arrangements with the large carriers known as ''interline agreements.'' Many of the small companies have come to depend on these agreements, which involve listing schedules, making passenger reservations and exchanging tickets and baggage.   ''It looks like the big boys are getting sick and tired of being taken advantage of by the little guys,'' said Eliot M. Fried, an airline analyst at Shearson/American Express. ''Now, the small airlines will have to pay for what service they get.''

headline: SURPRISES AT SILVER AUCTION
abstract: The Government surprised the silver trade yesterday by accepting bids for only 160,000 troy ounces of the 1.25 million ounces of silver bullion it offered at its first auction of the metal since 1970. The accepted bids ranged from a high of $9.41 an ounce to a low of $9.331 and were well below silver prices in the New York cash and futures markets.   Bids were submitted for nearly five times the amount of silver announced for sale.  Another shock to the trade came when only two of the 29 bidders were awarded silver. Many of the disappointed dealers had contracted to deliver the metal to their customers and, as is customary in such cases, had hedged their sales by selling silver futures short on New York's Commodity Exchange and smaller metals markets.

headline: COURT BACKS GRUMMAN IN LTV FIGHT
abstract: The Grumman Corporation won a major victory yesterday in its fight to block the LTV Corporation's $450 million tender offer when the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld Grumman's assertion that an LTV takeover would violate Federal antitrust laws.   Last month, LTV's staff counsel, Emmett Smith, had said that LTV would consider its bid for Grumman ''doomed'' if the Appeals Court ruling favored Grumman.   An LTV spokesman said late yesterday that the company was ''disappointed'' with the ruling but that a final decision on whether to continue with the takeover would not be made until Monday.   Grumman officials and employees were elated by the A - eals Court ruling. ''It's fantastic,'' said John C. Bierwirth, the company's chairman. ''It's like you've been holding your breath for a month and a half and you can finally breathe again. Everybody has a personal feeling of relief and victory.''

headline: ENERGY, METALS UP
abstract: Energy and precious-metal issues moved briskly higher yesterday, while the stock market over all posted a modest decline as investors sought to evaluate the assassination of President Sadat of Egypt.   In a late sell-off, the Dow Jones industrial average finished at 856.26, down 3.61 points. At 2:30 P.M., the indicator was ahead more than 4 1/2 points. Trading volume contracted to 45.5 million shares from Monday's 51.3 million.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Air Chicago Inc. said it had signed an agreement to buy five Boeing 727 aircraft from Pan American World Airways for $12.2 million.   * Burlington Northern Railroad Co. said it plans to spend $369 million next year on capital improvements, up from an expected $346 million in 1981.   * Firestone Tire and Rubber Co. said it will not extend or otherwise amend its offer to buy 10 million of its common shares at $11.50 a share and will allow the offer to expire on Wednesday as scheduled.

headline: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dow Reaches 838.38, Up 7.42
abstract: Stock prices rebounded yesterday after recent weakness that reflected continuing fears of high interest rates and a softening economy. Adverse earnings reports for the September quarter also had depressed the market.   The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.42 points, to 838.38. In the previous 11 sessions, it had dropped 42 points.  A slight improvement in bond prices, with a corresponding decline in yields, helped the tone of the stock market yesterday.  ''But unless bond prices show real improvement, you're not likely to see any sustainable rally in the equity market,'' said John A.  Conlon Jr., who heads the block trading desk at E.F. Hutton & Company. ''Institutional investors remain extremely cautious.''

headline: Homelite Thins Agency Search
abstract: The Homelite division of Textron, which recently went through a mutually agreed upon split with Henderson Advertising, Greenville, S.C., has decided on the six agencies that are going to compete for its account, according to a reliable agency-world source.

headline: Around the World; U.S. Reviewing Visa Of Ulster's Rev. Paisley
abstract: Amid pressure from Congress, the State Department said today that it was reviewing the multiple-entry visa of the Rev. Ian Paisley, the hard-line Northern Irish Protestant leader, who is planning to visit the United States soon.

headline: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Clean Air
abstract: To the Business Editor: Can our environment become too free from pollutants? One might reach such a conclusion from ''G.M. on Clean Air'' (Oct. 3). The carrot dangled before the public is that if only it will consent to a relaxation in atmospheric goals, it might save $300 on each car it buys.

headline: Bangor Punta Net Off
abstract: The Bangor Punta Corporation, whose products include Piper airplanes and Smith & Wesson handguns, said today that its profit in the fourth quarter ended Sept. 30 fell 60.4 percent, to $1.9 million, or 25 cents a share, from $4.8 million, or 63 cents a share, in the 1980 quarter.

headline: Protestant Militant in Ulster Slain by Police at Roadblock
abstract: Policemen shot and killed one man in a stolen taxi that raced through a roadblock early today and arrested two others, a police spokesman said.

headline: 2 Belgian Parties to Meet On Forming a Coalition
abstract: Former Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, a Social Christian, appeared today to have achieved a breakthrough in efforts to form a government when he announced that prospective coalition partners would meet Wednesday to negotiate on a program.   For the first time since inconclusive elections a month ago, the Social Christians and the Liberals agreed to begin talks. Mr.  Martens, who is the third politician to try to form a government in the last month, said believed that a coalition government would be formed quickly.

headline: The U.N. Today; Oct. 8, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Working Group on Rights of Nonciti- zens - 10:30 A.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M. headline: Ford Weighs Plant Closing
abstract: The Ford Motor Company has told workers at its aluminum-casting plant in Sheffield, Ala., that they must agree to pay and fringe-benefit cuts that total 50 percent or the plant will be closed.   ''The Sheffield plant has lost money for the last six years because its costs are too high,'' William H. Gay, general manager of Ford's casting division, said in a statement released in Detroit late Wednesday.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CORNELIUS CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mrs. Gandhi Urges Talks On Conflict in Cambodia
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, whose Government has recognized the Vietnamese-backed regime in Cambodia, said here today that India would welcome any conference that would seek a resolution of the conflict there.   The United Nations voted last month to recognize the Pol Pot forces as the legitimate Government of Cambodia, even though it has been accused of genocide.

headline: Scott Acquisition
abstract: The Scott Paper Company said it had acquired Amer ican Convenience Products Inc. of Milwaukee, a producer of paper prod ucts for the food service market.

headline: WESTERN MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FOR RUSSIANS, A GERMANIST
abstract: When Yuli Aleksandrovich Kvitsinsky was named this fall as chief Soviet negotiator for the Geneva nuclear arms reduction talks, American officials reacted at first with surprise, and then, after a quick intellectual double-take, with total comprehension.   The surprise involved Mr. Kvitsinsky's comparative youth -he is 45 years old - and his apparent status outside the highest levels of the Soviet hierarchy. The insight that immediately followed was this: Moscow had picked a German expert, a man who would be able to address West German public opinion throughout the talks with skill and nuance, and bring an understanding of West German strategic thinking - a factor of capital importance in the discussion of middle-range missiles - to the negotiating table and the corridors beyond.   Mr. Kvitsinsky had worked, until his appointment here, as minister counselor, or second man, in the Soviet Embassy in Bonn. Before that he had been an important behind-the-scenes figure in constructing the four-power agreement on Berlin more than a decade ago. He served in the Soviet Embassy in East Berlin and received a doctor of law degree with a thesis on West Berlin. He speaks impeccable German and is the kind of man, according to a diplomat who saw him often in Bonn, ''who can and will recite sections of the West German Constitution to you by heart.''

headline: INDUSTRIAL-AMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Marschalk Is Agency For You Panties
abstract: The Marschalk Company has been named agency for You panties, a new product introduced a year ago by Formfit Rogers, specialist in undergarments that is owned by Grupo Pliana of Mexico City.   The brand will be supported by about $8 million in media advertising during the coming year, according to Maude Ann Cauley, vice president of advertising and sales promotion.

headline: Thrift Units Make Gains
abstract: Ending a seven-month loss record, savers put $1.5 billion more into savings and loan associations last month than they took out, the Government said today. The gain was attributed mostly to the new tax-exempt ''All Savers'' certificates, which attracted $16.5 billion in accounts in savings and loans last month.

headline: ROLE OF AMERICANS IN LIBYAN WARFARE CONFIRMED BY U.S.
abstract: The United States today confirmed that Americans had been involved in military support activities in Libya and called the involvement ''reprehensible.''   According to Dean Fischer, a State Department spokesman, American citizens have been servicing planes of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Libyan Air Force, including C-130 transports and CH-47 helicopters.   Mr. Fischer also said that he could confirm that American citizens had also served as crew members on charter flights from Libya to Chad on United African Airways, a Libyan line used to ferry troops and equipment. But, the States Department spokesman added, ''Our information is that they have not been pilots'' on either the military or troop-carrying charter planes. Libya, a militant Arab nation in North Africa, has been warring in Chad.

headline: Egypt's Parliament Approves A Pension for Sadat's Widow
abstract: Parliament has approved a law to give President Anwar el-Sadat's widow, Jihan, a pension as well as his residences in Cairo and Alexandria.   The amount of the pension was not disclosed. The residences are to be shared by Mrs. Sadat and her children during their lifetimes and will become museums afterward.

headline: U.S. WILL SEND $29 MILLION FOOD AID TO POLAND
abstract: The United States said today that it would supply Poland with $29 million in surplus dairy products to help resolve its ''pressing difficulties peacefully and without foreign interference.''   In addition, Administration officials said, $50 million in food aid is being planned for early next year. So far, the United States has given Poland $741 million in credits and food aid this year.

headline: Patents; A 3d Patent For Cancer Treatment
abstract: WASHINGTON A YOUNG heart surgeon will receive the third in his series of patents on cancer treatment next week. An organization named Gordon Laboratories is being formed to develop equipment and arrange for early general use of the treatment in hospitals.

headline: 2 BANKS CUT PRIME TO 15 1/2%
abstract: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago and the Crocker National Bank in California announced yesterday that they would reduce their prime rate to 15 1/2 percent today.   At most major banks, this basic lending rate remained at 16 percent, a level it fell to last week.  A number of bankers and economists predicted, however, that the recent steep decline in interest rates is nearing its end. The prime rate, they said, is likely to bottom out somewhere between 13 and 15 percent within the next few months. This rate, around which rates on many other loans are set, has dropped sharply since September, when it stood at 20 1/2 percent.

headline: SPAIN'S COOKING OIL SCANDAL CRIPPLES ITS SEAFOOD CANNERS
abstract: A scandal involving adulterated cooking oil, which has killed 215 persons in Spain since last spring, has brought the nation's seafood canning industry to the verge of collapse.   Although no poisonous oil has been found in 18,000 spot-checks of canned seafood, consumers' confidence has been shattered.  ''We can't last through December if the situation continues,'' said Tomas Masso, president of the National Seafood Canning Federation.  The industry's inventory accumulation has grown to $134 million, compared with a normal figure of $38 million.

headline: Hess Official I.C.C. Choice
abstract: President Reagan today announced his intention to appoint Joseph J. Simmons 3d, a vice president of the Amerada Hess Corporation, to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

abstract: * Bass Brothers Enterprises said it had acquired a stake in Crown Zellerbach Corp. of 125,700 shares of the $4.625 cumulative convertible preferred stock, series A (no par value), or 5 percent, at a net purchase price of $6.3 million.   * Cummins Engine Co. said it plans to lay off about 800 production and office employees in the Columbus area beginning Nov. 29.

headline: MUSHROOM IMPORTS HURT U.S. FARMERS
abstract: The beam from the light on Gary Shroeder's cap cut through the dank darkness, gleaming on white plants mottling a bed of partly decayed organic matter, and the young man leaned over to pluck a plump mushroom and display it.   ''There now, that's just about perfect,'' said Mr. Shroeder, a supervisor for Phillips Mushroom Farms, which is one of the major enterprises in one of the largest commercial and agricultural activities in this area of southeastern Pennsylvania.   But that good plant and millions like it notwithstanding, there is trouble here in mushroom country, and the gloom among growers is as thick as the humid air in the windowless, concrete-block houses where the crop is grown.   ''We could just have to dump them,'' said Donald Needham, a local mushroom farmer, complaining of falling prices. ''It's extremely hard to stay in business the way things are,'' said James Yeatman, one of the area's largest producers.

headline: Bombs at Jewish Sites Hurt at Least 6 in Italy
abstract: Bomb attacks on two Jewish targets injured at least six people today, the police said.  A bomb exploded at a tourist information office of Israel's El Al national airlines on Rome's Via Veneto.

headline: MEDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

headline: Economic Scene; Reagan's Aims On Poor Lands
abstract: WASHINGTON JUST about the only piece of hard news to emerge from this year's annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund has been the admission to membership of the Republic of Vanuatu and the Kingdom of Bhutan.   For those who have forgotten, Vanuatu was formerly the British-French condominium of New Hebrides. It has a population of 105,000 spread over a chain of some 70 inhabited islands in the South Pacific. Bhutan, situated in the eastern Himalayas between China and India, has a population of about 1.3 million. The capital of Vanuatu is Port Vila and the capital of Bhutan is Phimbu.

headline: THE KREMLIN'S COSTLY COMMITMENT IN AFGHANISTAN
abstract: In the two years that Soviet troops have been in Afghanistan, their numbers have increased from the original 85,000 to 110,000 deployed in 11 divisions around the country, according to a senior Asian diplomat here.   The diplomat, who has traveled widely in the two years that he has served here, said that Western governments had steadfastly underreported the numbers of Soviet soldiers. Last spring, an American diplomat in Kabul reported a sudden jump in the size of the Soviet forces to about 110,000, but this was quickly denied by the United States Defense Department.   Although the exact number of Soviet soldiers in this country is a matter of debate, diplomats generally agree that the Russians have not been able to curb the widespread insurgency despite a costly commitment. The diplomats say Soviet losses have been significant and painful.

headline: Patents; A System To Identify Callers
abstract: WASHINGTON WHEN a telephone rings, the caller is identified even before the receiver is lifted. The equipment, patented this week, is available throughout the Bell System, and is being offered especially to small companies with few telephones.   Patent 4,296,282, which is assigned to Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., was granted Joseph T. O'Neil and Tse Lin Wang, staff members at the Holmdel, N.J., plant, and Thomas M. Quinn of the Denver office.   The instruments that identify selected business callers have already been supplied to 15,000 users, and 400 are being shipped every week. When a call comes in over one of the special lines each of the 20 selected callers has been given, one of 20 small lamps is lighted, drawing attention to a nearby label bearing the name of the caller. If the recipient would not be interested in talking to the caller at the time, he or she need not answer.

headline: High Court Ends Stay in Oil Price Case
abstract: The Federal Government moved a step closer today toward resolving the complex legal problems that have beset last January's termination of price controls on crude oil.   The Supreme Court cleared the way for the Department of Energy to issue a final list of ''entitlements,'' pay-ments that oil refiners owe one another for price-controlled oil used during the four weeks before President Reagan lifted the controls.   The Court, without explanation, lifted a stay it had granted three months ago to the Mobil Oil Corporation, which owes other refiners some $50 million under the entitlements program and has sued the Department of Energy on the ground that the program has been mismanaged. Stay Was Granted Sept. 3   The Supreme Court stay, granted to Mobil on Sept. 3 by Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr., had blocked the Energy Department from making the final calculations necessary to close its books on oil price controls.

headline: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Housing starts fell 6.9 percent in October, to a 15-year low, depressed by the lowest rate for single-family houses on record, the Commerce Department reported. In addition, building permits for future construction sank for the sixth consecutive month. (Page D1.)   New York City narrowed the competition for cable franchises in the boroughs outside Manhattan from 13 to 7 companies. (A1.) The action was seen as another indication that power in the cable industry is concentrating among large corporations. (B4.)

abstract: President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan, who arrived here yesterday, today presented his country's Sun of Freedom order to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, in a Kremlin ceremony. Mr. Karmal later left by air for an undisclosed destination.

headline: G.E. to Cut Emphasis On Consumer Ads
abstract: When the ''General Electric Theater,'' long a broadcasting feature, returns Saturday in a two-hour format on the ABC-TV Network it will mark an important turning point in the corporation's advertising. Among the eight commercials by Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn will be two that will be promoting industrial products, instead of the consumer products with which the public is most familiar.

headline: NCC AND SIMPLICITY END MERGER TALKS
abstract: NCC Energy Ltd. of London and the Simplicity Pattern Company, the nation's largest producer of sewing patterns, announced jointly yesterday that they had agreed to terminate plans for an earlier announced $85 million merger because of ''current circumstances.''   The two companies did not elaborate.

headline: POPE IS STILL URGING TALKS TO SOLVE THE POLISH CRISIS
abstract: Pope John Paul II is still trying to bring about a resumption of negotiations between the Polish authorities and the Solidarity labor union.   This was made clear today by Bishop Bronislaw Dabrowski, the secretary of the Polish Bishops Conference, before he left Rome to return to Warsaw after having briefed the Pope on the situation in Poland.   ''The role of the church at this moment is to try to bring about a dialogue between the two sides,'' Bishop Dabrowski said in a statement at the airport. ''The church is like a mother. It must save all its children.''

headline: Around the World; Flemish Liberal to Look For a Belgian Coalition
abstract: King Baudouin today asked Herman Vanderpoorten, a member of the Flemish Liberal Party, to consult political leaders to try to find the basis for a new coalition government.

headline: GENERAL FOODS PRESIDENT
abstract: Philip L. Smith, 48 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the General Foods Corporation, succeeding Ross Barzelay, 59, who will become vice chairman and retire at the end of the company's fiscal year on April 2, 1982.

headline: Deaths Now Put at 30 In Beirut Bomb Blast
abstract: The death toll in a bomb explosion at the Iraqi Embassy in Beirut, originally believed to have been 20, was put at 30 today.   Sources in the pro-Iraqi Baath Party said they were losing hope that the Iraqi Ambassador, Abdel-Razzak Mohammed Lafta, would be found alive.

headline: U.S. AIDE OPTIMISTIC ON WEAPONS TALKS
abstract: Paul H. Nitze, the chief United States arms negotiator, said today that there were ''prospects for reaching a fair, equitable and verifiable'' agreement with the Soviet Union in the talks that will open here Monday on the reduction of nuclear missiles in Europe.   The two nations have ''every reason to be sincere in their efforts to reach agreement on the reduction of nuclear weapons,'' Mr. Nitze said on his arrival for the first formal Soviet-American arms negotiations since the Reagan Administration took office.   Mr. Nitze, answering reporters' questions after reading a prepared statement at the airport, said he would be both ''reasonable and tough'' in the talks.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM BROADCASTS ON POLAND
abstract: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish here by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency, and a report from the Soviet press agency, Tass:   Strikes in Szczecin 4:10 A.M. Sunday   (10:10 P.M. Saturday, E.S.T.) The situation in Szczecin itself, the paper stresses, is different from that in the province. Although the centers of strikes are dying out, former Solidarity activists or activists of other opposition groups continue to come to light at work enterprises trying to persuade people not to observe the instructions and laws from the decree on martial law. They often exploit people's ignorance, the lack of a general knowledge of the prohibitions or injunctions in force under martial law.   Yesterday, for instance, irresponsible groups once again attempted to organize a strike in (word indistinct). Such action causes unease among the work force and the atmosphere becomes very tense. In the present situation such action is very irresponsible. Calm reigns on the streets of Szczecin and of the towns of the province. In general the instruction forbidding people to be in public places during the hours between 2 A.M. and 6 A.M. is being observed.

headline: Buyer-Selected Note Maturities
abstract: A new type of tax-exempt security is scheduled for sale next week by the state of Washington, which plans to issue $400 million of oneyear notes through underwriters led by Citibank and Salomon Brothers.   Unlike standard note issues of states, which offer only a few predetermined maturities, the buyer of the Washington notes may select a maturity to fall on the 15th of any month between now and October 1982.

headline: TREASURY PRICES FALL SHARPLY
abstract: Fears that the Federal Reserve will report a rise in the money supply tomorrow afternoon helped to send prices of Government securities tumbling yesterday. One dealer said this factor added an additional worry to what he called ''a gut-wringing market.''   The Treasury's bellwether 14 percent bond due in 2011 fell 1 3/4 points, to 104 1/2, thereby pushing the yield up to 13.37 percent.  Comparable price declines appeared in other coupon issues, while the yield on six-month Treasury bills rose 35 basis points, or hundredths of a percentge point, to 10.96 percent.

headline: Farm Fuel Costs Rise
abstract: Fuel prices continue to be among the top gainers on farmers' costs lists, the Agriculture Department says.

headline: U.S. Embassy Services In Poland Are Curbed
abstract: The State Department said yesterday in Washington that the United States Embassy in Warsaw could not provide normal services to American citizens because security forces were restricting access to the embassy and diplomats could not travel in the normal way.   Sondra McCarty, a department spokesman, said American citizens who had no compelling reason to remain in Poland ''may wish to leave the country.''

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SOME RADIO AND TV BROADCASTS IN POLAND FROM TASS
abstract: Following are excerpts from the Soviet press agency Tass and excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish here by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency Katowice Miners Strike 9 P.M. Monday, (3 P.M. Monday, E.S.T.)   Report by the Katowice correspondent of P.A.P., the Government press agency:   The difficut situation in the neighboring Ziemowit and Piast hard coal mines in Tychy continues. Since last Tuesday groups of miners there have been on strike underground.   Immense efforts are being made to resolve this dangerous conflict, using persuasion without the use of force. So far there have seen no casualties.   Despite strong pressure exercised by the strike organizers - Soldidarity extremists including persons who are not part of the work force - some miners are deciding to come to the surface.

headline: Eurodollar Trade Cleared
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today unanimously approved a Chicago Mercantile Exchange proposal to trade futures on three-month Eurodollar time deposit rates.   The unit of trading for the contract is the interest payable on $1 million principal value of London Eurodollar time deposits with three months remaining to maturity.

headline: People Express
abstract: People Express Airlines, a carrier based in Newark, said that it would suspend two daily flights from Indianapolis to Newark International Airport, effective Nov. 30. The airline, which offers cut-rate fares and no-frills service, said that the suspension was necessary because of cutbacks ordered at Newark by the Civil Aeronautics Board. The cutback will reduce from 48 to 36 the number of People Express flights to Newark.

headline: Volkswagen Adds Three 1982 Models
abstract: Volkswagen of America said it would introduce three models for 1982, including a replacement for its Dasher sedan.  The company said its Dasher model would be replaced by a slightly larger car, called the Quantum, that would be more fuel-efficient than the Dasher.

headline: Posner Buys Crown Stock
abstract: Victor Posner, the Miami Beach financier, announced that he has purchased an additional 390,000 shares of the Royal Crown Companies, the producer of soft-drinks and fast foods, for $16 a share, or a total of $6.2 million.   Mr. Posner already owns 532,200 shares, or nearly 6.49 percent, of Royal Crown's 8.2 million common shares outstanding, that he bought in May.

headline: Campbell-Mithun Fills President Post
abstract: Because certain health problems in his family have ''stabilized,'' William D. Dunlap, who decided against taking the presidency of Campbell-Mithun in Minneapolis, in October, took the job last Monday. The 43-year-old executive had been president of MCA Advertising in New York, and before that an Assistant Postmaster General for Consumer Marketing.   The agency took the occasion to announce another pair of promotions, both to vice chairman. They are Raymond L. Sachs, 51, and William E. Stein, 42. Mr. Sachs is a C.P.A. Do we detect a trend?

headline: EXCERPTS FROM ARCHBISHOP'S LETTER
abstract: Following are excerpts from a pastoral letter written by Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Primate of Poland, to be read in all Polish churches tonight. An Italian text of the letter, translated from the Polish by the Polish episcopal delegation to the Vatican, was translated by The New York Times.   Sisters and brothers: With a heavy and pain-filled heart I write you my wishes for Christmas and the New Year. I am writing after the proclamation of ''the state of war,'' and I do not know what will be the atmosphere, the spirit, in the Polish family during the holidays. But you too are waiting with trepidation for the days of the feast, and you ask: What can the Primate of Poland say in the face of violence, suspension of many civil rights and the danger of fratricidal war? The only essential and fundamental wish is that the state of war will end before Holy Christmas.

headline: U.S. STEEL DEMANDED OPTION ON YATES OILFIELD
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation demanded during negotiations with the Marathon Oil Company that it be given an exclusive option to buy Marathon's large Yates oilfield if its takeover of the entire company fell through, David M. Roderick, the steelmaker's chairman, testified today.   Mr. Roderick also said that his company did not engineer the option for the Yates oilfield in west Texas as a ''deterrent'' to Marathon's being bought by a third party, including the Mobil Corporation.   Mr. Roderick testified in Federal District Court in Columbus, where Mobil is seeking a permanent injunction against U.S. Steel's $6.3 billion offer for Marathon. Mobil is challenging Marathon's agreement to allow U.S. Steel to buy the Yates field for $2.8 billion in the event a third party, such as Mobil, gained control of Marathon.  Marathon's nearly 50 percent interest in the Yates field is considered its most valuable asset.

headline: U.N. Team in Thailand
abstract: A United Nations team arrived here today to investigate allegations that Vietnamese troops are using toxic chemicals against guerrillas in Cambodia. In their one-week visit, they are to interview Cambodian refugees along the Thai-Cambodian border.

headline: Dillingham Elects A New Top Officer
abstract: J. Joseph Casey, 60 years old, has been elected president of the Dillingham Corporation, a diversified Honolulu-based energy, maritime and construction company.   Effective next Jan.1, he will succeed Herbert C. Cornuelle, 61, who retired to become a trustee of the James Campbell Estate, a big Hawaiian land owner. Lowell S. Dillingham, the 70-year-old grandson of the founder, continues as chairman.

headline: BULGARIA IS ZEALOUSLY MARKING ITS 1,300 BIRTHDAY
abstract: There is a rush to finish construction by the end of the year on the National Palace of Culture, an arts center that will have an auditorium that seats more than 10,000 people and contain works by more than 100 of Bulgaria's best artists.   Last month at Plovdiv in the heart of ancient Thrace, the Government opened a magnificent, well-preserved Roman theater with marble seats for about 3,500 people. And this month, a vast stone and concrete memorial complex is scheduled to open at Kolarovgrad, formerly Shumen, an early capital and the cradle of Bulgarian history.   These events are part of a kind of national mobilization this year to mark the 13th centennial of the foundation of the Bulgarian nation.

headline: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1981; Companies
abstract: Partners are being sought for three New York City savings banks in danger of failing, according to banking sources. The institutions that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reportedly believes need to merge are the New York Bank for Savings, the Union Dime Savings Bank and the Central Savings Bank. (Page A1.)   The Amerada Hess Corporation will join the Mobil Corporation in making a new takeover bid for the Marathon Oil Company, sources said. The report fueled trading in Marathon stock, driving its price up $3.50 a share, to $102.50. (D1.)

headline: Soviet Selling Of Gold Seen
abstract: The Soviet Union has been selling increased amounts of gold in the last few days, taking advantage of firmer prices resulting from the crisis in Poland, bullion dealers said today. International gold prices usually rise at times of world tension, attracting investors who distrust currencies.

headline: IRAQ AGAIN OFFERS IRAN A TRUCE
abstract: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said today that his country was ready to end the 15-month-old war with Iran if the Iranians agreed to recognize Iraq's borders.   He also accused international mediators of failing to convey ''the truth'' and of ''intentional delays'' in their efforts.  The Iraqi President's remarks to delegates at a conference of labor ministers of developing countries that profess nonalignment was broadcast by Baghdad radio and monitored in Nicosia.

headline: CRISIS DOES NOT AFFECT SCHMIDT TRIP
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany visited this small East German town today, intent on demonstrating through his presence here that there was no purpose for the West to be too quick to dramatize the situation in Poland.   A senior adviser to the Chancellor said Mr. Schmidt felt that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should carefully consider the wisdom of any alliance meeting that might bring new elements of tension to the difficult Polish circumstances.   The visit and the aide's observations, coming on the last day of Mr. Schmidt's three days of talks with Erich Honecker, the East German leader, were meant to maintain visible East-West contacts at a moment of strain. Security Is Tight   But Chancellor Schmidt's walk through the town provided in itself a contradiction to his ideas of dialogue. East Germans were kept away from the town by thousands of police. There were multiple identity checks for those who did arrive here, a transparent selection of ''safe'' guests for the areas closest to Mr. Schmidt's itinerary.

headline: West German Held in East
abstract: East German security forces have arrested a Hamburg city government employee and charged him with spying, the East German press agency said today. The man, identifed only as Rudiger N., was arrested ''in the act'' of espionage and has been committed for trial, the press agency said.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Habib and Prince Fahd Discuss Saudi Peace Plan   BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 6 (AP) - Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East, met with Crown Prince Fahd today to discuss Saudi Arabia's peace plan, the Riyadh radio reported.   Mr. Habib, who arrived in the Middle East a week ago, has not disclosed details of his talks, but the radio, which was monitored here, said he held discussions with the Crown Prince on the eightpoint peace plan.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM COMMENTS ON POLAND AND MIDEAST
abstract: Following are excerpts from texts of television interviews yesterday with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation'' and with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' as recorded by The New York Times:   Following are excerpts from television interviews yesterday with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation'' and with Secretary of Defense Caspar W.  Weinberger on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' as recorded by The New York Times:   Haig on Poland   Q. Secretary Haig, a number of reports tell us that the Soviet Union has supplied technical assistance, advice, some supplies, all kinds of help and encouragement in the martial law imposed inside Poland. Are they not in a sense involved, are they not an involved party in the martial law in Poland?   A. I think as the President said in his statement this week, there's no question about Soviet cooperation and support for the activities going on in Poland today.   And just as the Polish authorities must be held be responsible for the excesses of the situation, so too must the Soviet Union.  Q. Does that mean, Mr. Secretary, that if there are any sanctions imposed against Poland, they should similarly be imposed against the country that is supporting it and pressing it on - the Soviet Union?

headline: RCTV
abstract: To the Business Editor: It is inaccurate to refer to ''NBC's Entertainment Channel.'' The Entertainment Channel, a new pay cable program service, is a joint venture of Rockefeller Center Inc. and the RCA Corporation. There is no affiliation with the National Broadcasting Company.  HOWARD BURKAT Vice President Advertising and Promotion The Entertainment Channel New York, N.Y., Oct. 27, 1981

headline: MARKET NATIONS STEP UP CASTIGATION OF WARSAW
abstract: The 10 Common Market countries, in a joint statement published today, condemned ''the grave violation of the human and civil rights of the Polish people.''   The language of their statement, expressing ''growing concern'' about events in Poland, was considerably stronger than that of a statement issued jointly by the 10 countries a week ago, soon after the declaration of martial law. Diplomats said that the change reflected the widespread conviction that the situation was deteriorating rapidly.

headline: Loss for China On Industries
abstract: China has 13,000 industrial enterprises operating at a yearly loss of $2.8 billion because of waste, poor planning and incompetent management, China's Finance Minister said in a report that was released today.   If these and other problems in production, construction and the movement of commodities were solved, China would gain $6.7 billion or more annually, the minister, Wang Bingqian, reported to the National Peoples Congress on Dec. 1.

headline: RELAXATION TANKS: A MARKET DEVELOPS
abstract: Four years ago Gary Higgins, then president of a small carpet-cleaning service in Denver, took his first ''float'' in a relaxation tank.   Mr. Higgins was so impressed with the tank, a rectangular structure partly filled with a saline solution, that he put his carpet-cleaning business up for sale the same day. Two months later Mr. Higgins opened his own tank manufacturing and distributing company, Float to Relax, based in Lakewood, Colo.   Now, Mr. Higgins's company is one of three manufacturers that sell the tanks to individuals and franchisees. Industrywide revenues from sales and rentals of the units are expected to top $4 million this year, Mr. Higgins said. ''We've just brushed the snow off the tip of the iceberg,'' he declared.

headline: Error on Date For 'All Savers'
abstract: The Depository Institutions Deregulation Committee said today that a new and lower interest rate on the taxexempt savings certificates, known as ''All Savers'' certificates, began on Sunday, Oct. 4, not on the following day, as a news release issued by the committee staff had said earlier.   Thus, depositors who signed up for the certificates that Sunday, hoping to take advantage of a higher rate that they thought expired that day, were already too late, the committee said.

headline: M.W. Kellogg
abstract: The M.W. Kellogg Company said it had a contract to design a $4 million fertilizer granulation plant for Bangladesh Chemical Industries. The plant will granulate triple superphosphate fertilizer produced in Bangladesh. Dutch development aid has been allocated for the project, which will be designed by Kellogg Continental, Netherlands, and built by the Hollandse Construction Group, using technology licensed by Stamicarbon, a subsidiary of Dutch State Mines.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Later this month on network and spot TV Alberto-Culver is going to introduce its first room deodorizer product.

headline: EXXON CLOSES PLANT AND LAYS OFF 1,100 IN OFFICE COMPANY
abstract: The Exxon Office Systems Company yesterday dismissed about a fifth of its work force and closed a manufacturing plant as part of what it called an effort to streamline operations.   The layoff of nearly 1,100 workers was the latest step in what has so far been an unsuccessful attempt to bring the Exxon Corporation's ailing office automation business into the black. Combined with layoffs of 600 workers a few months ago, the new cutbacks reduced the office company's work force from nearly 6,000 employees to 4,000.   ''The moves are really designed to strengthen the company and to move us from operating in the red to operating in the black, which is our target by the end of next year,'' said Fred Mason, director of public affairs of the office systems company, which is based in Stamford, Conn.

headline: Around the World; Cambodian Rebel Seeks To Form a Coalition
abstract: Son Sann, a leader of right-wing forces fighting the Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia, met here today with the Foreign Ministers of Thailand and Malaysia to discuss forming a coalition of rival resistance groups.   Malaysia's Foreign Minister, Ghazali Shafie, said Mr. Son Sann's organization and a rebel group headed by the exiled Prince Norodom Sihanouk agreed earlier to join a coalition.

headline: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Prospects
abstract: Buying Oil Companies   Mergers and acquisitions have always been common in the oil industry, but oil companies are generally the purchasers, not the targets. Thus U.S. Steel's $6.3 billion offer for Marathon Oil is a striking departure, and there could be others like it. And with oil prices expected to fall in real terms next year, some analysts say oil company assets and stock prices are likely to continue falling, setting the stage for more takeovers.   Although a 40 percent decline in the value of oil company shares since last November suggests that the markets have already discounted falling oil prices, further declines next year are likely to hit smaller oil companies particularly hard, experts say.
