abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HYDRAULIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KEKKONEN ILL, CANDIDATES MANEUVER
abstract: Questions of personalities and detail remain, but there is no question about the most important issue involving the successor to President Urho Kekkonen of Finland.  Whoever replaces the ailing 81-year-old leader will not change Finland's foreign policy of neutrality and of avoiding antagonisms with the Soviet Union.   ''Who would dare it, who would risk it?'' said Jan Magnus Jansson, editor in chief of the Swedish-language paper Hufvudstadsbladet and a likely candidate of the Swedish People's Party.   ''Everybody, including the Russians, starts from the assumption that there will be no change regardless of who takes over. A person who is anti-Soviet, or even vaguely thought of as such, cannot be a serious candidate.''

headline: IPM TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Dow Slips By 5.14; Volume Up; Dean Witter Surges by 13 1/2
abstract: Stock prices retreated slightly yesterday amid profit taking after the market's strong advance in the first four days of the week.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which had advanced 54 points in less than two weeks through Thursday, slipped 5.14 points, to end the week at 873. For the overall market, however, issues that advanced in price slightly outnumbered those that declined.   Volume expanded to 50.1 million shares from Thursday's 47.1 million.  The takeover sector produced another big winner as Dean Witter Reynolds soared 13 1/2 points, to 47 7/8. The stock reopened for trading after Sears, Roebuck, the nation's biggest retailer, announced Thursday night that it would acquire Dean Witter for $50 a share in cash and stock.

headline: Death Threats Cited By Belgrade Dissident
abstract: Milovan Djilas, a prominent dissident, said today that he had received anonymous death threats accusing him of anti-Yugoslav activities.

headline: WEST DELIVERS ITS PLAN ON NAMIBIA AUTONOMY
abstract: Western nations seeking to end the impasse over independence for South-West Africa formally presented a set of constitutional principles today that are designed to insure that whites and other minorities will have an opportunity to influence the shape of a new system of government there.   The proposals, presented to political parties in Windhoek, the capital of the disputed territory, modified a previous Western plan for the election of a constituent assembly. Under that plan, any party that won a majority of seats in an election would have had a free hand in writing the constitution of Namibia, as the territory is also known.

headline: Protest for Soviet Germans
abstract: About 1,000 people marched here today demanding that the Soviet Union allow ethnic Germans to emigrate.

headline: SCHRADER, ABE, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Fed Names Women As Bank Chairmen
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board in Washington yesterday appointed its first two women Federal Reserve Bank chairmen. Jean A. Crockett, 62 years old, will serve at the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and Caroline Ahmanson, 63, will serve at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco.   The appointments break another barrier at the nation's central bank, which has a woman on its board of governors - Nancy A. Teeters - and has had women chairmen of branch banks in each of the 12 regional districts.

headline: Zimbabwe Rallies Banned
abstract: The Government banned three rallies today as part of its crackdown on opposition political parties. At the same time, it granted permission for a rally by Prime Minister Robeert Mugabe's own party, the Zimbabwe African National Union.

headline: Bank of Canada Rate
abstract: The Bank of Canada interest rate continued its slow downward trend, slipping to 15 percent from 15.15 percent on Wednesday. Money market specialists say the bank rate, that charged chartered banks for loans from the central bank, would have increased slightly had it not been for intervention by the Bank of Canada in the weekly auction of Treasury bills at which the rate is set.

headline: Bethlehem Steel Sells Tax Credits
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it had agreed to sell an unspecified amount of tax credits to the R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company, a Chicago-based printing and publishing company, for about $45 million.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: U.N. Official, an Iraqi, To Snub Israel and Iran
abstract: The president of the General Assembly, Ismat Kittani of Iraq, said today that the Israeli and Iranian delegations could not expect him to accord them ''the usual courtesies'' of the presidency because of the harsh criticisms leveled by both nations after his election two weeks ago.   Immediately after the election of Mr. Kittani, whose country is fighting Iran and considers itself in ''a state of war'' with Israel, the chief Israeli delegate, Yehuda Z. Blum, denounced it as ''a measure of the regrettable decline of the United Nations' status.''

headline: DOMINICANS ADMONISH BUSH ON SUGAR
abstract: Vice President Bush, on a three-day visit to the Dominican Republic, went before a joint session of the Dominican National Assembly today with a speech castigating President Fidel Castro of Cuba and warning of the dangers of Cuban and Soviet expansionism.   Before he could deliver it, however, the presidents of both the Dominican Senate and the Chamber of Deputies, instead of delivering the predictable flowery introductions, made impassioned speeches on the dangers of measures now before the United States Congress. These, while protecting United States sugar producers, would harm the Dominican economy.   ''Every hard-won advance we have made toward the exercise of democracy in the last 15 years,'' said Senator Helvio A. Rodriguez, president of the Senate, ''would be seriously menaced by a misfortune in our economy such as the one now predicted, and the economy will not survive the eventual bankruptcy of the sugar industry.''

headline: GENERAL ELECTRIC BUYING 3 SOFTWARE COMPANIES
abstract: The General Electric Company, in a move intended to strengthen its computer services business, said it would acquire three private computer software companies for a price totaling between $35 million and $68 million, based on performance measurements over the next few years.   G.E. would pay between $27 and $48 million to buy the Software International Corporation of Andover, Mass., a leading producer of computer programs for accounting and other financial applications.  The other companies to be acquired are Banking Systems Inc. of Dallas, which specializes in programs for the banking industry, and Energy Enterprises of Denver, which does the same for the oil industry.

headline: CHASE CUTS PRIME RATE TO 15 3/4%
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's third largest, reduced its prime lending rate yesterday to 15 3/4 percent from 16 percent - the lowest level in more than a year - while a number of other major banks trimmed theirs to 16 percent from 16 1/2 percent as the economic downturn continued to dry up loan demand.   ''It's becoming obvious that the decline in short-term rates is for real,'' said Paul A. Mackey, a vice president and banking analyst at Bache Halsey Stuart Shields. ''The banks have been dragging their feet in bringing down the prime rate in line with the cost of funds.''

headline: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WARSAW PACT DENIES IT WANTS TO ACHIEVE FIRST-STRIKE CAPACITY
abstract: The Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies said today that they did not intend to be the first to make a nuclear strike.   In a communique at the end of a two-day meeting here, the foreign ministers of the Warsaw Pact nations also renewed an offer to dissolve their military alliance in return for simultaneous dismantling of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and blamed the West for a ''further deterioration in the international climate'' and a ''growing danger of war.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Acton Corp. said it had sold its International Food Service-Miami to C.F.S. Continental Inc. for more than $4 million in cash and notes.   * Affiliated Bancshares, a Boulder, Colo., bank-holding company, has assumed the deposit liabilities of the failed Midtown National Bank of Pueblo, Colo., according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.   * Applicon Inc. said it had entered into a definitive agreement calling for the merger of Applicon with a wholly owned subsidiary of Schlumberger Ltd. in accordance with an agreement in principle that called for the exchange of two Schlumberger shares for each three Applicon shares.

headline: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARCHIE MCCARDELL'S WOES
abstract: International Harvester completed a $4.2 billion financial restructuring plan, said to be the largest in American corporate history. Slackening demand for heavy trucks and construction equipment caused a loss of $635.7 million on continuing operations in its last fiscal year, and Harvester's chairman, Archie R. McCardell, (right) is gearing up for what may be a 30 percent drop in the coming decade's demand for heavy machinery as compared with 1970 levels.  Harvester plans to ask for $100 million of concessions from the United Autoworkers, but top executives are not expected to return their bonuses.

headline: WALESA WINS UNION VOTE WITH EASE
abstract: Lech Walesa was re-elected easily today asthe chairman of Solidarity, but the margin of victory showed that hishold over the union was not as unshakeable as it once was.   Against three other candidates, Mr. Walesa won slightly over 55 percent of the 837 votes cast at the independent union's national convention here. His term is to last two years.   Lost in a sea of photographers after the vote was announced in the Olivia Sports Arena, he accepted a bouquet of carnations in red and white - the Polish national colors - and mounted the dais to deliver a few remarks that struck a new tone of humility.

headline: Tensions in Sinai Town Are Said to Be Eased
abstract: Tensions were eased in the Sinai desert town of Yamit tonight when representatives of the townspeople announced they would try a new approach in negotiations for compensation.   The announcement came as inhabitants were fortifying Yamit behind sandbags, trenches and barbed wire in preparation for a confrontation if the army should attempt to displace them before the compensation issue is settled.

headline: BREZHNEV AND REAGAN ON ATOM WAR
abstract: Following are a question asked of President Reagan at a meeting with newspaper editors Friday in Washington and his answer as they appear in a White House transcript, and a question asked of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, by the newspaper Pravda yesterday and his answer, as translated by the Soviet press agency Tass:   Question for Reagan Q. I guess I think that some of the people in Europe who are opposed to some of our policies are afraid that they may wind up as kind of proxy victims in a war between us and the Soviet Union which - a fear that may be a little more, seem a little more plausible because of all the conversation about integrated battlefields and limited use of nucler weapons. And I wonder - we must think about this - do you believe that there could be a limited exchange of nuclear weapons between us and the Soviet Union or that it would simply escalate inevitably?   A. I don't honestly know. I think, again, until someplace - all over the world this is being, research going on, to try and find the defensive weapon. There never has been a weapon that someone hasn't come up with a defense. But it could - and the only defense is, well, you shoot yours and we'll shoot ours. And if you still had that kind of a stalemate, I could see where you could have the exchange of tactical weapons against troops in the field without it bringing either one of the major powers to pushing the button.

headline: U.S. Receives Bids For Silver
abstract: Bids for slightly more than three million ounces of silver were received today in the Government's fourth weekly auction of surplus silver from the country's stockpile, the General Services Administration said today.   The agency, which auctions 1.25 million ounces of the metal each week, drew bids from 10 banks and metal concerns.

headline: ALASKA INTERSTATE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SALVADORAN REBEL LEADER APPEALS FOR WEAPONS TO COUNTER U.S. AID
abstract: Arguing that many rebel units are still poorly armed, El Salvador's top guerrilla commander has appealed to ''the peoples of the world'' for weapons to counter American military assistance to the Salvadoran junta.   Salvador Cayetano Carpio, the 62-year-old leader of the Popular Forces of Liberation, denied American charges that the guerrillas were receiving armaments from Cuba and Nicaragua. He said that ''our arms are those we manufacture or take from the enemy at the cost of our own blood.''   ''But the supplies are evidently unequal,'' he said. ''While Yankee imperialism provides the assassins of the people with unrestricted amounts of increasingly modern weaponry, the forces of liberation do not receive even a rifle.''

headline: Police Raid Prison in Naples And Seize Arms and Drugs
abstract: Carabinieri policemen raided a topsecurity prison in Naples today and seized gas bombs, knives, heroin and large sums of cash, police sources said.   The raid was carried out by 400 Carabinieri, some brought in from Rome, in the early hours while the 1,800 inmates of Poggioreale Prison were asleep in their cells.   They seized 68 knives, 33 sharpened metal bars, assorted other crude weapons, 230 gas canisters, 10 grams of heroin and 300 grams of hashish, the sources said.

headline: Bangladesh Leader on Visit
abstract: President Abdus Sattar of Bangladesh left today for a four-day state visit to Saudi Arabia. He was accompanied by his foreign and finance ministers and other top officials.

headline: SYRIA PUTS HOPES IN U.N. SANCTION
abstract: Syria expects the United Nations Security Council to impose ''the required sanctions'' against Israel if Israel does not rescind its annexation of the Golan Heights by the next Council meeting on Jan. 5.   Although Syria is aware that the United States has traditionally vetoed any United Nations sanctions against Israel, there is some hope in Damascus that this time the Reagan Administration will at least abstain and not use the veto because it has condemned the Israeli action.   Syria is deeply concerned that Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel might be preparing for another Middle East war.  Nevertheless, Syria's leaders are determined to wage the struggle for the Golan Heights on the political plane and are certain of united Arab support on this issue despite Arab differences on other matters.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: By invoking a modest set of economic and political sanctions against the Soviet Union today with no guarantee that its allies will do the same, the Reagan Administration is consciously risking damage to the Western alliance without necessarily doing much to ameliorate the situation within Poland.   Senior Administration officials involved in the policy-making of the last two weeks assert that the United States had no choice but to take the gamble. To do nothing, or to wait indefinitely for a concerted allied response, they say, would be morally repugnant and would show the West to be impotent.   They assert, moreover, that there is still a possibility, however slim, that if the alliance does demonstrate it is truly angered by the crackdown in Poland, the authorities in Poland and in the Soviet Union might be persuaded to ease up on the repression sooner rather than later and to return to negotiations with the Solidarity union - which Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, contends is his goal.

headline: SEPTEMBER FACTORY ORDERS OFF
abstract: WASHINGTON (AP) - Orders for new manufactured goods fell ninetenths of 1 percent in September, the second consecutive monthly decline after having risen steadily since January, the Commerce Department said today.   The September decline, to a seasonally adjusted value of $168.54 billion, followed a drop of 1.5 percent in August, to an adjusted value of $170.06 billion.   The report appeared to be another sign of recession in a year of sluggish sales. ''It certainly indicates a weakness in the manufacturing sector,'' said Ago Ambre, a Commerce Department economist.

headline: MAYS, J W, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SAKHAROVS ARE DESCRIBED AS EMACIATED BUT ELATED
abstract: Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife are emaciated and weak as a result of their recently ended hunger strike, but united in a hospital suite and elated at their achievement, according to the woman for whose sake they underwent the ordeal.   Yelizaveta K. Alekseyeva, who will soon be joining Dr. Sakharov's stepson in the United States as a result of the fast, also reported today that the Sakharovs had not been force-fed during their involuntary hospitalization, despite threats of this by doctors.   Miss Alekseyeva, 26 years old, appeared radiant and relieved as she received friends and foreign correspondents to describe her brief visit with the Sakharovs yesterday at a district hospital in Gorky, the industrial city 250 miles east of Moscow to which Dr. Sakharov was banished 22 months ago.   Miss Alekseyeva said she arrived at the Semashko District Hospital in midafternoon with Natalya V. Gesse, an old friend of the Sakharovs, but had some trouble getting through because Dr. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, were registered under false names.

headline: PERMITS FALL AGAIN
abstract: Housing starts rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, the first monthly rise since July, to an annual rate of 871,000 units, a rate that still is one of the worst on record. The increase reflected a hefty increase in single-family home starts.   Despite the slight November rise overall, building permits for future construction dropped for the sixth consecutive month, indicating that the severe housing slump is not over.

headline: FRENCH COOL TO COMPENSATION DEMANDS
abstract: France's new Socialist Government today apparently turned down a joint demand by American and other foreign banks for a substantial improvement in the compensation being offered for their shareholdings in French industrial companies and banks scheduled for nationalization.   ''We think the indemnification proposals are just and equitable,'' Jean le Garrec, the French official responsible for the Socialists' nationalization program, said in a television interview. ''There is no question of any increase.'' To give foreign shareholders better terms than those given in France, he added, would be discriminatory.

headline: FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. TO TRAIN 1,500 SALVADORAN SOLDIERS
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that it planned to train a battalion of 1,000 Salvadoran soldiers and a group of 500 to 600 Salvadoran junior officers, probably in the United States.   Fred C. Ikle, Undersecretary of Defense for Policy, also told a Senate subcommittee that the Joint Chiefs of Staff had prepared contingency plans for American military action in Central America if President Reagan were to order United States intervention.   Mr. Ikle further provided new details about what he described as Soviet and Cuban infiltration into Nicaragua and other Central American nations, asserting that the Soviet Union was spending $3 billion a year to support Communist guerrillas in the region.   In addition, Mr. Ikle criticized European allies of the United States for being ''much too insouciant and cavalier about the growing military threat in the Caribbean.''

headline: Data Bank; October 4, 1981
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: BANK FOR SAVINGS FEELS SQUEEZE
abstract: For Thanksgiving this year, the New York Bank for Savings gave out special bonuses of up to $300 to each of its employees earning $30,000 a year or less. This was probably the last such bonus from the bank.   The bank's employees already have been told that they will not get Christmas bonuses, which in the past ranged up to $1,000 each. And the bank has stopped its savings incentive plan, through which it had matched the savings of some of its employees.

headline: William Ross Quits at J.W.T.
abstract: After a brief one-year run, the title of president-international of the J. Walter Thompson Company is being retired.

headline: CUT & CURL INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SAKE-DRINKING SLIPS IN JAPAN
abstract: Where matters of the pocketbook are concerned, the Japanese are said to be fiercely nationalistic. Yet a consumption trend is evident here that has the whiff of heresy to it.   The Japanese are drinking less sake.  Widely known as rice wine, sake is made in a process similar to the brewing of beer. It has been the drink of preference for centuries in Japan and it is an indispensable ingredient in the ritual and ceremonial life of this country. No Shinto or Buddhist wedding can be sealed without the betrothed exchanging and downing three nuptial cups of sake. And to any Westerner, no matter how naive concerning Japanese ways, sake is a symbol of Japan.

headline: GUARANTEE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: No Headline
abstract: 200,000 POLES END 22-DAY WILDCAT STRIKE BUT OTHER PROTESTS GO ON   WARSAW, Nov. 12 (UPI) - A 22-day wildcat strike by 200,000 factory and farm workers in the western province of Zielona Gora ended today after strike leaders agreed to drop a key demand.   But the end of the walkout, which was called over a variety of local issues, still left 250,000 Poles on strike, including 190,000 students who began sit-in protests across the country. The sit-ins were in sympathy with a student walkout in Radom, which began with a demand that an election to choose an engineering school dean be held again.

headline: Boeing to Modify 767 for Crew of 2
abstract: The Boeing Company said that it would modify the first production models of its new 767 series of aircraft to accommodate a flight deck crew of two rather than three.   Boeing, which said it will be able to meet its first deliveries, scheduled for July, despite the modifications, said the action was taken after consultation with several airlines that had originally requested the three-crew member configuration.   Earlier this year, a special safety panel appointed by President Reagan recommended that two-member flight-deck crews be permitted to operate Boeing's 757 and 767 series and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's DC-9/80 jetliners.

headline: PACIFIC REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CHINA SUGGESTS COMPROMISE ON U.N. JOB
abstract: China has tentatively proposed a compromise to settle the deadlocked race for Secretary General, suggesting that the next five-year term be divided between the incumbent, Kurt Waldheim of Austria, and Foreign Minister Salim A.  Salim of Tanzania.   United States officials said today that Peking had informally sounded out Security Council members on its compromise ideas. One version calls for Mr. Waldheim to be reappointed for two more years and for Mr. Salim to take over as Secretary General for the remaining three.

headline: Gillette to Shut Unit in Germany
abstract: The Gillette Company said that its subsidiary, Braun A.G., planned to close its plant in Munich, West Germany that makes movie cameras and equipment. About 450 employees would be dismissed, the company said. Braun previously agreed to sell the movie camera business to Robert Bosch G.m.b.H.   Braun said that so far it had been unable to find another company to use the Munich plant and planned to meet with representatives of its workers about closing the plant next year.

headline: DUTCH GROUP BUYS KEYES FROM ARCATA
abstract: The Arcata Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement to sell its Keyes Fiber Company unit, an international manufacturer of molded wood pulp and foam plastic containers, to a Dutch group, Royal Packaging Industries Van Leer B.V.   The companies said the cash purchase of Keyes's stock, which was not disclosed, was subject to certain conditions. Effective date of the sale is expected to be Dec. 31.

headline: Doing Business As
abstract: To the Business Editor: I must make one comment about what you said concerning a sole proprietorship in ''How to Structure Your Own Business'' (Sept. 20).  I refer to the staement that ''no legal forms or agreements need to be drawn up.''

headline: Around the World; One Killed and 4 Hurt In a Bombing in Belfast
abstract: A bomb exploded near the center of Belfast early today, killing a police officer and wounding three other officers and a civilian, the police said.   A spokesman at the Belfast police headquarters said the bomb had been hidden behind a fence and had probably been set off by remote control.   The spokesman, who in accordance with British police practice declined to be identified, said the explosion was heard over a wide area of the city and shattered windows of shops and homes in the area.

headline: Argentine Gas Project
abstract: A consortium of Argentine and American companies today announced plans to liquefy Argentine natural gas and export it to the United States. The project, valued at $2.3 billion, is subject to final approval by the authorities in Buenos Aires and Washington.

headline: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

headline: TAFT BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Aid for Afghan Refugees
abstract: The United Nations World Food Program said today that it would send an additional $12.2 million in emergency food aid for the 1.7 million Afghan refugees in Pakistan. The agency said the aid consisted of 44,000 tons of wheat and 2,000 tons of dates. Since January 1980, the program has provided $109 million in aid for the refugees, who fled to Pakistan after the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in December 1979.

headline: Around the World; Paper Links Saboteurs To Raid on Iraqi A-Plant
abstract: Israel's bombing attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor in Baghdad in June may have been a cover for explosives set inside the plant by undercover Israeli agents, The Sunday Times reported today. Quoting uni dentified Italian technicians who it said were employed at the reacto r when it was attacked by Israeli jets June 7, the papersaid the air attack may have been nothing more than a cover for an operation by saboteurs inside the complex.

headline: STOCK PRICES ARE CONTINUING RECOVERY
abstract: Stock prices edged higher yesterday on the heels of last week's sharp rally touched off by declining interest rates. Energy and railroad issues ranked among the better performers.   After showing a loss of 5 points early in the session, the Dow Jones industrial average finished at 888.98, producing a gain of 3.04 points. In the three previous sessions, the industrial average had climbed more than 34 points.

headline: Arafat Telegram Backs Group In Israel That Opposes Nation
abstract: Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has sent a telegram of support to an Orthodox Jewish group that opposes the nation of Israel, a spokesman for the group said today.

headline: REAGAN WARNS SOVIET ON AID
abstract: The following article is based on information arriving from Poland.   The Polish Government reported last night that seven people were killed Wednesday when policemen opened fire at a strikebound coal mine near Katowice in the southern industrial region of Silesia.   It was the first official confirmation of deaths in five days of resistance to martial law.  The Government also confirmed reports of widespread street clashes in the Baltic port city of Gdansk Wednesday night. The evening news broadcast said 160 policemen and 164 civilians were injured in Gdansk, where the Solidarity union movement was born in the summer of 1980.

headline: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RUMANIA'S ECONOMIC PROBLEMS BRING OUSTER OF THREE AIDES
abstract: Faced with his country's worst economic crisis in decades and signs of political discontent, President Nicolae Ceausescu has dismissed three long-serving colleagues in the ruling Communist Party.   They were two senior party figures, Virgil Trofin and Vasili Ogirlaci, who were expelled from the party's Central Committee late last month, and the local party secretary in a mining area, who was replaced. All were blamed for serious failures in the vitally important coal industry. One official said they had falsified production figures and tolerated inefficiency.

headline: GREEK SOCIALIST PREDICTS A VICTORY FOR HIS PARTY IN NEXT WEEK'S VOTE
abstract: After the largest rally of a heated campaign, the Socialist leader Andreas Papandreou confiden tly predicted her e today that his party would win ''a big majority'' in next Sunday's general election.   The unexpected intensity and enthusiasm of yesterday's reception of Mr. Papandreou in this center of the generally conservative northern Greece seemed to confirm latest opinion polls giving the Socialists 40 percent of the vote to 34 percent for the ruling conservative New Democracy Party.   Nevertheless, Prime Minister George Rallis said in an interview published today that the ''erosion'' of his party had been halted and that it would ''exceed its victory of 1977'' of 42 percent of the vote compared to 25 percent for Mr. Papandreou's Panhellenic Socialist Movement.

headline: ASSAILS DISPARITIES IN WEALTH
abstract: Javier Perez de Cuellar of Peru was sworn in as Secretary General today and called the gap in wealth between rich nations and poor a breach of ''the most fundamental human rights.''   The 61-year-old diplomat told the General Assembly he intended to ''provide impetus'' for global negotiations on transferring wealth from developed to developing countries.   But even as he spoke, negotiators agreed that they could make no further headway this year on planning global talks. The United States says it is ready only for preliminary talks and the developing countries want full-fledged bargaining.

headline: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PARK CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 11 Aswan Buildings Damaged In 3 Quakes but No One Dies
abstract: Three strong earthquakes damaged 11 buildings in Aswan yesterday and today but there were no reports of deaths, the Middle East News Agency said.   One quake in the city, which is about 600 miles south of Cairo and near the Aswan High Dam, occurred yesterday and the other two occurred today.

headline: PIERCE, S S, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Iranians Charged in Manila
abstract: Criminal charges have been filed against 68 Iranian students arrested after clashing with the authorities during demonstrations by supporters and opponents of the Teheran regime, the police said today. Six Iranians and two policemen were reported injured in the incident on Friday.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: In the last eight weeks the Grumman Corporation has discovered just how expensive fighting an unwanted takeover bid can be.  In its successful campaign to defeat the LTV Corporation's $450 million tender offer, Grumman spent more than $1.5 million in legal fees and $600,000 on newspaper advertising. The bills from its financial advisers are also expected to be steep.   But Grumman's out-of-pocket expenses do not reflect the full price of rebuffing LTV. After buying Grumman stock to keep it out of LTV's hands, Grumman and its allies have had to swallow some $25 million in paper losses. And, in a long-range sense, the battle with LTV has ended Grumman's aura of isolation on Long Island, where the aircraft manufacturer is by far the largest employer.

headline: OXOCO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOUTHWEST LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JAMES, FRED S, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: AMFAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: On Sunday, Oct. 4, a full brigade of the Palestine Liberation Organization, armed with tanks and artillery, made a mock attack against a settlement in Lebanon's   Bekka Valley. For the purpose of the exercise, the settlement represented a fortified Israeli village on the occupied West Bank.  The emergence of the P.L.O. as a conventional fighting force, armed by Libya and trained by Syria, is one reason why senior military officials in Israel are concerned over the duration of Israel's present military domination in the Middle East. Other reasons are the steady erosion of Israel's advantage in modern weapons and the stockpiling of Soviet arms in the region.

headline: NEW YORK STORES' SALES RISE ONLY 3.9%
abstract: New York City's seven largest department stores recorded their smallest sales gain in 18 months in October.  A spot-check found that the stores had an average sales rise of only 3.9 percent from October 1980, half the inflation rate in general retail merchandise. This meant that the retailers had a decline in the volume of sales last month.

headline: Patents; A Turbogenerator For Thermal Power
abstract: Sea Solar Power Inc., York, Pa., a pioneer in ocean thermal energy conversion, received a patent this week for a turbogenerator to be used in a thermal power plant. The equipment is regarded as important because of its compactness.

headline: Salvadoran Army Units Start Major Campaign
abstract: The Government said today that 1,500 troops had begun a major operation in Morazan Province, a mountainous region in northeast El Salvador where rebels control extensive territory.   The Government said a key goal of the drive was to open roads between isolated villages in a region some 125 miles northeast of San Salvador.   Guerrillas have dominated the mountainous region near the Honduran border for about a year.

headline: Business Conditions; SOVIET TRADE WEAKENS
abstract: A sharp cut in Western demand for Soviet oil, coupled with a rise in grain imports, weakened Moscow's trade position with industrialized countries during the first half of the year.   Through June, the Soviet Union's trade deficit with the West more than doubled from a year earlier, to $3.7 billion, recently released Soviet trade figures show.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HOW COPENHAGEN IS COPING
abstract: Election morning brought snow, which quickly packed down into slippery ice. Here and there among the avalanche of bicycles sweeping past Parliament, one would skid, pop into the air like a bedspring come loose, and send its rider sprawling.   The Danes have been coping with winter for a long time, but they are not ruthlessly efficient about it. There was no particular drive to get the streets clear. The snow was tolerated, like a difference of opinion. The street machines sprinkled a little salt, the buses drifted and skidded, and the pedestrians made their way up and down the small white drifts around the bronze statue of Archbishop Absalon.

headline: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The economy is sliding deeper into recession, but still has a long way to go before reaching bottom, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its latest monthly survey. The members, who are the executives who buy goods and services for the nation's businesses, also said that falling prices from suppliers indicated more downward pressure on inflation. (Page D1.)

headline: KRATOS ACQUISITION
abstract: Kratos Inc., the high-technology instrument and analytical-equipment concern, said that it had agreed to buy about two-thirds of the Keuffel & Easer Company of Morristown, N.J., a maker of drafting and engineering instruments, at $31 a share cash, or about $35 million.

headline: ...AND THE OLD
abstract: As long ago as last spring, the common wisdom in Warsaw was that Stanislaw Kania was finished after only seven months as the leader of Poland's Communist Party. He had failed to halt the endless strikes and economic crises that had brought down his predecessor, Edward Gierek, and the death knell of his own leadership was being tolled in Moscow.   Mr. Kania did not reverse the downhill slide of the economy or bring the independent trade union Solidarity to heel. But he managed to hang on for another six months until yesterday, when he was replaced by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski.

headline: HELIX TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: INVENTORIES UP BY 0.7% IN AUGUST
abstract: Inventory stockpiles held by United States businesses climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent in August as sales fell 1 percent in a new sign of a flat or declining national economy, the Commerce Department reported today.   The inventory-to-sales ratio rose in August to 1.43 from July's 1.41, meaning it would take about 1.43 months to sell off inventories at the current pace of sales.   The ratio is still relatively low by historical standards, but it has been rising steadily since declining to a record low of 1.37 in January and now is approaching the 1.48 of August 1980.

headline: HUNGARY'S 'OFFSHORE' BANK
abstract: One of the most encouraging sights a Western banker or executive will see in Eastern Europe these days lies up two flights of stairs in a squat office building at 54 Bartfai Utca, a dreary street in suburban Budapest lined with workers' apartments.   Situated here are the offices of the Central European International Bank Ltd., a novel partnership between Hungary's central bank, which is strongly committed to free enterprise, and six private Western banks from Austria, West Germany, Italy, France and Japan.   It is East Europe's only ''offshore'' bank, free from Hungarian supervision, taxes and controls. It is also the only joint venture in Eastern Europe between Communist and Western financial institutions in which the Western investors have the largest shareholding.

headline: U.S. INTENSIFIES DRIVE AGAINST WORLD PRESS CURBS
abstract: Bolstered by the Government's warning to Unesco against supporting moves to regulate journalists, American and international press groups believe they are now in a better position to deflect a campaign for what has become known as a new world information order.   However, those who monitor the world's press in support of journalistic freedoms say the battle is far from over.  ''In Unesco you have a built-in majority of governments that control the press,'' said Dana Bullen, a former foreign editor of The Washington Star, who became executive director of the World Press Freedom Committee on Oct. 1. ''But a great many bad things have been slowed down or held off.''

headline: LEVITT PLANS VENEZUELAN HOUSING
abstract: William J. Levitt, the builder behind Levittown, L.I., and other housing developments, and a Venezuelan group have agreed to build a $700 million, low-income housing project in Venezuela, and are seeking $20 million or $25 million in preliminary financing from United States banks for it, an aide to Mr. Levitt said yesterday.   Edward Cortese, a vice president of Mr. Levitt's Long-Island based International Community Corporation, said the financing would be used to purchase property for the project, which is to be near Valencia, a city in northern Venezuela, 75 miles southwest of Caracas.   Mr. Cortese said that the outlook for obtaining the American bank financing was ''extremely good,'' but that he could not say which banks it would come from.

headline: Around the World; Shcharansky Reported To Be Back in Prison
abstract: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Jewish dissident, has been transferred from a labor camp to the strictregime prison where he began his 13-year sentence on a conviction of spying for the United States and of anti-Soviet activities, sources close to his family said today.   The sources said they did not know the reason for his transfer Nov. 3 to a prison in Chistopol.  Mr. Shcharansky, 33 years old, was originally sent to the prison after his conviction in July 1978.

headline: Mortgage Rate R ises to 17.71%
abstract: The average interest rate charged Americans for new home loans rose to a record 17.71 percent in September for long-term, fixed-rate mortgages, the Government said today. It was the seventh consecutive monthly increase in interest rates for home loans.

headline: 39 POLES QUIT SHIPS AT PORT IN AFRICA
abstract: Thirty-nine Polish seamen from a fishing fleet docked at Walvis Bay in South-West Africa have jumped ship and asked for political asylum in South Africa, the South African Interior Minister, J. Chris Heunis, said yesterday.   The disclosure raised to at least 118 the number of Poles who have defected from ships in ports around the world. The number includes 15 in Japan and 64 in Canadian, Norwegian and Italian ports.

headline: Around the World; Zimbabwe Seizes M.P.  And Reports Coup Plot
abstract: The Government announced tonight that a white Member of Parliament had been detained in connection with what it said was a coup conspiracy.   The person was not identified, but the all-white Republican Front of former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said one of its M.P.'s, Wally Stuttaford, a retired railway worker, was arrested Thursday in his home city of Bulawayo.

headline: COMMUNISM AND BETTER LIFE: POLES FOUND WAIT TOO LONG
abstract: John Darnton, who has been chief of The New York Times bureau in Warsaw since September 1979, reports in the following article on the problems underlying the crisis in Poland.   WARSAW - Behind the workers' revolt that began with strikes in the summer of 1980 and grew to a revolution on the shoulders of the Solidarity union, the operation of which was suspended when martial law was declared, lies a story of failure. It is the failure of Communism, in the eyes of the workers, to deliver on its promise of a better life.   The revolt sprang from an unspoken consensus among Poles that despite more than three decades of sacrifice and toil, conditions of everyday life were scarcely improving and that the Communist system had failed most dramatically in precisely those areas, in the realm of social welfare, where its ideology called for greater exertion and improvement.   Appalling dirt and safety conditions in factories, cramped and unavailiable appartments, substandard and sloppy health care, lines in front of meat shops - food shortages in general despite a stringent rationing system - these were the distingushing traits of what the Government referred to as ''people's Poland.'' They were glossed over, ignored or denied by successive governments that pressed instead for higher production statistics in heavy industry.

headline: New Head Appointed For Durkee Foods
abstract: Ron Bowen, 40, will join Durkee Industrial Foods, a refiner of edible oils, on Jan. 4 as president. He will succeed Robert E.  Dorfmeyer, 65, who will retire from the Cleveland-based division of the SCM Corporation at the end of that month.

headline: Market Place; Boesky Plan For Vagabond
abstract: the-counter company two-thirds owned by the Ivan F. Boesky family, is likely to be four-fifths owned by it soon.   Until Ivan F. Boesky sold his arbitrage business some months back to pursue other business interests, he was one of Wall Street's best-known risk-takers. But Mr. Boesky appears to risk little in seeking added shares of Vagabond, a motel operator, for the Beverly Hills Hotel Corporation, which he and his wife control.   Vagabond proposes to raise $2.8 million through the sale of 708,000 shares of convertible preferred stock at $4 a share. A special meeting to vote on the plan is scheduled three days before Christmas at 10 A.M. in San Diego. Approval is a foregone conclusion since the Boesky interests already have enough votes to win.

headline: G.M. to Lay Off 37,500 for Week
abstract: The General Motors Corporation, hit by bulging inventories and slumping sales, said today that it would temporarily lay off 37,500 workers at eight assembly plants across the country.   The auto maker said that 27,200 workers will be idled temporarily during the week of Jan. 4, the first week following the holiday shutdown, while 10,300 will be laid off the following week.

headline: AMID THE LAWLESSNESS IN LEBANON, HASHISH TRADE FLOURISHES
abstract: The harvest is on in the Bekaa Valley, some of the most fertile land in the Middle East, and workers in the broad fields are bringing in another record crop of Lebanon's biggest cash export - hashish.   Some 80 percent of the cultivated land in the Upper Bekaa and the hills of Hermil just to the north are now planted in hashish. The development is attributed to the breakdown of authority since the outbreak of the civil war six years ago, which created a lawlessness that has complemented the Lebanese sense of untrammeled free enterprise.   ''Before the war, only 10 percent of the land was in hashish, and they planted corn around it to hide it,'' a young businessman here said. ''Now, it is everywhere.''

headline: SPAIN'S CHIEF NAMES NEW AIDES IN A BID TO END PARTY STRIFE
abstract: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo shuffled his Cabinet tonight in an attempt to patch up quarrels in the governing party. He appointed two deputy prime ministers, brought in six new ministers and replaced two ministers given top party jobs.

headline: CROP PRICES PAID TO FARMERS FALL
abstract: Prices paid to farmers for their crops fell 2.2 percent in September, cutting the buying power of the income received to its lowest point in nearly half a century, the Agriculture Department said today.   The decline also marked the second month in a row that prices have averaged below the levels of a year earlier, after 14 months of increases. At the same time, the prices farmers must pay to meet expenses remained unchanged from August's record level.

headline: Around the World; San Salvador Terrorists Set Off Five Bombs
abstract: Five bombs exploded in this capital city today, damaging a shopping center, two banks, a restaurant and a construction materials company, the authorities reported.

headline: 70 Dead in Chinese Floods
abstract: Seventy people died and many thousands were made homeless in recent floods in the Zhanjiang district of Guangdong Province.

headline: Advertising; McDonald's Switching To Burnett
abstract: THE Chicago advertising community was shocked yesterday to learn that the $75 million McDonald's Corporation account for national advertising will be going to the Leo Burnett Company, leaving behind the Chicago office of Needham, Harper & Steers and years of awardwinning advertising.   ''We were stunned, we can't believe it,'' said B. Blair Vedder Jr., chairman of the executive committee at Needham.  He said that Needham heard the first report about 10 days ago that McDonald's would possibly move to Burnett. And when his people went to officials of the fast-food chain to ask about the report, he said, they suddenly began to get complaints about service that had not been voiced before. None of those complaints, Mr. Vedder said, were grevious enough to switch an account.

headline: TECHNOLOGY ON BRITISH FARMS
abstract: One of Britain's few economic success stories can be illustrated dramatically through the simple statistics recorded by farmers such as Oliver Cooper.   Ten years ago, Mr. Cooper's 1,250-acre farm yielded less than 2.3 tons of wheat from each acre. This year, he expects his yield to reach 4.2 tons an acre.   While the 36-year-old Mr. Cooper has been particularly successful, he is by no means alone. In recent years, farmers here in East Anglia, a flat farming region northeast of London, and elsewhere in Britain have solidified their position as among the most efficient major producers in the world.

headline: Creative Media Plans Newspaper Ad Service
abstract: In a speech to the New England Newspaper Association in Providence, R.I., Thursday, Douglas K. Burch, president of Creative Media Services, Wilton, Conn., will announce a new service, the Newsprint Network.   It will the long-sought-after one-order, one-bill service for advertisers or their agencies interested in run-of-press national advertising programs.

headline: Better Auto Sales Seen DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP)
abstract: New-car sales could increase 16 percent and truck sales could jump 30 percent in 1982 if the overall economy grows and interest rates continue their decline, the president of the Ford Motor Company, Donald E. Petersen, said today.   ''I am neither an optimist nor a pessimist,'' Mr. Petersen told a joint meeting of the Economic Club of Detroit and the Greater Detroit Chamber of Commerce. ''I think I am, however, a realist, and I believe the U.S. auto industry is basically much stronger than a lot of people say it is.''

headline: 20% Interest On Tax Bills
abstract: Delinquent taxpayers will be charged 20 percent interest on their outstanding bills, and those who overpay will collect interest at the same rate starting Feb. 1, the Internal Revenue Service announced today.   The agency said it was raising the interest rate from 12 percent, in compliance with the tax act passed during the summer.
