abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: URUGUAY HITS SNAGS IN PLANNING 1984 ELECTION
abstract: Early problems have arisen in Uruguay's effort to restore representative government, with military leaders and politicians accusing each other of obstructing discussions.   Gen. Gregorio Alvarez, the former army commander who took over the presidency on Sept. 1, was appointed by the country's leading officers to try to arrange free and open general elections before his term expires in March 1985.   Consultations began immediately with the country's two traditional political groups, the Colorado and Blanco Parties, on setting up talks to restore political freedoms suspended when the military took over in 1973.   The talks have stalled, with politicians saying that the military has not clearly defined its program and the military countering that disagreements in the parties have prevented them from agreeing on representatives for the discussions.

headline: VW of America Expects Sales Rise
abstract: Volkswagen of America Inc. predicts sales of 330,000 cars in 1982, up 14 percent from this year's depressed levels, its president, James McLernon, said in a year-end statement. Mr. McLernon also said that production at the company plant in Sterling Heights, Mich., could begin in the spring of 1983 if market conditions improved.   Mr. McLernon said that 1981 would be remembered as ''one of the most difficult years in our nation's history related to economic planning and the business cycle.''

headline: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MORGAN, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ITT Continental Trade Complaint
abstract: The ITT Continental Baking Company has been charged with violating fair trade laws in the operations of its former Gwaltney meatpacking division, the Agriculture Department said today.   The department complaint stated that when ITT Continental owned the meatpacking concern, Gwaltney gave preferential treatment to certain food stores in violation of the Federal Packers and Stockyards Act, which is designed to promote fair competition in the marketing of meat.   Officials charged that from 1978 to 1980, ITT Continental paid for vacation trips for retail food store employees who were responsible for buying meat for their stores.

headline: MILTON ROY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Antigua Joins the U.N.
abstract: Antigua and Barbuda, the Caribbean nation that attained independence from Britain on Nov. 1, has become the 157th member of the United Nations.

headline: Chinese to See Reagan
abstract: Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China will meet with President Reagan on Friday for talks expected to include the subject of arms sales to Peking, the State Department said today.

headline: U.S. Debt Past $1 Trillion
abstract: The national debt passed the $1 trillion mark today, Treasury Department officials confirmed, but the acknowledgement came with little fanfare. ''It's not an issue for celebration,'' a spokesman said.

headline: Curbs on Oil Imports Urged
abstract: Democrats introduced legislation in the House and Senate today to ban Government imports of Libyan oil in retaliation for what they say is Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's support for international terrorism. The legislation would affect only Libyan oil bought for the Government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

headline: SHELL OIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mack Trucks
abstract: Mack Trucks Inc. may shut its Hagerstown plant for five days in January, according to an official of the United Automobile Workers union. Dave Smith, president of Hagerstown auto workers Local 171 said Mack Trucks officials had notified the union of the possible closing, which would affect most of the work force. A Mack spokesman at the truck maker's Allentown, Pa., headquarters declined to comment on the possibility of a shutdown in January.

headline: Officer Appointed, By RKO General
abstract: Hubert J. DeLynn, 60 years old, has been named vice chairman and chief operations officer of RKO General Inc., which operates four television and 12 radio stations, including WOR-TV, WOR-AM and WXLO-FM in New York. He succeeds John B. Poor Sr., who retired last July at the age of 66 after 29 years with the company, a New York-based unit of the General Tire and Rubber Company. Thomas F.  O'Neil, 66, continues as chairman and chief executive officer, and Frank Shakespeare, a 56-year-old former director of the United States Information Agency, remains president.

headline: WORD PROCESSORS SPELL OUT A NEW ROLE FOR CLERICAL STAFF
abstract: T HE growing business reliance on word processors, those small computers with typewriterlike keyboards designed to complete routine reports and other rote clerical chores, has barely begun, but it already is having a profound effect on the office of the present as well as the future.   Authors, including the novelist John Hersey and Jimmy Carter, working on an autobiography, have abandoned their typewriters in favor of them. Instead of employing secretaries to retype drafts, complete footnotes and number pages, authors are accomplishing these chores by touching a few keys.   Where there was one word processor for every 10 clerical workers last year, by mid-decade the figure will be one for every three.  However, the machines, experts believe, are not likely to lessen the demand for clerical workers in the 1980's. The use of the processors by small as well as large employers is expected to give secretaries more time and opportunity to perform duties now completed by managers. If this happens, experts believe, the serious shortage of secretaries may subside and the gap in wages between executives and secretaries may narrow.

headline: Japanese-British Trade
abstract: The leader of the Japanese economic mission said today that Japan and Britain must cooperate to strengthen trade between the two countries.

headline: TV Ad Bureau Head
abstract: At the annual meeting yesterday of the Television Bureau of Advertising in Miami Beach, David E. Henderson, president of Outlet Broadcasting in Providence, R.I., was elected chairman. He succeeds Thomas B. Cookerly, president-broadcast division of Allbritton Communications in Washington, D.C., who held the post for the past two years.

headline: 4,000 at a Mass for the Poles Hear Cooke Condemn Deaths
abstract: Terence Cardinal Cooke today denounced the bloodshed and death in Poland and called on lovers of freedom everywhere to express their support for the Polish people.   Speaking to more than 4,000 people who crowded into St. Patrick's Cathedral for a special mass for Poland, Cardinal Cooke condemned the ''inhumane detention and deportation'' in Poland.

headline: B.P. Rejects Kuwait Offer
abstract: The British Petroleum Company today confirmed that Kuwait, trying to increase its exports of crude oil, had offered easier credit terms that would reduce the effective price by $1 a barrel, to $34.50.   But British Petroleum said it had rejected the offer as inadequate.

headline: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.N. Refugee Chief Willing to Serve Again
abstract: Poul Hartling, a former Prime Minister of Denmark, said today that he would accept a renewal of his mandate as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees next year if reelected by the General Assembly.

headline: FURTHER RETRENCHMENT IS SCHEDULED BY A.&P.
abstract: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company announced yesterday that it planned to close or sell unprofitable stores and manufacturing plants and would finance the ensuing write-off by drawing $200 million from an overfunded pension plan.   The financially struggling food chain, which last week reported a fiscal second-quarter loss of $11.4 million on sales of $1.7 billion, declined to specify which of its 1,500 stores and 16 plants would be disposed of either through closing them or selling them in what it called ''a revitalization program.''   An A.& P. spokesman said that the facilities to be disposed of were still under study with the objective ''of affecting the least number of employees.'' But executives of competitive food chains said reports persisted that a large number of A.& P. stores in the metropolitan area would be shut.

headline: Prospects
abstract: Sagging Sales   'Tis the season to be jolly, but consumers seem anything but. Even though disposable incomes are rising -a rare event during periods of economic decline - concern about unemployment lines, not visions of sugarplums, are dancing through shoppers' heads. Fearful of the consequences, retailers are sacrificing profit margins to secure sales, and are discounting heavily. As a result, Christmas sales should rise 10 percent to 12 percent from a year earlier, say Elizabeth Allison and Evan Barrington, economists at Data Resources.  Yet sharp declines in durable goods purchases should cause fourthquarter retail sales to fall to an inflation-adjusted $135 billion. Moreover, the deepening recession and increased savings incentives should lead to further real declines through the first half of 1982. While this will stymie economic recovery in the short run, the longterm benefits may outweigh the costs. The longer consumer demand remains weak, the more inflation is likely to ease. Tough Trade Talks   Like oil and water, recessions and free trade don't mix. Amid rising cries from Congress and industry to consider new trade curbs, two United States delegations will be traveling abroad this week trying to smooth out long-standing disputes with officials from the Common Market and Japan.

headline: Schmidt in U.S. for Vacation; Will Meet With Reagan Jan. 5
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and his wife flew to the United States today for a 10-day vacation on the Florida island of Sanibel in the Gulf of Mexico.   Mr. Schmidt is scheduled to travel to Washington for a private meeting with President Reagan on Jan. 5.  Officials said earlier that the Chancellor might cancel his vacation plans because of the crisis in Poland, but his departure on schedule seemed to show Bonn's determination to take the Polish developments in its stride.

headline: GREECE CURTAILING ITS RENEWED ROLE IN NATO COMMAND
abstract: Greece told the Atlantic alliance today that it was partly suspending its return to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's military command and said it had already begun a disengagement process from certain alliance commitments.   The statement was made by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, the country's newly elected Socialist leader, at a meeting of the alliance's defense ministers, and was repeated later at a news conference.   An American official, who spoke with the understanding that his name not be used, said Mr. Papandreou's reference to a partial suspension would probably compromise all Greek involvement in NATO's integrated military structure. Arrangement 'Unacceptable'   Greece left the alliance's military command in 1974 in the wake of the Turkish invasion of Cyprus, returning in November 1980 under an agreement approved by the centrist Government that was ousted from power by Mr. Papandreou in October. The arrangement that brought Greece back into the military structure is referred to as the Rogers Agreement because it was worked out in part by Gen. Bernard Rogers, the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe. It was described by Mr.  Papandreou today as ''militarily and politically unacceptable.''

headline: THE SUBTLE CONTROL OF A VAST FORTUNE
abstract: PHILADELPHIA S IX years before his death in 1971 at age 93, J. Howard Pew, chairman of the Sun Oil Company and patriarch of the Pew family, whose fortune controlled the company, would call his 29-year-old greatnephew into his office. There, in a ritual that occurred every other day for about a month and lasted exactly one hour, R. Anderson Pew would be grilled about religion, his life goals and politics.   When the sessions finally ended, the young man universally known as Andy, who was working in Sun's treasurer's office, was named to the board of the Glenmede Trust Company. Glenmede, the sole trustee of the Pew Memorial Trust whose $1.16 billion in assets makes it the nation's second-largest charitable trust after the Ford Foundation, is the main repository of the assets of the Pew family, estimated to be among the 10 wealthiest families in the country.   Now at age 45, Andy Pew is chairman of the powerful committee that disperses charitable contributions for Glenmede, and is considered the head of the Pews in business and foundation matters. Like his great-uncle, he is a devout Presbyterian and a Republican, but those convictions no longer have the impact they had when J. Howard stamped his moralist imprint on the management and the spending of the Pew fortune. Andy sees himself as a ''communication link'' between Sun and the Pew family, whose more than 1,000 members are scattered around the United States.

headline: Marketers Resist Mobil
abstract: Several independent gasoline marketers have lined up against the Mobil Corporation in its fight in Federal appeals court here to win control of the Marathon Oil Company.   The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit scheduled arguments for Thursday on Mobil's appeal of two lower court rulings against the company's bid to acquire Marathon, based in Findlay, Ohio, for $6.5 billion.

headline: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BANGOR HYDRO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: I.M.F. PUTS PRESSURE ON BANGLADESH
abstract: The International Monetary Fund, which has recently come under pressure from the Reagan Administration to tighten its lending policies, has cracked down on one of the poorest countries in the world - Bangladesh.   The I.M.F. suspended payments in July on a three-year $912 million loan given to Bangladesh only seven months before. The fund cited that country's failure to cut Government spending and scale back food subsidy programs.   As a result of the suspension, Bangladesh has lost $100 million in funds it had expected this year, forcing the Government to line up $200 million in short-term credits with several commercial finance companies, including American Express, Manufacturers Hanover Trust and Morgan Guaranty.

headline: BANKS HAIL 2 PLANS FOR BROKER TIE
abstract: This week's move by two big California banks into the exclusive preserve of the securities industry - buying and selling stocks - has drawn a mixture of applause and raised eyebrows from bankers around the nation. Some praise its boldness, and some wonder about its legality.   The two institutions - the BankAmerica Corporation, owner of the Bank of America, the largest bank in the United States, and the Security Pacific National Bank, the nation's ninth-largest commercial bank - announced different plans to enter stock trading through ties with brokerage firms.   The first step came late Tuesday, when BankAmerica said it planned to acquire Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage house, for $53 million. Schwab has 210,000 customers, and its revenues total about $42 million a year. It has 38 offices across the country.

headline: BROADCASTER STARTS UP FINANCIAL TV NETWORK
abstract: Today is a red-letter day for Glen H. Taylor, a 56-year-old businessman with a variety of programming and television interests: His Financial News Network, a five-day-a-week, seven-hour-a-day television service, begins broadcasting on 13 stations around the country in an effort to expand the availability of business news to the public.   ''I believe that the whole United States is focusing on the financial condition not only of the economy, but also of the individual,'' said Mr. Taylor in a telephone interview from his Santa Monica, Calif., headquarters. ''You're going to find that a lot of businessmen will take that black-and-white TV set out of the children's bedroom and haul it into the office for this.''

headline: KEY ZAPATA STRATEGY: SHIFTING OF ASSETS
abstract: Back in 1952 George Bush, now Vice President of the United States, and J. Hugh Liedtke, now chairman of the Pennzoil Company, were sitting around their offices in the west Texas oil town of Midland, wondering what to name their fledgling drilling business.   They wanted something that would attract attention, something exotic, something that began with A or Z so it would be easy to find in the phone book. Marlon Brando and Anthony Quinn had just made a hit movie called ''Viva Zapata!''   So Zapata it became, and the company has been attracting attention ever since. By 1966, when both Mr. Bush and Mr. Liedtke had sold their interests, the Zapata Corporation had become one of the world's biggest offshore drilling contractors.

headline: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Sept 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: A.T.& T. Told To Pay MCI
abstract: A Federal Communications Commission law judge today ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to pay almost $1 million to MCI Communications Inc. for refusing to lease certain phone circuits in 1975 when MCI was trying to start its long-distance service.   Depending on the outcome of a lawsuit pending in California, however, MCI might end up having to turn over the $931,880 it was awarded to the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, a Bell System company owned by A.T.& T.   A.T.& T. said it would appeal to the full F.C.C. the decision by the F.C.C. administrative law judge, Joseph Chachkin.

headline: STUDY SEES RISK IN SALE OF SANTA FE
abstract: A Congressional research group has concluded that the prospective purchase by Kuwait of the Santa Fe International Corporation, which has a subsidiary that specializes in nuclear technology, could complicate efforts by the United States to stop the spread of atomic weapons.   The 11-page report, prepared by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment, found that nuclear and military-related work carried out by C.F. Braun & Company, a subsidiary acquired by Santa Fe in 1980, ''would be of use to any nation that wishes to produce nuclear weapons.''   C.F. Braun performed major design and engineering work between 1971 and 1981 at the Department of Energy's nuclear weapons plant at Rocky Flats, Colo. The company currently is performing what the report called ''general'' engineering services at the Hanford Reservation in Washington State, where facilities are being modified to increase the production of plutonium, a man-made fissionable material used in nuclear weapons.

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 3 P.M. and 8 P.M.   Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Competition Narrows For Hallmark Cards
abstract: The competition for the $12 million-to-$15 million Hallmark Cards account has now been narrowed to Foote, Cone & Belding of Chicago, the incumbent; the Leo Burnett Company, also of Chicago, and Young & Rubicam and Ogilvy & Mather, both of New York.   It is understood that the advertiser will be giving each agency $80,000 to do a television spot.  Foote, Cone has had the account for 37 years.

headline: Experts Divided Over Fed Policy
abstract: Monetary policy makers of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee will meet this week, and analysts do not agree about whether the Fed will continue to pump money into the banking system - a move that would cause short-term interes rates to fall.   ''I don't think the Fed will make another move to ease at the coming F.O.M.C. meeting,'' said Elliott Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette Securities Corporation. ''They will not change much until they get more economic statistics and learn how much the money supply increased in the last week of September and first week of October.''   Others, however, think that that the Federal Reserve will pay more attention to the weakening economy and vote in favor of continuing to supply more credit to the banking system. Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said in the Oct.3 issue of Comments on Credit that the Fed will ignore rapid growh in broadly defined measures of the money supply and focus its poli cy on stimulating moregrowth in M-1 B, the basic money supply.

headline: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TEXT OF CARTER'S SPEECH ATTACKING FOREIGN POLICY OF REAGAN ADMINISTRATION
abstract: Following is the prepared text of the speech by former President Jimmy Carter yesterday to the Council on Foreign Relations in New York.   With the possible exception of my two predecessors, I know better than anyone how complicated and intransigent are some of the foreign policy questions that confront a President. I also know from firsthand experience about innate human fallibility, even among those of us who have served in the Oval Office.   International problems often survive over long periods of time.  Harry Truman is my favorite among the Presidents I remember, and I made a special study of the challenges he faced and his reaction to them. It was surprising how many of the same ones I inherited in some form or another, all the way from Israel to China, and including nuclear weapons, energy, Iran and especially human rights.

headline: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Salvadorans Extending Martial Law for 30 Days
abstract: The junta announced yesterday that it was extending martial law for another 30 days, but said it was exempting seven right-wing and centrist parties from bans on freedom of the press and expression.

headline: SALVADORAN REFUGEES SUFFER AS WAR SPILLS INTO HONDURAS
abstract: Most of the 3,000 Salvadoran peasants who fled to this narrow river gorge came to escape bombing raids and artillery attacks by the Salvadoran Army during their operations to dislodge guerrillas from mountain strongholds.   About 8,000 other refugees are scattered in the surrounding hills.  Life in these camps has been hard, but the peasants had at least escaped the war.   But a few days ago, Salvadoran soldiers invaded refugee camps in Honduras, according to the peasants.  There were about 40 soldiers here, they said. Most were in full combat gear; others, dressed in civilian clothes, carried automatic weapons and wore military boots. The peasants also said they recognized some of the men as being members of Orden, a rural civil defense force in El Salvador that is more feared than the regular army.

headline: DEATH TOLL REACHES 48 IN MEXICO
abstract: The death toll in the collapse of a wall at a rally in a bullring where a politician was promising free stoves and refrigerators climbed to 48 today.   Red Cross and rescue workers said 70 people were injured when the wall collapsed last night in Merida, 1,100 miles southeast of Mexico City.

headline: FACTORY ORDERS OF IN OCTOBER
abstract: New orders for goods from the nation's factories tumbled 5.2 percent in October, the largest one-month decline since April 1980, when the nation was in a recession, the Commerce Department reported today.   The October decline, the third consecutive monthly drop, was principally a result of a 9.1 percent fall in new orders in the durable goods industries, which include appliances, autos, machinery and other goods with a life of three years or more. The durable goods decline was the biggest one-month drop since December 1974, a period of recession. The department had earlier estimated the October durable goods decline at 8 percent.

headline: SALVADORAN URGES FOREIGN MEDIATION
abstract: A Salvadoran opposition leader said Tuesday that the alliance of political groups and guerrilla forces opposed to the ruling junta was ready to discuss ''a political solution'' to the civil war if the Government removed its conditions for a cease-fire.   In a speech at Yale University, Hector Oqueli said the fighting had reached a stalemate, with the Government unable to maintain control.  President Jose Napoleon Duarte's offer to hold cease-fire talks is unrealistic, Mr. Oqueli said, because it is conditional on the willingness of the guerrillas to lay down their arms. Instead, Mr.  Oqueli called for international mediation.

headline: Student Strikes Spread In Polish Universities
abstract: (UPI) - Student strikes continued to spread across Poland today, closing two-thirds of the universities and a dozen high schools.   A total of 55,000 students were occupying university buildings at 81 campuses to demand the ouster of a newly appointed rector at the Radom Engineering School, a student spokesman said.   Farmer ferment continued and Jan Kulaj, the leader of the farm union, met with Deputy Prime Minister Roman Malinowski over grievances that have prompted sit-ins in four towns.

headline: Diagnostic Data Elects President-Chief Officer
abstract: After an extended two-year proxy contest that resulted in the formation of a new board of directors last September, Diagnostic Data Inc. has elected Dr. L. James Strand, 40, as president and chief executive officer.   And yesterday, Henry Lerman, 52, who led the dissident stockholder group that wound up with five of the eight board seats, explained why he spent his time trying to win control of the Mountain View, Calif., pharmaceutical company, which makes an anti-inflammatory drug whose generic name is orgotein.   ''You can't be afraid of competition, for it just spurs you on to do bigger and better things,'' he said. ''We want to see if we can further develop this drug, which we feel can make a contribution to mankind. And we hope to make a profit, because we have 10,000 shareholders and that is what they have invested for.''

headline: United Brands May Sell A &W
abstract: The United Brands Company announced that it was negotiating the sale of its A & W Restaurants subsidiary to a corporation headed by Alfred Taubman, one of its company directors.   The company said in a statement that it expected the sale to be completed by the end of November.

headline: TRANSIT FARE CUTS DIVIDING LONDON'S LEADERS
abstract: The people who govern London are locked in a bitter legal dispute about a very basic subject - bus and subway fares.   At a time when the price of almost everything else is going up sharply, the fares were reduced last month by an average of 25 percent, with the deficit made up by higher real estate taxes. But a successful court challenge to the reduction has now thrown the case into the House of Lords.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: When Miet Jan Faber, leader of the Dutch peace movement, wrote to rally similar groups around Europe earlier this year, every country answered him except France.   Last month, when hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in London, Rome and Brussels, the turnout in Paris was estimated at no more than 30,000 to 50,000, and the great bulk of them were Communist groups marching under party discipline and banners.   This week, when France's Defense Minister, Charles Hernu, presented the Government's defense plans to the National Assembly, the conservative opposition stayed away. It was not really a protest. The opposition is making a point of letting no Assembly session go by without vigorously attacking the Socialists and on defense it found it had virtually nothing to object to.

headline: Veterinarian Publications
abstract: Medical Economics of Oradell, N.J., a subsidiary of International Thomson Business Press, has acquired the Veterinary Medicine Publishing Company of Edwardsville, Kan., and will merge into it Veterinary Economics, a publication it acquired Nov. 12 from the United Publishing Corporation in Cleveland.

headline: QUEBEC, GENERAL DYNAMICS SET PACT ON ASBESTOS CONTROL
abstract: The Quebec government yesterday moved closer to its long-range goal of nationalizing the Montreal-based Asbestos Corporation Ltd. with an agreement to purchase voting control of the company from its American owner, the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis, for $16 million in Canadian currency.   Under the agreement, the government will receive 51 percent of the voting shares of General Dynamics Canada Ltd., the wholly owned subsidiary of the General Dynamics Corporation that holds 54.6 percent of the Asbestos Corporation stock, within the next five years.   The agreement does not give the provincial government any equity in Asbestos, but provides it with an option to buy, in a separate transaction at the end of the five-year period, the 1.6 million shares of Asbestos now held by General Dynamics Canada, Quebec's Finance Minister, Jacques Parizeau, and the Provincial Resources Minister, Yves Duhaime, said in a joint statement yesterday.   This arrangement falls short of the government's intention, first expressed four years ago by Premier Rene Levesque, to buy or, if necessary, expropriate 100 percent of the company. Asbestos is the second-largest producer of asbestos fibers in Quebec, which accounts for the vast majority of the free world's output of the mineral.

headline: Citicorp Plans A New Note
abstract: Citicorp, the parent of Citibank, announced yesterday that it would offer a new type of short-term, floating-rate debt instrument to institutional and corporate investors, beginning on Thursday. The holding company said its new notes would be issued in variable amounts.

headline: Chase Planning Appeal
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it would appeal a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit that would enable 11 Vietnamese to recover about $450,000, plus 26.5 percent interest, that had been on deposit at its Saigon branch.   The funds, in local currency, were lost when the Chase closed the branch six days before the city fell to the Communists on April 30, 1975.

headline: EGYPT DISMISSES 134 IN THE ARMY SUSPECTED OF 'EXTREMIST LEANINGS'
abstract: Thirty Egyptian officers and 104 enlisted men have been dismissed from the army and transferred to civilian jobs because of suspected ''extremist religious leanings,'' the army command announced today.   Lieut. Gen. Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, the Defense Minister, told Mayo, the official newspaper of the ruling National Democratic Party, that the transfers were ordered during the last few days as part of the measures taken after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat. He stressed that the men involved had ''no connection'' with the Oct. 6 assassination but were dismissed as part of a drive to ''rid the armed forces of any form of religious fanaticism.''   The leader of the group that killed Mr. Sadat during an army parade has been identified as Lieut. Khaled Ahmed Shawki al-Istanbuli, and his accomplices have been identified as extremist members of the armed forces. The official version is that there were four assailants. But in his statement to Mayo today, General Abu Ghazala hinted that several others could have been involved. He said that Mr. Istanbuli and his three accomplices continued to undergo interrogation ''along all others connected with the case.''

headline: SAUDIS REPORTED TO PLAN A HUGE STOCKPILE OF OIL
abstract: Saudi Arabia is planning to build the world's largest oil stockpile as a hedge against possible disruptions in the Persian Gulf region that might affect its oil production, according to Petroleum Information International, a weekly newsletter.   The new Houston-based publication said that the stockpile, when completed in the 1990's, would have a storage capacity of 1.5 billion barrels and would be able to withstand severe attacks. Its estimated cost exceeds $7 billion.

headline: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The protracted and politically sensitive investigation into Richard V. Allen's affairs, which has produced the most embarrassing publicity of President Reagan's first year in office, is nearing a turning point.   Within a matter of days, Attorney General William French Smith must decide whether to appoint a special prosecutor for Mr. Allen. But Mr. Smith's decision will do little to clarify the question of why the Reagan Administration allowed the Allen affair to drag on for more than two months before acting decisively.   One possible explanation for the failure to act quickly is that White House or Justice Department officials have turned up evidence damaging to Mr. Allen that has not yet come to light.   Assuming that there is no further evidence, the reasons for the slow response appear to be found within the highest councils of the Justice Department and the White House. At the Justice Department, for example, the Allen affair was originally handled as a routine inquiry until officials there became alarmed that the department might be laying itself open to charges of a ''cover-up.'' The decision by Mr. Smith and his top aides at the Justice Department to order the F.B.I. to renew an investigation that the bureau regarded as completed in October added weeks to the timetable of the Allen affair.

headline: INTRODUCING 'TELE-SHOPPING
abstract: Robin D. Jackson and Mark J. Penn found a new way to avoid the crush of Christmas shoppers this year. They ordered some gifts by typing on a computer terminal in their homes.   ''I was able to get some things in half an hour without traipsing around,'' said Mr. Jackson, the general manager of a chain of furniture stores, who ordered a television set for his parents and a tape deck for a friend. ''When I was buying those Christmas presents I was doing it at 1 A.M. one night,'' said Mr. Penn, a political pollster.   The two New Yorkers are early users of electronic shopping, or ''teleshopping,'' one of a number of new electronic services, collectively known as videotex, that are expected to become widely available during this decade.

headline: U.S. OPEN TO LEASING OIL LAND TO KUWAIT
abstract: The Reagan Administration is ''favorably inclined'' to grant leasing privileges on mineral lands to the Government-owned Kuwait National Petroleum Company to help encourage foreign investment here, an Interior Department official told Congress today.   The disclosure raised immediate questions about the application of a 61-year-old Federal statute barring ownership of oil and gas leases to citizens of countries that do not grant reciprocal rights to Americans.   Kuwait has been found not to offer these rights, the Interior Department says.  The issue has come up in relation to Kuwait Petroleum's proposed $2.5 billion acquisition of the Santa Fe International Corporation, a major oil-equipment and engineering enterprise and the owner of $10 million worth of Federal leases.

headline: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET OPEN TALKS TODAY ON NUCLEAR WEAPONRY IN EUROPE
abstract: The Geneva negotiations on theater nuclear forces in Western Europe are scheduled to deal with missiles, aircraft and eventually also with nuclear artillery.   The negotiations are meant to deal with weapons classified as tactical, or theater, arms - weapons that would be used in tactical support of ground forces. The issue of exactly what kind of weapons can be so classified and thus included in the negotiations is expected by State and Defense Department officials to dominate the opening sessions of the conference.   The largest and most destructive weapons involved are the intermediate-range ballistic missiles of the two superpowers.  President Reagan offered earlier this month to forgo plans to deploy new American missiles in Western Europe if the Soviet Union would dismantle the ones it has targeted at the area. The term ''intermediate range'' has been subject to a wide variety of definitions, but is usually used to cover weapons with ranges of 1,000 to 4,000 miles. The exact definition for purposes of the negotiations will have to be determined at the conference.

headline: UNIROYAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Interest Rates in Sharp Drop; 1-Year Bills Yield 13.159%
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday as fears of rising rates and heavy Federal borrowings subsided following Wednesday's announcement of Treasury borrowing plans.   The average rate for one-year Treasury bills, for example, dropped to 13.159 percent at yesterday's auction, far lower than the 13.6 percent rate for outstanding one-year bills two days earlier, and well below the 14.58 percent average at the Oct. 1 auction. Based on the auction results, financial institutions may sell one-year tax-exempt certificates with a 10.77 percent yield starting Nov. 1, down from 12.14 percent currently.   ''The refunding announcement cleared the air,'' explained Richard Davis, director of fixed-income research at the First Boston Corporation. ''Even though the Treasury issues are sizable'' he said, ''people know what to expect.'' The Treasury said it would sell $4.5 billion of three-year notes next Monday, $2.25 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $2 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.

headline: U.S. BAPTIST GROUP ENDS ISRAELI VISIT
abstract: The Rev. Bailey E. Smith, the president of the Southern Baptist Convention who stirred a storm of protest with his statement last year that ''God Almighty does not hear the prayer of a Jew,'' left Israel today after a nine-day visit in which no Israeli official challenged him over the remark.   He did not see Prime Minister Menachem Begin, who had agreed to meet him but was then hospitalized after falling and breaking his thigh. Mr. Smith held discussions with President Yitzhak Navon, Yosef Burg, the Religious Affairs and Interior Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, the former Prime Minister, Moshe Arens, Ambassador-designate to the United States, and other officials.   The delegation, which included about a dozen Baptists, was sponsored by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith as an effort to improve relations between Baptists and Jews in the United States, and to build support for Israel. Atmosphere Termed Very Friendly   The atmosphere was described by participants as harmonious and extremely friendly. Mr. Smith, an outgoing and cheerful man of 42 years, set a good-natured tone in each meeting by beginning with a statement of warm support for Israel. After that, according to one Israeli who attended the sessions, officials evidently felt no need to raise the question of his remark a year ago.

headline: Soccer Player From Rumania Is Denied Asylum in Australia
abstract: A Rumanian soccer player lost his bid for political asylum in Australia and left for home today after receiving assurances that he would not be punished in Rumania, his lawyer said.   Gheorghe Viscreanu, 20 years old, left Melbourne on a flight for London.

headline: PRESIDENT IS APPOINTED AT FIELDCREST
abstract: Francis X. Larkin, 54, has been named president and chief operating officer of Fieldcrest Mills Inc., a manufacturer of home furnishings textiles based in Eden, N.C. He succeeds as president Willim C.  Battle, 61, who retains the position of chief executive officer.  Albert B. Hunt, the 71-year-old chairman and chairman of the Amoskeag Company, which owns 40 percent of Fieldcrest, continues in those posts.

headline: MCGRAW-EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SAUDIS, IN FIRM CONTROL, FACE LONG-TERM DANGERS
abstract: At his news conference on Oct. 1, President Reagan vowed that the United States would never permit Saudi Arabia ''to be an Iran.''   The warning was a graphic one, conjuring up the specter of virulent anti-Americanism, religious fanaticism and political strife. The President seemed to be saying that the United States would be able to control such turmoil in Saudi Arabia.   The question of the desert kingdom's stability is central to the debate over whether the United States should sell the Saudis Awacs surveillance planes. If the Saudi royal family was forced from power, as happened to the Shah in Iran, the Awacs might fall into hostile hands.

headline: STATE OFFICIALS DEFIES JUDGE ON TRANSFERS OF RIKERS PRISONERS
abstract: The state's Commissioner of Correctional Services said today that he would refuse to comply with an order by a Federal judge to speed the transfer of state prisoners held in New York City jails, even if the refusal put him in contempt of court.   The Commissioner, Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, said at a news conference that the order by Judge Morris E. Lasker of Federal District Court, issued Tuesday in New York City, would force him to create unsafe conditions in the state's prisons. The State Correctional Services Department says its prisons, which now contain 25,600 inmates, are already 12 percent over capacity.   ''My responsibility is to run safe facilities,'' Mr. Coughlin said in an interview. ''I can't do that and comply with his order. If that's contempt, I'm sorry about it.
