headline: Moody's Lowers Woolworth Rating
abstract: Moody's Investors Service Inc., a major bond rating service, said it had lowered its rating on the F.W. Woolworth Company's senior debt to Baa from A. Moody's ratings range from AAA, considered the highest quality, to C, considered the highest risk. Baa is at the low end of what is considered investment grade.

headline: 3 Killed by Shotguns in Italy
abstract: Gunmen using sawed-off shotguns killed three members of a family in what appeared to be a gangland slaying, the police said today. The killings were apparently the result of a feud between rival gangs trying to control organized crime here, according to the authorities.

headline: PHILIPS' LAMP DIMS A BIT
abstract: EINDHOVEN, The Netherlands I T'S a bad time to be an electrical and/or electronics company in Europe. Recession is dragging at traditional markets and productivity is down. Japan Inc., having hopped the Pacific and cut a wide swath in North America, has hopped again, this time across the Atlantic.  And its freshly alerted American competition is right on its heels.   Among the Continent's giants, West Germany's Siemens had a 21 percent profit drop in the year ended Sept. 30, to a slim $192.2 million, while AEG-Telefunken, also German-based, lost $284.5 million last year and expects to lose another $300 million this year.   At N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken, the giant of them all and a pillar of the Dutch economy, the triple threat has resulted in radical therapy. Philips is on a drastic diet - cutting manpower in Europe, weeding out weak operations and trying to weave a cooperative network with companies in Europe and abroad to share the burgeoning costs of developing and marketing new products.

headline: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FIELDCREST MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Xerox Lifts Prices
abstract: The Xerox Corporation said it will raise the price of medium- and high-volume copiers and duplicators an average of about 9 percent in the United States effective Jan. 4.  Xerox said the sales price of its 2300 low-volume copier will also be raised to $3,295 from $2,995. Prices of other low-volume copiers will not be changed, it added.

headline: A 'HOMELAND' SPURS PROTEST FROM BLACKS
abstract: Thozamile Gqweta, a 29-yearold leader of a black labor union who has become a symbol of resistance to South Africa's ''homeland'' politics, had another funeral to go to today.   So did several thousand of his followers in the South African Allied Workers Union for whom the ceremony inevitably became a protest against the impending independence of Ciskei, an impoverished territory adjacent to this Indian Ocean port that is due to receive an ambiguous sovereignty from South Africa on Dec. 4.   Two weeks ago Mr. Gqweta buried his mother and uncle, who had been burned to death in a mysterious fire. Today he buried a 20-year-old union member named Deliswa Roxisa, who had been his lover.   She was killed by what were said to be stray police bullets as she walked on the fringe of a procession returning from the funeral of Mr. Gqweta's mother. There will be yet another political funeral in Ciskei on Sunday for a black lawyer named Griffiths Mxenge, whose many political activities included advising Mr. Gqweta and his union.

headline: Seagram Offer
abstract: The Seagram Company, the world's largest producer of liquor and wines, said that about 13.6 million of its common shares had been tendered under its recently expired offer to buy 5 million of its own shares. Seagram said that about 37 percent of the shares tendered would be purchased. It said that as previously announced, all shares bought under the offer were being purchased on a prorated basis.

headline: Market Place; Teledyne Plan For Harvester
abstract: MANY in the Wall Street community are perplexed by Teledyne's persistent investments in International Harvester, the troubled Chicago farm equipment and truck manufacturer.   In some ways, the Harvester commitment is typical of the portfolio investments of Henry Singleton, Teledyne's chairman. In other respects, it is a mystery, one that Teyedyne is not willing to resolve for publication.   Mr. Singleton commonly invests the assets of Teledyne's three casualty insurance subsidiaries in out-of-favor stocks. These investments have brought the company spectacular success in the past, helping to raise the value of the combined investment portfolios to a reported $1.5 billion or so.

headline: Union Upset By G.M. Plea
abstract: The United Automobile Workers union reacted angrily yesterday to a campaign by the General Motors Corporation, made public earlier this week, that is aimed at convincing G.M.'s workers to ''reduce or eliminate unrealistic expectations about economic gains'' in the 1982 contract negotiations.   The campaign, in which all of G.M.'s 499,000 hourly and salaried workers are to attend classes to receive information on what the company calls its impaired financial situation, also hopes to convince employees that the company's survival is at stake.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Anaconda Copper Co., a subsidiary of the Atlantic Richfield Co., said it would change its name to the Anaconda Minerals Co. effective Jan. 1.   * HCI Holdings Ltd. said it had increased its stake in Symbol Technologies Inc. to 242,325 shares, or 8.8 percent, by purchasing 142,625 shares for $641,812.

headline: Scottish Islanders Lose Fight Against Air Base
abstract: Britain gave the go-ahead for a North Atlantic Treaty Organization emergency air base on the island of Lewis off the west coast of Scotland today despite objections from islanders who fear for their quiet way of life.   The Secretary of State for Scotland, George Younger, said the strategic location of the 770-square-mile island 40 miles off the coast meant it was needed as a forward base ''in times of tension and war.''   NATO is to meet almost the entire $78 million cost of extending runways and building fuel storage tanks and an undersea fuel pipeline to Lewis's existing Royal Air Force base at Stornoway.

headline: SECRETARY OF CABINET IN ISRAEL FACES A DISCIPLINARY HEARING
abstract: The Secretary of the Israeli Cabinet has been charged with improperly divulging information about a reported conversation between President Jimmy Carter and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany.   Although the information had already been disclosed and rebutted in the Israeli press, the Secretary, Aryeh Naor, faces a civil service disciplinary hearing next month. The charge against him is conduct unbecoming a civil servant and actions that could harm the reputation of the civil service.

headline: No Headline
abstract: 67 AMERICANS FLY OUT OF LIBYA   TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 14 (UPI) - Nearly 70 Mobil oil executives and their families flew home today with praise for Libyan friends and mixed feelings about President Reagan's request that Americans pull out of Libya.   ''This is a hard way to leave,'' said Mike Deets, of Wichita Falls, Tex., who boarded a chartered Lufthansa flight to Frankfurt and London.

headline: SPECTRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Top Executives View Economy
abstract: Top-level business executives are slightly more pessimistic about the economy, but their outlook for six months from now continues to hold up, the Conference Board said yesterday.   The business-financed research group said its Measure of Business Confidence fell to 57, on a scale of 100, in the third quarter, down from 61 in the second quarter.

headline: FINANCIAL FUTURES TIE SOUGHT
abstract: Two of the nation's leading exchanges today presented a proposal for a joint trading venture on new financial instruments.   The plan was recommended by a joint committee of the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest futures exchange, and the Chicago Board Options Exchange, an eight-year-old offshoot of the Board of Trade that has taken a lead in the marketing of stock options.   Board of Trade directors took no formal action on the proposal but sent it to the membership for discussion. The C.B.O.E. executive committee recommended that its directors approve the plan.

headline: SCHLITZ PRESIDENT RESIGNS HIS POST
abstract: Jerome E. Vielehr resigned yesterday as president of the Jos.  Schlitz Brewing Company, and Frank J. Sellinger, vice chairman and chief executive officer, took over his duties.   The resignation was announced without explanation. A spokesman for the Milwaukee-based company, John A. Rourke, said the 49-year-old Mr. Vielehr, who has been president since April 1980, ''gave no reasons nor did he announce any plans.''

headline: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EGYPTIANS VOTING TO ELECT MUBARAK
abstract: A week after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, Egyptians voted today in a referendum to elect Vice President Hosni Mubarak the country's new President.   The 53-year-old Vice President, who is already Prime Minister and head of the ruling National Democratic Party, is the only candidate to succeed Mr. Sadat, so his election is assured. The vote count will be disclosed when Parliament convenes tomorrow to swear in Mr.  Mubarak. He will then make his first speech to the nation since he announced that Mr. Sadat had been slain.

headline: PREMIER OF QUEBEC THREATENS TO RESIGN OVER PARTY PROGRAM
abstract: Premier Rene Levesque stunned his Quebec separatist party today by rejecting the radical conclusions of its biannual convention and announcing he was on the point of resigning as the party's president.   At the close of three days of impassioned and bitter discussion on how to achieve independence for Quebec, Mr. Levesque left the Parti Quebecois in complete disarray and even unsure he would remain as premier of Quebec after the 10-minute tongue-lashing he gave the convention.   Mr. Levesque was angered by the decision of the majority of delegates to move immediately on the question of independence if the party wins the next provincial election. He had urged restraint because of provincial and national economic problems.

headline: NORTH AMERICAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: Ariel Sharon, Israel's Defense Minister, is due in Washington later this month to discuss the fashioning of a strategic alliance that has become urgently important to the Israelis.   Intelligence sources in this country report that Saudi Arabia is building two new airfields in the northwestern region close to Israel. One is at Turaif, which the sources said would be about 10 minutes' flying time from Jerusalem. The other, to the south, is at Quraiya, about 12 minutes' distant.

headline: Money Funds' Assets Drop
abstract: For the first time in 30 weeks, assets of the nation's money market mutual funds have declined, Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.   The drop - $1.056 billion during the past week - put the assets of the 141 funds at $184.2 billion.

headline: BL Workers Vote Nov. 2 Walkout
abstract: Nearly 60,000 workers at BL Ltd., the former British Leyland, voted by a margin of 2 to 1 to walk off the job Nov. 2, defying threats by Sir Michael Edwardes, BL chairman, to close the ailing state-financed car company if the strike goes ahead.    British Leyland employees, who earn an average of 112, or about $201, a week, want a $38 pay increase.

headline: Around the World; Pentagon Plans to Sell F-16 Jets to Venezuela
abstract: The Pentagon formally notified Congress today of plans to sell 24 F-16 jet fighters to Venezuela.

headline: Operating Net Up at El Paso
abstract: The El Paso Company, a diversified energy concern, said today that its third-quarter operating profits soared 53.7 percent on a 20.7 percent rise in revenues.

headline: TENNANT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ENERGY MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CATERPILLAR TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NEW MIDEAST UNCERTAINTY FELT
abstract: American business and economic leaders expressed fears yesterday that the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat could further shake the Middle East's fragile stability. Concern over the shooting of the Egyptian President drove up the price of gold, the dollar and domestic oil stocks.   ''Clearly this tragic event does create additional uncertainty in an area fraught with uncertainty,'' said Edward G. Jefferson, chairman of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. ''While Sadat played a constructive role toward peace, events of this kind can be unsettling and destabilizing, although I'm ho ping that this won't.''

headline: Danish Politician Convicted of Tax Evasion
abstract: Mogens Glistrup, who built up a powerful political party in Denmark by advocating the abolition of taxes, was convicted today of tax evasion. He received the maxiumum sentence of four years in prison and a $1 million fine.

headline: ILLINI BEEF PACKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SEISCOM DELTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. Steel to Shut Furnace in Gary
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation said that it was taking out of operation a blast furnace at its Gary, Ind., works, leaving only two of the mill's six furnaces there in operation.   A spokesman said that layoffs at the company's two Chicago-area plants have increased by 1,500 in the past month because of weakness in orders for steel products.   The Gary works, he said, now have about 2,300 employees laid off out of a total of 20,000.

headline: Other Business; UNEASY ACCESS
abstract: ''I'm sorry to say that the last Easy Access statement you received was incorrect. Since they're programmed by people, computers are only human...'' Thus began an early November letter from Citibank vice president Russel A. Herz.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: The Reagan Administration has found itself in a new dispute with Israel that raises questions about Washington's ability to encourage both a continuing Saudi Arabian involvement in Middle East diplomacy and an early resolution of the Egyptian-Israeli negotiations on Palestinian self-rule. President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. insist that they are solidly behind the ''Camp David process,'' the Administration's term for the talks on Palestinian autonomy and the fulfillment of terms of the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty.   With King Hussein of Jordan having arrived here today for talks with President Reagan, the scene has been set for a public discussion of the Administration's Middle East strategy, if indeed the Administration is ready to go beyond generalities. U.S. Response to Saudi Plan   Senior officials say they cannot understand why Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel has evidently chosen to make a major issue out of the Administration's modest words of welcome for some aspects of an eight-point list of principles for a Middle East solution that was offered in August by Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia.   Mr. Begin, appearing on the ABC News program ''Issues and Answers'' today from Jerusalem, acknowledged receipt of a letter from President Reagan in which ''he reassures me that the United States are committed to the security of Israel,'' and that the United States ''will safeguard - this is the expression - the military and technological advantages of Israel.''

headline: TOP OIL EXECUTIVES SEE LITTLE CHANGE IN PRICES
abstract: Leaders of the American oil industry predicted today that oil prices would stagnate for a year or more.  The executives, who assembled here yesterday for the annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute, said that this meant continuation of a trend that has seen the average price of a gallon of gasoline decline by nearly 5 cents since March, to $1.34.   The predictions of price weakness come in sharp contrast to a forecast at last year's A.P.I. meeting by Dan Lundberg, a retail oil analyst, that gasoline prices might reach $2 a gallon in 1981.   Nonetheless, oilmen suggested that the good news on the price front carried several worrisome implications: Pressure on refining and marketing profit margins might intensify, development of alternative forms of energy would likely be postponed and the prices of energy company stocks could not be expected to rise.

headline: BROCKWAY GLASS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MERRILL FEE IS FAIR, COURT SAYS
abstract: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the investment advisory fees charged by Merrill Lynch Asset Management Inc., which manages the world's largest money market mutual fund, were not excessive, no matter how profitable they might have been.   In so ruling, Judge Milton Pollack of the United States District Court in Manhattan dismissed charges brought in 1979 by two investors, Irving L. Gartenberg and Simone C. Andre, that the adviser was making ''too much money'' by levying fees that were disproportionate to the services rendered, and therefore a violation of fiduciary duty.   William P. Rogers, senior partner of the law firm of Rogers & Wells, and Secretary of State in the Nixon Administration, called Judge Pollack's ruling ''a landmark decision.''   The decision, said Mr. Rogers, whose firm represented Merrill Lynch in the case, ''establishes the law insofar as the fee that can be charged'' by a mutual fund adviser. Until now, he added, suits challenging advisory fees were settled out of court - with the adviser usually reducing fees - thus giving no guidance to the industry.

headline: Record World Coffee Crop Forecast
abstract: World coffee production in the current season will be greater than previously expected and will set a record, the Agriculture Department said today.

headline: FOR MARGARET PAPANDREOU, A 'QUIET RAGE' OF FEMINISM
abstract: Margaret Papandreou believes her husband's new Socialist Government will mean a breakthrough for Greek women, who she says ''have been largely suppressed through our capitalist system and our patriarchal mentality.''   The American-born wife of Greece's new Prime Minister is a dedicated feminist, a Socialist and the guiding inspiration behind the Women's Union of Greece.   ''Women's problems are the same in Greece as in most countries, though maybe to a greater degree,'' Mrs. Papandreou said in a recent interview. She emphasized the need to open more jobs to women, set up more child care centers, change the education system, revise family laws and legalize abortions.

headline: Around the World; Angola Envoy Clarifies Remarks on Guerrillas
abstract: Angola's Ambassador to Portugal said today that he had been misquoted in reports saying that he expressed his Government's willingness to talk with the head of a pro-Western guerrilla group.   The ambassador, Adriano Sebastiao, said he had stated that the Angolan Government was willing to talk with the guerrilla chief, Jonas Savimbi, who is the leader of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, but only ''as an Angolan citizen and once he has broken his ties to South Africa.''

headline: Bankruptcy in Chile
abstract: Industria de Radio y Television, a major manufacturer, has been declared bankrupt, Jose Manuel Riera, a vice president of the company, disclosed today.

headline: Other Business; ALL SAVERS: THE BIG WINNERS ARE NEWSPAPERS
abstract: Who were the biggest beneficiaries of the Oct. 1 launch of ''All Savers'' certificates? Not the savers. They'll have to wait a year to realize the tax-free benefits. And it wasn't the banks, at least not yet. It was the nation's newspapers.

headline: Massey-Ferguson Layoffs Are Set
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Industries Ltd. announced that because of depressed conditions in the farm machinery industry, it will cut one shift at its Brantford, Ontario, combine plant on Nov. 6, a move that will result in the layoff of about 600 of the plant's 2,800 employes.   The company, a unit of Massey-Ferguson Ltd., cited high interest rates and weak commodity prices for its decision.

headline: INTERTEC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Belgian Blast Toll Rises to 3
abstract: A man died today from injuries suffered in Tuesday's bomb blast outside a synagogue in Antwerp's diamond district, bringing the death toll to three.

headline: Battelle Memorial Appoints New Head
abstract: Ronald S. Paul, 58 years old, has been appointed president of the Battelle Memorial Institute, a research institute with headquarters in Columbus, Ohio. He succeeds Sherwood L. Fawcett, 61, who was named chairman of the board of trustees, while continuing as chief executive officer   Battelle, a leading independent organization, which is nonprofit but not tax exempt, employs 7,500 scientists, engineers and support personnel.

headline: ZIMMER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hart Industries Seeks to Dissolve
abstract: Hart Industries, the troubled discount long-distance telephone service, has filed a petition with Federal Bankruptcy Court in Miami asking for permission to voluntarily dissolve.

headline: INTERNATIONAL VIDEO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN AWACS PLEDGES APPEAR TO BE SOFTENING
abstract: The White House was not as specific today about the pledges given to win acceptance of the Awacs sale to Saudi Arabia as some senators had seemed to believe yesterday.   In answer to questions from reporters on the meaning and legal nature of the pledges, James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, said the President's letter to the Senate made public yesterday in the course of a debate on the $8.5 billion arms sale ''probably does not have technical legal effect.'' But he added that it would be ''binding'' on President Reagan as a moral commitment.   The letter, dated Oct. 28 but under preparation for several weeks, said that the actual transfer of five Airborne Warning and Control System planes would take place ''only after the Congress has received in writing a Presidential certification, containing agreements with Saudi Arabia, that the following conditions have been met.'' The letter then listed six subjects, some divided into subsections.

headline: Futures Exchange Names Top Officer
abstract: The New York Futures Exchange, a subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange, known as N.Y.F.E. and pronounced ''knife,'' made the longawaited announcement yesterday that John F. Kelley, 37, who heads institutional financial futures trading at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, has been named president and chief executive officer, effective Nov. 2.   The futures exchange also said that Frank J. Jones, 42, a senior vice president for the last two years, was appointed to the new post of executive vice president and chief operating officer. In addition, Harry B. Anderson, a 67-year-old retired vice chairman of Merrill Lynch & Co. and chairman of the N.Y.F.E. executive committee, has been elected its vice chairman.

headline: Libya Asks U.N. Inquiry Into Murder Charges
abstract: Libya has said that it would welcome an investigation by a United Nations committee into reports that it was plotting to kill President Reagan.   In a letter to the Security Council, dated Nov. 23 and made public today, Foreign Minister Abdulati al-Obeidi denied that Libya had equipped assassination squads to kill Mr. Reagan and Vice President Bush, as reported by Newsweek magazine and by NBC News.   The letter also denied allegations attributed to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that Libya was plotting against other Americans.

headline: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: W.R. Grace Sets P lant in Germany
abstract: W.R. Grace & Company said it would start construction immediately of a multimillion-dollar plant in Worms, West Germany, to manufacture fluid cracking catalysts used to refine crude oil into light-grade petroleum products.

headline: energywatch
abstract: OCT. 16, 1981 Crude oil stocks fell to 370.4 million barrels, a drawdown of 6 million, in an inventory adjustment.

headline: VICTORIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RAID KEPT SECRET BY SOUTH AFRICANS
abstract: South Africa's announcement that its forces had destroyed another regional headquarters of the insurgent South-West Africa People's Organization in Angola came more than a month after the start of the operation.   The attack, which was reported today to have begun on Nov. 1 and lasted 18 days, took South African forces deeper into Angolan territory than had any previous campaign against the guerrillas.   According to reports by six South African reporters who accompanied the Defense Forces in the attack, the insurgent base was about 150 miles north of the Cunene River, which is the border between Angola and the disputed territory of South-West Africa, also known as Namibia.

headline: Report by Jurists Group Says Sri Lanka Represses Minority
abstract: A report of the International Commission of Jurists, written by an American and published here today, accused Sri Lanka of repressing its Tamil minority and said the situation could grow into violence.   The 88-page report, drawn up by Prof. Virginia Leary of the State University of New York, said that police and army repression of the Tamil community appeared to be growing.

headline: Kodak Dividends
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said that it would pay a record $245.8 million wage ''dividend'' to 93,000 of its employees in the United States.

headline: IN TURKEY, HARD TIMES FOR U.S. CULTURAL UNIT
abstract: The Turkish American Association may become a victim of the United States Government's sweeping cuts in overseas cultural programs.   While the United States has steadily increased military and economic aid to Turkey, it has cut back dramatically in aid for academic exchanges. The United States spends $600,000 on academic exchanges in Turkey and five times that amount on military exchange programs, in addition to the $700 million just voted by Congress for military and economic aid.   Enrollment in the Turkish American Association ''has dropped a lot because of the troubles - in fact, it's incredible that it's still here,'' said Dr. Toni Cross, who was recently named director of the association, and whose mission is to save it from extinction.

headline: Africans Plan to Meet Today On the Peace Force for Chad
abstract: Leaders of the African nations that have pledged to send peacekeeping troops to Chad will meet here Friday, the official Kenyan news agency reported today.

headline: A SHAKEN BURMAH OIL NOW RISK-SHY
abstract: The once-aggressive Burmah Oil Company has emerged from an ordeal of failure in the mid-1970's as a slow-moving, risk-shy conglomerate with little remaining connection to the oil industry.   The company finally righted itself by going to the Bank of England for help. But that transaction, too, turned bitter, from Burmah's point of view, leading to a $1.8 billion lawsuit filed by the company that it lost. And now Burmah is quietly pondering its future.

headline: CONSERVATIVES IN GREECE OUST LEADER AFTER ELECTION DEFEAT
abstract: Former Prime Minister George Rallis, paying the consequences of his party's heavy election defeat to the Socialists six weeks ago, was ousted today from the party leadership.   Sixty-one of the 112 parliamentary deputies of the New Democracy Party voted against Mr. Rallis. A party announcement said the caucus would meet on Wednesday to elect a new leader.

headline: FRANCE'S LEFT IS SPLIT BY SHOWDOWN IN POLAND
abstract: The army crackdown in Poland has made a serious crack in the uneasy relationship between France's Socialists and their Communist partners in the Government.   A rally and march took place this afternoon to protest the proclamation of martial law and the arrest of the Solidarity leadership. Led by the Socialist Party and the major pro-Socialist labor federation, the thousands of demonstrators parading from the Gare Montparnasse to the Invalides represented every current in the French left except one.   Both the Communist Party and the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor, the largest labor grouping here, boycotted the demonstration.

headline: NEW IN JAPAN: THE MANLESS FACTORY
abstract: each with a pair of yellow tool drums that resemble enlarged roulette wheels - are grinding, boring and fashioning parts for high-technology machines like themselves.   ''Robots making robots'' is the catch-phrase used to describe the process here. Only a few human workers are involved; they direct cranes that load metal castings onto fixtures that are then wheeled automatically to a storage area.   On the night shift, the machines work unassisted. The place is rather dimly lit. One solitary human sentinel -the night watchman - patrols the factory floor, armed with a flashlight, as the machines labor on, milling metal castings weighing several tons and moving them about the plant.

headline: West Bank Mayors Set Back
abstract: The Defense Ministry has rejected an appeal by two expelled Palestinian Mayors to return to the occupied West Bank, Israel radio reported today. Mayors Fahad Kawasmeh of Hebron and Mohammed Milhem of Halhoul were expelled in May 1980. They were accused of creating the climate for a Palestinian attack on Jewish worshipers in Hebron in which 16 Jews were killed.

headline: Charter to Move Insurance Unit
abstract: The Charter Company, which announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell six radio stations in a $32 million transaction, said it had also decided to move an insurance subsidiary from Jacksonville to New York to take advantage of changes in the insurance market.   The oil, insurance and communications conglomerate called the sale of the radio unit and the move of the Charter Security Life Insurance Companies to New York ''a move to redefine operations and to redeploy assets.''

headline: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 24
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Wang Presents Audio System
abstract: Wang Laboratories, a leading maker of computers and word processing equipment based in Lowell, Mass., took a step yesterday toward an industry goal of producing a machine that can automatically type spoken English.   The company introduced an ''audio work station,'' which, although it stops short of full translation of audio into type, does to spoken messages what a word processor does to written messages.

headline: CESSNA AIRCRAFT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Thrace Oil Find Cited
abstract: The Turkish Petroleum Office has discovered petroleum deposits at a depth of 9,800 feet in the Hamitabat region of Thrace, the Turkish daily newspaper Cumhuriyet said today. It said that a quality test would be completed in a few days.

headline: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Sambo's Is Late On Loan Payment
abstract: Sambo's Restaurants Inc., which has about 1,100 units nationwide, disclosed that it had failed to pay $4.8 million it owed as the first installment of a $100 million restructured loan arrangement critical to the survival of the chain.   The debt restructuring took place after GDV Inc., a unit of the City Investing Company, assumed control of the financially ailing restaurant operator in 1979.

headline: BEVERAGE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; French Parliament Backs Cut in Nuclear Building
abstract: The National Assembly today overwhelmingly approved the Socialist Government's plans to cut back on nuclear power plant construction.   The Government, which had made the issue a vote of confidence, won 331 to 67.

headline: Rolls-Royce Ltd.
abstract: Rolls-Royce Ltd. said that a decsion by the Lockheed Corporation to stop making L-1011 airliners would force some layoffs at its British plants.

headline: REGAN OPENS TALKS IN CHINA
abstract: A high-level American delegation led by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan opened discussions today with Chinese officials on a full range of economic and commercial issues affecting China and the United States.   The talks here marked the second annual meeting of the U.S.-China Joint Economic Committee, which was formed in 1979 shortly after the two countries established diplomatic relations.   Since the initial meeting in Washington in September 1980, this is the first direct opportunity afforded the Reagan Administration to explore matters with Peking's economic specialists. This afternoon, Secretary Regan was received by the Deputy Prime Minister for the Economy, Bo Yibo, who also is co-chairman of the joint committee.

headline: 45 Leftists Held in Turkey
abstract: Security forces have arrested 45 people in Kayseri Province said to belong to Revolutionary Path, an outlawed leftist organization, officials said today.

headline: POLICE IN WARSAW RAID FIRE ACADEMY TO BREAK UP SIT-IN
abstract: Polish policemen backed by army units mounted a helicopter assault on the academy of striking fire cadets here today and removed the 300 students without bloodshed.   As a crowd ringing the three-story academy outside a cordon of soldiers jeered the police, the cadets, in dress uniforms, were driven out of the building in buses and set free at various Warsaw rail terminals. Most of them went to the local headquarters of the Solidarity union, where they were reunited with their families in emotional scenes.   The swift police operation ended a confrontation between the cadets, who were demanding a status equal to that of university students, and the Government, which considered the eight-day sit-in more a mutiny than a civil protest.

headline: ANACONDA-ERICSSON TO ACQUIRE CITICORP AXXA OFFICE PRODUCTS
abstract: Citicorp, which is barred by law from marketing office automation systems it developed primarily for its own use, has sold its office automation subsidiary to Anaconda-Ericsson Inc., a joint venture of the Atlantic Richfield Company and the LM Ericsson Telephone Company of Sweden.   The sale of the Axxa Corporation, as the subsidiary is called, will allow its product to be sold commercially and will allow Citicorp to recoup some or all of its investment.   The sale is the second this year of a Citicorp unit that had developed advanced office technology. In February the bank holding company sold its Lexar unit, which had developed an electronic switchboard, to the United Technologies Corporation. Citicorp said that deal would bring it as much as $7 million over three years.  Because of the Bank Holding Company Act and other regulations, banking companies are not allowed to manufacture or sell commercial products for nonbank applications.

headline: CAR PHONE POLICY SET BY F.C.C.
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission today affirmed its decision in April to give telephone companies half of the new cellular radio business in each locality rather than open this new field to any company on an equal footing.   The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which pioneered the system designed to improve mobile telephone communications, is expected to be the leading beneficiary of the policy because its local operating companies already hold the franchises in the nation's largest cities.   The F.C.C.'s action came despite reports that the April plan might be unraveling because the staff of the commission had reversed its recommendation, with the agreement of Mark S. Fowler, the agency chairman.   Picford A. Wagner, an A.T.& T. spokesman, indicated that the company was gratified by today's   A.T.& T. said it earned $1.96 billion in the fourth quarter, a 23.3 percent gain from a year ago. Page D4. decision and he said the first cellular service could be started by November 1983, with possibly 70 cities receiving it within five years.

headline: BRAZIL BLOCKS 13 ADOPTIONS BY AMERICANS
abstract: Brazilian authorities have abruptly and without explanation barred a group of legally adopted children from leaving the country with their American parents.   Thirteen Brazilian infants are involved, and three of the mothers have been stranded in Rio since June with the children they adopted here, trying to find out who issued the order and why.   For one three-day period the mothers went into hiding with the infants because of warnings that they were about to be kidnapped.Government officials have refused to provide any accounting to the parents, their Brazilian sponsors or American Consulate authorities.

headline: Commodities; Fertilizer As a Crop Indicator
abstract: STUDYING fertilizer usage as an indicator of future farm output and price trends has never been very popular with grain and soybean crop analysts. Most of the forecasters followed by farm commodity futures traders concentrate on weather patterns, output-per-acre statistics, foreign crop conditions, interest rates, political trends and other factors.   As a result, most futures traders again were buffeted by often contradictory projections about grain and soybean market fundamentals all year. And most again lost money, according to futures brokers, because the farm expert who was consistently right from the start of the 1980-81 season was Emil Sherer Finley, who is not a professional crop forecaster, but rather a leading exporter of fertilizer.

headline: ECONOMIC ILLS SAP TRUDEAU'S SUPPORT
abstract: At the end of a year of unusual political achievement, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberal Government appears so out of favor with the public that it would probably be ousted in any election held now.   As a result of some hard negotiations between Ottawa and the provinces, Canada is due to get its own constitution early next year, and an ambitious energy program has gotten under way after the provinces that produce the nation's oil and gas ended their opposition to it. But it appears that any political benefits the Prime Minister might have expected have been largely nullified by the same recession that is afflicting the United States economy.   Early last month, just after Mr. Trudeau won the agreement of 9 of the 10 provinces on a plan to transform the 114-year-old British North America Act into a fully Canadian constitution, a Gallup poll jolted the Liberal leadership. It showed the Liberals trailing the Progressive Conservatives by four points among decided voters, enough of a difference, the Gallup organization said, to insure a Conservative majority government if an election were held now.

headline: Permalens Account
abstract: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners has become agency for Permalens soft contact lenses from the Coopervision Optics division of Cooper Laboratories in Palo Alto, Calif. An additional part of the assignment is the promotion of the contact solutions and related products. The lens, which can be worn up to two weeks, was approved last January by the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Business Conditions; WEAKNESS IN POWER
abstract: Cooler weather across the nation prompted a rise in electricity generation last month, but continuing conservation and a slumping economy have dampened demand for the year so far.   Through the week ending Nov. 7, the Edison Electric Institute said the nation's 200 major power companies, which produce more than 75 percent of the nation's electricity, had generated 2.3 trillion kilowatt hours of electricity, up only 1.1 percent from year-earlier levels, and far below earlier projections.

headline: A BANK, BY ANY OTHER NAME . . .
abstract: Sears. RCA. Gulf and Western. National Steel. Baldwin United. Greyhound. General Electric. Control Data. Not to mention American Express, Merrill Lynch, Prudential, Beneficial and Transamerica.   These are the bankers of today. And the list goes on.  Need a loan? Want to make a deposit? Get a line of credit? Sign up for a credit card, an auto loan, a second mortgage, a first mortgage?  Americans no longer need banks to satisfy their financial needs.  Nor are the banks themselves ''just banks'' any more. They are, or are trying to be, go-go financial marketers. They prefer to call themselves ''financial services companies,'' just like the American Expresses and the Merrill Lynches.   The banks are even finding ways around federal laws that prohibit them from engaging in certain activities or branching across state lines. Despite the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which bars commercial banks from many investment banking activities, the BankAmerica Corp.  recently announced that it planned to buy Charles Schwab & Co., one of the nation's largest discount brokerage firms.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE   FREEPORT-MCMORAN INC.

headline: Sun Cuts Prices
abstract: The Sun Company has cut the wholesale price of its unleaded gasoline by as much as 1.8 cents a gallon in Pennsylvania, Delaware and New Jersey, and a subsidiary, Sunmark Industries, reduced wholesale heating oil prices by two-tenths of a cent to 1.6 cents a gallon on the Eastern Seaboard and in parts of Tennessee, Kentucky, Ohio and Michigan. The Sun Company is the 11th-largest gasoline marketer in the United States. A Sun spokesman said the company was ''adjusting to a competitive market.''

headline: CLARK EQUIPMENT HIRES G.M. OFFICER
abstract: James R. Rinehart, 50 years old, resigned yesterday as president of General Motors of Canada Ltd. to become president and chief executive officer of the Clark Equipment Company, a manufacturer of material-handling equipment, construction equipment, axles and transmissions. At Clark he succeeds Bert E. Phillips, 62, who remains chairman.

headline: STRUGGLE FOR CENCO EXPANDING
abstract: The bidding war for Cenco Inc., one of the nation's largest nursing home operators, expanded today as a Canadian company appeared as a possible suitor.   And National Medical Enterprises Inc. of Los Angeles, the company that was apparently being outbid in its attempt to take over Cenco, said that it was extending its tender offer deadline for Cenco stock to keep its options open.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: METRO AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SELF-MANAGEMENT: CURE FOR POLISH WOES?
abstract: An eerie silence pervades the halls at the new Ursus state tractor plant, built some eight years ago with the help of Massey-Ferguson on the outskirts of the Polish capital.   Shiny new machines, worth millions of dollars, stand in neat rows, bearing some of the noblest names in heavy engineering. There are computer-controlled metal lathes from Cincinnati Milacron and presses built by West Germany's Demag. Vickers of Britain, Sperry Rand, Ingersoll-Rand and Siemens are some of the other famous makers of machine tools whose equipment has been standing here unused for several years.

headline: CHINA VOTES TO CUT BUREAUCRATIC FAT
abstract: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang pledged today that China's Government bureaucracy would be reduced in size to make it more efficient.   Mr. Zhao said that the State Council, the top agency in Government, resolved to take firm steps to trim the ''bloated overlapping administrative structure.'' He said the council's decision had been made after discussions with the Communist Party's Central Committee.   The reorganization, the Prime Minister declared, would get under way next month in administrative departments under the State Council. These include 50 separate ministries and several trade and financial institutions such as the Bank of China.  Mr. Zhao proposed that the overlapping functions and duties of these departments be more sharply delineated through legislation.

headline: Italian Leaves for Cuba
abstract: Enrico Berlinguer, the head of Italy's Communist Party, left today for Cuba at the start of a 12-day tour of the Central American region.

headline: Two Canadian Nuns in Brazil Are Given Police Protection
abstract: Two Canadian Roman Catholic nuns were granted police protection to continue their work after being threatened with expulsion from a poor northeastern village, the Canadian Embassy said today.

headline: Transcanada Gas
abstract: Transcanada Pipelines Ltd. said that it was concluding contracts with about 100 Alberta producers to buy additional gas supplies in order to fill contracts for export sales totaling a billion cubic feet a day that it signed earlier this year. The company said that gas deliveries from the new contracts would begin when its current contracted supply can no longer satisfy markets.

headline: GIDDINGS & LEWIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CREATING PRODUCTS FOR MARKETPLACE
abstract: It is written in Ecclesiastes that there is no new thing under the sun. But Gerald Schoenfeld has his own idea about that. ''Who's to say what's new?'' Mr. Schoenfeld asked heatedly. ''It's the world's most boring argument.''   Mr. Schoenfeld ought to believe in new things, because he is paid to create them. His company, founded six years ago, is one of a halfdozen or so major new product shops, according to many leading package goods manufacturers, which hire them to develop new products for as-yet-unfilled niches in the marketplace. Such companies, typically founded by advertising agency employees, specialize in the conception of new product ideas as well as in repositioning existing products.

headline: BULGARIA A RUSSIAN LOOK-ALIKE? WELL LOOK AGAIN
abstract: At first glance, Sofia looks like a provincial town in the Soviet Union - gray, sooty, down at the heel, with a huge central square dominated by a Stalin-Gothic building housing Communist Party offices.   At first glance, the Bulgarian Government, led by the 70-year-old President, Todor Zhivkov, seems like a carbon copy of the Soviet Government, echoing its ideological pronouncements, careful to follow a foreign policy neither too far ahead of nor too far behind that proclaimed in the Kremlin.   Lada and Moskvitch cars, the latter assembled here, dominate the streets of the city. The uniforms of the countless military officers walking through the downtown area look a great deal like those of their Soviet counterparts. Even the alphabet is the same; the Bulgarians, like the Russians, use the Cyrillic characters attributed to two 9th-century Bulgarian brothers, later sanctified, named Cyril and Methodius.

headline: CROWN CRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Prospects
abstract: Triple-Digit Deficits   ''Wall Street doesn't discount the same news twice.'' That's how Treasury Secretary Regan sees it, and consequently the Administration believes the fallout would be minimal from recent announcements that the Government would be far deeper in deficit than it had thought.  Private economists, who had questioned the accuracy of earlier deficit forecasts, tend to disagree.   Figures that suggest deficits could rise from a $100 billion the current fiscal year are likely to prevent interest rates from falling as far as they otherwise might in a period of economic contraction, says David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston. By publishing these figures, the Administration may have prolonged the recession, he adds.

headline: RATES RISE
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose by $800 million in the week ended Dec. 9, an increase that surprised some analysts who had been expecting a modest decline. It was the fourth increase in the last five weeks, for a net gain of $7.3 billion, and touched off a spurt in short-term interest rates and a decline in bond prices that economists termed an ''overreaction.''   Earlier this year, however, expansion of the money supply was slow, and the growth rate for the past year is only 4.7 percent, significantly below the Fed's 1981 growth target of 6 to 8 1/2 percent. The M-1B money supply measure, used by the Fed as a proxy for the amount of money the public has available for spending, is defined as currency in circulation plus all kinds of checking accounts.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New President Named At Barco of California
abstract: Michael K. Donner, 38, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Barco of California, a leading uniform manufacturer. He succeeds David S. Grutman, 73, who was named vice chairman of the Los Angeles-based company.

headline: U.S. Post in Taiwan Filled
abstract: James R. Lilley, a career intelligence officer with the Central Intelligence Agency, has been appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, it was announced today. The institute was established under the Taiwan Relations Act as the vehicle for dealings with the Nationalist Government after President Jimmy Carter broke diplomatic relations with Taiwan in January 1979. Mr. Lilley replaces Charles T. Cross, who has resigned.

headline: NORTHWEST AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Utility Delays Plant
abstract: The Atlantic City Electric Company said it would delay construction of its proposed Cumberland generating station in Millville, N.J., to 1991 from 1988. The utility noted that while slower demand growth rates had necessitated the delay, the Cumberland plant would still be needed in the 1990's. The utility provides electric service in a 2,700-square-mile area in southern New Jersey with an estimated population of 1 million.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Alexander & Alexander Inc. has named Tinsley H. Irvin president and chief executive officer.   * Allied Stores Corp. has appointed Robert Rieland president and chief executive officer of the Miller & Rhoads division.   * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. has elected to its board Thomas H. Wyman, president and chief executive officer of CBS Inc.

headline: Cunningham & Walsh Expands Dallas Office
abstract: The small Dallas office set up by Cunningham & Walsh last September to handle the then newly acquired Lennox Industries and La Quinta Motor Inns account, has been expanded into a full service office to be headed by Harve Chapman as president and general manager.   And to go along with that expansion, a new client, The Dallas Morning News, previously handled by KCBN Inc. of Dallas, where Mr.  Chapman had been chairman.

headline: INVENTORIES UP AGAIN IN OCTOBER
abstract: Unsold goods held by United States businesses rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in October as sales dropped sharply and the recession took hold, the Government reported today.   October's rise in the seasonally adjusted value of business inventories, the 10th consecutive monthly increase, was accompanied by a 2.3 percent drop in sales, the second decrease in three months, a Commerce Department report said.   That raised the inventory-to-sales ratio, which business officials try to keep low, from September's 1.44 to 1.48, the highest it has been since the 1.52 mark at the height of last year's recession. The ratio reflects the number of months it would take to sell off current stockpiles of products and materials at October's sales pace.

headline: CHRYSLER TANK UNIT STIRS BUYER INTEREST
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said today that several companies had ''expressed an interest'' in buying Chrysler Defense Inc., the subsidiary that makes tanks for the Army.   Chrysler said, in a terse announcement, that it had provided information about the subsidiary to the unnamed companies and that representatives of the potential buyers had toured the tank plants in Lima, Ohio, and Warren, Mich. Both plants are owned by the Army and operated by Chrysler.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bethlehem S teel Corp., Bethlehem, Pa., has elected to its board Silas S. Cath cart, chairman of Illinois Tool Works Inc. * Business International Corp. has appointed Frank X. White senior vice president in charge of worldwide client programs. *Callahan Mining Corp., Phoenix has named Charles D. Snead Jr., president and chief executive officer, to the additional post of chairman.

headline: INCOME UP 0,6% IN U.S. IN OCTOBER
abstract: Americans' personal income rose sixtenths of 1 percent in October, the smallest increase since May, and their spending declined for the first time since April, the Commerce Department reported today in a new sign that the economy is in recession.   The report ''was not very pleasant news for the economy in general and Christmas shopping in particular,'' said Sandra Shaber, an economist at Chase Econometrics. But consumer spending has been a major prop for an economy that has been sluggish all year, she noted, and seems likely to keep the economy from falling into an even deeper recession than it might otherwise.

headline: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Economic Scene; Finding a Path To Stability
abstract: HOW can national economic policy aimed at curing ''stagflation'' avoid, on one side, the danger of pushing the economy into a depression and, on the other, regenerating higher inflation? The problem is exacerbated today by the overstrained debt positions of many companies, as indicated by liquidity ratios calculated by the Bank of New York.   The classic remedy for a fragile financial structure is recession.  For in a recession two things happen to improve the financial position of corporations: First, although cash flow is reduced, business outlays on capital goods and inventories shrink even more, so the ratio of cash flow to capital and inventory spending improves.    Second, the level of both short- and long-term interest rates comes down, and the yield curve becomes positive, with short rates dropping more than long rates. Corporations, with long rates at their recession lows, then move to convert their short-term obligations into long-term debts, thereby strengthening their liquidity. And investors are more willing to switch from short- to long-term securities.

headline: BUSH TELLS BRAZIL ATOM BAN IS EASED
abstract: Vice President Bush announced tonight that the United States had made a ''special-case exemption'' to allow Brazil, which has not signed the international treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, to purchase fuel for its nuclear reactor.   Aides traveling with the Vice President on his three-nation Latin American tour said this exemption was the first to be granted since Congress passed the so-called Nonproliferation Act in 1978.   The decision came at a time when the Reagan Administration has expressed interest in easing restrictions governing United States nuclear policy toward foreign nations.   It removes a key element of discord between the United States and the increasingly independent-minded leaders of Latin America's largest country. Mr. Bush suggested that a further easing of the restriction could be worked out in the coming year.

headline: No Headline
abstract: MOSCOW SEES A DIRECT THREAT FROM POLAND'S 'ANTISOCIALISTS'   MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (AP) - The Soviet Union charged today that its security was directly threatened by counterrevolutionary elements in Poland, and it condemned Poland's Roman Catholic Church for stirring up what it characterized as anti-Communist sentiment.   Tass, the official Soviet press agency, accused Polish priests of using services to discredit ''actions of the Government in defense of socialism.''   ''At the same time, attacks on the allied ties of Poland are being stepped up and demagogical demands are being made for Poland's withdrawal'' from the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact and the Comecon economic group, Tass said.

headline: Finn Denies Reports Of Impending Merger
abstract: David Finn, a founder of Ruder & Finn, the nation's largest independent public realtions firm, yesterday denied a strong rumor that the company was merging with Harsh-Rotman & Druck, the secondlargest firm.   Mr. Finn did say, however, that the two companies had had conversations in the past - indeed, Ruder & Finn had had conversations with many companies, he said - and that there were more recent conversations as well.   ''It's possible,'' Mr. Finn said, ''that something will develop but there is nothing to report at this point.''

headline: Korean Ship Contracts
abstract: The value of foreign shipbuilding contracts won by South Korean concerns totaled $1.58 billion for 55 ships in the first eight months of this year, more than twice the $748 million for 44 vessels in the comparable 1980 period, officials of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry said today. Korean companies are also negotiating contracts for 47 ships worth $741 million, they said, adding that the ministry expects the 1981 target of $2 billion of ship construction to be surpassed.

headline: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1981; The Economy
abstract: A free trade zone in international banking opens in New York today, and many bankers and state officials predict that the zones will make the city indisputably the world's foremost international financial center. Hundreds of billions of dollars now held by banks overseas are expected to return to New York, and officials predicted that thousands of jobs will be created. (A1.)   President Reagan is likely to seek selective tax increases, including some tightening of rules on business-leasing tax breaks, according to Howard H. Baker Jr., Senate majority leader. The Administration, however, said no proposal on leasing had been developed. (D1.)

headline: Dutch Nuclear Plant Shut
abstract: The only commercial Dutch nuclear power plant was taken out of operation last night after a leak was found in one of its cooling pumps, the provincial electricity authority said. The 450-megawatt plant at Borssele is likely to be out of action for about five days, it said.

headline: G.M. May Offer A 'Basic' Chevrolet
abstract: The General Motors Corporation is considering introducing a lower-priced, stripped-down version of its Chevrolet Cavalier in a bid to increase the car's lagging sales, a Chevrolet spokesman said today.   The lower-priced version of the Cavalier would contain less standard equipment and would be a major departure for a product once advertised as ''the complete car.''

headline: CONVERTING A POLITICAL CLUB IN PARK SLOPE INTO CO-OPS
abstract: It is no ordinary building that the Kossak brothers, Jeffrey and Steven, have found in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn for their first venture in housing development. It is the landmark Weber house, built in 1909 for the president of a brewery and after 1944, when it became the home of the Unity Club, the favored hideaway of leading Brooklyn Demo crats. It is at 101 Eighth Avenue, on the corner of President Str eet.   Nor are the Kossaks ordinary developers, although there is probably no way to categorize that breed except to say that they are all entrepreneurs. Jeffrey Kossak, 33 years old, left law practice on Wall Street two years ago in pursuit of entrepreneurial ventures, real estate and otherwise. And Steven, 31, who is watching over construction in Park Slope, is an artist. He studied painting at Yale and the Maryland Institute of Fine Arts.

headline: Auto Output Down in Japan
abstract: Japan's automobile production in October fell by 3.5 percent, to 970,497 units, from October 1980, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association announced today.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SOME DOMESTIC RADIO AND TELEVISION BROADCASTS IN POLAND
abstract: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency: Solidarity Leaders Detained 10 P.M. Friday   (4 P.M. Friday, E.S.T.) According to a press spokesman for the General Prosecutor's Office, units of the prosecutor's office are continuing determined action to prosecute those who have committed particularly dangerous crimes while martial law is in force.   Prosecutors are also embarking on preventive action. Among other things, prosecutors, accompanied by representatives of the Polish Army, informed the work forces in certain work places of the legal regulations introduced by the provisions of martial law. This has made it possible in many cases to calm the mood of work forces and to keep production flowing without disruption.   This was, for instance, the case in the construction modules factory in Boleslawiec where, on Dec. 14, Jan Filipek, chairman of the Solidarity unit, announced a meeting of the work force and proclaimed a warning strike. After explanations from a prosecutor and an army major, the work force started work, and Jan Filipek fled.  Summary proceedings have been instituted against him.

headline: Massachusetts Bank Merger
abstract: Stockholders of the Shawmut Corporation and Worcester Bancorp have approved the proposed merger of the two bank holding companies at an estimated value of $46.8 million.   The proposed transaction involves the exchange of 1.1 to 1.3 shares of Shawmut stock for each share of Worcester stock. It still must be approved by Federal and state regulators, approval the companies expect within six months.

headline: Market Place; Aiding Hostile Takeover Bids
abstract: INCO'S recent withdrawal from the battery business after becoming mired in losses raises questions about the wisdom of hostile takeovers. Inco had hoped that ESB, formerly the Electric Storage Battery Company, would help it to exploit what it called a ''monopoly in nickel and extensive research in nickel battery technology.''   Inco announced its bid for ESB in July 1974, and it soon became clear that this was no ordinary corporate proposal. Inco's takeover attempt, an unwelcome move, represented something new and important that shocked the business community: This was the first time a conservative blue-chip company had fired its cannon at a peaceable target.

headline: Auto Imports Down in U.S.
abstract: Auto imports to the United States fell 31 percent in September compared with September 1980, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: International Loans Up
abstract: New funds raised on international capital markets totaled $15.1 billion in November, up from $11.7 billion in October but below September's $16.4 billion, the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development said today. The rise from October to November was because of a $2.1 billion increase in the volume of external bond offerings and a $1.3 billion rise in completions for medium-term and long-term syndicated Euroloans, the O.E.C.D. said. The November figures bring the total of new funds raised so far this year to $171 billion, the organization added, but gave no comparative 1980 figures.

abstract: Steel production fell to 1.903 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 1 percent from the previous week's 1.922 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

headline: CUTS IN FOREIGN AID SUDDENLY WORRY REAGAN
abstract: Foreign aid, traditionally a low priority for Republicans, appears to be the only area in which the Reagan Administration believes too little rather than too much money was provided in the budget resolution that Mr. Reagan vetoed today.   The Administration, particularly Secretary of State Alexander M.  Haig Jr., lobbied hard over the weekend to convince House-Senate conferees that military and economic assistance programs were in danger of being undercut by inadequate funds. Economic support, as distinct from food and development aid, is made available to friendly countries that are also recipients of military aid or purchasers of American arms.   Senate Republicans were in agreement. ''The levels contained in the continuing resolution that the President vetoed would severely restrict the President's ability to carry out his foreign policy,'' said Senator Charles H. Percy, the Illinois Republican who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.

headline: Personal Income Up By 0.6%
abstract: Personal income rose a modest six-tenths of 1 percent in November, and spending climbed a full 1 percent for the first time since August, the Commerce Department reported today.   Personal spending by recession-wary Americans fell slightly in September and rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in October.  Michael K. Evans, a private economist who heads a forecasting firm in Washington, called the new figures ''mildly encouraging.'' But he also said the current downturn ''has still got a couple of months to run.''

headline: BUILDING TO BE HALTED ON COAST NUCLEAR PLANTS
abstract: Directors of the Washington Public Power Supply System have approved a $150 million plan to suspend construction of two nuclear power plants for which $2.25 billion has already been raised.   The plants, called No.4 and No.5, are two of five now under construction in the Pacific Northwest. Their financing, plagued by cost overruns and construction delays, has resulted in the largest issuance of public debt from one municipal agency.

headline: ADMINISTRATION POSTPONES ACTION ON SAUDI PLANES
abstract: The Reagan Administration today postponed by a day formal notification to Congress of a plan to sell radar planes to Saudi Arabia. There were reports that the Saudis had agreed to adjustments in the deal.   White House officials said the notification would be filed with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tomorrow morning. Congress then has 30 days in which to disapprove the sale or to let it proceed. A resolution of disapproval would have to be passed by both houses.

headline: LETTER BY WALL ST. TO REAGAN NOTES MARKET INDEPENDENCE
abstract: President Reagan, in an effort to show that Wall Street supports his economic program, read at his news conference today a two-week-old letter from the Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's leading trade group.   But while the letter endorsed the President's economic program, it also expressed the association's view that it will take time both for the program to work and for the financial markets to reflect its success.   And the President left out one pertinent paragraph when he read the letter during his nationally televised news conference - the paragraph that said that stock prices and interest rates move independently of Wall Street's preferences and will continue to do so, in part reflecting investors' expectations of what lies ahead.

abstract: Three people arrested in Milan in connection with the Red Brigades kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier have refused to answer questions and declared themselves political prisoners, the police said today.   No important information about General Dozier, the ranking American officer at NATO headquarters for southern Europe here, has come from the three people in the five days they have been detained.

headline: TWO MORE SENATORS PLANNING TO OPPOSE AWACS SALE TO SAUDIS
abstract: Senator Dale Bumpers announced today that he would oppose the sale of Awacs radar planes and advanced air-to-air missiles to Saudi Arabia.   An aide to Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, said the Senator would also vote against the arms sale.

headline: Business Conditions; A STUBBORN COMMODITY
abstract: Although high interest rates and slumping demand have resulted in sharp price declines for major commodities during the past 12 months, oil prices have bucked those trends.   While the composite price for a barrel of oil to refiners has shown steady declines since April, the $33.57-a-barrel price quoted by the Department of Energy as the September figure is 16 percent above levels of a year earlier.

headline: GROWTH, AND RISKS, FOR BOSCH
abstract: Some people like to think of the Robert Bosch company as a West German auto parts manufacturer with hobbies.  Although Bosch diversified into products like home appliances and radio equipment as early as the 1920's, its reputation still rests largely on its sophisticated auto ignitions, fuel injection and lighting systems.   But now Bosch plans a major investment in telecommunications, using as a channel the operations of the faltering AEG-Telefunken group.  Executives at Bosch headquarters outside this south German city hope the new venture will grow into one of its most profitable.

headline: Lease Fee Rises Asked
abstract: Fees to participate in the Government's popular oil and gas leasing lotteries would triple under a proposal announced today by Interior Secretary James G. Watt. Mr. Watt proposed raising the filing fee from $25 to $75 and increasing rental fees in the second half of the 10-year leases from $1 an acre to $3 an acre. The changes are needed to eliminate ''casual speculative filing'' and encourage those who are interested in developing energy resources, Mr. Watt said.

headline: Patents; EQUIPMENT MONITORS PATIENTS IN SHOCK
abstract: The Institute of Critical Care Medicine, Los Angeles, received a patent this week on apparatus for monitoring the condition of seriously ill patients.

headline: Appliance Park Recall by G.E.
abstract: About 10,000 workers at General Electric Company's giant Appliance Park here have been recalled from two-week furloughs, but 900 G.E. employees with the least seniority face indefinite layoffs beginning Nov. 9.   The 10,000 workers were laid off for two weeks as G.E. sought to reduce its inventory of unsold major appliances such as ranges, refrigerators and washers.

headline: Syrian Communists Lose All Parliamentary Seats
abstract: Parliamentary election results announced today showed that Syria's Communist Party lost all eight seats it held in the previous Parliament, while President Hafez al-Assad's ruling Socialist Baath Party won at least 60 percent of the seats.   The other seats were distributed among the Baath Party's partners in the Government coalition. The Baathist Government is widely regarded one of the Soviet Union's closest Middle East allies.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Bank of New York has named Gerard P. Dougherty, Brian P. Reilly and Robert J. Wolf vice presidents.   * Bausch & Lomb has named Thomas C. McDermott senior vice president-human resources.

headline: CURBS CREDIT AND COMMERCE
abstract: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland. Normal communications with The Times's Warsaw bureau chief, John Darnton, have been barred by the authorities there since Dec. 14.   It is clear that the workers' resistance to martial law and to suppression of their newly won civil and union rights has been more widespread and persistent than the military authorities anticipated.   According to unofficial but knowledgeable sources, many more than 5,000 people - the figure acknowledged by the authorities - have been arrested or interned since the imposition of martial law Dec. 13.   Conditions vary, but many are being held under conditions of little food, clothing or heating in temperatures as low as 10 degrees, these sources say. The information comes from members of a large, semiunderground volunteer effort aimed at bringing relief to those in the prisons and detention camps, where they say 10,000, and perhaps as many as 20,000 people, are being held.
