headline: Kissinger in Singapore
abstract: Former Secretary of State Henry A.  Kissinger arrived here tonight for a four-day private visit in which he will talk informally with leaders from the five-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

headline: LEARNING HOW TO PLAY SANTA AT MACY'S
abstract: Macy's, like most other businesses, has a sharp eye on costs these days, but one would not know it from Santaland. According to its records, Macy's has had a Santa at Herald Square as far back as World War I and possibly since the store's opening in 1902. This year at least 140 people are staffing the department store's eighth-floor Santaland, and visions of 375,000 visitors a day dance in their heads.   The Santas at Macy's are almost all between 20 and 35 years of age and have experience in acting or dancing roles in repertory, Broadway, Off Broadway or television shows. Gone, apparently, are the older, more naturally well-padded Santas of earlier years.

headline: IRAN NAMES 2 TO NEW CABINET
abstract: Iran's Prime Minister completed the formation of his Cabinet today, nominating a new Foreign Minister and a new Interior Minister, the Teheran radio reported.   The state-run radio said Prime Minister Mir Hussein Moussavi introduced Ali Akbar Vellayati to Parliament as his nomination for Foreign Minister and Ali Akbar Nateq Noori, a clergyman, as the new Minister of Interior, to replace Kamaleddin Nik-Ravesh. It was not clear when Parliament would meet to vote on the nominations.

headline: FIRST ATLANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PENN CENTRAL CLIMBS BY 80.6%, TANDY UP BY 57.4% IN QUARTER
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation, a broadly diversified energy, industrial and leisure-products company, reported yesterday that the inclusion of the results of a recently acquired electronics company caused earnings in the third quarter of 1981 to soar 80.6 percent as sales widened by 72 percent.   Penn Central said that net income in the latest three months rose to $58.5 million, or $2.33 a share, from $32.4 million, or $1.10, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales increased to $935.4 million from $543.8 million.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Agriculture Secretary Has Talks in China
abstract: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block of the United States held talks with Chinese officials in Peking today on expanding trade in farm and forestry products, the New China News Agency reported.

headline: SNOWDRIFTS AND WIND SNARL TRAVEL ACROSS LARGE PARTS OF BRITISH ISLES
abstract: Hurricane-force winds and mounting snowdrifts caused chaos in travel today and blacked out large parts of Britain and Ireland. At least one person died in storm-related accidents.   After a night in which temperatures dipped to their lowest on record for the date, a third snowstorm in five days snapped power lines in Devon and Cornwall in southwestern England, southern Wales and Northern Ireland, power company officials said.

headline: CRISIS IN POLAND PART OF U.S. PLOT, PRAVDA CHARGES
abstract: The Soviet Union today published the most comprehensive charges to date that events in Poland over the last 17 months were part of a long and intricate campaign by the United States to wrest Poland from the Communist camp.   Western diplomats asserted that the 3,600-word Pravda article by Vladimir Bolshakov was less remarkable for the substance of its claims than for what it revealed about the Kremlin's insecurity and suspicion.   Mr. Bolshakov described virtually every Polish emigre organization, thousands of Polish-Americans who returned to retire in Poland, all the supplies and donations sent to Solidarity and virtually every contact between the labor union and the West as part of a web spun by the United States Central Intelligence Agency ''to undermine the socialist statehood and to create conditions for a counterrevolutionary coup.''   (Asked to comment on the Pravda article, Mark D. Weinberg, the assistant White House press secretary, said in Washington: ''Charges similar to these have been made in the past. There was no truth to them then and there is no truth to them now.'')

headline: MESA PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Advertising; New Look In Cotton Campaign
abstract: FOR the first time - starting tonight - Cotton Inc., which is dedicated to increasing sales of cotton products in behalf of 50,000 United States cotton growers, will be advertising on the television evening news. And, as usual, its messages will be aimed at a number of audiences made up of buying decision makers.   One is the consumer, who will buy from the retailer. Then there is the retailer, who buys from the manufacturer. Finally, and primarily, there is the manufacturer, who must decide whether he is going to use cotton, or polyester.

headline: JONATHAN LOGAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NICARAGUA ARMS CALLED PERIL TO AREA
abstract: The Reagan Administration is portraying Nicaragua as a serious threat to Central America because of a military buildup directed by Cuba and the Soviet Union.   A senior official, quoting intelligence reports, told reporters today that Nicaragua was ''on the verge of becoming a superpower in Central American terms.'' The official also said that Nicaragua was fostering left-wing insurgencies in Honduras and Guatemala as well as El Salvador. Like other Administration officials and military analysts interviewed on the subject, the official spoke on condition that he not be identified.

headline: Angola Reported Ready To Talk With Rebel
abstract: Angola's Ambassador to Portugal said today that his Government was ready to hold talks with Jonas Savimbi, who has led an armed rebellion against the Marxist Angolan Government for the last six years, the Portuguese news agency reported.   The Government will talk with the rebel leader ''as long as he remains an Angolan citizen and cuts his ties with South Africa,'' Ambassador Adriano Sebastiao said.

headline: HARVESTER REFINANCING SUPPORTED
abstract: Archie McCardell, chairman of the troubled International Harvester Company, predicted today that the company would suffer a ''substantial loss'' in the first quarter of 1982, following a loss of $635.7 million on continuing operations for the fiscal year 1981.   In the fiscal year 1980, Harvester sank $374.8 million into the red.  Mr. McCardell made his prediction as the company was announcing the completion of a $4.2 billion financial restructuring plan, which Harvester officials said was the largest in American corporate history.   The remarks on losses underscored the company's assertion that completion of the financing agreement -after months of negotiation - was only an inital step in pulling the company back from the brink of bankruptcy. 'Volatile Environment'   ''The environment is going to be much more volatile than in the past,'' Mr. McCardell asserted, explaining that demand for the company's heavy trucks, farm machinery and construction equipment could in the coming years be as much as 30 percent below the levels that existed in the late 1970's. Harvester said that its business plan for 1982 assumes that its markets will shrink 10 percent to 15 percent from this year's depressed levels.

headline: Continental Air Near Texas Tie
abstract: The Civil Aeronautics Board said that it will permit the takeover by Texas International Airlines of Continental Air Lines to become effective immediately. The action followed approval of the merger by President Reagan.

headline: EDO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRIAL OF 24 IN SADAT ASSASSINATION OPENS IN CAIRO
abstract: The trial of 24 Moslem fundamentalists charged in connection with the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat opened here today with the 23 defendants who were present in the heavily guarded courtroom appearing in an iron cage before three military judges.   Four defendants are accused of killing Mr. Sadat on Oct. 6 as he watched a parade. The others are accused of complicity. The prosecution has called for the death penalty for all 24, one of whom is still in the hospital with injuries.

headline: WALLACE, SAM P, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BOMBARDIER-MLW LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLES ASK ADMITTANCE INTO I.M.F.
abstract: Poland formally applied today for membership in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Its action opened the door to the possibility of loans from these institutions as a means of dealing with its mounting financial and economic problems.   The move, which has been encouraged by West Germany, the United States and other Western powers and now apparently has the support of the Soviet Union, had been expected in the wake of discussions that have been under way in Europe for several weeks.   Before the latest discussions, the Soviet Union was understood to have vetoed Poland's earlier wish for membership. There was no immediate explanation about why the Russians changed position, but some Western analysts said it could represent recognition that a Polish economic collapse would be costly to them, as well as for Western financial institutions.

headline: Israel to Request a Revision In Statement on Sinai Force
abstract: Israel's Cabinet decided today to request a change in the draft of the proposed American-Israeli statement on the Sinai peacekeeping force.   The revisions are to be forwarded to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. for his approval, according to Aryeh Naor, Cabinet secretary.

headline: Market Place; Saving Taxes For College
abstract: MANY investors have accumulated substantial assets over a lifetime only to see them disappear in a few years of paying college tuition.  But under a little noticed Federal case, some taxpayers have managed to hang onto capital while at the same time funding college tuition costs. They are doing so through interest-free loans to their children.   Assume the student is typical and earns so little that no income tax is due. Parents in the 50 percent tax bracket who lend to that student, by making this transfer, would save half of every dollar earned by this capital.

headline: HAIG IS CONFIDENT SINAI PEACE FORCE WILL BE DEPLOYED
abstract: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that although there may be unresolved questions about the makeup of a Sinai peacekeeping force there was no doubt that a force would be put into place, and that Sinai would be returned to Egypt as planned.   On the Sinai force, Mr. Haig said, ''We are now in the final stages of determining whether it is going to be a broad peacekeeping force, which we prefer, or a narrow one.''   The Secretary was speaking at the headquarters of the Freedoms Foundation in Valley Forge, Pa. The foundation, a private, nonprofit group that promotes the study of the United States Constitution, presented Mr. Haig with its American Patriots Medal.

headline: CANADIAN TIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POLAND'S COAL MINE STRUGGLE
abstract: Andrezej Szoltysik, a 28-year-old miner, walked out of the shower room dressed in blue jeans and a tartan shirt, passing the statue of the Virgin Mary and a banner saying ''God Bless You.''   ''No, I don't work on Saturdays,'' he said. ''It's better to have free time.'' As they emerged from the shower room, other miners, who six hours earlier were dropped in a steel cage 1,500 feet into the heart of a Silesian coal seam, also explained why they were not cooperating with the Government's drive to encourage weekend work in the mines as a way to ease Poland's bitter economic crisis.

headline: Coal Slurry Bill Gains; Coal Slurry Pipeline Bill Advances
abstract: Rejecting efforts to put tighter restrictions on water use, the House Interior Committee today moved closer to approving legislation that would allow pipelines to compete with railroads in bringing Western coal to market.   The committee, considering a bill that would give pipeline companies the right to condemn land they need for right of way, rejected a series of amendments that would have restricted access to state water supplies. The preliminary votes set the stage for approval of the bill tomorrow.

headline: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Mayor of Hiroshima Protests Nuclear Tests
abstract: Hiroshima, the target of an atomic bomb in World War II, sent telegrams to the United States and the Soviet Union today protesting nuclear tests carried out by both nations yesterday.   The telegrams, signed by Mayor Takeshi Araki of Hiroshima, were sent to the Ambassadors of the United States and the Soviet Union, Mike Mansfield and Dmitri S. Polyansky.   City officials said the Mayor, in his telegrams, criticized yesterday's nuclear tests in Nevada and Novaya Zemlya, an archipeligo in the Soviet northwest, and called for an end to nuclear testing.

headline: Curtiss Seeks More Of Western Union
abstract: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, whose chairman, T. Roland Berner, almost succeeded in taking over the Kennecott Corporation last year, said yesterday that it intended to acquire at least $15 million worth of Western Union Corporation stock.   That stock, which has been advancing steadily from $22 at midyear, rose $1.50 yesterday, to $30.75.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: President Reagan's surprise remark that the nation's economy was in a ''slight recession'' may have startled his economic advisers, but it is not likely to send this Administration on the search for new policy initiatives.   In the face of a recession, there is remarkably little pressure on the Administration to change its economic policy. The reason is that, taken together, the President's huge personal tax cuts and the promised increases in military spending could turn out to be the stimulative spark the economy needs to escape the doldrums.   ''This would be a great time to have a tax cut,'' Murray L.  Weidenbaum, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today in an interview. ''And guess what?'' Mr.  Weidenbaum said, alluding to the Administration's three-year, 25 percent individual tax cut, ''it's already baked into the cake.''

headline: Penn Central
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation said it had acquired Willis Drilling Company Inc., a privately held company based in Edinburgh, Tex., for undisclosed terms. Penn Central said the acquisition would increase the number of drilling rigs it owns to 32. Willis owns six drilling rigs and has a seventh on order that will become operational next year, Penn Central said.

headline: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The Administration has dropped its proposal to Congress for $3 billion in new revenue for 1982, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said. The figure was part of President Reagan's Sept. 24 proposal to raise $22 billion in tax revenue over three years. Mr. Regan said in an interview that the larger package still stands. Meanwhile, Congressional analysts said the B-1 bombers sought by the President would cost $39.8 billion, double the Air Force's estimate. (Page A1.)    New York State savings banks lost a total of $372 million in the third quarter, 23 percent more than the record level of the second quarter, according to Muriel Siebert, the state's Superintendent of Banks. She indicated she expected more failures. (D1.)

headline: TREASURY BACKS CHANGE IN SAVINGS BABK AID
abstract: In a major policy shift, the Treasury Department today supported a legislative change that would make it easier for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to assist financially troubled mutual savings banks.   The department's new position, favoring a liberalization of rules governing the F.D.I.C.'s infusion of capital into these institutions, was expected to be particularly important in New York, where there are many mutual savings banks. It was announced as the Reagan Administration endorsed proposals to increase competition within the banking and financial services industry.   The F.D.I.C. insures deposits in nearly 15,000 commercial and mutual savings banks. It now has the authority to lend capital to institutions hit by unfavorable economic circumstances, and has used this authority several times in recent months. But it can do so only if the institutions are found to be ''essential to provide adequate banking services in the community.'' The Treasury Department said today that it would agree to drop this provision.

headline: Bausch & Lomb To End Eyeglasses
abstract: Bausch & Lomb Inc., for generations a well-known name in precision lenses, said today that it planned to discontinue its eyeglass business worldwide to emphasize its retail contact lens and growing scientific instrument operations.   Daniel E. Gill, president of the leading maker of soft contact lenses, cited declining profits from the sale of eyeglass frames, ophthalmic glass and eyeglass lenses for the decision.

headline: SENATE BILL ASKS BANK DECONTROL
abstract: Senator Jake Garn, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee , citing the ''revolution th at is taking place in the financial services industry,'' introduced legislation today designed to help banks and thrift institution s compete more effectively against other institutions offeri ng financial services.   The Utah Republican's bill, which among other things would authorize banks and thrift institutions to sell interests in mutual funds and permit commercial banks to underwrite municipal revenue bonds, is expected to open up a major battle with the securities industry.   The legislation chips away at barriers nearly a half-century old that have kept banks out of the securities business. Its introduction follows a series of moves by the securities industry in recent years to offer bank-type services.

headline: Bally Acquisition
abstract: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, the world's leading manufacturer of coin-operated amusement games, said it had reached an agreement to acquire the Scientific Games Development Corporation, a major designer, producer and supplier of instant and weekly lottery games. Bally operates a casino-hotel in Atlantic City and a national chain of family amusement centers. It had 1980 sales of $690 million.

headline: REICHHOLD CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAELI SETTLERS IN SINAI START FORTIFYING TOWN
abstract: The Israeli Cabinet today invited the 6,000 settlers in the Sinai Peninsula to reopen negotiations with the Government on compensation for their evacuation from the region, which is required under the terms of the Camp David accords with Egypt. But a committee representing the settlers promptly turned down the offer, saying the proposal contained nothing new, and the settlers began fortifying their positions.   The settlers began digging communications trenches and positions along the perimeter fence of Yamit, their frontier desert town, and hinted at the possibility of bloodshed if the Government tried to evict them before a satisfactory agreement was reached on compensation for the business and property they must leave behind.

headline: MOUNTAIN
abstract: Inflation and recession have caused Western economists to revise downward their projections of regional labor growth, but the general belief is that the Rocky Mountain area, in the words of Walter R.  Siebert of the Rocky Mountain States Employers Council, ''will continue to experience steady growth, with energy development playing a key role.''   Helen Rubenstein, an economist with the Colorado Division of Employment and Training, for example, predict ed that there would be no ''recession-type environment'' in Colorado in the year ahead.

headline: Egypt-U.S. Wheat Deal
abstract: The United States will sell Egypt 1.1 million tons of wheat and wheat flour worth $200 million at concessionary rates under its Food for Peace program, United States officials said today. The agreement is the largest single element in Washington's civilian aid package to Egypt, now running at more than $1 billion a year. Under an agreement signed here yesterday, Egypt will pay for the wheat over 40 years at an interest rate of less than 3 percent.

headline: WIDER HOUSE ROLE IN A.T.&T. DEBATE
abstract: Every branch of government seems to be getting in on the act of reshaping the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and, in the process, national policy in telecommunications.   The Justice Department is pursuing a longstanding antitrust suit.  The Federal Communications Commission has outlined its own program for splitting the company into a regulated telephone company and an unregulated equipment and data-processing company. The Senate has passed its own bill laying down a new structure. And the Reagan Administration is pressing its own views. Attention Shifts to House   Now attention is shifting to the House of Representatives, where Timothy E. Wirth, a Colorado Democrat who specializes in communications policy, expects approval by next June of legislation lifting restrictions on A.T.& T. and promoting competition in the communications industry.

headline: Honda to Build Ohio Parts Plant
abstract: The Honda Motor Company said it would build a $3 million parts factory to employ 200 people next to its new $200 million auto assembly plant.

headline: WALKER COLOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SUDAN CALLS U.S. AID DEFICIENT
abstract: The Sudan asserted today that military aid offered by the United States was insufficient to meet its immediate defense needs.   The implied criticism was made by Gen. Abdel Magid Hamid Khali, the country's First Vice President and Defense Minister, who told a news conference that United States military aid totaling $100 million in the current fiscal year contained unspecified ''deficiencies'' that could only be remedied with long-term assistance.   The American military aid package, which is to include M-60 tanks and F-5 warplanes, would ''upgrade the efficiency of our defense means in the near future,'' the General said, but did ''not meet our total demand.''

headline: ACME UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CLEVEPAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NET RISES AT MONSANTO, DIGITAL
abstract: The Monsanto Company reported yesterday that the sale of part of its petrochemicals business caused earnings in the third quarter to more than quadruple, as sales increased 5.8 percent.   The St. Louis-based company, the nation's fourth-largest chemical concern, said that net income in the latest three months climbed to $123.6 million, or $3.09 a share, from $29.6 million, or 81 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1980. Sales expanded to $1.63 billion from $1.54 billion.   John W. Hanley, chairman and chief executive of Monsanto, said the previously announced sale to E.I.du Pont de Nemours & Company of a joint petrochemical venture by Monsanto and Conoco Inc. on the Texas Gulf Coast added an after-tax gain of $67.7 million, or $1.75 a share, to Monsanto's third-quarter results.

headline: Rumanian Crop-Burner Jailed
abstract: A court in eastern Rumania has sentenced a state farm manager to two years in prison for burning his unharvested crops, a Bucharest newspaper reported. Reports circulating in Bucharest recently said some farm managers had burned corps that could not be harvested before the Government-set deadline so they could report harvesting all crops on schedule.

headline: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Harvester Order
abstract: The International Harvester Company, its traditional business for farm implements battered by the nation's economic slowdown, said it had secured a multimillion-dollar order from the Army for 769 rough terrain forklifts. Harvester said the contract is worth $53 million over four years and could reach a value of $128 million if the Army exercises an option for another 769 units. Production is set to begin at Harvester's Libertyville plant next August, the company said.

headline: Ashland Talks
abstract: The Ashland Oil Company said it was negotiating to acquire the Tresler Oil Company, a privately held fuel distributor based here. Ashland, with yearly sales of $7 billion, is a wholesale supplier for Tresler, which markets gasoline, heating oil and other petroleum products and owns a chain of service stations.  The purchase could improve Ashland's gasoline sales by insuring that Ashland would be Tresler's only supplier.

headline: U.S. BLOCKS DOCUMENTS ON ENERGY
abstract: The Reagan Administration today invoked executive privilege for the first time, and refused to hand over various documents to a House oversight subcommittee exploring ways to curb takeovers by Canadians of United States energy companies.   Interior Secretary James G. Watt told the subcommittee during a two-and-a-half-hour appearance that he would not deliver the subpoenaed documents, despite indications that he might be cited for contempt of Congress.   The Secretary invoked a memorandum signed by the President. ''It is my decision,'' President Reagan said in the memorandum he signed yesterday before Mr. Watt's appearance, ''that you should not release these documents since they either deal with sensitive foreign policy negotiations now in process or constitute materials prepared for the Cabinet as part of the executive branch deliberative process through which recommendations are made to me.''

headline: AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Oct. 1, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.  Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. adn 3 P.M.  Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.  Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 3 P.M.  Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M.  THE U. N. TODAY

headline: HOW TO CHOOSE A REAL ESTATE AGENT
abstract: B ECAUSE persistently high interest rates have put a crimp in the housing market, a homeowner's choice of the right real estate agent can be crucial. But in a business where much depends on intangibles, and where word-of-mouth can be as important as a track record, selection is not easy.   ''What a seller really is looking for is a buyer,'' says Joan Harris Spencer, who runs a real estate agency of the same name in Bronxville, N.Y. What that means is an agent who seems to offer the greatest likelihood of locating qualified buyers, and one who will not let the deal fall through because of problems in arranging financing.   Today, the best agent may be someone who can skillfully maneuver buyers and sellers through the intricacies of ''creative financing.'' ''There are at least 40 different ways of financing a sale, and if an agent can't name at least 10 right off the bat, you might want to find someone else,'' suggests Norman N. Kailo, sales manager of the Soldoveri Agency of Totowa and Wayne, N.J., and past president of the New Jersey Association of Realtors.

headline: POLLOCK PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Penn Central Suit Ended
abstract: A Federal judge today dismissed a suit filed by a group of Penn Central Corporation stockholders who sought to stop the company's proposed acquisition of Colt Industries.   In an unusual, 2 1/2-hour oral opinion, United States District Judge Lewis Pollack said that the proposed merger would not violate Penn Central's earlier acquisition agreement with the Marathon Manufacturing Company, of Texas, acquired by Penn Central in December 1979, nor would it violate Pennsylvania, New York or United States merger laws.

headline: K-TEL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Gulf and Western Stake in Polaroid
abstract: Gulf and Western Industries, a diversified New York-based manufacturer with extensive minority investments in other companies, said it had purchased 1.88 million shares, or 5.72 percent, of the common stock of the Polaroid Corporation in a transaction valued at $38.75 million.   In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said that its purchase was for investment purposes and that it might either make further purchases or dispose of its holdings, depending on market conditions. News of the purchase helped send Polaroid's stock up 3/4 of a point, to 21 3/4, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: INTEGRITY ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Big Textile Deficit Seen
abstract: The United States will have a $5.4 billion textile and apparel trade deficit this year, its largest in history, according to Robert E. Coleman, president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute.

headline: 5 Children Lost in Floods
abstract: Flash floods washed five children out to sea, wrecked 150 homes and caused a new bridge to collapse here after two days of heavy rain, officials said today. Up to 900 people were made homeless by floods from the Dumaca River, which runs through this city 60 miles southeast of Manila.

headline: CHARITY DILEMMA FOR BUSINESS
abstract: Corporate America, under pressure from President Reagan to step up charitable contributions as the Government cuts its own spending, is grappling with just how deeply it should be involved in philanthropy.    For years, business leaders across the country have supported organizations that they believed indirectly benefited their companies, shareholders, employees and customers.   "Our job is more than making a product," said John Bacon, director of corporate contributions at R.J. Reynolds Industries, one of the leading corporate gift-givers.  There has been a growing realization, he added, that business was "the last pool of substantial resources" for philanthropy.   Indeed, many companies are willing to join forces in support of a single project, said Richard F. Neblett, the Exxon Corporation's coordinator of contributions.  He recently invited other executives to discuss a combined effort to aid the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: AMERICAN HERITAGE LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: More Steel Suits Seen
abstract: The Government will file another series of lawsuits against foreign steel-exporting countries this week or next, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.   Last week the Commerce Department announced it had filed suits against Belgium, Brazil, Rumania, France and South Africa accusing them of subsidizing steel exports to the United States at unfairly low prices. Mr. Baldrige declined to say how many suits would be filed.   ''We will have a final decision this week or next week,'' he said.  ''At that time, we will bring as many suits as we feel we can prove.''

headline: WEST GERMAN PARTIES RESISTING NATO MISSILE PLAN
abstract: Regional conventions of both the Social Democratic and Free Democratic Parties passed resolutions over the weekend rejecting the planned deployment in Western Europe of new United States medium-range missiles.   The votes appear to be evidence that the start of United States-Soviet negotiations in Geneva on arms reductions and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's meetings in Bonn with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, had little effect in altering resistance in segments of both parties to NATO's missile program.   Several leading members of the Social Democratic and Free Democratic Parties, which make up the Government coalition, had privately suggested to Americans that opposition to the missiles would start to dissipate once the arms talks were under way.

headline: Patents; Fee Rise Asked for Patents
abstract: WASHINGTON THE cost of getting and maintaining patents and trademarks is likely to be substantially increased. Gerald J. Mossinghoff, Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, told a meeting of attorneys this week that proposals will be made to adopt charges in the fiscal year 1983 that are several times as high as current rates.

headline: Celanese to End Textured Yarn
abstract: The Celanese Corporation said that it plans to terminate the production and sale of textured polyester yar n by the end of next year.

headline: Careers; New Titles For New Demands
abstract: THERE are at least five vice presidencies in many large corporations today that did not even exist a decade or more ago, according to Dr. J. Ray Watson, assistant dean for executive education at Duke University's Fuqua Graduate School of Business.   His list includes vice presidents in charge of information systems, quality control, human resources, distribution and government relations.   ''With the coming of the new vice presidencies there is more pinpointing of responsibility, and new rewards are based on critical success factors in each area,'' Dr. Watson said.   The post of vice president in charge of information systems, for example, is a logical outgrowth of the needs to computerize company operations in many areas. In fact, a recent study issued by Russell Reynolds Associates Inc., the management recruiting firm, notes that demand this year for experts in information systems and computers continues strong despite the economic slump.

headline: EGYPT ARRESTS 230 IN A 'TERRORIST RELIGIOUS GROUP'
abstract: The Government announced tonight that its security forces had arrested 230 members of a ''terrorist religious group'' who had planned assassinations and other acts of violence to undermine public security.   Although the Government statement did not identify the group by name, it was believed that those arrested belonged to Takfir Wahigra, the underground fundamentalist organization that has been blamed by the authorities for the Oct. 6 assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat. The group, whose name means Atonement and Repentance, was also accused of being behind the large-scale fighting that erupted two days later in Asyut, Upper Egypt, when armed men operating in paramilitary units overran a police station and attacked other Government targets.   Today's statement linked the arrests to the Asyut fighting. It said that some of the arrested men ''confessed that they had planned to carry the uprising in Asyut'' into another area, ''but decided against it because they suffered heavy losses.'' A large security force has been operating in Asyut, ferreting out hideaways of suspected terrorists ever since the fighting started.

headline: PROTESTS GROW IN MANILA SINCE EASING OF LAW
abstract: More than 1,000 people crowded into the gymnasium of a seminary here today to call for the release of political detainees and the end of purported civil rights abuses by the Philippine military.   The occasion was the 33d anniversary of the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights. The rally was staged to test the recently restored freedoms of assembly and expression in the Philippines and to protest what the demonstrators call United States approval of Philippine human rights policies.

headline: Around the World; Brazilian Labor Leader Is Sentenced to 3 1/2 Years
abstract: A military court Thursday sentenced the nation's top labor leader to three and a half years in prison for inciting workers to strike illegally.

headline: Patents; A Method for Treating Malignancies in the Eye
abstract: A method of treating malignancies in the eye by inserting a capsule filled with an effective drug was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline: TODD SHIPYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOVIET SAYS MOVES ARE UP IN POLAND
abstract: The first official Soviet comment on events in Poland said today that they were ''an internal matter.'' It described any ''different interpretation'' implying Soviet manipulation as an attempt in itself to interfere in Polish affairs.   The statement, issued by the Government's press agency Tass, indicated that the Kremlin, was eager to counter charges in the West that Soviet pressure had forced the Polish authorities to impose martial law and suspend the operations of the Solidarity trade union, and the statement did not explicitly endorse the crackdown. Moves Termed Polish Initiative   The Soviet press has presented the crackdown as a purely Polish initiative to save the country from the ''mortal danger'' of counterrevolution.

headline: CSX Corp. Net Soars by 87.5%
abstract: The CSX Corporation, a diversified railroad holding company formed through the November 1980 merger of the Chessie System and Seaboard Coast Line industries, reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter ended Sept. 30 soared 87.5 percent while revenues increased 16.7 percent.

headline: HOW TO UNSTOP A JOB BOTTLENECK
abstract: ''I EXPECTED to get the jobs no one else wanted when I started working,'' said Paul Waggoner, a college graduate who was employed in the corporate-communications office of a large bank for eight months. ''But even though I've been given good raises, I've been assigned more and more secretarial work than writing jobs, which I was promised when they hired me.''   Mr. Waggoner's complaint is a common one. With the labor market increasingly bottlenecked with highly educated workers more experienced than the recent college graduates, those who find work in their chosen fields are discovering that it's a slow climb up the ladder.

headline: Crocker Bank Sues Rockwell
abstract: Crocker National Bank has filed suit in Federal court here seeking $52.8 million in damages from the Rockwell International Corporation and two other defendants in a dispute over financing of data processing equipment.   Also named as defendants by the California bank and its parent, the Crocker National Corporation, were Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., a New York investment banker and securities underwriter, and the New York law firm of Singer, Hutner, Levine & Seeman.

headline: EASTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ADOBE OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Technology; 'Zoning' Rules For Satellites
abstract: THE demand for satellite communications facilities is so strong, compared with the present supply, that owning a satellite or the rights to use it has been likened to owning a desirable piece of real estate. That was demonstrated last month when the RCA Corporation decided to auction off leases for seven satellite facilities. The winning bids totaled $90.1 million.   This real estate in the sky is now facing a possible ''zoning'' change. The Federal Communications Commission proposes to cut the spacing between domestic communications satellites in half - to 2 degrees of longitude from 4 degrees. That would double the number of satellites that could be placed in the part of the orbit controlled by the United States.

headline: Porsche Prices Up
abstract: Volkswagen of America is increasing prices on its 1982 Porsche and Audi models an average of 3.2 percent, or about $516 a car, from 1981 levels, the auto maker said. Prices on optional equipment for the imported models are also going up an average of 6.8 percent, VW said. Base prices for the Porsche-Audi models range from $9,755 for the Audi 4000 to $39,500 for the Porsche 928.

headline: MARVIN JOSEPHSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MOROCCO REPORTS MAJOR BATTLE
abstract: King Hassan II said tonight that two Moroccan planes were shot down today by Soviet-made missiles in a major battle in the Western Sahara.   In a letter to world leaders, the King accused Algerian-backed Polisario guerrillas of launching an attack on the Moroccan garrison of Guelta Zemmur from neighboring Mauritania.   He said SAM-6 or SAM-8 missiles were used to shoot down an American-made Hercules C-130 troop transport and a French-made Mirage F-1 fighter.

headline: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1981; Companies
abstract: An agreement for U.S. Steel to acquire Marathon Oil for about $6.3 billion was announced by the two companies. The dramatic new step in Marathon's effort to fend off a takeover by Mobil would, if consumated, create the nation's 13th-largest industrial concern. The takeover would be the second-largest ever, surpassed only by Du Pont's $7.3 billion purchase of Conoco. More than 1.5 million Marathon shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange. The company's stock soared $27.25, closing at $104.25. (Page A1.)   Serious questions about the U.S. Steel-Marathon agreement were raised both in Congress and at the Commerce Department. (D4.) Analysts said the proposed merger was another indication that the steel industry was increasingly looking beyond the bounds of its traditional business for growth. (D4.) The U.S. Steel bid consists of a combination of cash and notes that would be offered for the 60 million outstanding shares of Marathon stock. (D5.)

headline: MEESE DEFENDS ACTIONS OF ADMINISTRATION AIDES IN ALLEN CASE
abstract: Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, said today that both White House and Justice Department officials had been ''scrupulously'' correct in their contacts during the investigation into a $1,000 payment to Richard V. Allen, the White House national security adviser, by a Japanese magazine.   Mr. Meese, speaking on the CBS News ''Face the Nation'' program, acknowledged that the Allen controversy might ''do some damage'' to the Reagan Presidency. ''We hope it won't be a great deal of damage,'' Mr. Meese added, promising that the Justice Department inquiry must ''totally clarify and absolve'' Mr. Allen's behavior or ''appropriate action will be taken.''   In a related development, an Administration official confirmed today that three top assistants to Attorney General William French Smith met Friday with William H. Webster, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and criticized the quality of the F.B.I.'s investigation of Mr. Allen. Renewed Investigation Ordered   Justice Department officials called for a renewed investigation of Mr. Allen because of evidence found in Mr. Allen's safe indicating that he might have received $10,000 rather than $1,000, The New York Times reported today, quoting an Administration official who asked not to be named because of the sensitivity of the matter.

headline: POLES IN TORONTO START A PRO-SOLIDARITY PAPER
abstract: A small group of Polish-Canadians has begun a publishing venture to support the Solidarity labor movement in Poland and possibly give themselves new careers in Canada.   Led by Alexander Pruszynski, who came to Canada nine years ago, the group publishes a new weekly newspaper here, Slowo, or The Word. The paper includes four pages of locally written news in Polish plus a complete 16-page reprint of the Solidarity newspaper that is published in Warsaw and smuggled out of the country to supporters abroad.

headline: MONOCLONAL ANTIBODIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 20
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SEARS EARNINGS WEAKER
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company, which announced agreements this week to acquire a major securities firm and a nationwide real estate brokerage for more than $780 million, said yesterday that thirdquarter earnings ''will not exceed and may be slightly lower'' than in the comparable 1980 quarter.   The retailing group said that ''merchandising results are expected to improve compared with the 1980 quarter.'' But the company added in a statement that overall figures had been adversely affected by ''deteriorating'' underwriting results caused by higher-thanexpected claim payments by Sears's Allstate Insurance subsidiary.

headline: WALESA HOLDS TALKS WITH POLISH ARCHBISHOP
abstract: Lech Walesa, leader of the Solidarity union movement, met today with the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, apparently to discuss deteriorating relations between the independent union and the Government.   The union's news service, which announced the meeting, did not disclose the nature of the talks. Church sources who asked not to be identified said the discussions lasted two-and-a-half hours, but they gave no details.

headline: Week's Coal Output Up
abstract: The National Coal Association reported today that bituminous coal production for the week ended Dec. 12 was 17,250,000 tons, up from the previous week's production of 16,430,000 tons.

headline: Advertising; A New Shopping Promotion
abstract: year-old former football hero for Cornell and the Buffalo Bills, gets his thrills these days from end runs in the supermarket aisles and shelves rather than on the gridiron. The longer the checkout lines, the happier he is, especially if he is responsible.   As part of Weston/Herron Promotions, Westport, Conn., he has devised a new promotion that is intended to help the retailer avoid the expensive and nonproductive practice of bonus couponing. He is calling it Shoppers Reward, and it is similar to Cash Rebate, a promotion he devised before being discharged from the Glendinning Companies in 1979.

headline: BAKER SEES NO CHANGE IN AWACS TERMS
abstract: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader of the Senate, said today that he did not envision any important change in the terms and conditions of the proposed sale of Awacs radar aircraft to Saudi Arabia.   He said, however, that he believed it was still possible to prevent defeat for the proposed sale when the Senate votes on Wednesday.  The Tennessee Republican's remarks, made during a television appearance on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' seemed to confirm statements by Administration officials that no effort was made to reopen or to renegotiate the terms of the $8.5 billion sale of the Airborne Warning and Control System planes and other air combat equipment when President Reagan met Friday in Cancun, Mexico, with Prince Fahd, the administrative head of the Saudi Arabian Government.   Some Senators, including Republicans who have indicated they might consider switching from opposition to support of the sale, have said they would be influenced by any modification of the outright Saudi control and ownership of the Awacs aircraft that is an important element of the present proposal.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Three 'Detained' Poles Turn Out to Be Abroad
abstract: At least three of the 57 unionists and dissidents reported by the Warsaw radio to be interned in Poland are abroad.  Two - Miroslaw Chojecki and Wojciech Karpinski - were in New York on Thursday.

headline: Cave-In Suit: $219 Million
abstract: The Diamond Crystal Salt Company said today that it was seeking $219 million from Texaco Inc. and the State of Louisiana for damages resulting from the spectacular collapse of its Jefferson Island salt mine a year ago.   A news release from the Michigan-based company said that the estimate of damages was contained in an amendment to the lawsuits filed earlier in Federal District Court in Lafayette and in a Louisiana district court at Baton Rouge.

headline: SOCIALIST TEST: TAXING RICHES OF THE FRENCH
abstract: ''The opposition should at least be consistent,'' Budget Minister Laurent Fabius said, looking haggard after spending a hard week in the National Assembly over the Government's proposed wealth tax. ''First they attack us for making it too harsh. When we amend it, they say it is ineffectual.''   The wealth tax, which began last week as one of the big symbolic spearheads of the Socialist battle to create a more egalitarian economic system, has come out the size of a penknife.

headline: U.S. STUDY TELLS OF AFGHAN DEADLOCK
abstract: A State Department analysis made public to mark the second anniversary of the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan depicts a deadlock in which both insurgents and the Soviet-backed Government are weakened by internal divisions.   On the one side, the ruling People's Democratic Party is reported to be divided between two factions. On the rebel side, the State Department says, ''the resistance movement as a whole remains fragmented'' and ''liberation forces occasionally fight each other to establish territorial pre-eminence.''   The report, ''Afghanistan: Two Years of Occupation,'' was compiled by the department's Bureau of Intelligence and Research. A senior official discussed it this week and it was released for publication today. It will be made available to the public on Monday.

headline: SOVIET FIRM ON GOALS OF 5-YEAR PLAN
abstract: Soviet planners today reported a poor start on the current five-year plan and a sizable reduction in projected capital investment. But they still asserted that they planned to stick with most economic goals set by the Communist Party through 1985.   The targets announced before the Supreme Soviet by Nikolai K.  Baibakov, chairman of the State Planning Committee, would require four successive harvests of a level never previously approached and a dramatic upturn in labor productivity.

headline: Texaco Credit Action Fought
abstract: Wholesalers of Texaco gasoline filed suit to block the imposition of a proposed 3 percent surcharge on retail credit card sales of Texaco gasoline starting Nov. 1.   Attorneys for the National Association of Texaco Wholesalers sought a preliminary injunction against the Texaco Inc., surcharge in a class-action suit filed in United States District Court for the District of Columbia.

headline: GROUP PROPOSES MERGER RULES
abstract: An informal study group of antitrust experts has recommended that the Government adopt rules to make it clearer when mergers between direct competitors would be allowed. The group has also proposed guidelines that, if adopted, could effectively increase the number of such mergers that would be permitted.   The recommendations by the nine members were contained in an 80-page report recently sent to the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission. Both agencies are revising their own merger criteria in preparation for an attempt to agree on guidelines that both would use. The report will be published in the Columbia Law Review in February.

headline: TRANS WORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOW THE U.S. STRUCK OUT IN JAPAN
abstract: TOKYO VIEWED against the huge trade deficit the United States is running with Japan, expected to reach as much as $15 billion this year, the market for aluminum baseball bats in Japan is puny - roughly $15 million a year.   Yet the story of how American metal bat makers were first pushed back in the Japanese market during the middle 1970's, after holding a leadership position, and then excluded altogether is becoming a cause celebre among American trade officials.   The reason is that, faced with mounting trade deficits with Japan, American and Western European officials have started all-out campaigns to try to open up what they regard as the clam-like economic system of Japan. Foreigners charge that there are many Japanese markets that can be exceedingly difficult to crack, including those for beef, citrus fruits, pharmaceuticals, financial services, communications equipment and computers.   To be sure, foreign companies trying to sell in Japan have often invested too little time and money in learning the markets, product preferences and the ways of doing business here - not to mention mastering the difficult Japanese language. But what also deters many companies from making long-term commitments in Japan is the perception that its markets are inhospitable. Accordingly, they seek more promising opportunities elsewhere. The Japanese, for their part, have long held that the notion of a closed Japanese economy is outdated.

headline: Burroughs Wellcome Fills Combined Post
abstract: William M. Sullivan, 47, has been named chairman and president of the Burroughs Wellcome Company, a major pharmaceutical manufacturer with headquarters in Research Triangle Park, N.C. He succeeds Fred A. Coe Jr., who retired from the American subsidiary of the Wellcome Foundation, a British multinational corporation, at the age of 65.   Looking at his industry, and the impact of liberalized marketing of generic drugs, Mr. Sullivan, in a telephone interview, said that ''those companies that are able to develop new products are doing well.''

headline: TV Stereotypes
abstract: To the Business Editor: In Jan R. Van Meter's article, ''A Message for the Medium'' (Oct.  25), he offered some free advice on how to deal with special interest groups who threaten boycotts because they do not like television programs that companies sponsor.   Unfortunately, Mr. Van Meter devalues his advice by basing it on stereotypes about television.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * A.M. International Inc. said it had completed the sale of the United States portion of its Addressograph division to D.B.S. Inc., a privately held investment company based in Randolph, Mass., for undisclosed terms.   * Charter Co. said it had agreed in principle to sell two AM and four FM radio stations to Surrey Broadcasting Co. of Tuscon, Ariz., at an undisclosed price.   * Cone Mills Corp. said Sunbury Textile Mills Inc., a company that it had tentatively agreed to acquire, had called off merger negotiations.

headline: SOME ARE SAD TO LEAVE LIBYA
abstract: Several Americans in Libya said today that they did not feel threatened, and wanted to stay there despite a request by President Reagan that they leave.   With businesses closed for the Moslem Sabbath, some Americans played soccer, while others listened to the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corporation for more information on the decision announced Thursday by the Reagan Administration.   Four Americans reached by telephone in Tripoli said that they thought the United States Government and the American press had exaggerated their difficulties in Libya. There are 1,500 Americans in Libya, mostly oil company employees and their families.

headline: MACANDREWS & FORBES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Company Earnings; DUPONT NET SOARS ON CONOCO RESULTS
abstract: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that the inclusion of the results of Conoco Inc. for the last two months of the third quarter caused net income in that period almost to triple as sales more than doubled.   Du Pont's merger with Conoco, the nation's ninth-largest oil company, became effective on Sept. 30.  Du Pont, the nation's biggest chemical company, said that earnings in the latest three months soared to $278 million, or $1.44 a share, from $86 million, or 54 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues advanced to $7.24 billion from $3.23 billion.

headline: Personal Finance; Q. & A.: HOUSING, DIVORCE, THE I.R.S.
abstract: T HE following are answers to some questions asked recently by readers.  Q: I'd like to take advantage of the new rule that lets older people exclude from income up to $125,000 of their profits when they sell their home. I'm over 55 and have lived in my apartment for 15 years, but have only owned it the two years that it has been a cooperative. Do I qualify?   A: No. The law requires that you must have owned, as well as occupied, the home as your principal dwelling for three out of the five years preceding the date of sale. You'll have to hold on to your co-op for another year in order to qualify for this tax break.

headline: Sawdon Named Agency For La Yogurt
abstract: Sawdon & Bess, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, is going to be the ad agency for La Yogurt French Style Yogurt, a product of Johanna Farms in Flemington, N.J.   The product, which was previously handled by Venet Advertising, will be distributed all along the East Coast, according to Jerome Bess, chief officer, who was closed-mouthed about the budget but obviously thinking big thoughts about moo-la.

headline: Houses Votes Banking Bill
abstract: The House tonight approved by voice vote a bill that would free banks from having to charge Federal insurance fees on deposits attracted to special international accounts that are to go into effect on Dec. 3.   The bill, which exempts the deposits from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation assessment of one-twelfth of 1 percent, now goes to the Senate where similar legislation is pending.

headline: DeLorean Is Cleared
abstract: John Z. DeLorean was cleared today of any financial wrongdoing in setting up an assembly line with heavy British Government subsidies to build a stainless steel sports car in Northern Ireland. Britain's Director of Public Prosecutions said after a police inquiry that there was no evidence to support accusations against Mr. DeLorean by a former employee, Marian Gibson. Miss Gibson said that Mr. DeLorean, a former General Motors vice president, put in only a small fraction of the $7.2 million he was required to invest in return for the $125 million he secured in Government grants and loans.

headline: MITTERRAND TELLS THE AFRICANS FRANCE WILL KEEP UP ITS AID
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand promised today that France would continue the active role it has traditionally played in its former African colonies, but with a difference.   At the start of a two-day meeting here with leaders and observers from 30 African nations, Mr. Mitterrand and other French officials repeatedly suggested that France will continue to assist with the defense and development of African nations, but it would not interfere in their internal politics.   In an interview today with the newspaper Le Monde, Mr. Mitterrand said ''No, we will not intervene in others' internal affairs; yes, we are present on the African scene and we shall fulfil on it the full range of our obligations.''

headline: U.N. Extends Cyprus Force
abstract: The United Nations Security Council decided today to keep peacekeeping troops in Cyprus for another six months.

headline: IC LIFTS CASH SHARE OF SUNBEAM OFFER
abstract: The bidding battle for the Sunbeam Corporation continued yesterday as IC Industries increased the number of shares it would buy for cash to 12 million, or 80 percent of the total shares outstanding, from 7.25 million, or 48 percent.   IC's offer remained at $36 a share.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The Polish crackdown against the independent trade union Solidarity may not be as successful as it is pictured in official pronouncements from Warsaw, according to analysts in Washington and at NATO headquarters in Brussels.   One analyst said that the two Soviet armored divisions in Poland had left their barracks and been deployed in urban areas, suggesting that this reflected difficulties faced by the Polish martial-law regime. The analyst would not identify the destinations of the armored units, but sources at North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters said they believed that the tanks had been sent to the Gdansk and Warsaw regions.   The Soviet divisions appear to be playing a backup role.  Intelligence sources say that the Soviet Union does not want to intervene but that Soviet political and military leaders hold that, if the Polish repression fails, intervention may be necessary to stifle a movement that could have the gravest effect on the rest of the Soviet bloc.

headline: Heizer Announces Decline in Value
abstract: The Heizer Corporation announced that its total assets have declined about 20 percent since June 30 because of the decline in the stock market. The company, a business development concern, said that its total assets from June 30 to Sept.30 dropped to $259.6 million, or $15.25 a share, from $325.6 million, or $19.14 a share.

headline: Soviet Airline Explains 2 Unauthorized Flights
abstract: The Soviet airline Aeroflot said today that air traffic controllers were responsible for two of its flights taking an unauthorized route over southern New England on Nov. 8. The incidents prompted a State Department request for a weeklong suspension of Aeroflot flights.

headline: Disputes Seen Within OPEC
abstract: One of the organizers of the the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was quoted today as saying that the future of the organization is endangered by political differences among its 13 members.   ''If absolute sincerity does not prevail among its members, then the future of OPEC is in doubt because the organization is the only means enabling its member states to extract profits from the pockets of world majors,'' Sheik Abdullah al-Turaiki, a former Saudi Arabian oil minister, was quoted as saying in an interview with the newspaper Al Watan.

headline: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1981; The Economy
abstract: The Consumer Price Index rose 1.2 percent in September. The rate, projected annually, was more than 14 percent, continuing a reversal of the slowing trend registered last spring. The chief impetus came from rising food, transportation, interest and medical costs. (Page 1.) The index in the New York area rose 1.5 percent. (30.)   The requirement that 1982 cars be equipped with airbags or other automatic crash protection devices was thrown out by the Administration. It said auto makers were planning to meet the requirement with passive belts that would not have been effective.  (1.)

headline: AFGHAN WAR ECONOMY: THIN DIETS, FAST FORTUNE
abstract: Considering that a guerrilla war has been raging in Afghanistan for more than three years, the rural economy of the largely isolated desert and mountain settlements has survived with remarkable self-sufficiency.   During six weeks of traveling in the countryside, most of it far from major roads or towns, this reporter found people living in stark conditions, but there were no signs of hunger or widescale malnutrition.   Certainly for most of the hardy and poor people of Afghanistan the war has meant a steady, meager diet of bread and tea, often without sugar. For some, willing and eager to run the new risks of conflict, the war has brought relative riches, mostly from an active trade in guns and hashish.

headline: Steel Exports Of Japan Fall
abstract: Japan's steel exports in the six months ended Sept. 30 fell 3.8 percent in tonnage from a year earlier, but the value rose 5.6 percent because of price increases, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today.   Exports in the latest period totaled 14.8 million metric tons, worth $856 million.

headline: Military Analysis
abstract: The balance of military power in the Middle East, especially in terms of air strength, is likely to be significantly affected by the scheduled completion of the Israeli withdrawal from Sinai in April.   Air power, military analysts in Washington and at NATO headquarters in Belgium point out, is not measured simply in terms of aircraft but is a conglomerate of bases, radar systems, fuel and ammunition depots and planes. Israel will be abandoning two of its most important air bases at Etzion and Eitam in Sinai when the withdrawal is completed.   This contraction of Israeli air resources will take place, the analysts and Israeli military sources pointed out, in a period when the Arabs forces are receiving aircraft, tanks and other weapons ordered over the last three years. A recent United Nations report gave some idea of the scope of Arab purchases and deliveries.

headline: 'ALL SAVERS' DEPOSITS BOLSTER THRIFT UNITS
abstract: Fed by an influx of funds from the sale of tax-exempt savings certificates, deposits at savings and loan associations exceeded withdrawals last month for the first time since February, according to an industry official.   Rollin D. Barnard, president of the United States League of Savings Associations, said at a news conference last Friday that Americans had deposited $18.7 billion in ''All Savers'' certificates at the nation's almost 5,000 savings associations during October, the first month they were available.   Mr. Bernard disputed reports by industry analysts that the certificates had not lived up to expectations. The new certificates were ''the most successful new savings product we've ever seen,'' he said.

headline: GRUMMAN'S LOYAL WORKERS
abstract: After 21 years as a Grumman engineer, Ray Lokkenberg wasted no time when he heard that a Texas conglomerate wanted to take control of the company that he says is more like a family member than an employer. He called a stockbroker and bought 300 shares of Grumman.   People who work outside Grumman's 500-acre fenced-in reservation - with its huge assembly-line buildings and no-frills offices - might think he was out to make some quick money. Mr. Lokkenberg paid less than $35 a share for stock the LTV Corporation was offering to buy for $45 a share. But profit was not really what he had in mind.

headline: Process For Creating A Feline Disease
abstract: One of the week's patents related to forms of life concerns a process of promoting a disease in cats. Two Dutch inventors, Marian C. Horzinek of Bilthoven and Albertus D.M.E. Osterhaus of Bunnik, were granted patent 4,293,653 for a method of propagating feline infectious peritonitis virus.

headline: Husky Oil Net Down by 79.3%
abstract: Husky Oil Ltd. reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter dropped 79.3 percent, to $9.1 million from $44 million a year earlier.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * A.H. Belo Corp., which owns and operates The Dallas Morning News, WFFA-TV of Dallas, and other newspapers and radio stations, said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 2 million common shares, to be sold through a Goldman, Sachs & Co.  group.

headline: Pope Says His Ordeal Was 'a Special Grace'
abstract: Pope John Paul II said today that his suffering after the May 13 attempt on his life ''has turned out to be a special grace for me and for the whole church.''

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Abraham & Straus has appointed Wilmer Weiss vice president-merchandise presentation.   * American Agronomics Corp., Tampa, Fla., has named Kenneth A.  Barnebey deputy chairman and chief corporate officer.

headline: HIGH COURT TAKES BANKRUPTCY CASE
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a key portion of the new Federal bankruptcy law, enacted in 1978 to allow consumers to protect a portion of their personal property from bankruptcy proceedings, applies to consumer loans that were made before the new law took effect.   The case affects thousands of individual bankruptcy proceedings.  Typically, sometime before declaring bankruptcy, the individual has pledged most or all household goods as collateral for a loan from a finance company. The new law specifies that creditors may not obtain liens on certain possessions, including up to $500 in jewelry, $750 in professional books, and other personal holdings, despite the fact that everything might have been pledged at the time the loan was obtained.

headline: U.S. REPORTS SNAGS ON EUROPEAN ROLE IN THE SINAI
abstract: Administration officials said today that unexpected problems had developed in efforts to secure British and other European participation in the Sinai peacekeeping force.   The officials said the European Economic Community had planned to issue a statement earlier this week opening the way for Britain, France, Italy and the Netherlands to take part in the force.   But the proposed statement, which discussed their entry in terms of European desires for a broader peace involving the rights of Palestinians, was regarded as so offensive to Israel that the United States persuaded the Europeans not to issue it and to review their position. Hopes for Action Next Week   American specialists on Europe and British Embassy sources said they hoped that a European statement acceptable to Israel could be issued next week, but some Administration experts on the Middle East predicted that it would take longer.

headline: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FRANCE PLANS RESTRICTIVE MEASURES TO CUT INFLATION AND HELP EXPORTS
abstract: France's Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, announced plans today to reinforce the devaluation of the franc by freezing a wide range of retail prices, deferring some public spending increases and working out wage guidelines with labor.   His action amounted to a first step away from the expansionary economic policies that France's Socialist Government has been following since it came to power last spring.   The aim of the new measures, Mr. Delors said, is to reduce France's annual inflation rate to 10 percent from 14 percent, thus enabling French industry to reap the full benefits of devaluation, which should swell exports and employment by making French goods cheaper in foreign markets. In yesterday's currency realignment, the West German mark and Dutch guilder were raised 5.5 percent while the French franc and Italian lira were lowered 3 percent in relation to other currencies in the European Monetary System.

headline: SHOOTOUT OVER FEDERAL EXPORT POLICY, AND MONEY
abstract: WASHINGTON O N Thursday, Nov. 12, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige received a memo from David A. Stockman, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, demanding $174 million of additional cuts in Commerce activities mostly affecting support the department provides for American exports.   Mr. Stockman said he wanted Mr. Baldrige, among other things, to wipe out the Foreign Commercial Service, the Bureau of Industrial Economics and the Office of Export Development which altogether employ more than 1,000 Americans here and abroad and consume about $70 million a year.   The Budget Director, in effect, gave the Commerce Secretary 72 hours to show cause why the cuts should not be made. In other words, the onus was on the department to justify these activities, and do it fast.   The rodeo-riding Commerce Secretary, whose department has already gone through drastic shrinkage while at the same time absorbing new responsibilities, saw red.

headline: Libyan Oil Output Up
abstract: Libya produced an average of 1.2 million barrels a day of oil in the first two weeks of December, more than double the output of earlier this year, the heavy industries secretary, Omar Mostafa Montasser, said here today. Mr.  Montasser said Libya hoped to maintain the new level and he foresaw no problems resulting from the withdrawal of personnel of United States oil companies.

headline: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LORIMAR PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 24
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SADAT'S DEATH TURNS SPOTLIGHT TO A SUDANESE WAR OF SORTS
abstract: There is a war going on in this land where the hot, pale desert peopled by nomads provides an inhospitable and improbable theater of confrontation between East and West.   It is not so much a shooting conflict as a battle involving propaganda, ancient trade routes and a surrogate army that wants the United States to support it against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.   Geneina lies on the indistinct border between the Sudan, a pro-Western bulwark protecting Egypt's southern flank, and Chad, a country that the Soviet-supported Colonel Qaddafi all but annexed 10 months ago. Nomads Know No Boundaries   This region is known as Darfur, an area the size of France that was once a proud, independent sultanate run by a dynasty of rulers that lasted 560 years. From Geneina, caravans of pilgrims heading overland to Mecca make their way east. Men of the Tuareg stock of desert nomads roam the area, dressed in long white robes and white turbans.  With their camels and mules and trappings they recognize no international boundaries, lines that appear on the maps but not on the shifting sands and dry river beds they traverse. The town itself is one of flat-roofed houses, stretched resources and economic decay.

headline: BIRTH CONTROL ADS MAKE DEBUT ON FRENCH TV
abstract: French television has a new hit - a Governmentsponsored commercial advocating contraception. Appearing daily through Dec. 9, the commercial is part of the first public information campaign on contraception since birth control was legalized in France in 1967.   The campaign and the idea for the commercial originated with the new Minister for Women's Rights, Yvette Roudy. The 30-second television spot was made by Agnes Varda, a prominent French actress, director and feminist, with the theme, ''Today, every woman should be able to choose.''

headline: Poor Harvest In Soviet Seen
abstract: This year's Soviet grain harvest, hit by dry hot weather, could be less than 170 million metric tons, Soviet agricultural sources said today.   The sources said that their estimate of the final total was unofficial but based on access to official preliminary harvest figures.

headline: MONUMENTAL INSURANCE FILLS TOP POST
abstract: The Monumental National Life Insurance Company of New York, a newly acquired subsidiary of the Monumental Corporation, has appointed Martha M. McCaffrey, 49, president and chief executive officer. On Jan.1 she will succeed John G. Wick, 56, who will return to private law practice.

headline: Fireman's Fund To Buy Insurer
abstract: Fireman's Fund Inc. of New York will acquire the Wisconsin Employers Group insurance company under an agreement in principle reached by the two companies, a Wisconsin Employers spokesman said.   The acquisition must be approved by Wisconsin's insurance commissioner and the directors of both companies, the spokesman said.

headline: LUTHERAN OFFICES SEIZED IN ETHIOPIA
abstract: The Marxist regime of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam has rejected the formal protests of Sweden and Norway over the recent seizure by armed soldiers of the headquarters of the Scandinavian-supported Lutheran Church, Ethiopia's major Protestant denomination.   Foreign Minister Felleke Gedle-Giorgis summoned West European ambassadors to his office this month and, as later disclosed by one ambassador, told them that ''pressure from abroad will not change our Government's mind.''   A Swedish diplomat said the Government's rejection of the protests could result in reduced economic aid from Scandinavian nations at a time when Ethiopia is seeking more money from the West to help its ailing economy.   The diplomat said several members of Sweden's Parliament had urged such reduction. Sweden gives Ethiopia $20 million every year, and Norway gives $10 million. Sweden is the biggest donor of aid to Ethiopia and had proposed a $2 million increase next year.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Gould in Agreement For Microsystems
abstract: Gould Inc., which tried unsuccessfully to acquire two semiconductor companies in 1979, announced yesterday that it would buy American Microsystems Inc., a leading manufacturer of customized integrated circuits, in a transaction valued at roughly $200 million.   Under the terms of the agreement, Gould will issue 1.78 shares of its common stock for each share of A.M.I. common and preferred stock and for the shares reserved for previously granted employee stock options and warrants.   Based on Gould's closing price yesterday of 24 1/8 on the New York Exchange, which was down 7/8, the transaction would be worth $218.5 million or $42.94 a share of A.M.I. stock. A.M.I. stock, traded over the counter, shot up to 37 3/4 bid, from last week's close of 26 5/8 bid. Trading in the stock had been halted last Wednesday and Friday pending yesterday's announcement.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **
