abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.M. on Gas
abstract: To the Business Editor: I'd like to clear up the misunderstanding that has resulted from the way the General Motors' position on natural gas deregulation was set forth in the table accompanying ''The New Battle Over Natural Gas'' (Sept. 6).

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Alliance Capital Corp. has named Paula Brown a senior vice president and director of marketing, Anthony D. Bune and Joseph C.  Williams vice presidents of the corporation and of Alliance Capital Management International, Alexander Laird 3d vice president and fixed-income portfolio manager and Charles Taylor vice president and research analyst.   * American General Corp. has elected J.J. Gray Jr. president of its American General Investment Corp. subsidiary.   * Avery Coal Co. has elected to its board Nelson Peltz, chairman of Trafalgar Industries, and Peter W. May, Trafalgar's president and chief operating officer.

headline: Thatcher Wins Party Vote
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was formally re-elected today as leader of the governing Conservative Party. Mrs. Thatcher, Prime Minister since May 1979, was re-elected unanimously.

headline: The U.N. Today; Oct. 28, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 11 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: Oil Find Off Brazil
abstract: Brazil has struck oil in an exploratory well offshore that could be part of a major oilfield, the Government oil company, Petrobras, announced today.

headline: HOW INDUSTRY LEADERS VIEW THE CRITICAL ISSUES
abstract: O NE benefit of the economic problems of the 1980's, for job hunters at least, is that they offer several clues to where positions might be found. The energy crisis, the growing emphasis on military might and the developing shortages of skilled technicians, among other issues, can apply in the most personal way to those seeking a new career or a change.   Leaders of industry in various parts of the nation were asked recently what they considered critical issues affecting the world of work and how these applied to their own companies and to the nation as a whole. High on their lists were the state of the economy, productivity, the energy problem and the pressing shortages of engineers and technically trained workers.

headline: 2D BANK IN PACT WITH A BROKER
abstract: The Security Pacific National Bank announced yesterday that its 600 branches throughout California would begin buying and selling securities for the bank's customers.   Scheduled to begin in February, the service will be made possible as a result of an agreement between Security Pacific, the nation's ninth-largest bank, and Fidelity Brokerage Services Inc., one of the largest discount brokerage firms in the United States.   Only a day earlier, the BankAmerica Corporation stunned the banking community by announcing that it planned to acquire Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm. BankAmerica, which owns the Bank of America, plans to offer services similar to those of Security Pacific through Schwab, and eventually through its own branches.

headline: Angolan Warship Stops Italian Racing Yacht
abstract: An Italian yacht sailing in an aroundthe-world race was stopped by an Angolan warship and the crew was held for seven days as suspected South African spies, the race organizers said today.

headline: Around the World; Hijackers Free Hostages And Fly to El Salvador
abstract: The right-wing hijackers of a Costa Rican airliner landed in El Salvador today after releasing all of their hostages except the two pilots in exchange for six jailed Nicaraguans. The exchange took place at Costa Rica's international airport.

headline: U.S. ENVOY ARRIVES IN BEIRUT
abstract: President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, Philip C. Habib, arrived here today for another round of Middle East peace negotiations. Mr. Habib is expected to visit Syria, Israel, and possibly Saudi Arabia.   Mr. Habib's visit - his fourth since this spring - follows the breakup of the Arab League summit meeting last week in disagreement over Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia's eight-point peace plan.

headline: MEDIA GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.E. Pact Set in Japan
abstract: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had signed a contract worth more than $500 million with the Tokyo Electric Power Company to build a huge electric power plant on a landfill in Tokyo Bay.   The contract with G.E. for the 2,000-megawatt plant, described as the world's largest combined-cycle facility, will amount to about $396 million for equipment and $10 million for services.

headline: Sunbeam Net Down
abstract: The Sunbeam Corporation said today that it earned $12.4 million, or 82 cents a share, in its third quarter ended Sept.30, down 10.8 percent from the $13.9 million, or 92 cents a share, it earned in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues dropped 1.3 percent, to $349.9 million, from $354.5 million. The company said that third-quarter profit was slashed 30 cents a share by foreign currency translation losses and 11 cents a share by higher interest charges.

headline: Rank Xerox Plans Unit in Europe
abstract: Rank Xerox, the French affiliate of the Xerox Corporation, said that it intended to set up a unit in Europe to manufacture electronic office equipment at a cost of about 100 million francs, or approximately $18 million.   The production unit, the first for Xerox in Europe, will make electronic typewriters, word processors and other small electronic office equipment that until now had been imported from the United States.   The Xerox affiliate said that two possible sites for the new unit had been selected - one at Xerox's existing plant at Lille in northern France and one at another factory in the Netherlands.

headline: WHITE HOUSE FEARS A LAG IN ECONOMY WILL DAMAGE G.O.P.
abstract: White House officials are increasingly resigned to the likelihood of slow economic growth, possibly even a recession extending through the spring of 1982. They are seeking to prevent the economic downturn from damaging Republican chances in the election next year.   White House aides involved in carrying out Mr. Reagan's economic policies said in interviews that they feared that if the unemployment rate crept past 8 percent from its present level of 7.5 percent unemployment would replace inflation as the chief issue among voters. Some forecasters have predicted such a rise.

headline: Dow Up 4.47; Amex Off by 4 7/8
abstract: Stock prices edged higher yesterday after having plummeted on Monday in response to the crisis that developed in Poland over the weekend.   The Dow Jones industrial average gained 4.47 points, to 875.95.  Volume remained moderate at 44.1 million shares, down slightly from the previous session's 44.7 million.

headline: No Headline
abstract: AROUND THE WORLD; Renault Head Reported To Be Next U.S. Envoy   PARIS, Oct. 14 (AP) - Bernard Vernier-Palliez, head of the Renault auto concern, will reportedly become envoy to the United States in a shake-up of the diplomatic service.   A Government spokesman, Pierre Beregovoy, said after a Cabinet meeting that 50 posts, including those in the United States, West Germany, Italy and African and Latin American nations, would be changed at the request of Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson.

headline: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Miklos B. Korodi, 44, has been appointed to the new post of president of Warner Amex Security Systems, which is selling a home security alarm that operates on a two-way cable television network owned by Warner Amex Cable Communications in Columbus, Ohio.   Mr. Korodi's company, which began operations in 1979 as a unit of Warner Amex Cable, does not use the video or audio elements of the Qube cable television system in Columbus. However, the two-way Qube circuits are used to transmit a continuous impulse from a central office to each subscriber's home and back to the central office. If that impulse is interrupted because someone - a burglar - trips a sensor implanted in a door or window, then an alarm rings in the central office and the police are alerted.

headline: Deere Unit Rating Cut
abstract: The Standard and Poor's Corporation said that it had downgraded the Deere & Company credit subsidiary's senior debt ratings to AA from AA and subordinated debt rating to A+ from AA. It noted that the ratings applied to almost $400 miliion of securities. S.& P. said the changes reflected the credit subsidiary's growing use of short-term, variable-rate debt to finance its fixed-rate receivables portfolio.  This imbalance has resulted in falling earnings, necessitating income-support payments from the parent to maintain fixed-charge coverage, it added.

headline: Fuqua Settles Shareholder Suit
abstract: Fuqua Industries said it had settled a shareholders' lawsuit challenging its plan to buy back its stock at $20 a share. The settlement, which must still have court approval in Delaware, stipulates that the company pay an additional 25 cents a share tendered.

headline: COMPLAINTS ON IMPORTS OF STEEL
abstract: A year-old truce over steel imports is ending, raising the specter of another major trade confrontation as the United States and major steel exporting countries struggle to preserve jobs as economies weaken.   Both the domestic steel industry and the Reagan Administration are threatening to take legal action against producers in Europe and elsewhere because of recent surges in imports.   The American steelmakers charge that foreign steel companies are selling here at unfairly low prices and that some of the costs of this steel are being heavily subsidized by foreign governments.   American Government sources reported that Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige told industry leaders today in New York that the Government, in an unusual move, was preparing to file countervailing duty actions against steelmakers in France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Rumania and South Africa.

headline: DIXICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TEXT OF HAIG STATEMENT ON AWACS TO SENATE PANEL
abstract: Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today on the Reagan Administration's proposal to sell five Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia: Special to the New York Times   WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 - Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today on the Reagan Administration's proposal to sell five Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia:   I want to say a few words about two key points of difference between those who support the President's dec ision on arms sales to Saudi Arabia and those who apparently oppose it.   Given all the controversy, there is a surprising amount of agreement between both groups. We are united in our desires to strengthen peace and security in the Middle East. We are united in our commitment to preserving a strong and secure Israel. We agree about the need to improve our capability to deal with the greatly increased military threats to that vital region.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Quebec Separatist Is Guilty
abstract: A Quebec separatist, Marc Carbonneau, pleaded guilty in court today to the kidnapping of the British diplomat James Cross here in 1970. Mr. Carbonneau, who belonged to the now-defunct Quebec Liberation Front, returned to Canada last May from self-exile in France. He will be sentenced after the judge hears a probation officer's report on Dec. 11.

headline: CHINA AND INDIA STARTING TALKS ON BORDER DISPUTE
abstract: Nearly two decades after they fought a short, fierce border war, China and India took a major step today toward improving relations by opening negotiations on their Himalayan frontier dispute.   The delicate talks, the details of which are being kept secret, were agreed to when the Chinese Foreign Minister, Huang Hua, visited India in June.   No specific agenda has been announced, and Peking-based diplomats following the talks do not expect any breakthroughs at this initial session, which is to end Monday. An Asian diplomatic analyst said he believed that the two sides would start by seeking a framework for dealing with the complex and emotional border issue. The talks will also cover scientific and cultural contacts and trade.

headline: WOLOHAN LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Ailing Argentine Chief Steps Down Temporarily
abstract: President Roberto Eduardo Viola is temporarily stepping down from his duties because of heart trouble, the Government announced today.

headline: BRITISH DEBATE EXCHANGE CURB
abstract: Two years after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher dropped foreign-exchange controls, a flood of money out of the country has provoked a spate of calls for renewed strictures.   In just the past few weeks, demands for controls have come from politicians and agencies representing a variety of persuasions, including Edward Heath, the former Conservative Prime Minister, and the Trades Union Congress, the workers group closely allied to the Labor Party.   For her part, Mrs. Thatcher has remained adamantly opposed to any such action. Her Cabinet ministers do not share the ''siege economic view that if money flows overseas, it will deprive people of jobs,'' a Treasury official said. ''It makes economic sense in Government policy to build up this level of overseas dividend flow.''

headline: DISCONTENT SPREADING IN LIBYA AS OIL BOOM FADES
abstract: Libya's oil boom, long the source of well-being and a high standard of living, has been eroded by the glut on world markets. Foreign analysts say that the resultant economic plight coincides with other indications of discontent springing from Col.  Muammar el-Qaddafi's authoritarian rule.   This year, one authoritative source said, oil revenues could be down by half of the $25 billion that Libya's economic planners had been expecting.   Such is the pervasive nervousness and fear generated by internal security agencies that informants declined to be interviewed except on the understanding that articles based on the discussions contain no clue as to their identity.

headline: 1,500 PROTEST AT POLISH MISSION
abstract: A labor-sponsored rally protesting the crackdown on the Solidarity movement in Poland drew 1,500 people to the streets outside the Polish Consulate in New York yesterday.   Mayor Koch and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, were among the dozen speakers, most of whom represented unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: France Comes Nearer To Recognizing P.L.O.
abstract: France came closer today than it has in the past to recognizing the Palestine Liberation Organization as the sole representative of the Palestinian people.   In a statement to a group of Arab reporters, Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said: ''We have never said that the P.L.O. was not the sole representative of the Palestinian people.

headline: BANK BIDS $53 MILLION FOR BROKER
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation announced yesterday that it intended to acquire Charles Schwab & Company Inc., America's largest discount brokerage firm, for about $53 million in common stock. The transaction could develop into a historic test case for Federal banking laws.   The proposed merger would appear to conflict with the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which drew a line between investment banking and commercial banking. The act forbids commercial banks to own, underwrite or deal in corporate stocks and bonds.

headline: Businessmen in Sinai Town Of Yamit End Their Lockout
abstract: A self-imposed lockout by businessmen in Yamit, the Sinai town scheduled to go back to Egyptian control next April, was ended this morning when residents allowed Defense Minister Ariel Sharon to enter for negotiations.   The businessmen had closed off the town and set fire to five buildings recently to protest what they said was inadequate compensation for their withdrawal.

headline: WAGE RISE MODERATION SEEN FOR '82
abstract: Collective bargaining settlements in industries that have historically set wage patterns are expected to be ''very moderate'' next year and are unlikely to exert the influence that they have in the past, according to an annual forecast by the Conference Board that was released yesterday.   A panel of 10 labor experts from industry, unions and education predicted that first-year wage settlements would increase an average 8 percent next year, compared with first-year rises of 11.5 percent from January through September of this year.   ''The economic brakes will clearly be on,'' said Audrey Freedman of the Conference Board, an independent, nonprofit business research organizaation, and chairman of the panel. ''Moderation in wage demands will not spring from job competition from the growing ranks of the unemployed, but from efforts by employers to cut labor costs.  The coming year will be marked by wage freezes and reduced labor forces in many industries.''

headline: GEOSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Midland-Ross
abstract: The Midland-Ross Corporation, the nation's largest supplier of freight car couplers and a major producer of other cast steel components, said that it was closing four foundries for the rest of this year because of a continuing decline in rail car orders. The action, which will temporarily idle a total of about 1,100 hourly employees, will shut foundries in Toledo, Ohio; Melrose Park and Cicero, Ill., and Sharon, Pa. Production is expected to resume at all four facilities Jan. 4, Midland-Ross said.

headline: TURKS TREAT PAPANDREOU WITH PATIENCE
abstract: The Turkish military junta has decided that the best policy toward Greece's new Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, is patience.   Without actually turning the other cheek, the junta has reacted with restraint to Mr. Papandreou's statements both before and after the election victory of his Socialist Party last month.   ''We're waiting for the Greek Government's program and its actions,'' Foreign Minister Ilter Turkmen said in a recent interview. Mr. Papandreou is expected to present the program to Parliament next Sunday.   The principal question between Greece and Turkey today, as in the past, is the Aegean Sea. Turkey holds that it is not ''a Greek lake'' and demands an equitable division of sea and airspace.

headline: DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DARKER DAYS FOR COLLEGE GRADS
abstract: A S an undergraduate at Boston College, Susan Stoller had to tailor her goals to suit a precarious job market. She switched her major from elementary education to special education, where there is a higher demand, and she resigned herself to moving out of Massachusetts because tax cuts had resulted in a freeze in the demand for teachers. She arranged her job interviews through the Massachusetts Educational Recruiting Consortium, a group of colleges that invites representatives from out-of-state school systems.  ''Every time a school system was coming to recruit, I would take the interview regardless of whether I wanted to go there,'' said Miss Stoller, who graduated this year.   She also visited the campus placement office 15 times and mailed 50 resumes. But despite a high grade-point average and extensive involvement in extracurricular activities, she wound up with only two offers. She now has a job teaching learning-disabled adolescents in Brevard County, Fla., and she considers herself lucky.   Miss Stoller's experience is one example of the ways college graduates are having to adjust to the demands of an increasingly complex and competitive job market.

headline: The Week in Business; RATES AND INFLATION EASE AS RECESSION BITES
abstract: The prime rate dropped to its lowest level in almost a year.  Several major banks cut the key lending rate to 16 1/2 percent from 17 percent. Bankers and economists predicted further declines.

headline: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: I.M.F. TEAM VISITS POLAND
abstract: Washington -- Twenty-four hours before martial law descended on Poland a team from the International Monetary Fund arrived in Warsaw to begin the process of weighing the Polish application to join the 141-nation lending body.   The five fund staff members went at the invitation of the Polish Government, and had access to the Finance Ministry before leaving Warsaw at the end of last week. The aim of the mission was to collect preliminary data on hard currency reserves, trade flows, output and income per capita and other yardsticks of economic performance to establish what would be Poland's quota if the membership bid is approved.   The quota, a measure of relative financial strength, is used as the basis for making loans. Fund officials insist that it is far too early even to guess at what Poland's quota might be, but judging from numbers publicly available it could be worked at somewhere around 1 percent of the $80 billion pool of resources that the Fund represents.

headline: WHILE AWAITING MERGER, INA REALIGNS DUTIES
abstract: Following Monday's announcement that the INA Corporation and the Connecticut General Corporation plan to merge, forming what would be the nation's sixth-largest insurance company, INA has named a new chief operating officer to handle its day-to-day operations. John R.  Cox, 49, INA's senior executive vice president, will assume the additional title on Nov. 25.   This action follows the disclosure that Ralph S. Saul, 59, INA's chairman, president and chief executive officer, will also become chairman and co-chief executive officer of the merged company - to be called the North American General Corporation. Analysts indicated that Mr. Saul would probably be busy first with the merger arrangements and then with getting the new corporation under way and that Mr. Cox would probably take over some of Mr. Saul's INA duties.

headline: ESMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business Digest; FRIDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1981; The Economy
abstract: President Reagan pledged to veto any appropriations bill that violates his plan to reduce Federal outlays. He called at a news conference for public patience with his economic program. (Page A1.) The President, in an effort to show Wall Street support, cited a Securities Industry Association letter. (A22.) Meanwhile, his budget chief, David A. Stockman, told Congress it would have to cast painful budget-cutting votes ''again and again and again.'' (A29.)   The economy will remain slow through the first half of 1982, according to economists and businessmen at a Conference Board symposium. Many expressed surprise that business has remained as strong as it has in the face of high interest rates. (D1.)

headline: Ford Closes Its Dutch Plant
abstract: The Ford Motor Company's Dutch subsidiary said it had closed its plant here, despite a fight by employees to keep the factory operating.   The closing will end the jobs of 1,200 assembly line workers, who go off the the company's payroll on March 1, said a Ford-Nederland spokesman, John Hoberg.

headline: DYATRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. SEEMS UNSURE ABOUT SPEEDING ARMS FLOW TO THE SUDAN
abstract: The Administration said today that it hoped to speed deliveries of military equipment to the Sudan but was uncertain how much faster deliveries could be made.   Officials in the State and Defense Departments and Congressional aides also questioned the immediacy of the threat to Khartoum.  Yesterday in Cairo, President Gaafar al-Nimeiry predicted a Libyan invasion of the Sudan, and other officials in that country said there was also a Libyan-inspired internal threat.   Dean Fischer, the State Department spokesman, said a final decision on Khartoum's immediate needs would be made after Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. is briefed by an American diplomatic and military delegation that has been assessing the situation in the Sudan for several days. That delegation, led by Robert C. McFarlane, the State Department counselor, is back in Washington.

headline: Other Business; RUBIK'S CUBE: IDEAL TOY TAKES ON THE KNOCK-OFFS; by Mark Roman
abstract: The obfuscating little puzzle, Rubik's Cube, is sold by the Ideal Toy Corporation - and only the Ideal Toy Corporation. That's what Ideal says, anyway. Spokesmen for the company are worried that amid the influx of myriad duplicates, people will forget that.   Ideal has sold over 10 million cubes, which range in price from $7 to $10, and holds exclusive rights to Rubik's Cube here and abr oad.  But since t he toy's introduction, the market has been deluged with nearly exact copies that have turned up on street stands, novelty andsouvenir stor es and even at Macy's.

headline: Winn-Dixie Net Rises
abstract: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc. announced yesterday that net income in the 12 weeks ended Sept. 16 increased 13.7 percent, to $19.1 million, or 77 cents a share, from $16.8 million, or 64 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales climbed 8.1 percent, to $1.47 billion, from $1.36 billion.

headline: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Chile Seals Off 2 Areas In Search for Criminals
abstract: National policemen, backed by army and air force units, cordoned off two working-class neighborhoods and arrested about 700 people, the Government said today.

headline: SAKAROVS BEARING UP IN THEIR HUNGER STRIKE
abstract: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, said today that he and his wife, Yelena Bonner, were ''holding on cheerfully'' after 10 days of a hunger strike.   ''We are O.K.'' they said in a telegram. ''We are holding on cheerfully. We are following our regimen.'' Word of their condition was sent from their place of exile in Gorky to Yelizaveta Alekseyeva, the 26-year-old woman in whose support Dr. Sakharov began his protest. The action is intended to obtain permission for her to emigrate to Newton, Mass., to join Dr.  Sakharov's stepson, Alexey Semyonov, to whom she has been married by proxy.

headline: EGYPTIAN CITY IS QUIET AFTER CLASHES
abstract: After 24 hours of clashes between policemen and Moslem fundamentalists, quiet returned today to this southern city. Policemen reinforced by soldiers brought in yesterday and today were hunting remaining snipers.   According to officials, at least 20 people - 14 policemen and 6 Moslem fundamentalists - were killed in the fighting that began at dawn yesterday with an attack on security forces here. Some intermittent firing was reported this morning.

headline: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LONG ISLAND LIGHTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Reaching The China Market
abstract: IN Peking and probably in all of China, Angela Newsome, 27 years old, is Madison Avenue. For about a month, Miss Newsome, who speaks fluent Mandarin Chinese, has been the representative in China of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, ''the only international agency,'' she said, ''registered and accredited and working in China.''   Actually, she is on the payroll of McCann-Erickson Jardine, a joint venture of the agency and the Jardine-Matheson Trading Company, of which McCann owns 80 percent.

headline: TELERENT LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: New Business Computer Line
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc. said that it would sell a new line of desk computers for small business, becoming the latest of several companies to enter a market estimated to contain 2.2 million individual businesses.   Computers designed to sell to this market generally cost $5,000 to $10,000, slightly more than the so-called personal computers, although there is a great deal of overlap.

headline: Socialist Will Attempt To Form Danish Cabinet
abstract: COPENHAGEN, Dec. 22 (Reuters) Anker Jorgensen, Denmark's caretaker Prime Minister and Social Democratic Party leader, said today that he had accepted Queen Margrethe's request that he try to form a new minority government.   His new Cabinet was not expected to be formed until after Christmas and will probably be made up entirely of Social Democrats or a coalition of Social Democrats and members of the small centrist Radical Liberal Party.   The Queen asked Mr. Jorgensen to try to form a government after having a second round of talks with representatives of the nine parties returned to the new Parliamant in the inconclusive general election of Dec. 8, sources in Parliament said.

headline: METHODICALLY, SMALL DEVELOPER EXPANDS IN MANHATTAN
abstract: Project by project, a small development company called Britton Development Ltd. has been growing since it was founded seven years ago by an accountant and an architect.   Starting with conversions of older buildings into rental apartments on East 26th Street and East 30th Street, moving on through a 16-unit cooperative currently nearly completed in the shell of four existing buildings on Columbus Avenue at 81st Street, Britton Development has systematically widened its housing production activities in Manhattan.   In the last two years it has acquired, with the help of outside investors, land for sizable new apartment buildings in Chelsea, the East Side and the East Village. And it has plans for other building ventures in Woodstock, N.Y., and Philadelphia.

headline: MOBILE WELL OFF CANADA BOLSTERS HIBERNIA FIND
abstract: Mobil Oil Canada Ltd., the operator and largest partner in the Hibernia oilfield off the Newfoundland coast, announced today that another test well had produced sufficient oil to strengthen the belief that Hibernia was a major find.   In a statement from Calgary, Alberta, Mobil Canada, wholly owned by the Mobil Oil Corporation, said that in initial tests, the Hibernia K-18 well, drilled to a depth of 16,533 feet, flowed oil from five different levels at rates of up to 4,642 barrels a day.

headline: SPANG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Holiday Closings
abstract: Because of the holiday, these tables were not available: Foreign Exchange, World Gold and London Metal Market.

headline: LOBBYING INTENSIFIES OVER BANKRUPTCY LAWS
abstract: Alarmed by the swelling tide of consumer bankruptcies, the credit industry is lobbying heavily for Congress to repeal most of the liberalized bankruptcy laws passed three years ago.   Consumer advocates, equally alarmed by the prospect of success for the industry's campaign, contend that the depressed economy and the greater availability of credit, not the Federal laws, are responsible for the increase in bankruptcy cases. They also say that the industry's proposals, incorporated in a House bill last week, would essentially convert bankruptcy courts into bill-collecting agencies and would condemn some poor people to involuntary servitude.   The House Judiciary Subcommittee on Commercial Law and Monopolies is already holding hearings on the proposals. On Thursday the Senate Subcommittee on Courts will begin its hearings on proposed amendments to the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978.

headline: Oil Shale Plans Delayed
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Tenneco Corporation said they had decided to delay for an undetermined period development of their joint Cathedral Bluffs oil shale recovery project in Colorado.   The companies said the delay was necessary to permit a reassessment of the feasibility of the project in view of ''current increased construction costs, oil prices and high interest rates.''

headline: THE LOW U.S. RATE OF SAVINGS
abstract: More than most countries, the United States is a land of consumers. Of every dollar of income after taxes, on average, 95 cents are spent and only about 5 cents are saved.   To Reagan Administration economists, who are trying to increase the savings rate, that low savings figure is what has held down investment and slowed the growth of productivity.   But as the Government's program to increase the personal savings rate moves into high gear on Jan. 1, when all workers become eligible to set up tax-exempt retirement accounts, many economists contend that the Government will be able to lift the rate only a small amount, if at all.   ''There is no strong reason to think that the economic program is going to increase savings sufficiently to make a difference,'' said Irwin Friend, an economics professor at the University of Pennsylvania who has studied American savings patterns.

headline: MILLIONS OF POLES STRIKE FOR AN HOUR IN A PROTEST
abstract: Millions of Polish workers staged a one-hour general strike today.  A spokesman for the Solidarity union in Gdansk, where reports of the effectiveness of the work stoppage were still coming in, pronounced himself ''satisfied'' with the scope of the protest.   But for the first time since strikes became the main weapon in the workers' movement for more freedom and influence in government 14 months ago, the authorities said the strike had failed.   ''The total strike this time did not succeed,'' Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Communist Party leader, said at a Central Committee meeting, according to television. ''For the first time, political and social organizations have categorically spoken out against it.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: CONVICTION GROWS ON LOWER RATES
abstract: Accompanying the decline in short-and long-term interest rates last week was the growing conviction among some analysts that the drop would not be a temporary one followed by a surge in rates to record levels.   There are many who disagree, but those who expect the interest rate decline to continue often cite the growing weakness of the economy as well as the Federal Reserve's money policy.   Certainly, the credit markets have been anticipating lower rates in the future, as shown by a drop in the six-month bill rate to 11.9 percent late Friday from 12.72 percent at last Monday's auction. For three-year Treasury notes, yields fell to 13.59 percent late Friday from 14.43 percent Monday, while the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 13.75 percent from 14.4 percent.

headline: 100,000 Spanish Basques Protest Autonomy Issue
abstract: Basque nationalist leaders led as many as 100,000 silent marchers through central Bilbao today to protest what they said were moves by the Government to reduce their autonomy.

headline: New Computer Systems by Exxon
abstract: The Exxon Corporation, whose move into the automated office has floundered badly, partly for lack of new products, introduced two new desktop computerized ''work stations.''

headline: Bombs Are Exploded in Rome At 2 Latin American Offices
abstract: Bombs exploded today in an Argentine Government commercial office and outside the Guatemalan mission to the Vatican, the police said.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Science Digest magazine increasing both its circulation rate base, to 500,000 from 450,000, and advertising rates, by 11.1 percent, effective with the January issue.

headline: DAYS OF PROSPERITY AT HARVARD REVIEW
abstract: Tilting its fare more toward people in business rather than lecture halls, the Harvard Business Review is shedding its stuffy academic image with some sharp critiques of American management.   Its authors have chided executives for poor product quality, raised warning flags on topics ranging from pension liability to global competition and preached the need for cash management in small businesses.   To be sure, readers say that some articles are a bit theoretical, but in the main they are more avidly scanning each issue and finding useful ideas.   ''If I were someone fighting my way up inside a large organization, I would want this information to give me confidence in my own ideas, and give me new ideas, too,'' said Richard J. Hanschen, a venture capitalist and former executive at Texas Instruments Inc. Circulation Climbing   On the eve of its 60th year of publication, circulation is 230,000 and climbing smartly. Longtime subscribers say they are reading more articles before laying a current issue, like an elitist badge, on desks, bookshelves or anteroom tables at the office.

headline: Patents; Avoiding Closed Eyes As Photos Are Taken
abstract: An engineer for the Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, has found a way to avoid poor photographs of people who shut their eyes. Before the exposure begins, a flash of light is released to cause the subject to blink.

headline: HAITIAN PRESIDENT EXPECTING U.S. AID
abstract: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 30 -President Jean-Claude Duvalier said tonight that he expected that the United States would provide new economic and social aid soon to this poverty-stricken country.   Mr. President made his comments in a rare and brief appearance here before reporters who sought to learn details of a joint agreement between the United States and Haiti aimed at stopping the migration of Haitians to the United States.   The occasion was his appearance for a picture session that followed a meeting with Gov. Bob Graham of Florida, in whose state thousands of Haitians have sought refuge in past months, and Ernest H. Preeg, the new American Ambassador to Haiti, who worked out the agreement with Government officials here.

headline: OGILVY & MATHER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Appeal by Rumanian Leader
abstract: Nicolae Ceausescu, Rumania's President and Communist Party leader, appealed today to President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to insure the success of the Geneva negotiations for reduction of nuclear forces in Europe. Mr. Ceausescu has orchestrated a disarmament campaign of mass demonstrations across Rumania in recent weeks.

headline: Market Place; Fund Manages Without Stock
abstract: JUDGING from performance records, money managers have been heavily committed to stocks during the current bear market. The average equity fund followed by Arthur Lipper & Company, which monitors mutual fund performance, fell 4.24 percent between Jan.1 and Oct.22 this year - with all distributions presumed reinvested.   That's better than the market as a whole. The Standard & Poor index of 500 stocks dropped 11.87 percent for the same period.  Nevertheless, the relatively good performance of Lipper's 332 equity funds is cold comfort to investors, who could have been earning high returns in the money market.

headline: Sears's Stake In Coldwell
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced that 1.4 million shares, or 28 percent, of the shares outstanding of Coldwell, Banker & Company's common stock had been tendered under its offer of $42 a share.

headline: HOW TO READ THE ECONOMY
abstract: WASHINGTON P EOPLE might feel it in their paychecks and the supermarket. But there's only one way most folks really know how the economy is doing, and that's by watching the reports that the Government's statisticians keep cranking out, month by month, quarter by quarter.  These indicators produce more than a picture of the economy. They also form the basis for economic policy decisions and signal whether policies then in effect are working.   These major indicators, and the many others that receive less public attention, have their own pecularities and problems. Some are better than others. Some are being changed. And some could be changed, but the improvement might not make a major difference. In addition, there are complaints that the Reagan Administration's budget cuts could eventually hurt the quality of the statistics. Here is a primer on some of the economic indicators. GROWTH   The gross national product is the broadest measure of the nation's economy. The G.N.P., which is reported quarterly, can have a strong effect on government policy - because it shows whether the economy is in a recession and whether inflation is out of line.

headline: CHROMALLOY AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; U.S. General Meets Worried Nicaraguans
abstract: A United States Army general has opened talks with Nicaraguan officials to calm their fears about joint Honduran-United States naval maneuvers scheduled for next week, Government spokesmen in Managua said.   Some Nicaraguan officials have said the manuevers, set for Oct.  7-9, might be used as a cover for an invasion of their country by rightists living in exile in Honduras.

headline: Japan-Soviet Loan Pact
abstract: The Export-Import Bank of Japan said today that it and 23 Japanese commercial banks had signed contracts to supply $206 million in loans to the Soviet Union and East Germany to finance industrial projects.

headline: United Cuts Fares
abstract: United Airlines announced sharp fare reductions Tuesday for coast-to-coast flights and on flights from the Midwest to the West Coast.

headline: LABOR DEPT. IN 2D GRUMMAN INQUIRY
abstract: The Labor Department, which is seeking to oust the trustees of the Grumman Corporation's pension plan, is also conducting a separate investigation of possible Federal pension law violations by the company's employee investment plan, officials in Washington said yesterday.   The inquiry, which parallels the department's investigation of the pension fund, is focusing on whether a conflict of interest arose when the investment plan's three trustees voted not to tender 3.2 million shares of Grumman stock to the LTV Corporation.   The three trustees are high-ranking Grumman executives. The pension fund trustees are also three Grumman officials, but not the same ones. Unlike the pension fund, which purchased 1.16 million shares of Grumman stock, the investment fund has not bought any stock in the company since LTV last month announced its $450 million offer for Grumman.

headline: ALLEN DEFENDS THE SALE OF HIS CONSULTING COMPANY
abstract: Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, said today that he had sold his Washington consulting business on a three-year installment plan and stood to make only $39,000 from the sale, which he characterized as a ''perfectly ordinary commercial transaction.''   Mr. Allen also said during a telephone interview that he would not ''terminate friendships'' with some of his former Japanese associates or clients or with Peter D. Hannaford, the purchaser of Mr. Allen's business, simply ''because I've become a public official.'' Mr. Allen said that Mr. Hannaford's concern, the Hannaford Company Inc., still owed him $50,000 in connection with the sale.   Mr. Allen spoke, sometimes angrily, after a published report suggested that his installment sale of the Potomac International Corporation might have placed him in a conflict of interest. The report questioned Mr. Allen's continuing relationship with Mr.  Hannaford, Mr. Hannaford's clients, some of whom were Mr. Allen's clients when he owned Potomac, and a Japanese professor, with whom Mr. Allen has long enjoyed a close business and social relationship.

headline: I.B.M. WINS FIGHT FOR BONN CONTRACT
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation has won a hotly contested battle for a communications contract from the West German Government, it was announced today.   The Government-run Postal Ministry awarded contracts for I.B.M. to supply the central computers for the West German version of videotex, called bildschirmtext.   Videotex is an electronic communications system being developed now in several countries that uses telephone lines to transmit information from central data banks to commercial and private users, where it is displayed on a color television screen.

headline: Texaco in Venture
abstract: Texaco Financial Services Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Texaco Inc., has joined in the formation of a new company that will specialize in brokering time-deposit money market instruments and foreign currencies between corporations and world financial markets.  In a joint announcement with its new partner in the venture, Charles Fulton Holdings Ltd., of London, Texaco Financial said that the new company would be named Ful-Tex Euro Services Inc.

headline: FORECASTS TOO GLUM FOR REGAN
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan predicted today that the current recession would not be so steep as many private economists believe.   Mr. Regan, speaking on ABC television's ''This Week with David Brinkley,'' said the nation's economic growth would decline only between 3 and 3.5 percent in the final quarter of 1981 rather than the 5 percent predicted by most private economists.   While the Treasury Secretary reiterated the Administration's view that the economy will pull out of the recession by spring, he conceded that the unemployment rate in the United States would remain near or above its current 8 percent level even after the recession ends.   ''By the fall of 1982, the economy will be coming back,'' he said.  ''It won't be humming along as fast as we might like, and unemployment will probably be in the 7.5 percent to 8.5 percent range,'' Mr. Regan said.

headline: ADIA RIGHTS GROUP GETS GRANT
abstract: A human rights group in Asia has been given a three-year grant by the Ford Foundation to investigate violations in the region.  The Research Institute of the Law Association for Asia and the Western Pacific, called Lawasia, was given $120,639, the Ford Foundation announced yesterday.

headline: Business Digest; SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1981; The Economy
abstract: Industrial output fell 1.5 percent in October, the steepest drop in 16 months, the Federal Reserve Board reported. The biggest declines were in the production of cars, building materials and big consumer items usually bought on credit. Analysts said the new figures indicated that the economy was seriously weakening. (Page 29.)   Business inventories rose 0.9 percent in September, the Commerce Department reported. The inventory-to-sales ratio climbed to 1.43, the highest since the previous September. (30.)

headline: BREZHNEV RESPONSE TO REAGAN'S LETTER IS CALLED 'NEGATIVE'
abstract: President Reagan said today that a letter received Friday from Leonid I. Brezhnev on the Polish situation was ''negative'' in tone. However, another Administration official later said the Soviet leader's message did not seem to close the door to further discussion on the crisis.   Soviet-American relations have become increasingly involved because of Mr. Reagan's warning to Mr. Brezhnev last week that unless the repression in Poland eased soon, the United States would have no choice but to take economic and political actions against the Soviet Union. Contents Not Disclosed   Neither Mr. Reagan nor other senior officials would divulge the contents of Mr. Brezhnev's reply Friday night to Mr. Reagan's letter, which was sent late Tuesday. But aboard his Air Force plane en route to California, where he will spend the rest of the holidays, Mr.  Reagan, when asked if the Brezhnev letter was positive or negative in tone, replied, ''With them, it's always negative.''

headline: Poland's Sugar Output
abstract: Poland's sugar production this year will amount to 1.6 million tons, nearly restoring output to pre-1979 levels and matching the domestic market demand for sugar, the official press agency, P.A.P. said today.

headline: HARWYN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Geers Gross To Put Sloane on TV
abstract: W&J Sloane, a major furniture chain, has assigned its account to Geers Gross Advertising.  The account, worth about $2 million plus, had previously been handled in-house.  The initial Geers campaign for the new client will represent the first time that Sloane has used television.

headline: Major Battle Reported In the Western Sahara
abstract: Fierce fighting was going on today between guerrillas and Moroccan forces in the Western Sahara some 650 miles southeast of Rabat, according to reports reaching here.   Moroccan military sources said it was one of the biggest battles in the conflict for control of the former Spanish colony.

headline: Economic Affairs; THE ELEGANCE OF DOING NOTHING
abstract: W HEN confronted with a complex public policy problem, it has always been difficult to sell what is often the most elegant and sophisticated policy option. That is, to do absolutely nothing.   Even when doing nothing has considerable intellectual appeal, politicians seem unable to make a positive case for it. No one wants to be a member of a do-nothing Congress or Administration. Generally, we have to do nothing very quietly.

headline: CHEEZEM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Robotics Seen Strong in U.S.
abstract: The United States is ahead of the Soviet Union in the technology of robots, but a lack of engineers is putting this country at a disadvantage, according to a university specialist.   ''Engineering manpower is crucial to us,'' said Dr. Delbert Tesar, director of the University of Florida's Center for Intelligent Machines and Robotics.

headline: COLONIAL PENN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: POPE PUTS JESUITS UNDER CLOSER REIN
abstract: Pope John Paul II has appointed a conservative Italian theologian to take over direction of the Jesuit order as his personal ''delegate'' until the order elects a new leader.   The Pope's move, which was announced by the Jesuit headquarters here in a short statement today, will greatly strengthen the Pope's control over the traditionally independent Society of Jesus, Vatican sources said.   In a letter to the Rev. Pedro Arrupe, the Jesuit leader, who suffered a stroke in August, the Pope said the appointment of Father Paolo Dezza was meant ''to represent me more closely in the society.''

headline: Reader Comment; SOCIAL SECURITY'S NOT DOING ITS JOB
abstract: S OMETHING has to be said in response to ''Relax, Social Security Is Doing Its Job'' (Nov. 15). Barbara R. Bergman maintains that the detractors of the system are ''barking up the wrong tree economically as well as politically.'' But her own analysis points to the contrary.   Her central thesis is that everyone but the ''extreme right'' agrees ''that older people in an affluent country ought to be assured of a decent stipend.'' She adds that generous Social Security benefits may act as a personal savings disincentive, straining the growth of the country's capitalization, but that such a phenomenon ''is in no way regrettable.''

headline: BRITISH CASINO SALE BY PLAYBOY
abstract: Playboy Enterprises Inc., threatened with the loss of gambling licenses for two of its three London casinos, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its British gambling operations.   The casinos alone accounted for 86 percent of the Chicago-based company's pretax profits in the fiscal year that ended last June 30.  ''The difference will be felt,'' Derick J. Daniels, Playboy's president, said in a telephone interview, ''but this is going to be a very profitable company.''   He refused to say how the company would spend the proceeds of the sale, noting only that ''it gives us lots of flexibility.'' Analysts said that the company was expanding its existing ventures, but these were unlikely to match the profitability of the London casinos.

headline: 3,000 EVANGELICALS MEET IN JERUSALEM
abstract: Three thousand evangelical Christians from the United States, Western Europe and elsewhere gathered this week in Jerusalem to demonstrate their support for Israel.   The visit came under the auspices of the International Christian Embassy in Jerusalem, which was set up in September 1980 to support Israel's claim to Jerusalem as its capital. The mission was set up after 13 countries removed their embassies from Jerusalem to protest Israeli legislation passed in July of that year that proclaimed Jerusalem as the country's ''united and indivisible'' capital.

headline: LIBYA CALLS OIL COMPANIES TO DISCUSS OUTPUT AND PRICES
abstract: Libya has summoned representatives of Western oil companies to Tripoli to discuss oil pricing and production, several European and American companies reported yesterday.   Oil analysts immediately speculated that Libya would again try to persuade the companies to buy more of its high-priced oil, as it has done several times this year. However, some analysts suggested that Libya might finally be ready to lower its official price of $40 a barrel because of slipping sales.   The companies that buy oil from Libya have rebelled against paying Libya's high price. They have slashed their purchases from 1.6 million barrels a day, which was the pace early this year, to approximately 700,000 barrels a day.

headline: CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Thomson-Brandt To Buy RCA Unit
abstract: The RCA Corporation said that the Thomson-Brandt electronics group of France had agreed to buy RCA's 42 percent stake in Videocolor, Europe's second-biggest producer of color television tubes.   The transaction, for an undisclosed price, would give Thomson-Brandt full control of Videocolor because AEG-Telefunken A.G. of West Germany has disclosed it is pulling out of Videocolor's parent concern, Europacolor, and selling its 49 percent stake to Thomson.

headline: British Inflation Rises to 12%
abstract: Britain's inflation rate jumped to 12 percent last month from 11.7 percent in October and now stands at its highest level since April, the Trade Department has announced.   It is the third increase in four months and a serious setback for the Government's economic strategy.

headline: VW to Reduce U.S. Operation
abstract: Volkswagen of America said it would cut production at its Pennsylvania auto assembly plant, put construction at a second plant on ''deferred schedule'' and lay off about 350 workers because of a continuing slump in domestic auto sales.   Volkswagen said that its Westmoreland, Pa., assembly plant will be closed from Dec. 24 to Jan. 11 to reduce inventories following a regularly scheduled holiday vacation.

headline: ENTWISTLE CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. DIPLOMATS IN CUBA DISSENT ON RADIO PLAN
abstract: The United States diplomatic mission in Havana has objected to a Reagan Administration plan to set up a radio service modeled on Radio Free Europe to beam broadcasts to Cuba.   Despite its objection and questions raised in Congress, State Department officials said, the Administration is going ahead with the selection of a site in Florida for the new station. The station, to be called Radio Marti after the Cuban patriot Jose Marti, is being developed by a private nonprofit corporation set up in late September by the Administration to get the project started.   According to a message sent to the State Department Oct. 14 by the United States Interests Section in the Swiss Embassy in Havana, the American diplomats questioned the potential credibility of the proposed station and its cost effectiveness.

headline: Arab Is Reported to Confess To Killing Vienna Aide in May
abstract: An Arab detained after an attack on a synagogue here in August has confessed to the killing in May of a Vienna city councilor with close ties to Israel, Interior Minister Erwin Lanc said today.   Mr. Lanc said at a news conference that the man, identified as Husham Rajih, traveling on an Iraqi passport, told the Austrian police in his interrogation that he had acted for a breakaway hardline Palestinian group headed by Abu Nidal.   Mr. Rajih admitted shooting the Vienna councilor, Heinz Nittel, head of the Austria-Israel Friendship Society, outside his home on May 1.

headline: BIG MACS FOR LEO BURNETT
abstract: The Leo Burnett Company of Chicago was the proud winner last week of the coveted $75 million McDonald's account for national advertising. The Chicago office of Needham, Harper & Steers, which held the account for over 11 years, and apparently had no inkling that anything was afoot, was shocked.

headline: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KRUEGER, W A, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: KUWAIT IS CLEARED IN BID FOR SANTA FE
abstract: The Kuwaiti Government's proposed $2.5 billion purchase of the Santa Fe International Corporation cleared its final Government hurdle today as the Justice Department terminated the mandatory waiting period for the deal.   Both the Justice Department and the interagency Committee on Foreign Investments said the sale of the American oil drilling company to a wholly owned subsidiary of the Kuwaiti Government would have no ''major negative implications'' for the United States.   Santa Fe, whose shareholders approved the deal Tuesday, said after the Justice Department's announcement that it would complete the sale to the Kuwait Petrolem Corporation late today.

headline: Begin Cites Conditions For Sinai Peace Force
abstract: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Israel would disqualify any European country from the Sinai peacekeeping force if that country's announcement of participation mentioned any documents other than those related to the Camp David accords.   The Prime Minister told the Cabinet that any reference to the European Economic Community's 1980 Venice declaration, in which Palestinian self-determination was embraced and the Palestine Liberation Organization named as a part of the peace process, would disqualify a country from participation.   ''The nonmention of any documents other than those above is, for Israel, an ultimate condition for the participation of any country in the force,'' the Cabinet said in a communique.

headline: CORPORATE BONDS SELL WELL
abstract: Credit market activity centered in the corporate sector yesterday, where investment bankers said sales were good for several new issues recently brought to market.   In secondary market activity yesterday, short-term interest rates rose slightly, while long-term bond prices rose as much as a point.  Treasury bill rates were little changed, but elsewhere in the money markets, the yield for three- and six-month bank certificates of deposit rose to 11.7 percent and 12.15 percent, respectively, up about an eighth of a percentage point on the day. World Bank Offering   Although many corporations are still waiting for yields to decline further before they sell new notes and bonds, current market conditions were favorable enough for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to proceed with a $600 million, threepart offering yesterday. Its triple-A-rated five-year notes were publicly offered by Morgan Stanley & Company to yield 14 5/8 percent, rising to 15 percent for seven-year notes and 15.17 percent for 10-year notes.

headline: Retailer's Profit Falls
abstract: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation said yesterday that net income for the third quarter, ended Oct. 31, fell 4.2 percent, to $10.1 million, or 56 cents a share, from $10.6 million, or 79 cents, in the similar 1980 period. Net sales, including those of the newly acquired Caldor subsidiary, rose 48 percent, to $710 million from $479.8 million. The retailer attributed the decline in earnings to significantly higher interest charges stemming from the Caldor acquisition.

headline: The U.N. Today; Nov. 16, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY

Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 8 P.M. headline: Life Savers Sold
abstract: Nabisco Brands Inc. said that it had completed the purchase of Life Savers Inc. from the Squibb Corporation for cash and notes valued at about $250 million. Nabisco Brands also said that it had assumed certain outstanding Life Savers debts but did not elaborate. Life Savers, which makes candies and chewing gums at four factories in the United States, had operating income of $42 million on sales of $342 million in 1980.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * ACF Industries has named J. Donald Brinkerhoff to executive vice president-operations, Herbert A. Borst executive vice presidentfinance and Charles L. Harper a vice president and general manager of the W-K-M division.   * Alexander & Alexander Inc. has named Edmund G. Langhorne director of the Greater New York Region and managing vice president of its New York office.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Hearst/ABC Video Services to TLK Direct Marketing, the New York division of Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago.

headline: IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: British Steel Fears Curb
abstract: The British Steel Corporation could lose 10 percent of its business if the United States adopts measures it is considering to protect its steel industry against European imports, Ian MacGregor, the chairman of British Steel, said today.

headline: ANALYSTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LABORITE LEADER DENOUNCES TONY BENN
abstract: Michael Foot, the leader of the Labor Party, abandoned his effort to conciliate Tony Benn, the leader of its left wing, and bitterly denounced him today.   Mr. Foot's outspoken condemnation of his party colleague, a highly unusual political act, increased the probability of further wrangling in the badly divided opposition party at a time when its leaders wish they could concentrate their energy on attacking the Conservative Government.   The criticism was welcome news for Britain's new Social Democratic Party, which is rapidly gaining ground in the ideological center with defections from Labor.

headline: F.T.C. CLEARS U.S. STEEL ON ITS BID FOR MARATHON
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation won antitrust clearance yesterday from the Federal Trade Commission to proceed with its $6.3 billion takeover bid for the Marathon Oil Company.   The move - not unexpected - gave U.S. Steel a clear tactical advantage over the Mobil Corporation, which is offering to pay $6.5 billion for Marathon but has so far received no indication from the Government agency that it would get similar clearance.   A spokesman for U.S. Steel in Pittsburgh said the company would have no comment on the F.T.C. decision, which was not publicly announced.   Wall Street analysts said that, even allowing for the anticipated emergence early next week of a new bid, expected to be some form of joint arrangement involving Mobil and the Amerada Hess Corporation, U.S. Steel might be able to purchase Marathon stock from shareholders as early as Dec. 22.

headline: TIMES FIBER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

headline: G.M. PRESSES CAMPAIGN TO HOLD DOWN WAGES
abstract: The General Motors Corporation has started an unusual campaign to convince its 499,000 employees of the ''hard realities that may be required for survival'' of the company, according to a private G.M.  memorandum obtained yesterday.   A major purpose of the campaign, begun this month, is to persuade the company's employees to ''reduce or eliminate unrealistic expectations about economic gains in the forthcoming contract negotiations,'' the memorandum said.   This will be done largely at meetings that all hourly and salaried employees are to attend in groups of 25 to 35. Each General Motors employee is to attend four meetings conducted by division and plant general managers.

headline: EMBITTERED ENVOY
abstract: Zdzislaw Rurarz, the Polish Ambassador to Japan who has been granted asylum in the United States, was a model product of the Communist system and the Polish Civil Service. But Mr. Rurarz was one thing more: a self-made man who achieved a steady upfrom-poverty rise in the Polish bureaucracy.   Mr. Rurarz told Japanese officials today that he planned to join the struggle against the current Polish regime after he arrives in the United States. He is an economist known for his remarkable physical strength and, until he entered the American Embassy in Tokyo Wednesday to request political asylum, his devotion to the economic and political system the Soviet Union imposed on Poland at the end of World War II.

headline: SECURITIES GROUP ELECTS A CHAIRMAN
abstract: Larry F. Clyde, a 39-year-old executive vice president of the Crocker National Bank in San Francisco, has been elected chairman of the Public Securities Association, the trade group of banks and brokers that underwrite and trade municipal and Federal Government securities.   After his election, at the association's annual conference last week in Puerto Rico, Mr. Clyde spoke in an interview about the state of the industry:   "There is a constant onslaught of legislative and regulatory challenges to the municipal market.

headline: Algeria Agrees to Oil Parley
abstract: Algeria has agreed to a special meeting of the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to try to establish a common price structure, the official Algerian press agency said today. The next scheduled OPEC meeting is in Abu Dhabi on Dec. 9, but sources in several oil-producing nations have suggested that a meeting might be held earlier, possibly before the end of this month.

headline: Conoco Now Part of Du Pont
abstract: Conoco Inc. and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company completed the largest corporate takeover in American history when Conoco shareholders overwhelmingly approved a $7.6 billion merger of the two giants.   During a subdued meeting that lasted less than 30 minutes, more than 99 percent of Conoco's shares were voted in favor of the merger, creating the seventh largest United States industrial concern, with combined annual sales of $32 billion.

headline: COBB RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BANKS CUT PRIME RATE TO 15 3/4%
abstract: Most major banks, led by Citibank, lowered their prime lending rates by a quarter of a point yesterday, to 15 3/4 percent, from 16 percent.   Joining Citibank, the nation's second-largest bank, at the lowest general prime level in more than a year were the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the First National Bank of Boston, the Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh, the First National Bank of Chicago, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, the Bank of New York, the Marine Midland Bank, and the Bank of America, the nation's largest bank.   Last week, most major banks lowered their prime rates to 16 percent with the Chase Manhattan Bank, the third-largest commercial bank, dropping its prime to 15 3/4 percent.

headline: MORTGAGE DEFAULTS INCREASE
abstract: Mortgage delinquency and foreclosure rates are reaching the worrisome proportions of the mid-1970's, putting the hard-pressed housing industry under still more pressure.   This trend has stirred concern among home builders and real estate salesmen, who fear that more foreclosures will depress home values and further weaken an industry already staggered by high interest rates. Prices of existing houses are already affected, new-home construction has been in a slump for two years and mortgage lenders have been suffering mounting losses.   Mortgage delinquencies - payments more than 60 days past due -are ''rising to serious levels,'' said Brian Smith, an economist for the United States League for Savings, a trade organization of savings and loan associations.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Cellu-Craft Inc. said its board had authorized the company to offer to purchase for cash from its shareholders up to 300,000 shares of its common stock at $6 a share, representing about 13 percent of the company's outstanding stock.   * Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. and A.C.L.I. International said they had signed a definitive merger agreement with a closing expected to take place in November.

headline: The U.N. Today; Oct. 7, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
abstract: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.
