headline: STANLEY HOME PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: More at Tourister Facing Layoffs
abstract: American Tourister, one of the nation's leading luggage manufacturers, said it will lay off 40 more workers, put the rest of its 1,000 factory employees on a four-day workweek during portions of December and January and temporarily shut down operations during the last two weeks of this month. Ronald R.  Snyder, company human resources director, said reduced sales and a sagging economy were to blame for the company's action.

headline: COLDWELL HOLDERS APPROVE SEARS PACT
abstract: Coldwell, Banker & Company said its shareholders voted overwhelmingly today to approve the $215 million acquisition of their company by Sears, Roebuck & Company.   The merger is scheduled to take effect on Thursday.

headline: 12 CONVICTED OF BRIBERY INCLUDE 4 AT ITT-AUSTRIA
abstract: Austria's biggest postwar bribery trial ended today with the conviction of all 12 defendants. They included four top executives of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's Austrian subsidiary.   The trial arose from a hospital construction scandal that helped oust a Finance Minister in Vienna last year.  Fritz W. Mayer, 70 years old, chairman of ITT-Austria's executive committee, and Edmund Hainisch, the company's chief executive officer, were both convicted today of bribery and corrupting a public official. Both executives were sentenced to three years in prison.

headline: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hilton Seeks New Hotel Talks
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corporation officials are willing to discuss ways to salvage a proposed $250 million hotel that would be the centerpiece of the North Loop redevelopment plan, an executive of the company says.   James F. Sheerin, Hilton senior vice president, said he was willing to meet with city officials and Thomas Hynes, Cook County Assessor, to see if something ''might be worked out'' to revive the plan.

headline: Japan Market For Arkansas
abstract: Arkansas is finding a growing market for its poultry products in Japan, where poultry consumption has increased 10 times in the past 20 years.   The largest poultry producers in Arkansas - Tyson Foods and Valmac Industries - will not say how much poultry they have sold to Japan.

headline: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hilton in Pact On Webb Hotel
abstract: The Del E. Webb Corporation has completed an agreement with the Hilton Hotels Corporation for sale of the Sahara Reno Hotel to Hilton for $34.5 million in cash and an option to acquire the Sahara Tahoe by March 31.   Robert K. Swanson, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Webb, and Barron Hilton, chairman and president of Hilton, said the transaction had been completed for the 20-story hotel, to be known as the Reno Hilton. Mr. Swanson said Webb had not contemplated sale of the Sahara Tahoe, but ''the offer received from Hilton was contingent upon inclusion of that property.''

headline: MUSE AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOVIET REJECTS SWEDISH PROTEST IN SUBMARINE AFFAIR
abstract: The Soviet Government today rejected Sweden's complaint that a Soviet submarine recently stranded in Swedish waters had been conducting ''impermissible activities.''   At the same time, Moscow challenged Stockholm's contention that the submarine might have been armed with nuclear weapons.  The statements, along with a renewed call for a nuclear-free zone in northern Europe, ended a public silence on the submarine incident, previously broken only by a brief press dispatch saying that the submarine, which bore the numerical designation 137, had strayed into Swedish waters because of faulty navigational equipment.   Today's statements repeated that contention. They also termed Sweden's conclusion that the submarine was probably carrying nuclear arms ''inventions evidently intended for ignoramuses.'' Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency, said the furor over the incident had been concocted by the Western press to fan anti-Soviet feelings.

headline: BID FOR $3 BILLION IN TAXES DROPPED BY ADMINISTRATION
abstract: Donald T. Regan, the Secretary of the Treasury, said today that the Administration had dropped its proposal to raise $3 billion more in tax revenue in the 1982 fiscal year.   The $3 billion was part of President Reagan's Sept. 24 proposal - made in a nationally televised policy speech - to raise $22 billion in taxes over three years.   Secretary Regan, in an interview with news agency reporters, said the larger package was not being abandoned but, reversing earlier plans, he indicated a strong disinclination to send the specific legislative proposals to Congress before January. The import of the Secretary's remarks was that the Administration would go ahead with its announced intention of raising additional tax revenue in the years after fiscal 1982. Reasons Called Tactical   A White House official said that ''very serious consideration'' was being given to delaying the request for $3 billion of extra revenue in the 1982 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, but he added that the delay was being caused by tactical reasons and that President Reagan remained committed to the package.

headline: Concern Lifts Coffee Prices
abstract: Despite a worldwide glut of coffee supplies and a drop in demand among consuming nations, the Coca-Cola Company said today that its foods division had raised the wholesale prices of its three brands of coffee.   The company said the wholesale list prices on roast and ground coffee on its Maryland Club, Butter Nut and Admiration brands were increased to $2.70 from $2.55 a pound, effective immediately.

headline: OPEC Price Policy Review
abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries intends to adopt a pricing formula allowing oil price cuts under certain conditions, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said here today.   All previous OPEC discussions of pricing policies had provided for increases, but not declines, in oil prices.  While Sheik Yamani refused to disclose details of the new ''flexible'' formula, the Indonesian oil minister, Subroto, who also serves as OPEC's president, said it could become effective sometime next year.

headline: ITI CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Beatrice Net Increases 4.6%
abstract: The Beatrice Foods Company reported today that its profit increased 4.6 percent in the third quarter compared with the similar period in 1980, although sales were up only marginally.   Beatrice, a diversified food products company, said net income for the three months ended Nov. 30 was $84.5 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with $80.8 million, or 78 cents a share, in 1980.

headline: New Building Down by 10%
abstract: Partly because of continued depression in the housing industry, the value of construction projects started in November fell 10 percent from October, a construction-monitoring concern said today.   The F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported that construction contracts on new projects declined to $9.7 billion in November from about $10.8 billion the previous month.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: STOCKS STAGE ROBUST GAINS
abstract: Wall Street's takeover fever spread to brokerage issues yesterday as the general stock market staged a robust advance. Analysts said they were impressed by the market's remarkably steady tone in the wake of political and economic uncertainties created by Tuesday's assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.   The Dow Jones industrial average, finishing at its high for the session, climbed 12.46 points, to 868.72.  ''The market is saying that renewed turbulence in the Middle East promises to s peed the flow of investment money from abroad into United States securities,'' Alan Ackerman, director of foreign research for Herzfeld & Stern, declared. ''In times of such turbulence, t he American and Japanese markets become favorite havens for foreign m oney.''

headline: Selling Diamonds In Reader's Digest
abstract: You may have an image of Reader's Digest readers as nice, unsophisticated, down-home, middle American types.  That obviously is not the way De Beers Conslidated Mines, the major supplier of the world's diamonds, and its agency-for-ages, N.W. Ayer, see them, or they certainly would not be running a 10-page advertising insert in the December issue promoting diamonds to a stagnant market badly hurt by the recession.

headline: RUMANIA DETERMINED TO AVOID POLAND'S PLIGHT
abstract: Every day, Rumanians, like the people of Poland, have to stand in long lines for food and often cannot find cooking oil, sugar, dairy products, fresh meat or eggs.   Like Poland, too, Rumania is faced with a rising external debt, balance-of-payments problems, hard-currency shortages, overinvestment in heavy industry and neglect of agriculture.   But officials say they have learned from the Polish experience.  They are determined to prevent any organized protest movement from developing along the lines of the Solidarity union.

headline: CARNATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ALLIED TO WRITE OFF NUCLEAR FUEL PLANT
abstract: The Allied Corporation, which disclosed that it had unsuccessfully bid $6.5 billion to acquire the Marathon Oil Company, said today it would take an $87 million writeoff to shut its nuclear fuel processing plant in Barnwell, S.C.   ''The political future is so uncertain,'' an Allied spokesman, James Simon, said in explaining the company's move. ''We didn't want to carry it any longer on the books.''

headline: Case to Extend Plant Shutdowns
abstract: J I Case, a unit of Tenneco Inc., said it will close manufacturing plants in six states for four weeks b eginning Jan . 4 because of ''sluggish'' demand for farm and construction equipment.

headline: U.S. LIKELY TO ASK SEA LAW REVISION
abstract: A nine-month policy review by the Reagan Administration has concluded that the United States should negotiate changes in a treaty regulating use of the seas and their mineral resources rather than abandon it, senior Administration officials said today. President Reagan is expected to announce this decision by the end of the month.   The officials said that the principal agencies involved, the Departments of State, Defense, Treasury and Interior, have agreed that the best course for the United States is to renegotiate provisions that create an international cartel to manage the mining of nickel, copper, cobalt and manganese on the seabed.   An ''options paper'' prepared by these agencies and endorsed by the Departments of Commerce, Energy and Transportation and the Environmental Protection Agency is to be sent to Mr. Reagan in a few days. The paper, officials said, weighs the advantages and disadvantages of refusing to sign the so-called Law of the Sea treaty, the product of eight years' labor by 150 nations.

headline: PROFITS OFF MANY COMPANIES
abstract: The dollar's international strength, high interest rates and the persistently sluggish American economy combined to depress earnings at many of the nation's companies in the third quarter, a compilation by The New York Times of 286 major corporations shows. Many others, however, fared better than had been expected.   The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was one of the most notable casualties of currency exchange. In last year's third quarter I.T.T. earned $197.9 million, but by contrast it had a loss of $34.8 million in this year's third quarter. The dollar's strength in Europe also upset the balance sheets of such other huge multinational companies as the NCR Corporation, Honeywell Inc., the Sperry Corporation, the Eastman Kodak Company and Revlon Inc.

headline: Around the World; Rebels Said to Kill An Afghan Defense Aide
abstract: Anti-Government rebels in Kabul, Afghanistan, killed a senior Afghan Defense Ministry official and his wife and several party functionaries this week, according to a report from the Afghan capital today.

headline: SOFIA MELDING RELICS OF PAST INTO DAILY LIFE
abstract: Five years ago the Bulgarian Government made the defense of national monuments official policy and declared the entire historical center of Sofia an archeological site.   As a result, construction work on a Bulgarian Foreign Trade Bank was held up for several years because the site was on part of the ancient city wall as well as the ruins of a medieval church. The ruins have been preserved as an ''archeological island,'' and the construction has resumed.   Similarly, the main entrances of the Communist Party headquarters, the Council of Ministers and the Council of State remained closed for two years while archeologists worked on excavations nearby.

headline: New Raboy Account
abstract: The first packaged-goods account for Epstein Raboy Advertising has just come through the door: the E.T. Bowne Drug Company of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., maker of the Palmer's line of Cocoa Butter Formula Moisturizing cream and soap, Hair Success Treatment and Skin Success soaps. The account, previously with the Howard Goldstein Organization, has been billing about $50,000, according to Leading National Advertisers, but the client said it would spend more than $1 million next year.

headline: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: IN MOSCOW, A BAD REVIEW OF BEST SELLER
abstract: What would a Soviet publisher do with a novel that starts off with disfigured corpses in Central Park, continues with dark intrigues involving city cops, F.B.I. agents, Russian detectives and Hollywood starlets, and winds up with everyone getting killed in a Moscow suburb and the recovery of Coca-Cola concealed in Greek amphorae by the director of a Soviet soda-pop bottling plant?   Kirill Senin, writing recently in Literaturnaya Gazeta, the journal of the Soviet Union of Writers, vows that in the unlikely event that such ''rubbish'' is ever written, ''workers at any of our publishing houses would shove the author out by the scruff of his neck, even at the risk of subsequent explanations to the police.''   But the self-same plot, Mr. Senin reports with a tone of incredulity, but with American and Soviet characters and locations reversed, made Martin Cruz Smith's ''Gorky Park'' one of the bestselling novels of 1981.   Mr. Senin's bitterly sarcastic review is the first extensive Soviet examination of ''Gorky Park,'' a mystery novel about a Moscow detective whose investigation of a bizarre murder leads to an international intrigue involving the K.G.B., the F.B.I., the New York City police, sable smuggling and a host of killings. The best-selling book has been praised by some American critics for the pace of its action and for its effort to recreate the atmosphere of Moscow life.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: For President Reagan, the crucial Senate vote tomorrow on his proposed arms sale to Saudi Arabia offers an opportunity to revive his leadership image during a difficult time when he has lost the momentum of his Administration's early months.   Although Mr. Reagan can ill afford the setback of a major defeat, he has risked his personal prestige heavily on the final effort to swing undecided senators to his side and has brought himself to the brink of victory on the eve of the vote.   White House strategists have calculated that the outcome will have an impact not only on the President's conduct of foreign policy but also on the general perception in Washington of his influence with Congress in this second, more trying phase of his Presidency.   ''There's more at stake here than the President's ability to conduct foreign policy,'' asserted James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, between calls to influential senators. ''A win here would really restore momentum to our overall efforts. A loss makes it tougher to get back the momentum that we had before the summer break.''

headline: Advertising; Tarkenton's New Field
abstract: IF there were a Super Bowl for salesmen, Fran Tarkenton would play in it every year, if he weren't playing in the one for entrepreneurs.  The 41-year-old former National Football League quarterback is a dynamo, a dynamo who has been frequently quoted as saying, ''I am a businessman.''   He's also a former adman, having worked off-season at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn as an account man on a piece of business from the state of Georgia and at McCann-Erickson on Coca-Cola.

headline: MONEY SUPPLY DECLINES $1.5 BILLION
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday afternoon that a key measure of the nation's money supply fell $1.5 billion in the week ended Oct. 14, a drop that was widely predicted by economists who expected a portion of the previous week's extraordinarily large $5.6 billion increase to be eliminated.   Including the latest results, growth of the M-1B money supply measure remains far below the minimum 6 percent annual growth target that the Federal Reserve set before the year began. M-1B, which now totals $433.9 billion, consists of currency plus all types of checking accounts, and is used by economists as a proxy for the amount of money the public has available for spending.   Many analysts and traders in the credit markets concluded that the latest money supply and banking data provided few new clues about the future direction of interest rates.

headline: JWT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ISRAEL MAY DELAY DECIDING MAKEUP OF THE SINAI FORCE
abstract: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel left open the possibility today that his Government might postpone a decision on the participation by four European nations in the Sinai peacekeeping force.   The Israeli Cabinet is scheduled to meet Sunday to discuss the makeup of the multinational force that is due to move into Sinai when Israel withdraws from the area in April.   Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel has said he opposes the participation of Britain, France, Italy and the Netherlands in the force because of their support for positions that the Israelis see as pro-Palestinian. 'Clarification' Reported   In announcing their willingness to participate in the Sinai force, the Europeans had made statements reiterating these views. Tonight, after Mr. Shamir left Washington following talks with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., Israeli diplomats here said Mr. Haig had apparently discussed with the Europeans a ''clarification'' of their position that might make a compromise with Israel possible.

headline: 4 SOLIDARITY LEADERS FAIL TO GAIN SEATS ON NATIONAL PANEL
abstract: Four top Solidarity officials, including one involved in the controversy over cigarette price increases, failed today to win seats on the national leadership commission.   Solidarity sources said the union's convention may be forced to hold a third session as a result of the unsuccessful voting and the lengthy debates.   A third round of balloting became necessary in the complicated proportional voting when not enough candidates won a sufficient number of votes to be seated on the union's 69-member ruling body. A union spokesman said five seats remained to be filled.

headline: LFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 23
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BIRD & SON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: J.C. PENNEY WILL OFFER LEVI BRAND
abstract: Levi Strauss & Company announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with the J.C. Penney Company to sell Levi's clothing through the retailer. The decision marks the first entry by San Francisco-based Levi Strauss, the world's largest apparel manufacturer, into national chain distribution.   Until now, Levi's clothes have been available to department and specialty stores, but the company has avoided the mass merchandisers and discount stores. J.C. Penney is the nation's third-largest retailer, behind Sears, Roebuck & Company and the K Mart Corporation.

headline: Earnings Up 20.3% At Chase
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, in step with the emerging pattern of higher third-quarter bank profits, said yesterday that its operating earnings rose by 20.3 percent during the latest three months.   The improvement was partially a result of more loans on its books, as well as a widening spread between what it paid for money and the interest charges on its loans, a factor related to declining rates in the closing weeks of the quarter.   The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, benefiting from the same conditions in the money markets, reported that its operating earnings rose 18.2 percent in the quarter. Operating earnings excludes gains or losses from securities transactions.

headline: Israel Reports 91.6% Inflation In the First 11 Months of '81
abstract: Inflation was 91.6 percent in the first 11 months of this year, the Central Bureau of Statistics announced today.   The Government bureau said the cost-of-living index rose 5.8 percent in November after having risen 9 percent in October.  Israeli workers receive automatic pay increases to compensate for rises in the cost-of-living index.

headline: Needham Gets Account Of Washington Post
abstract: The Washington Post has hired the Washington office of Needham, Harper & Steers to do its advertising.

headline: Ex-British Intelligence Officer Admits He Spied for Moscow
abstract: A former British intelligence officer has admitted that he supplied important military secrets to the Soviet Union in World War II and later escaped prosecution despite the exposure of his espionage ring, The Sunday Times reported.   ''I feel deep remorse for what I have done,'' the former officer, Leo Long, told the London newspaper.  It said Mr. Long, a retired film company executive, admitted that he had supplied top-grade military intelligence to Anthony Blunt, who was for a time an art adviser to Queen Elizabeth II and who admitted having spied for Moscow.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: 7 Gambians Sentenced To Death Over Coup
abstract: Seven Gambians were sentenced to death today for their part in the attempt to overthrow Gambia's President, Sir Dawda Kairaba Jawara, last July.

headline: REAGAN DASHES HOPES OF GUATEMALA
abstract: The euphoria here that followed Ronald Reagan's Presidential victory a year ago has given way to confusion, disappointment and anger.   Elated at the defeat of Jimmy Carter, Government supporters celebrated with bursts of automatic weapons, fireworks and a marimba band in front of the United States Embassy.   They blamed Mr. Carter's human rights policy for the leftist revolution that led to the overthrow of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle in Nicaragua and for serious guerrilla threats to the governments here and in El Salvador.   ''There were those who expected guns, helicopters, ammunition on Jan. 21,'' said a civic leader who devotes much time to trying to improve United States-Guatemalan relations.

headline: NEED FOR BIG POLISH AID SEEN
abstract: Poland is likely to need at least $12 billion in Western aid next year, just to keep its economic crisis from getting worse, according to a strongly pessimistic report released here this week. The report was prepared for Societe Generale, one of France's three big state-owned banks, by its chief economist.   Any permanent cure, the report finds, is likely to require much greater assistance from the West. The economist, Yves Laulan, based his report on a visit to Poland last month with six other economists. They represented the Western banks currently negotiating an easing of repayment terms for the roughly $18 billion that Poland owes them.

headline: MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Moscow Issues Warning To U.S. on Arms Talks
abstract: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda warned today that the Soviet Union would have to take steps to guarantee a balance between East and West in nuclear weapons in Europe if arms talks with the United States next month were marked by bad faith.   The commentary seemed to imply that the Soviet Union would increase its nuclear arsenal in Europe if the United States, despite the talks, proceeded with plans to modernize allied nuclear missiles on the Continent.

headline: NOVAR ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; U.N. Group Proclaims World Food Day
abstract: The first World Food Day at the Rome headquarters of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization was opened today by former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany, who said that more than half a billion people were suffering from hunger and malnutrition   Mr. Brandt made the keynote address as chairman of the Independent Commission on International Development Issues. World Food Day was organized to call attention to food problems and to spur action to increase food production and more equitable distribution.   The morning ceremonies, attended by representatives of the Food and Agriculture Organization's 147 member nations, was the centerpiece of World Food Day activities in more than 141 countries.

headline: U.S. Productivity Panel
abstract: President Reagan today established an advisory committee on productivity and named former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon to head the group. The panel, consisting of 33 members, most of them business executives, is to study ways the Government affects productivity and to advise the Reagan Administration on how it can encourage growth.

headline: ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NATIONAL CITY LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SOME STATES ACT TO CUT BUSINESS TAX LOSSES
abstract: A number of states, perhaps as many as 19, are taking steps to diminish revenue losses that would result from the more generous depreciation allowances for business adopted by Congress this year, according to a survey released today.   Such actions would require businesses to pay roughly $12.3 billion more in income taxes to the states in the years 1981-86 than they would pay if the states go along with the change in Federal law.   The survey also found that 14 states, including Connecticut and Vermont, ''appear likely'' to adopt the more generous Federal formula for tax write-offs for the cost of buildings, vehicles and equipment.

headline: MCI-AMERICAN EXPRESS PACT
abstract: MCI Communications Inc., a Washingtonbased company that competes with the Bell System for long-distance telephone business, said today that it had signed a marketing agreement with the American Express Company giving it access to more than nine million holders of American Express cards.   Agreement on a final contract had been expected.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STELCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. DROPS ARAB SATELLITE PLANS
abstract: Stung by Congressional criticism, the Reagan Administration today withdrew a plan to sell communications satellite equipment to an Arab consortium that includes Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization.   Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. indicated, however, that the Administration might resubmit the plan after it had time to lay the groundwork.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Anti-Soviet Protest in Delhi
abstract: About 500 people, including some Afghans, demonstrated outside the Soviet Embassy here today to protest the presence of Soviet troops in Afghanistan and developments in Poland.

headline: RYKOFF, S E, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TIMES CO. IS ASSAILED
abstract: An advertisement in The New York Times yesterday accused The New York Times Company of anti-union tactics at a paper mill in Madison, Me., in which the company is a partner.   Walter E. Mattson, president and chief operating officer of The New York Times Company, said yesterday in response to questions about the advertisement that a five-year union contract, including a company-sponsored pension plan, was in effect at the mill.

headline: SCHMIDT WILL MEET HONECKER IN EAST GERMANY NEXT WEEK
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Erich Honecker, the East German leader, will meet in East Germany next week, a Bonn Government spokesman said today.   The spokesman, Kurt Becker, said the talks were part of the ''German contribution to the dialogue between East and West,'' and would deal with East-West relations, the situation in Europe, the relations between the two Germanys, and the state of the economy, including the worldwide recession.   Mr. Becker said the meeting, scheduled for Dec. 11-13, was part of efforts to achieve a reduction of tensions. They follow a visit here by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, and the opening of the Geneva talks on medium-range missiles in Europe.

headline: GCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Broker Loan Rate Up
abstract: The United States Trust Company raised its broker loan rate to 13 1/2 percent from 13 1/4 percent, effective yesterday, a bank spokesman said. Broker rates, the charge on loans used to finance stock purchases on credit, now stand between 13 1/2 percent and 14 percent at major banks.

headline: Needham Creates Post Of Agency Media Head
abstract: Richard C. Anderson, 50 years old, who has been executive vice president and director of media resources at Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, is returning to New York, where he will fill the newly created position of corporate director of media and programming for the agency. He continues with the proud title of executive vice president and also moves on to the board.   His road to media glory included New York-area stops at Frankfurt Communications, Daniel Starch & Staff, the research firm, and Young & Rubicam.

headline: Burroughs Price Rises
abstract: The Burroughs Corporation said today that it would increase the lease and purchase price of its information processing equipment by 5 percent, effective Jan. 1. The company added that prices on selected products would be increased by up to 10 percent.

headline: Paper Units Post Gains
abstract: The Weyerhaeuser Company, one of the nation's largest timber owners, said yesterday that its earnings for the third quarter rose 52 percent. to $50.1 million, or 34 cents a share, from $32.8 million, or 23 cents, in the comparable period a year earlier. Sales fell 1.2 percent, to $1.09 billion from $1.11 billion.

headline: SPECIALIZED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hoffman-Koos Account To Albert J. Rosenthal
abstract: Huffman-Koos, the 14-outlet furniture store chain, has assigned its broadcast advertising account to Albert J. Rosenthal & Company.

headline: Search Goes On After St. Lawrence Blaze
abstract: Helicopters searched the icy waters of the lower St. Lawrence River today for three crewmen missing after a Christmas Day fire on the oil tanker Hudson Transport.

headline: SUDAN'S LEADER PREDICTS AN INVASION BY LIBYANS
abstract: Maj. Gen. Gaafar al-Nimeiry, President of the Sudan, said today that he expected Libya to invade the Sudan through Chad in the near future and that such an invasion was ''going to be pushed by the Soviet Union and its bloc.''   In an interview, General Nimeiry said that, as a result of his talks here with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., American arms deliveries to the Sudan would be accelerated. There was also discussion of possible Sudanese participation in the Rapid Deployment Force exercise scheduled by the United States in Egypt in November.   General Nimeiry said he had also discussed plans with the new Egyptian administration for having Sudanese forces visit Egypt and Egyptian forces visit Sudan as part of a joint training exercise under their mutual defense treaty.

headline: New Hiller Offer Rejected by Kaiser
abstract: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said that its directors had rejected a new offer from the Hiller Investment Company to acquire the company for $54 a share. Hiller, a private investment group based in Menlo Park, Calif., had previously offered $52 a share.   Kaiser, which said that no further talks would be held with Hiller, said that its current business plan, which includes a possible buyback of its own shares, would better serve its shareholders than the Hiller proposal.

headline: IN OLD JERUSALEM, PRAYER CAN BE AN INCENDIARY ACT
abstract: Shortly after noon last Thursday, a group of about 30 Jews walked briskly up a long, curved ramp to the Gate of the Mughrebins, which opens onto Jerusalem's Temple Mount.   There, through the narrow opening, lay the land on which the temples of Solomon and Herod had stood, and where two Moslem mosques now mark the third holiest place of Islam.   All morning, tourists had been going onto the Temple Mount through this gate. But when the Jews approached, they were met by a row of six policemen - some Arabs, some Jews - who blocked their way.

headline: Around the World; Athens Cracks Down On Industrial Polluters
abstract: Drastic measures went into effect here Wednesday to fight record pollution levels registered in the Greek capital, including a reduction of traffic volume by one half and of certain industrial plants' production by 30 percent, and a ban on heating in almost all public buildings.   The measures were ordered after pollution Wednesday exceeded the internationally stipulated emergency level of five photometric units, in a city already listed as the second most polluted metropolis in the world.

headline: BUCKLEY GROUP TO PAY $800,000 IN S.E.C. SUIT
abstract: The company founded by the late oilman William F. Buckley Sr. was ordered today, along with some associates, to make payments and relinquish royalties totaling more than $800,000.   The payments were ordered in a consent agreement entered into by the Buckley interests and the Securities and Exchange Commission. The agreement grew out of charges of financial irregularities relating to activities from 1969 to 1980 of the Catawba Corporation, 98 percentowned by the Buckley family. Under the terms of the agreement, the Buckley interests neither admitted nor denied the charges.

headline: Regular Times Dividend
abstract: The New York Times Company declared a regular quarterly dividend of 27 1/2 cents a share yesterday on its class A and class B common stock, payable Jan. 4 to shareholders of record on Dec. 4. A regular quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share on the 5 1/2 percent cumulative prior preference stock was also declared, with the same effective dates.

headline: U.S. STUDY ON SOVIET POWER WELCOMED BY NATO
abstract: The European allies of the United States have generally welcomed the publication this week of the Defense Department's comprehensive study of Soviet military power.   The 99-page booklet, which was conceived at a meeting of defense ministers in Bonn in April, provided the North Atlantic Treaty Organization governments with fresh ammunition against the new European wave of opposition to the deployment of American nuclear weapons and to increases in military spending.   ''It will be very useful in countering the unilateralists,'' a British diplomat said, reflecting a common view.  The booklet, which is full of maps, color photographs and charts assessing the military strength of the Soviet Union and the threat it poses to the West, is being widely distributed by American Embassies. The demand from European newspapers, governments and foun dations is reported to be strong, and sup plies have been quickly exhausted.

headline: A PRINCIPAL SHARES VIEWS OF APPAREL CONCERN
abstract: Marvin Blumenfeld, one of the principals in last week's merger of three companies in the men's apparel industry into a corporation with annual sales of $100 million, summarized yesterday how the deal was born.   ''There had been a synergy of relationships that existed between the parties all along,'' he said. ''The whole affair developed from a luncheon meeting when we sat down and said that this is something that could be put together.''

headline: ACCELERATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ZAMBIAN UNIONIST OPPOSING KAUNDA
abstract: Shortly before he was detained last summer, Frederick Chiluba, Zambia's most prominent labor leader, sought increased contacts with Western diplomats here and invited them to compare his movement to the Solidarity union in Poland.   The message, one of the Western envoys said, was clear: Mr.  Chiluba, the chairman of the Zambia Congress of Trade Unions, was presenting himself as an alternative to President Kenneth D. Kaunda and his United National Independence Party, the country's only lawful political group.   Mr. Chiluba's aspirations did not go unnoticed by the President. On July 4, after a series of strikes in Zambia's copper mines, he ordered the detention of Mr. Chiluba and three other union leaders.  Since then there has been a standoff in the potentially explosive dispute between Mr. Kaunda and the unions.

headline: Survey Research For Cosmetics Sales
abstract: Marketers who sell through supermarkets and drugstores are aided in their competitive wars by having available syndicated market share data that will let them know just where they stand relative to the others in their category - whether that dip in sales is everyone's problem or just theirs.   But data of that kind are not available to all marketers and that is what Robert N. Reitter, president of Reitter, Wilkins & Associates, marketing research, is planning to do something about.

headline: French Joblessness Up
abstract: French seasonally adjusted unemployment is estimated to have risen to 1.82 million in October from 1.81 million in September, the Labor Ministry said today.

headline: CGA COMPUTER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MOSCOW IS SILENT ON REAGAN THREAT
abstract: The Soviet press agency Tass today condemned President Reagan's economic sanctions against Poland as an ''abominable intervention'' in Polish affairs but gave only a brief comment on his contention that the Soviet Union bore a major share of the blame for the Polish crackdown.   Soviet reaction was limited to two Tass dispatches from Washington, the first of which ignored the President's references to the Soviet Union. A second report this evening said Mr. Reagan had groundlessly slandered the Soviet Union, but made no mention of his warning that the United States would take political and economic measures against the Kremlin if the Polish crackdown continued.

headline: Around the World; British Leyland Accord Fails to Avert a Stoppage
abstract: Last-ditch talks by management and unions of British Leyland, the huge state-owned auto manufacturer, produced a tentative settlement late yesterday, but it came too late to avert a strike that began at midnight.   Sir John Boyd, general secretary of the Amalgamated Union of Engineering Workers, said that the strike by 58,000 workers would go ahead and that the union would submit the proposed settlement to the strikers at a meeting this week.   The 11 unions have been demanding a 17.5 percent pay increase.

headline: Marcos Drafts Program For Third-World Aid
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos consulted the four other members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations today on a program for third-world resource development that he plans to present at a meeting of developing and industrial nations in Cancun, Mexico, this month.

headline: African Trade Pact
abstract: Only nine of a possible 18 countries signed a treaty today at a conference here to form an East and Southern African Preferential Trade Area.

headline: Iran Plans to Rebuff Amnesty International
abstract: Iran's revolutionary prosecutor said today that he would deny a request by Amnesty International to visit Iranian jails until the group also condemns the treatment of prisoners in Iraq, Israel, Egypt and the United States.   The prosecutor, Hojatolislam Hussein Mussavi, said, according to the Teheran radio, that the number of executions had decreased.

headline: Yields of New Bills Advance; 6-Month Rate Set at 12.45%
abstract: Rates continued to climb at yesterday's Treasury auction of threeand six-month bills. The average yield on three-month bills jumped to 11.690 percent from 11.037 a week ago, while the rate on the companion six-month bills advanced to 12.45 percent from 11.84 percent.   As a result, banks and thrift institutions may offer a maximum rate of 12.698 percent on their new six-month savings certificates, effective today. The top rate on these instruments last week was 12.088 percent.

headline: U.S.-PEKING RELATIONS CALLED DELICATE
abstract: The prospect of American military sales to Taiwan is producing a ''very delicate moment'' in relations between the United States and China, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale said today.   His assessment, Mr. Mondale said, was based upon private talks with Chinese leaders, principally Deputy Prime Ministers Deng Xiaopeng and Wan Li, over the last few days here.   Speaking to reporters at a news conference concluding his four-day visit as a guest of the Chinese Government, Mr. Mondale said: ''I cannot deny, based on my discussions, that the current disputes surrounding the potential arms sales to Taiwan - the potential advanced fighters and the rest - is creating a very delicate moment in our relationship.'' Delay in Delivering Computers   Mr. Mondale said that an additional, although ''not fundamental,'' irritant for the Chinese was continuing American delay in delivering several large computers that the Carter Administration had promised, including one that China wants for a census next year.

headline: RAMPART GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

headline: EGYPT-ISRAEL FERRY IS PLANNED
abstract: Israel and Egypt signed an agreement today to open a ferry line between the Mediterranean port towns of Ashdod and Port Said after Israel's final scheduled withdrawal from Sinai next April.   The agreement was accompanied by an announcement that the two nations planned to coordinate their operations to encourage international tourism.

headline: Japan Plans Tariff Cuts
abstract: The governmental tariff rate council said today that that it had recommended tariff reductions over the next three years for 1,653 items, beginning next April 1, to help ease trade frictions with other countries.   The council is an advisory panel to Finance Minister Michio Watanabe, who estimated that tariff revenues would fall $182 million next year.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Camp David Finished, A British Envoy Asserts
abstract: Ambassador David Roberts of Britain was quoted today as having said that the United Statessponsored Camp David peace process between Israel and Egypt was ''finished, more or less.''   In an interview with the English-language weekly Monday Morning, he said that the way forward lay in a fusion of Saudi Arabian and Western European proposals for a Middle East peace.

headline: ALLIED MAINTENANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: DOW ADDS 1.24
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average edged 1.24 points higher yesterday, extending its gain in five sessions to more than 38 points. But, over all, declines outnumbered advances by 4-to-3 on the New York Stock Exchange.   The Dow closed at 890.22. Volume expanded to 54 million shares from Monday's 47.6 million.  ''The market absorbed profit taking quite well today,'' Raymond F.  DeVoe Jr. of Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc. said. ''Basically, stock prices are still marching to the drummer of lower interest rates.''

headline: 'BAN THE BOMB' MOVEMENT IS BOUNCING BACK IN BRITAIN
abstract: Two years ago the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament seemed as anachronistic as the @miniskirt, another quaint relic from the optimistic, extroverted Britain of the 1960's.   Not any more. Membership in the national organization has risen from 3,000 to 30,000. There are now 1,000 local branches, compared with 30 in 1979. Circulation of the group's publication, Sanity, has swollen from 5,000 to 60,000. The total budget last year was $50,000; this year the campaign will spend $200,000 on publications alone.

headline: XEROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: U.S. IS INSISTENT
abstract: Libya's ruler, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, denied yesterday that he had plotted to assassinate President Reagan or anyone else. But the State Department said that it had evidence of such plans.   ''We are sure we haven't sent any people to kill Reagan or any other people in the world,'' Colonel Qaddafi said. After he spoke in an interview televised from his Tripoli office, the State Department issued a statement in Washington that said, ''We have strong evidence that Qaddafi has been planning the murder of American officials both here and overseas.''

headline: LIFESURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Business Forum; THE MEMORIES OF A CHASE BANKER
abstract: A FTER working at the State Department, the author was a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank and chief of staff to its former chairman, David Rockefeller. Following Mr. Rockefeller's retirement in April, Mr. Reed became senior adviser to Willard C.  Butcher, who curently is chairman of Chase. In September, Mr. Reed was appointed Ambassador to the Kingdom of Morocco. Before leaving, he pulled together some recollections of his career at Chase and published them in a brochure that he sent to some of his former colleagues. Following are excerpts:   When I returned from Foggy Bottom to the Big Apple and was assigned to work with the Bank's chairman, I was duly awed. As time passed, however, I learned the Rule of the Great:   ''When someone you greatly admire and respect appears to be thinking deep thoughts, he is probably thinking about lunch.'' I think you will agree that ''D.R.,'' ''Mr. Chairman,'' David, Mr.  Rockefeller, our Captain, is the outstanding ''business-statesman'' in the world today. I am grateful and proud to have been a member of his crew.

headline: PRODUCERS' PRICES CONTINUE TO SHOW INFLATION SLOWING
abstract: Three indexes that measure prices at various levels of production indicated a continued easing of inflation during October.   The Producer Price Index, which applies to finished goods and is a rough measure of the level of inflation that consumers will face in coming months, inched up by six-tenths of 1 percent in October from September, the Labor Department reported today.   Although this was the biggest advance for this index since April, economists said that it reflected mainly a big jump in the prices of 1982-model cars and an end of auto makers' rebate programs. The rebates had helped to keep the rise in the finished goods index in September to just two-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: Japan Curbs U.S. Flights
abstract: Japan, which has long asserted that there are ''gross inequalities'' in its aviation pact with the United States, announced sanctions against United States airlines today in response to American restrictions on its flag carrier.   Japan's Transport Ministry said the sanctions included a freeze on applications from United States carriers for rights to take Tokyobound flights on to other destinations.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Hecht & Partners
abstract: The 14-year-old Hecht, Higgins & Petterson today will become Arthur Hecht & Partners, which is sensible because Walter Higgins and Lewis Petterson are elsewhere. The agency, with $8 million in billings, specializes in making cable television ads. The agency has also formed three subsidiaries, two of which produce programs for cable and radio and a third that will publish advertising-supported books on sports and other leisure activities.

headline: MOROCCO GIVES UP 2 BASES IN WESTERN SAHARA
abstract: The Moroccan Army has abandoned two key outposts to guerrillas in the Western Sahara in what appears to be a strategic withdrawal behind a special line of fixed defenses.   In a communique issued in Algiers on Friday, the Polisario Front said its guerrillas had occupied the outposts of Guelta Zemmur and Bir Anzaran since the Moroccans evacuated them after dynamiting all the military installations. The official Algerian press agency, monitored by Reuters, said the outposts had been in the hands of the guerrillas since Nov. 9.

headline: POLISH AIRWAVES: WARSAW REPORTS A 'FESTIVE' AIR
abstract: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government Agency: Report to the Polish People 12:08 P.M. Sunday   (6:08 A.M. Sunday, E.S.T.) We are spending the third day of the Christmas holiday in really wintry weather. Snow has been falling over almost the entire country since this morning. This has made transportation difficult, but both town and country have taken on a festive appearance. It may be more difficult to visit family and friends today using public or private transport, but it is warm enough to take long healthy walks. Not everyone is on holiday, however. The special services are operating as are duty groups in almost all workplaces. They are getting the workplaces ready for tomorrow, which should pass without any disruptions, because production tasks are currently very large and binding on everyone.   In the capital, the planned number of 20 trolleys and 420 buses are operating today but this morning they are almost empty. Warsaw is deep in snow but the main arteries are clear.

headline: Strike Delays Italian Trains
abstract: Italian trains were delayed up to 10 hours today when thousands of railroad workers went on strike for 24 hours. It was the first of a series of rail strikes planned this month by unions protesting the Government's decision to delay negotiations on new contracts.

headline: THE SAVINGS BANKS CUSHION
abstract: Although experiencing heavy losses, most of New York City's savings banks are not in danger of immediate failure, and many have enough surplus reserves to sustain current losses for five years or more.   At least four, however, are apparently in a precarious position as a result of high interest rates, a survey by The New York Times has found. If the cost of money remains at or near current levels, the four could be in danger of failing within the next 12 months.   These are the New York Bank for Savings, the city's 3d-largest state-chartered savings bank, with total deposits of $3 billion; the Greenwich Savings Bank, the 8th-largest, with deposits of $2 billion; the Union Dime Savings Bank, the 17th-largest with deposits of $1.3 billion, and the Central Savings Bank, the 25th largest with deposits of $734 million.   All deposits of up to $100,000 in savings banks are insured for both principal and interest by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, an agency of the Federal Government. Officials last week stressed that even those individuals with more than $100,000 on deposit would be fully protected by the agency.

headline: LTV-Grumman
abstract: The LTV Corporation said that a United States District Court will hear arguments on Thursday on its charges that the Grumman Corporation made material omissions and misrepresentations in public statements on LTV's tender offer for Grumman stock. It said the court in Dallas will also hear its charges that recent purchases of Grumman stock by the company and its pension plan violated securities laws.

headline: FRENCH TAKEOVERS FACE CHALLENGE FROM ABROAD
abstract: France's new Socialist Government appears to be facing a major defeat in its sweeping nationalization program.  A Geneva-based financial group announced today that it had acquired more than half the capital of Paribas (Suisse), the Geneva subsidiary of Compagnie Financiere de Paris et des Pays-Bas, the big French investment bank that is on the Government's nationalization list.   Andre de Pyffyer, president of the Geneva group, Pargesa Holding S.A., said today that he might attempt ''other operations concerning the international holdings'' of Paribas. There have been reports that Pargesa is preparing a takeover bid for one of the major Belgian assets of Paribas, an industrial holding company called Copeba, with assets of about $250 million.

headline: SOVIET BACKING GAVE KEKKONEN ROOM TO FINESSE
abstract: The announcement that 81-year-old President Urho Kekkonen of Finland has resigned for reasons of health brings to an end a presidency that has lasted more than 25 of the nation's 64 years of independence.   Charged by the Finnish Constitution with responsibility for the nation's foreign policy, he has been an activist President, guiding Finland into participation in international affairs unthinkable when he first won election in February 1956 at a time of uneasy relations with the Soviet Union, with which Finland shares 788 miles of border.    The Finns, under President Kekkonen, have gradually enlarged their freedom of maneuver while pursuing a policy designed to keep the Soviet Union convinced that its security is not being imperiled through Finland. For Moscow, the most important component of the policy, which stresses neutrality and friendly relations with all nations, particularly the Soviet Union, has been the person carrying it out, President Kekkonen himself.   The most notable example of this policy is the special trade agreement Finland signed in October 1973 with the European Economic Community, which the Soviet Union had long denounced.

headline: Small Growth Seen in Travel
abstract: The travel industry, plagued by a poor economy and the air traffic controllers' strike in 1981, is taking a ''wait and hope'' attitude toward 1982.   About 200 travel executives met here recently to examine business patterns for 1982.

headline: U.S. Steel Layoffs
abstract: About 1,800 workers at the Fairless Works of the United States Steel Corporation will be laid off for at least two weeks over the Christmas holidays, the company announced today.

headline: Railroads Receive Project Loan
abstract: The Chicago & North Western Transportation Company and the Union Pacific Corporation said they had obtained financing for a rail line project estimated to cost $460 million into the coal-rich Powder River Basin in Wyoming.   Railroad officials announced jointly that they had obtained financing commitments for the project, with Chicago & North Western lining up $345 million in loans from a group of banks for 75 percent of the project.

headline: VICE PRESIDENT AFFIRMS 'ALL TREATIES'
abstract: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was shot and killed today by a group of men in military uniforms who hurled hand grenades and fired rifles at him as he watched a military parade commemorating the 1973 war against Israel.   Vice President Hosni Mubarak, in announcing Mr. Sadat's death, said  Mubarak speech excerpted, page A9. Egypt's treaties and international commitments would be respected. He said the Speaker of Parliament, Sufi Abu Taleb, would serve as interim President pending an election in 60 days.   The assassins' bullets ended the life of a man who earned a reputation for making bold decisions in foreign affairs, a reputation based in large part on his decision in 1977 to journey to the camp of Egypt's foe, Israel, to make peace. Sadat Forged His Own Regime   Regarded as an interim ruler when he came to power in 1970 on the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser, Mr. Sadat forged his own regime and ran Egypt single-handedly. He was bent on moving this impoverished country into the late 20th century, a drive that led him to abandon an alliance with the Soviet Union and embrace the West.

headline: MOSCOW OFFICIAL VOWS TO MATCH BUILDUP IN ARMS
abstract: The Soviet Union celebrated the 64th anniversary of its revolution today with the traditional display of military might in Red Square. From atop the Lenin Mausoleum, Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said the country would never allow another to achieve military superiority.   He made the comments in a brief ''order of the day'' to troops of the Moscow garrison massed in the square for the annual celebration.  Accusing the West and China of ''lunatic imperialist reaction,'' Marshal Ustinov said the Soviet Union paid ''unremitting attention'' to its defenses.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Bracken Exploration Co. is selling 400,000 shares of common stock at $13 a share, to be offered through a Rotan Mosle Inc. group.   * Dayton-Hudson Corp. is selling $100 million of 15 1/4 percent notes due 1991 to be offered by a Goldman, Sachs & Co. group at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 15.35 percent.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J. has appointed James L.  Vincent group vice president of the corporation and president of its health and scientific products company.   * Avera Corp., Scotts Valley, Calif., has elected to its board Pierre R. Lamond, a former vice president with National Semiconductor.   * Bankers Trust Company has elected David L. Hinds and Thomas C.  Miller senior vice presidents.

headline: CHINESE MAY TRADE MINERALS FOR ARMS
abstract: China may have found a solution to its most pressing military problem: how to modernize its army on limited financial resources.  The solution, according to a recent study, may be the production and sale of strategic minerals to the United States and other members of the Atlantic alliance to provide the money required to begin in earnest the modernization program the army needs.   The authors of the study, Douglas T. Stuart and William T. Tow of the University of Southern California's School of International Relations, have explored the topic and its ramifications.   One of their conclusions is that the United States and China will continue to expand arms trade in the medium term but that ''actual weapons purchases will probably be infrequent and of limited financial or military importance.''

headline: I.C.C. Chief Assailed
abstract: A bipartisan panel of regulatory experts today assailed Reese H. Taylor Jr., chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and his agency's application of the new trucking bill.   Alfred E. Kahn, who introduced airline deregulation three years ago and helped to complete the Motor Carrier Act of 1980 as a member of the Carter Administration, said that developments at the commission had upset him.   ''I'm not sad; I'm mad,'' he told theJoint Economic Committee.  Mr. Kahn, two former members of the I.C.C. and Thomas Gale Moore, a conservative economist, criticized the new chairman for maintaining restrictive policies that run counter to the mandate to promote increased competition in the vast national trucking industry.

headline: Marriott's Net Rises by 11.5%
abstract: The Marriott Corporation, the big hotel chain based in Washington, reported yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter ended Sept. 11 rose by 11.5 percent on an increase in sales of 15.3 percent.   Marriott said that net income in the latest three months expanded to $28.2 million, or $1.05 a share, from $25.3 million, or 96 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

headline: MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARMS FOR CHINA AND TAIWAN: TWISTS IN DIPLOMACY
abstract: A week before President Reagan's private meeting with China's Prime Minister at the conference in Mexico on the developing world, the United States, China and Taiwan are enmeshed in an intricate game of arms sales diplomacy.   According to Administration officials and foreign diplomats, the sequence of events began in 1980 with a request by China for American arms. Then, last August, the Reagan Administration offered to sell about 30 of the 52 weapons systems and technologies on the Chinese list.   But now Peking is refusing even to discuss the package for fear of being trapped into accepting the sale of the new FX fighter aircraft to Taiwan as a quid pro quo. Peking also continues to threaten a rupture in Chinese-American relations if that sale is made.

headline: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REGAN PUTS DEFICIT UNDER $100 BILLION
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Administration hoped to hold the budget deficit in the current fiscal year below $100 billion without rescinding or delaying the reduction in income tax rates that was enacted last August.   Some experts on Wall Street believe this goal will be difficult to achieve. But the White House Office of Management and Budget leans toward optimism. ''Oh, that's possible,'' said Edwin L. Dale Jr., the budget office spokesman, in referring to Mr. Regan's comment.

headline: BRAZILIAN'S BEQUEST SETS OFF $12 BILLION SCRAMBLE
abstract: Though there is every evidence that Domingos Faustino Correa was anything but a good family man, thousands of South Americans are earnestly trying to prove they were related to him.   He killed one of his brothers and he denied the families of his other siblings any part of his estate. The snub was particularly gratuitous since by then all eight brothers and sisters were dead.   The irascible old landowner died childless in 1873 but only after inserting a clause in his will 14 days beforehand that in effect assured that his spleen would live on after him. The added language said that no one in his family could lay hand on any of his considerable possessions until 100 years hence.

headline: Around the World; The Two Yemens Agree To Set Up Closer Ties
abstract: Yemen and Southern Yemen said today that they had agreed on wide-ranging political and economic cooperation to follow up an unfulfilled merger agreement of two years ago.

headline: Afghan Refugees Increase
abstract: The number of Afghan refugees in Pakistan has risen to about 2.5 million and the country is now the ''single largest refugee theater in the world,'' a senior Pakistani refugee official said today.

headline: British Leyland Increases Layoffs
abstract: A five-day-old strike over tea breaks caused British Leyland to lay off 2,000 more workers at its giant Longbridge plant outside Birmingham, with all car production at a standstill.

headline: LONDON PRINTERS REJECT PACT AT THE SUNDAY TIMES
abstract: Workers at The Sunday Times tonight rejected a proposed settlement of their dispute with management, throwing into doubt the future of the paper and its sister publication, The Times of London.   ''I am not closing them down tonight, but I 'm not saying what I will do tomorrow,'' Rupert Murdoch, owner of the papers, said after the vote. He said that he felt ''some sadness and some anger'' but that he had ''a few cards to play yet.''

headline: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BURMESE ABOUT TO SIGN AID ACCORD WITH U.S.
abstract: The Burmese Government is reported to be on the verge of signing an aid agreement with the United States providing $30 million in agricultural assistance spread over a period of three to five years.   The accord is viewed by Americans as a significant step by the determinedly neutralist Government of President Ne Win, which has refused economic aid from either the Soviet Union or the United States since it came into office by military coup in 1962. Diplomats said Burma continued to ignore offers of assistance from Moscow.   The only American aid that Burma has been accepting is in narcotics suppression. Since 1974 the United States has supplied 26 helicopters and 5 transport planes to help the Burmese Army fight rebel groups that cultivate, transport and refine opium near the eastern frontier. An annual program, amounting to $4.6 million for this fiscal year, provides plane maintenance, communications equipment and assistance in crop-substitution programs for opium growers.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bank of Montreal has elected to its board Walther Leisler Kiep, a German businessman.   * Bankers Trust Co. has named Anthony O. Arcuni, senior vice president, head of the Middle East/Africa Group of the International Department, and J. Anthony Wallace to senior vice president and head of the International Investment Management Group.

headline: Philippines Plant
abstract: United Coconut Oil Mills is likely to choose Lurgi of West Germany as its partner in a chemical project costing $500 million, sources close to the negotiations said.

headline: ARMY IS IN CONTROL IN POLAND BUT PARTY IS NOT COUNTED OUT
abstract: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland. Normal communications with The Times's Warsaw bureau chief, John Darnton, have been barred by authorities there since Dec. 14.   The Communist Party has been almost totally eclipsed by the military authorities running the day-to-day affairs of the martial law Government, but that does not mean the party is a spent force in national life, Western analysts in Warsaw believe.   ''I have a feeling that the party's interests are being looked after,'' said one well informed person, who pointed out that since all of the top military men are also party members, it is hard to tell where the army leaves off and the Communist Party begins.   The authorities, including Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who heads the military, the party and the Government, have gone to great lengths to insist that the takeover of Dec. 13 was not a coup d'etat. The normal institutions of Government have been left in place and are still functioning, they argue.

headline: RATES SLIDE AGAIN IN BOND RALLY
abstract: Prices of long-term bonds advanced sharply yesterday, with investor demand boosting by more than a point the bellwether Treasury issues due in 30 years. They have advanced about 17 points since late October - a $170 gain per $1,000 face value and easily the largest increase in bond prices in more than 18 months.   While the higher prices cut the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds to 12.77 percent late yesterday, from 15.22 percent on Oct.27, interest rates on shorter-term issues such as Treasury bills have dropped by even larger amounts. Yesterday, for example, the Treasury sold new one-year bills at an average rate of 10.506 percent, which resulted in an 8.34 percent yield for the special one-year tax-exempt savings deposits, popularly known as ''All Savers'' certificates.   Until the new rate goes into effect next week, banks and other financial institutions may pay a 10.71 percent rate on the one-year tax-exempt certificates. They were first offered Oct.1 at a yield of 12.61 percent.

headline: ATTACK ON REAGAN EASED BY MOSCOW
abstract: In the period leading up to the talks between the United States and the Soviet Union on intermediate-range nuclear weapons, which are scheduled to open Monday in Geneva, the two sides have staked out positions that look almost irreconcilable.   But a senior Western diplomat who met with top Soviet officials after President Reagan proposed a mutual renunciation of the missiles later reported that his Kremlin contacts had advised him not to take too seriously the contemptuous commentaries on Mr. Reagan's offer that were made in the Soviet press. The implication, the diplomat felt, was that the President's proposal would receive a more careful hearing in Geneva.   The initial Soviet response to the Reagan proposal was to castigate the President for adopting the guise of a peace-maker while putting forward an offer he knew Moscow would refuse. According to the Russians, Mr. Reagan's purpose was to ease antinuclear protests in Western Europe and so clear the path for the deployment of a new generation of American missiles that would give Washington firststrike ability against the Soviet Union's strategic missile force.

headline: Accountant at Helm Of Vitt Media Service
abstract: There was a bit of surprise in the advertising community when it was announced that Roy A. Muro, the new president and chief operating officer of Vitt Media International, a buying service, is by training an accountant. Mr. Muro, however, is not surprised.

headline: SECURITY COUNCIL TO DEBATE THE GOLAN ANNEXATION
abstract: The Security Council is scheduled to begin debate on Wednesday of a Syrian draft resolution calling Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights illegal but not condemning the Israelis for their action.   United States officials here have not disclosed the Reagan Administration's response, but Arab diplomats said the document was drafted to win Washington's support. The 14 other Council members, diplomats said, appear virtually certain to approve the text.   The Syrian document neither deplores the Israeli action nor condemns Israel, a standard feature of similar resolutions in the past, and is milder than the statements that the Reagan Administration has already made.

headline: REPORT ON ROME ENVOY DISPUTED BY U.S. AIDES BUT ALSO CONFIRMED
abstract: American officials in Washington and Rome today disputed a report in the Sunday issue of The New York Times that the American Ambassador to Rome had been hastily evacuated from Italy to protect him from an assassination plot by Libya.   But a Government source in a position to have intimate knowledge of the events asserted today that The Times's article was true.  The article, however, incorrectly stated that the Ambassador, Maxwell M. Rabb, was flown to Washington last Wednesday, Oct. 21.  Actually, he was evacuated on the previous Wednesday, Oct. 14, and arrived late that night in Washington after a stopover in New York, according to the source.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: Behind President Reagan's stern denunciation of Poland's military crackdown today is an effort to use the leverage of future American economic aid to get the Polish Government to end coercive measures and resume political negotiations with the Solidarity union leadership.   After a series of cautious and restrained American statements, the President intended his sharp news-conference declaration to provide psychological support for the Polish people without either encouraging violent resistance against the Polish Government or provoking the Soviet Union to intervene with force.   To the leadership, Mr. Reagan showed both stick and carrot. It would be impossible, he asserted, for Washington to respond to Warsaw's continuing pleas for food, credit and other economic assistance during a period of martial law when ''thousands are imprisoned and the legal rights of free trade unions, previously granted by the Government, are now denied.''

headline: VERMONT RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PRICES AND MONEY, BY THE WINNER OF THE NOBEL
abstract: James Tobin, Sterling Professor of Economics at Yale University, won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science last week. Professor Tobin, who was a member of President John F. Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers, won the prize for his scholarly analysis of financial markets. Among his latest writings is a section on inflation for a new ''Encyclopedia of Economics,'' to be published next month by McGraw-Hill. Here is an excerpt: Measurement of Inflation   T O measure inflation over a month or a year or decade, it is necessary to average the diverse changes in thousands and thousands of specific prices. This is not easy, and it is bound to be arbitrary. If prices all moved together in proportion, there would be no ambiguity about the direction and amount of change in the price level. But they do not; relative prices are always changing. In practice statisticians, usually in government agencies, calculate price indexes. In three indexes commodities are weighted by their importance in comsumer budgets, or in the gross national product (G.N.P.), or in other aggregates. Indexes with weights differing in concept or in base data give different results.

headline: POLAND TO REDUCE THE MEAT RATION FOR MOST CITIZENS
abstract: The Warsaw radio announced today that meat rations for all Poles except manual workers would be reduced next month.   As the third week of martial law began for Poland, officials said that the country faced a serious shortage of meat supplies and that large quantities of imports from the Soviet Union and other countries in the Communist bloc would be needed to maintain the ration for miners and other manual workers at the December level.   The shortage of meat and other commodities was one of the causes of the birth of the Solidarity free trade union, which has led protests against the Government, in the summer of 1980. Productivity Said to Improve   The announcement of a further reduction in meat rations was in contrast to official reports of a gradual return to work and improved productivity despite continuing resistance by 1,111 coal miners in the Piast mine in Silesia.

headline: Brazil Plans Better Wells
abstract: Brazil will close five oil-producing wells offshore next year for eight months to make equipment improvements, the state-owned oil company, Petrobras, announced today.

headline: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TELEGRAPH MEASURE ADVANCES IN HOUSE
abstract: A House panel passed a bill today to increase international and domestic competition in telegraph services, virtually assuring Congressional approval of some changes in the industry.   The bill was cleared 16 to 0 by the subcommittee on telecommunications. A companion bill, more limited in scope, was approved by the full Senate in June.

headline: Economic Scene; Signs of Slump Remold Policy
abstract: GROWING evidence that the United States economy is slipping into recession has called forth a striking change in the Reagan Administration's monetary and fiscal policies. The most recent indication came from Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, who made known his conviction that the Federal Reserve Board ought to start loosening up the money supply if the nation is to grow and create more jobs next year.   The gross national product has declined in this year's second and third quarters and is showing no sign of an upturn. If the Administration is to come anywhere close to its forecast of a 5.2 percent increase in real G.N.P. next year, Secretary Regan thinks monetary policy will have to be eased now.

headline: THE CLOUD OVER LAKER AIR
abstract: Atlantic flights. He is promoting his new ''Regency'' firstclass air fare for business travel, which costs a whopping $526 oneway, $322 more than the standby tourist fare that made his name a household word.   Is this the same Freddie Laker, champion of backpackers, pensioners and the ''forgotten traveler,'' the same man whose name is synonymous with cheap, no-frills trans-Atlantic fare?   Yes. And then again, no.  Sir Freddie still sees himself in battle against the big guys, among whom he now includes his bankers as well as his more familiar opponents, the major airlines. But in addition to battling the airlines in his traditional preserve, the low-cost economy fare, he has gone into the high-priced end of the market, which he has shunned until now, in an effort to lift sagging profits.

headline: Other Business; DETROIT: 26 WAYS TO NAME A CAR
abstract: What will they do when they run out of letters? General Motors had the ''X'' cars and the ''J'' cars. Chrysler claimed the ''K.'' Early next year, G.M. plans to start selling its new ''A'' cars and sporty ''F'' models.   In this case, the company won't call them by those names, although the automotive press might. The ''A'' cars are a series of frontwheel-drive intermediate-size models that will be marketed, in slightly different forms, by four of the corporation's five automobile divisions. To the public they will be the Chevrolet Celebrity, Pontiac 6000, Oldsmobile Ciera and Buick Century.

headline: Advertising; RCA's Videodisk Campaign
abstract: THE RCA Corporation yesterday began the first independent advertising for its videodisks, a $1 million, six-week investment on five radio networks that will promote them as ideal Christmas gifts.   ''Entertainment movie posters for your ears,'' is what Dancer Fitzgerald Sample is calling the advertising.  Each of the eight national spots contains the names of six different available movies or other special features. They augment the advertising for the videodisks that has been included in all of the advertising for the Selectavision videodisk player that started running last March as part of a $20 million spring and fall media advertising campaign.

headline: Continental To Sell Unit
abstract: The Continental Group, a diversified international concern with interests in packaging, forest products, insurance and energy, said it had agreed to sell its Teepak Inc. meat casings subsidiary for about $110 million in cash to Hillside Capital Inc.   Continental, based in Stamford, Conn., said the divestiture was part of a program to redeploy between $400 million and $500 million in assets in the next three years.

headline: Japan's Video Exports
abstract: The Japan Electronic Industries Association said today that Japan's export of videotape recorders soared 101.1 percent in November from a year ago because of brisk shipments to the United States and European countries.
