headline: DOME REPORTS POTENTIALLY BIG FIND
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said tonight that initial evaluations of drilling in the Beaufort Sea ''give positive confirmation of major oil potential on Dome interest lands.''   In an announcement eagerly awaited by investors, Dome, of Calgary, Alberta, said that its Koakoak and Kopanoar wells had potential oil deposits of as much as 9.5 billion barrels, of which 15 to 40 percent was believed to be recoverable.   Dome said that an independent analysis by DeGolyer and MacNaughton, of Dallas, found that the two major structures in the Beaufort, 70 miles offshore of the delta of the Mackenzie River, ''have the potential to be hydrocarbon accumulations with oil in place between 1.8 billion and 4.5 billion barrels in the Kopanoar structure and 2 billion to 5 billion barrels in the Koakoak structure,'' of which between 15 and 40 percent are recoverable.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM STATEMENT OF FORMER POLISH ENVOY
abstract: Following are excerpts from a statement given today by Zdzislaw Rurarz, the former Polish Ambassador to Japan, to the United States Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe:   Poland is now on the lips of all.  In a country with long tradition of tolerance and compromise, basic human rights are being violated on an unprecedented scale and with excessive brutality.   I do not say that this is something new in Poland and born only on that fatal Dec. 13.  Poland has been constantly living under horror for more than 42 years. That terror cost it millions of lives. Having fallen the victim of big politics during World War II, Poland had to adopt the alien system based on terror as the surest means of its existence.  Many of us, having had no other choice, thought that we could turn somehow our prison into something livable and eventually even into something which by the logic of evolution may make one day the bars disappear.

headline: MONEY SUPPLY OFF
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday as a steep decline in the nation's money supply and an increase in the unemployment rate to 8 percent in October provided more evidence of the economy's slide into a recession.   The Federal Reserve Board's late-afternoon announcement of a larger-than-expected $3.3 billion decline in a key measure of the money supply for the week ended Oct. 28 was quickly followed by a move to lower interest rates, extending the steep declines that had occurred earlier in the day.   After the money supply announcement, six-month Treasury bills were bid at a rate of 11.90 percent, down from 12.57 percent Thursday and 12.72 percent at Monday's auction. The rate on overnight loans that banks make to each other in the Federal funds market also dropped to about 13.75 percent yesterday, well below the 14.79 percent average for the week ended Nov. 3.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Pan Am Realigns Top Management
abstract: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it had realigned its top management in order to conform with its present structure as an airline, rather than a holding company.   C. Edward Acker, the chairman and chief executive of Pan Am, said in a statement that since the sale of its Intercontinental Hotels division in early September, there was no longer a need for Pan Am to have a holding company structure.

headline: SAMBO'S HAS CLOSED 447 RESTAURANTS
abstract: Sambo's Restaurants Inc. has closed 447 restaurants, resulting in layoffs of up to 10,000 employees, an official said today.   Arthur Dowd, a Sambo's vice president, said that the closings had nothing to do with a decision Wednesday to give ''serious consideration'' to declaring bankruptcy if Sambo's lenders refused to restructure the company's debt; the decision to close the restaurants was made well before that announcement, he said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Air Florida Systems Inc. said it had increased its share in Western Airlines to 12.6 percent of the common stock outstanding.   * Amdahl Corp. said it had signed a $370 million multicurrency credit agreement with 12 international banks, including the Bank of America as agent.   * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it would seek a listing for its common shares on the London Stock Exchange effective January 1982.

headline: Magazine Research Panel Is Proposed
abstract: The media policy committee of the American Association of Advertising Agencies is calling for the establishment of a magazine research committee.   It would, according to Joseph Ostrow, executive vice president of Young & Rubicam and chairman of the media policy committee, advise and counsel - not replace - the commercially syndicated audience-research companies ''so they don't go down paths the industry won't accept.''   The media policy committee, which urged that the research council be composed of agency, advertising and media representatives, said it would be willing to work with the Association of National Advertisers and the Magazine Publishers Association.

headline: RATING ON G.M.'S BONDS IS CUT TO AA BY MOODY'S
abstract: The credit rating of the General Motors Corporation, long the symbol of America's industrial strength, was lowered yesterday by Moody's Investors Service.   Moody's said the action - which downgraded G.M.'s bonds to Aa, the second-highest level, from Aaa - was taken in view of G.M.'s longterm outlook, and not on the basis of recent losses.   ''We focused on the change in the competitive advantage of American automobile companies versus foreign auto makers, mainly in Japan,'' said Thomas J. McGuire, executive vice president in charge of Moody's corporate department. Higher Operating Costs   United States automobile manufacturers operate at a significantly higher cost differential than the Japanese, ''and we don't see that being reduced in the short term,'' Mr. McGuire said.

headline: Canada's Imperial Oil Selects a Chairman
abstract: Donald K. McIvor, 53, deputy chairman of Imperial Oil Ltd. of Canada, will become chairman and chief executive officer on Jan.1, succeeding John A. Armstrong, 64, who will retire. Mr. McIvor, a geologist who joined Imperial in 1950, assumes the top post at a time when the company, Canada's largest integrated oil concern, is facing serious pressures because of its 70 percent ownership by the Exxon Corporation.   Canada's National Energy Program, announced 13 months ago, favors Canadian-controlled companies by granting them exploration incentives in ''frontier'' areas on a sliding scale according to their degree of domestic ownership. These incentives are denied to foreignowned concerns, but Imperial has some degree of protection because about 48 percent of its earnings are from nonpetroleum sources.

headline: I.B.M. REPORTED TO PLAN MAJOR SHIFTS
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer c ompany, is reported to be o n the verge of a major reorganization, spurred in part by heated com petition and internal conflicts within its sales groups.   Executives of the company, which has its headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., were said by analysts and sources within I.B.M.'s globespanning organization to be explaining the shifts at meetings with division vice presidents yesterday.   The changes apparently include scrapping its traditional divisionbased sales approach, in which separate sales representatives from the data processing, general systems and office products units might all call on the same customer. Instead, I.B.M. customers will be able to order a full range of I.B.M. products, ranging from its large mainframe computers, to small desktop business computers from the same sales personnel.

headline: PEKING PAPER FOR OUTSIDERS FINDS A NICHE
abstract: Anyone who wants his National Hockey League scores along with news of the Xinjiang cotton harvest, the latest results of basketball tournaments in New York and light industry in Shanghai, tips on bridge-playing and bridge-building need look no further than a newspaper called China Daily.   As China's first English-language newspaper since the Nationalists shut down their presses and fled to Taiwan in 1949, China Daily has become a success six months after it started formal publication, with a circulation up from an initally cautious 20,000 copies to 50,000 today.   It was devised for foreigners, but two-thirds of its readership is Chinese -often ranking bureaucrats - who brush up on their English while enjoying a less restricted view of the world than is normally found in the Chinese press.   ''Our newspaper is mainly geared to foreign readers,'' said Guan Zaihan, who serves on the China Daily editorial board. ''That's why we serve so much foreign news. But we also want to tell our foreign friends about China.''

abstract: The Braniff International Corporation, holding company for Braniff Airways Inc., yesterday reported a loss of $20.3 million for the third quarter, contrasted with net income of $17 million, or 85 cents a share, in the third quarter of last year.   Revenues for the third quarter dropped to $306.6 million, a decline of 19.5 percent from revenues of $381 million for the similar quarter the year before.

headline: 20 People Are Seized in Sicily On Drug-Smuggling Charges
abstract: Authorities charged 20 people today with involvement in international drug smuggling, including the shipping of cocaine and heroin to the United States hidden inside household furniture.   The 20 suspects were accused of being members of a criminal organization involved in drug smuggling. Among those charged was a lawyer who is the son of a suspected Mafia leader who was shot to death in Palermo last spring.

headline: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $900 MILLION
abstract: After three consecutive weeks of monetary growth totaling $6 billion, the basic money supply fell $900 million in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday.   The Fed's latest report was issued against a backdrop of deteriorating economic statistics and forecasts of further declines in interest rates.   ''The key here is that the recession continues to deepen and that, in turn, provides the Fed with the justification to ease further on its monetary policy,'' said Philip Braverman, a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

headline: News Analysis
abstract: West Africa, Oct. 30 - Although it remains easy to come up with reasons for pessimism about a settlement in South-West Africa, the excruciatingly slow and wayward diplomatic effort to bring this vast territory to independence looked less moribund this week than at any other time in the last two and a half years. It was even possible to speak of a climate of faint hope. The Western diplomatic mission left Windhoek this afternoon in its American Air Force jet without a definite response from South Africa or the political parties here to the constitutional guidelines it presented this week. But it seemed unlikely that any of the key parties to the dispute over South Africa's continued occupation of a territory it once held on a League of Nations mandate is prepared to see negotiations break down over constitutional questions.   ''People realize that this is the only game in town,'' said a senior American diplomat in the five-nation mission. His point seemed to be that rejection of the constitutional principles would mean scuttling the chance for a negotiated settlement - or in the case of the smaller political parties, of being left out if it does move ahead.

headline: BONN LEGISLATORS ASSAIL SOVIET
abstract: Some 50 leftist legislators in West Germany's ruling Social Democratic Party have written to Leonid I.  Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, criticizing Moscow's military policies.   The legislators, many of them critical of Western rearmament plans, expressed concern over the size of Soviet conventional forces and Moscow's deployment of SS-20 medium-range nuclear missiles.

headline: RELIABILITY OF POLISH ARMED FORCES A CRUCIAL ISSUE
abstract: The effectiveness of army rule in Poland will depend on the reliability of conscripted soldiers and noncommissioned and junior officers. The expectation is that the military regime will rely on the internal security forces for initial action against strikers or rioters.   This view is virtually unanimous among United States and NATO analysts, who add that there is no question of the loyalty of senior officers to the military regime established by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader. The analysts said most of these officers had close ties with the Soviet military establishment and had received their higher military education at Soviet Hint at Possible Resistance   The decree on army rule seems to hint that its drafters took into account the possibility of resistance within the army to moving against civilians.

headline: GREEK PARTY SWINGS TO RIGHT
abstract: Evangelos Averoff, a former Defense Minister, was elected leader tonight of the conservative New Democracy Party.  The development will probably result in the opposition party's adopting a more right-wing stance than it had taken under former Prime Minister George Rallis, who was ousted from the leadership on Monday.

abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Vornado Store Closings Seen
abstract: Vornado Inc., the operator of the Two Guys discount store chain, plans to close a ''substantial number'' of its stores in New Jersey and Connecticut in the near future, according to reliable trade sources.   But a company spokesman said that he knew of no reason why Vornado's common was among the big percentage gainers on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing up 2, to 12 7/8, with 56,200 shares traded.

headline: Mobil-Marathon Hearing Nov.17
abstract: A Federal judge has set Nov.17 as the date for a hearing on the preliminary injunction in the Marathon Oil Company's antitrust complaint against the Mobil Corporation's attempt to buy a controlling $3.4 billion interest.   Mobil was barred from pursuing its offer to Marathon shareholders by United States District Judge Frank J. Battisti in a temporary restraining order issued Sunday night.

headline: Nickel Output Is Reduced
abstract: A French mineral producer, Ste.  Metallurgique le Nickel, said today that it was shutting two of its nickel smelting units in New Caledonia.

headline: FOES OF PENN CENTRAL-COLT MERGER LEADING IN VOTE
abstract: With nearly 400,000 votes still to be tallied, stockholders of the Penn Central Corporation apparently have narrowly rejected a proposal to acquire Colt Industries, Penn Central announced yesterday.   The company cautioned that the results should ''in no way be considered final'' because the unresolved votes could change the outcome. The vote is being counted by CT Corporation System, a corporate service concern, in Wilmington, Del.

headline: Loan for Libya
abstract: The Libyan Government's new Libyan Arab Foreign Investment Company is raising $200 million through a sevenyear international loan, banking sources said here today. Most of the underwriting banks are Arab. The interest rate will be one-half percentage point above the London interbank rate.

headline: AMERICAN MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: zf PLAYBOY IN LONDON LOSES CASINO FIGHT
abstract: A court ruling today lifted the gambling licenses of Playboy's two most profitable London casinos, charging that they had engaged in gambling improprieties.   The Playboy Club in Park Lane and The Clermont Club in Berkeley Square were affected by the ruling. Along with the Victoria Sporting Club of London, they constitute the major profit center of Playboy Enterprises Inc., accounting for 85 percent of the Chicago-based company's pretax earnings in the latest fiscal year.   The licenses of the Victoria casino, which is also a major income source, as well as of two other Playboy casinos outside of London that break even, are also being reviewed.

headline: Business Conditions; CURRENCY DEMAND DIPS
abstract: Since the beginning of the year, according to Federal Reserve statistics, growth of currency in circulation, the major component of the monetary base, has slowed considerably.   In the third quarter it rose only 6.4 percent from a year earlier, the slowest rate of increase since 1972.

headline: AMERICAN PACEMAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: G.M. Plant Started
abstract: Construction workers began pouring concrete at the site of the General Motors Corporation's new $500 million assembly plant astride the Detroit-Hamtramck border. The plant, which will assemble front-wheel-drive luxury cars such as Cadillac's Eldorado and Seville models, is scheduled to be completed by early 1984.

headline: QUICK WITHDRAWAL FROM CHAD VOWED
abstract: The commander of Libya's troops in Chad said tonight that all his forces would leave the central African country within seven days.   This statement by Col. Radwan Salah was broadcast on French television as the evacuation, which he said was suddenly ordered yesterday by the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, reportedly went into its second day. But the Libyan Government remained silent about its troops in Chad, estimated to number from 8,000 to 9,000, and about its intentions.   Nevertheless, there was agreement at the annual two-day French-African conference that closed here today that a force drawn from several African countries should be rushed to Chad to replace the Libyans. Participants in the conference, in which 21 African heads of state or government met with President Francois Mitterrand, adopted a resolution asking international assistance in forming such a force, which was agreed upon by the Organization of African Unity some months ago.

headline: Angolan Aide Demoted Over Raid on Refinery
abstract: Angola's Minister of State Security, Kundi Paiama, was demoted this weekend, and Western diplomats said the move was apparently because of the security lapse that led to the Nov. 30 attack on the country's only oil refinery.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * Associates Corp. of North America amended its pending offer of $100 million of senior notes. The issue is now set to mature on Feb.  1, 1990.

headline: Personal Finance; SHOULD A PENSION BE A TAKEOVER TOOL?
abstract: H OW safe are the assets in your pension fund?  The decision of the Grumman Corporation pension plan trustees to use the plan's holdings of Grumman stock to foil a takeover attempt by the LTV Corporation raises fundamental questions about the fiduciary responsibilities of pension fund managers and how much control companies can exert over the funds they contribute to the plans.   Should the managers' sole concern be short-term return on investment? Or can they make what may appear to be more unorthodox investments if they adopt a longer-term view? To take the case of Grumman, is it wise to make investments that benefit the company sponsoring the pension plan?   The last question resembles those raised when New York City was wrestling with near bankruptcy a few years ago and the city's five big pension plans purchased Big Mac bonds. Critics said that an impartial party, not concerned with the city's welfare, probably would not have made those investments. With corporate takeovers and mergers on the rise, it is likely that more companies will view pension plans as a tool to finance or fend off a takeover.

headline: MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Car Dealerships Show a Decline
abstract: The number of United States auto dealerships handling domestic makes fell to 21,187 during the 1981 model year, down 758 from 21,945 at the end of the previous year, according to an industry journal.   Automotive News said yesterday that the dealership decline for the year, which ended Sept. 30, was less than half the 1,643 dealership closings reported during the 1980 model year but otherwise was the worst since a decline of 793 dealerships in 1970.

headline: U.S. EXPORTS TO POLAND EXCEED IMPORTS
abstract: The United States sells far more goods to Poland than it buys from that Communist-bloc nation, according to Commerce Department figures, although the totals being shipped in either direction are relatively small.   Farm products account for most of Poland's purchases from this country, although American machinery, transportation equipment and chemicals are still being sold in relatively small amounts.   Jerzy Strebski, commercial attache at the Polish Embassy in Washington, said in a telephone interview yesterday that in addition to trade ties with this country, Poland also operates fishing vessels in American territorial waters, a Government airline between New York and Warsaw and a cargo service between Polish and American ports.

headline: ACME ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Data Access Consent Pact
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Data Access Systems, a New Jersey computer-systems company, with improper accounting procedures and violations of Federal securities law.   Data Access signed a consent decree at the same time the charges were filed in a New Jersey Federal court.

headline: SHE PROGRAMS A SUCCESS STORY
abstract: When Sandra L. Kurtzig and her husband decided it was time to start a family, Mrs. Kurtzig quit her job at General Electric and began writing computer programs at home as a part-time job.   Now Mrs. Kurtzig is the mother of two boys, 8 and 5. She is also the founder, president and 60 percent shareholder of ASK Computer Systems, a fast-growing computer software company that went public less than two weeks ago.   From its quiet start in the Kurtzigs' apartment in 1972, ASK has grown to a company that employs about 120 persons and now occupies a four-building office complex in Los Altos, Calif., south of San Francisco. The company earned $1.5 million on sales of $13 million in the year ended June 30, a 50 percent increase over the previous year.

headline: ROCHESTER GAS & ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Factory Utilization Off 1.5% in October
abstract: The utilization of the nation's factories slipped 1.5 percent in October, to 76.9 percent of capacity, the lowest level since August 1980 at the end of last year's recession, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   It was the latest statistical indication that the national economy has entered a new recession. The drop from September's factory utilization rate had been expected in light of a 1.5 percent October decline in industrial production, reported last Friday.

headline: Leftist Elected Leader Of British Coal Miners
abstract: Arthur Scargill, a left-wing militant, was overwhelmingly elected leader of Britain's 240,000 coal miners, it was announced today. He hinted at a showdown with the Government over pay.

headline: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Publications Group Names New President
abstract: American Business Press Inc., the association of specialized business publications, has named Thomas H. King president.  Mr. King, 48 years old, a group vice president at McGraw-Hill Publications, is succeeding Charles S. Mill, who retired from the post earlier this month. He will be taking over the salaried post on Nov. 2.

headline: GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Traveling Woes
abstract: To the Business Editor: ''The Traveling Life, and the Toll It Takes'' (Nov. 29), indicated the impact of travel on men. Dr. Mel S. Goldsmith, for example, noted that the traveling husband loses his status as head of the household. My discussions with traveling women indicate an opposite problem.

headline: CLARKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: King Hussein Forsees A Key Role for Egypt
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan said today that Egypt had an important part to play in Arab affairs but that it was too early to say when that nation might be able ''to resume its place in the Arab family.''   Speaking on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' the King, who has been on an official visit to the United States, said he ''was not very happy'' to see Egypt in continued isolation.

headline: Shell Group's Earnings Up 8.4% in Period
abstract: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that its net income rose 8.4 percent in the third quarter, mainly because of improved earnings by the Shell Oil Company, its American affiliate.   Net income for the three months, ended Sept. 30, rose to the equivalent of $763 million on revenues of $22.9 billion, converting the pound at its current exchange rate, from earnings of $704 million on revenues of $17.5 billion in the similar 1980 period.

headline: Stocks Advance, Even as Dow Slips 0.86
abstract: The stock market overall moved slightly higher yesterday amid profit-taking pressures after last week's strong recovery. Takeover situations once again produced large price swings. Railroad stocks were strong.   After climbing more than 8 points in early trading, however, the Dow Jones industrial average finished at 859.87, showing a token loss for the day of 0.86 point. Advancing for all five sessions last week, the Dow climbed more than 36 points to score its best weekly gain since February.

headline: U.S. Volkswagen Sets Diesel Rebate
abstract: In an attempt to sell its leftover 1981 Rabbit diesel cars and pickup trucks, Volkswagen of America Inc. said that it would offer rebate checks to customers through Dec.31.

headline: NEWCOURT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: EX-PREMIER KEEPS ALL SPAIN GUESSING
abstract: Rarely has a politician who has supposedly left politics attracted such attention as Adolfo Suarez.  He has lost a battle for control of the party he founded five years ago; his handpicked successor as Prime Minister, Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo, has won. Adolfo Suarez should be a political has-been.

headline: Business People; Diamond's Stores Chief May Go to Ward's Unit
abstract: Arthur F. Baumann, the 43-year old chairman and chief executive of Diamond's department stores of Phoenix and Las Vegas, is expected shortly to be named president and chief operating officer of the Jefferson Ward discount store division of Montgomery Ward, based in Miami.   The reports of Mr. Baumann's imminent appointment after two and a half years in his post at Diamond's come from retail trade sources who say that the Arizona retailer will soon join an expanding new executive team at Montgomery Ward.

headline: 5.61 RISE PUTS DOW AT 856.26
abstract: The stock market, battered this week by investor concern over lower third-quarter earnings reported by a number of large corporations, registered a modest advance yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 5.61 points, to 856.26.   In the four previous sessions, the blue-chip barometer tumbled about 28 points, including a loss of 14.93 points on Wednesday.  Concern over interest rates, analysts said, was a factor in the sharp decline.

headline: LEAVE EXTENDED FOR KEKKONEN
abstract: The medical leave of Finland's President, 81-year-old Urho Kekkonen, has been extended for a second month, and reports from Helsinki say one of the reasons is to give more time for political parties to prepare for special elections to replace him.   Another reason is said to be the hope that he will recover sufficiently before his leave is scheduled to end on Nov. 10 to announce his own resignation.

headline: MILWAUKEE WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: MEDFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SAB HARMON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Capital Cities Communications Inc. said it had completed its acquisition of the Atlanta-area radio station WBIE from the privately held Marietta Broadcasting Co. for about $7.5 million.   * W.R. Grace & Co. said that its subsidiary, TRG Drilling Corp. of Oklahoma City, would spend more than $120 million in 1982 to acquire 15 new drilling rigs and upgrade existing equipment.

headline: Pacific Holding's Dan River Stake
abstract: The Pacific Holding Corporation, which is controlled by David H.  Murdock, a Los Angeles financier, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired a 5.76 percent interest in Dan River Inc., a major textile and apparel manufacturer.   Pacific Holding disclosed that it had purchased 327,400 Dan River common shares for $5.3 million for investment purposes. Mr. Murdock said that he intended to seek ''a role of constructive participation with existing management.''   Pacific Holding has interests in a number of major corporations.  Mr. Murdock, a close friend of Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, is a major shareholder in both Occidental and the Zapata Corporation, which was the target of a recent takeover attempt by Occidental.

headline: Washington Watch; Oil Import Fee Stirring Again
abstract: WASHINGTON QUIETLY simmering as a possible way to raise copious revenues is a rehash of the oil import fees concocted in both the Ford and Carter Administrations but never actually served up. Up to $10 billion a year could flow into the Treasury, giving the President a big boost toward his goal of a balanced budget by 1984.   Mr. Reagan's decision to go for some ''revenue enhancement,'' as well as additional budget cuts, has drawn the attention of the White House and Congress to the idea. That world oil prices are now falling has increased its attractiveness.

headline: STOCKS UP A BIT IN CALMER DAY
abstract: Following a dramatic two-day rally, stock prices edged higher yesterday as relative calm settled over Wall Street in the final session of the third quarter. Some analysts expressed the belief that prices probably would move higher in October before entering a period of testing recent lows.   Volume contracted to 40.7 million shares, from Tuesday's 49.8 million, and issues that advanced in price sl ightly outnumbered those that declined.

headline: Around the World; Diplomats in Zimbabwe Report Restrictions
abstract: Zimbabwe has ordered restrictions on the movement of diplomats and the size of the 60 embassies and consulates here, diplomats said today.

headline: Soviet Bank Financing
abstract: The Soviet Union relied heavily on its foreign bank deposits for its financing needs in the first half of this year, the Bank for International Settlements said today.   In its quarterly review of international banking, it said that estimated Soviet deposits at the banks had declined to the equivalent of $3.6 billion at the end of June, from $5.5 billion at the end of March and $8.6 billion at the end of 1980.   In its previous report covering the first quarter, the bank, which acts as a clearing agency for major central banks, suggested the withdrawals were linked to Soviet aid for Poland, but it offered no explanation for the renewed fall.

headline: SALAVADOR REBELS SEE OPENING TO U.S.
abstract: Two leaders of the Salvadoran guerrillas' political organization have had their first meeting with Administration officials here and said afterward that a channel of communication between the rebels and the Reagan State Department had finally been opened.   ''We were at little bit surprised that a meeting took place at all,'' Ruben Zamora, a member of the political and diplomatic commisssion of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, said in an interview. ''The meeting was cordial. They listened and we listened.''

headline: BETHLEHEM POSTS GAIN IN QUARTER
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel producer, yesterday reported a profit of $76.3 million, or $1.75 a share, in the third quarter, in contrast to a loss of $32.3 million during the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose 25 percent, to $1.85 billion from $1.48 billion.

headline: NEW HOME BUILDING DOWN 1.7%
abstract: New housing construction fell 1.7 percent in September, to an annual rate of 918,000 units, the thirdlowest level on record, the Government reported today.   The drop was attributed to high interest rates and was seen by housing industry economists as an indication that the nation might be in for more than the ''slight recession'' that President Reagan said yesterday had already started.   Building permits, which indicate future construction trends, also fell in September compared with August, according to the Commerce Department.

headline: RATES DROP SHARPLY ON FED MOVE
abstract: A surprising move by the Federal Reserve adding credit to the banking system led to a steep drop in interest rates yesterday, but by late in the day rates climbed above their lowest levels as some analysts began to doubt the significance of the Fed's action.   Despite the late-afternoon increases, short- and long-term interest rates ended the day significantly lower. The three-month Treasury bill, for example, closed at 10.02 percent, down from 10.59 percent a day earlier. In volatile trading, the three-month issue traded briefly at 9.75 percent, the first time it has dropped below 10 percent since early September 1980.

headline: Boston Exchange Selects First Chief
abstract: Following the pattern established by the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and other regional stock exchanges, the Boston Stock Exchange has created a full-time salaried position of chairman and chief executive officer. And the first person to occupy it, beginning on Oct. 26, will be Charles J. Mohr, 34 years old, who is now a vice president of the Big Board.

headline: GOLAN AREA LONG DISPUTED
abstract: The Golan Heights, 444 square miles of rocky land rising to 7,000 feet in the foothills of Mount Hermon at the southwest corner of Syria, has been a political bone of contention since Israel occupied the area in the 1967 war.   Overlooking the upper Jordan valley, the Golan Heights has been valued by Israelis as the linchpin of their security against Syria and its Arab allies. To Syria, the occupation has been a constant reminder of its defeat in 1967.

headline: House of Commons Suspends 3 Ulster M.P.'s
abstract: Three Protestant Members of Parliament from Northern Ireland were suspended indefinitely today after they shouted abuse during a Government statement in the House of Commons on the continuing guerrilla violence in their province.   The three, among them the Rev. Ian Paisley, head of the Ulster Democratic Unionist Party, denounced pleas for calm and said they would set up vigilante-style groups unless the British Government cracked down on the outlawed, predominantly Roman Catholic Provisional I.R.A., which for 12 years has waged a campaign to drive the British out and unite the province with the mainly Catholic Irish Republic.   In Belfast, the I.R.A.'s publicity bureau issued a statement on the killing last week of the Rev. Robert Bradford, a Protestant Member of Parliament, saying that people who whipped up anti-I.R.A.  sentiment ''cannot expect to remain immune forever.''

headline: LIBBY SAYS IT WILL SELL ITS CANNING OPERATIONS
abstract: Libby, McNeill & Libby Inc., the Chicago-based producer of canned foods, said today that it had reached an agreement to sell its United States fruit and vegetable canning operations to two agribusiness concerns, California Canners and Growers of San Francisco and S.S. Pierce of Dundee, N.Y.   For Libby, a wholly owned subsidiary of Swiss-based Nestle and the second-largest fruit-and-vegetable canner after the Del Monte Corporation, a division of R.J. Reynolds Industries, the sale represents a new corporate strategy to get out of businesses that depend on commodities and seasonal flucuations.   ''Our fruit and vegetable operations weren't unprofitable, but we felt that they could grow more in the hands of another company,'' said Vivian Manuel, a Libby company spokesman.   Although no dollar figures were announced, it is believed that the deal involved millions of dollars, and would leave Libby with its fruit juices and specialty foods units that it operates under its Crosse & Blackwell and Maggi, Florida Citrus Groves Corporation and Dunkley Company subsidiaries. The company also said it was planning new acquisitions and product lines, but refused to elaborate.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Barnwell Industries has elected to its board Daniel Jacobson, president of Page Mill Group Ltd.   * CBS Video Enterprises has appointed Myron A. Hyman an executive vice president.   * Chemical Business Credit Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chemical New York Corp., has named Thomas F. Michels executive vice president; Ronald P. Schwartz and John R. Feldman senior vice presidents.

headline: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Around the World; Protesters in Poland Swell to 400,000
abstract: Brief strikes took place today in the Baltic port of Szczecin and a number of universities, swelling the ranks of protesters to about 400,000 across Poland.   In Budapest, the Warsaw Pact's military council opened a ''regular session'' attended by defense ministers or their assistants from the seven East Bloc member nations, the Hungarian press agency said.

headline: Rationing Programs Have Not Succeeded
abstract: Most foods and many other goods have been rationed in Poland over the last year, but the system has had little success in insuring that there are sufficient or equal amounts for everyone.

headline: PERU ACTS TO STEM TRADE IN STOLEN ARTWORKS
abstract: The Peruvian Government is waging an urgent campa ign to halt a billion-dollar trade in st olen art treasures that is ravaging the country's cultural heritage.   Diplomatic efforts culminated in the signing of an agree ment with the United St ates in mid-September to facilitate the return of stolen works of art recovered by United States authorities.   At the same time, the Public Prosecutor's Office has launched an investigation into the activities of Peruvian dealers and collectors who are said to act as the agents for foreign buyers.   The export of artwork has been prohibited since 1929. But the law has failed to stop a boom in the trading of gold and silver objects, colonial-era paintings and centuries-old pottery.

headline: EDWARDS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: CASCO-NORTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Text of the draft letter, page A12.
abstract: The White House has prepared a letter saying that if Saudi Arabia should adopt ''policies which are disruptive to prospects for stability'' in the Middle East President Reagan would cancel delivery of Awacs planes.   The letter, not yet formally delivered to members of the Senate, is intended to win support for Mr. Reagan's proposal to sell Saudi Arabia $8.5 billion in air defense equipment, including five Airborne Warning and Control System planes as well as tanker aircraft, missiles and fuel tanks to increase the combat capability of 62 F-15 fighters.   A draft of the President's letter spoke of four ''arrangements'' that would be incorporated into written agreements with the Saudi Arabian Government. One provides for an agreement to maintain physical security for the Awacs planes, their manuals and other equipment and for ''periodic inspection'' of such facilities by American experts.

headline: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Steelmakers Set Cuts
abstract: Steel producers, faced with a decline in orders and the prospect of a stagnant fourth-quarter market, are temporarily furloughing workers and suspending some operations.   In the Monongahela Valley, 2,720 steelworkers are temporarily out of work. In Buffalo the Republic Steel Company said it would stop operating two steel bar mills because of a slump in demand and temporarily furlough 400 workers.

headline: Careers; Advanced Study for Engineers
abstract: CLASSES begin at 7 A.M. at least once a week for 980 working engineers who are part of the Early Bird Engineering Program at the University of Santa Clara, in California's ''Silicon Valley.'' They are slowly working part time toward master's degrees at the university.   ''We use about 150 adjunct professors to teach the courses,'' Dr.  Robert J. Parden, dean of the engineering school, said. He added that the adjuncts work as full-time senior engineers for high-technology companies in the area.

headline: Around the World; North Korea Says U.S.  Is Violating Its Airspace
abstract: North Korea said today that two United States fighter-bombers violated its airspace yesterday.

headline: ARABS TRYING TO AVERT CONFRONTATION ON SAUDI PLAN
abstract: Arab nations and the Palestinian guerrilla movement are trying to avoid an open confrontation over a plan put forward by Saudi Arabia for a Middle East settlement.   The 15-member executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization failed at a meeting here last night to adopt a definite stand on the eight-point plan presented in August by Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia.   The plan, among other things, implied recognition of Israel's right to exist as a nation in exchange for the establishment of an independent Palestinian nation in the West Bank and Gaza. These areas have been under Israeli occupation for 14 years.

headline: GREAT BASINS PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Yr to July 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Air Service to Brazil
abstract: President Reagan has approved an order by the Civil Aeronautics Board awarding Eastern, American and Capitol Airlines routes between the United States and Brazil, the board said today.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: * BarclaysAmerican Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $75 million of two-year extendable notes.   * Beneficial Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $100 million of medium-term notes, maturing from nine months to five years from the date of issuance, as selected by the purchaser, and to be sold through a Merrill Lynch group.

headline: HARD-DRIVEN ELECTRONICS FIRM
abstract: In California's Silicon Valley, many firms boast about an assortment of employee benefits such as flexible work hours, swimming pools and Friday afternoon social hours.   But Convergent Technologies, which makes desk-top work stations for the so-called office of the future, marches to a different beat - that of a military march. ''There is no question,'' says the president, Allen Michaels, who puts in six-day workweeks and expects his employees to do the same, ''this is the Marine Corps of the computer industry.''   By any measure, Convergent Technologies has had an unusually successful beginning. In two years, it has recorded $10 million in sales and has gotten at least $350 million in orders from large computer manufacturers.

headline: Ethnic Melees Reported In Caucasus Region
abstract: Soviet authorities sent extra security forces and imposed a curfew in a southern mountain city late last month after disorders among two ethnic groups, according to unofficial reports reaching Moscow. No official reports of the incident have appeared here.

headline: TYPE UNIT SELLING 51% TO AGFA
abstract: Agfa-Gevaert, the photographic products subsidiary of the Bayer chemical group of West Germany, will acquire 51 percent of the Compugraphic Corporation, the leading maker of photocomposition equipment, for about $60 million, the two companies announced yesterday.   Analysts labeled the transaction a ''distress sale,'' noting that Compugraphic had suffered a sharp two-year decline after more than a decade of rapid growth. The company's dividend of 7 cents a share was eliminated in April, its banks forced it to lower its credit line in July to $40 million from $70 million and analysts expect it to report next month that it finished the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 with a loss on sales of about $280 million.

headline: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WHEN COMPUTERS DON'T WORK
abstract: Buddy Smith, an insurance agent in Warrenville, Ill., bought a computer in 1978 to automate his record-keeping and mailings. ''By 1980,'' he said, ''it ended up in my basement, with a year and a half of absolute hell in between.''   The computer, Mr. Smith said, would not function, no matter what he tried. He took a college course on computers. Once he stayed in the office three straight days and nights working with the computer, only to be taken to the hospital suffering from exhaustion and bronchial pneumonia. Finally, he said: ''I took the computer out of here. I couldn't stand the sight of it.''   Now Mr. Smith is suing the Burroughs Corporation, the manufacturer of the $21,000 machine, contending that the company fraudulently misrepresented the capabilities of its product, a charge that Burroughs is expected to deny.

headline: EGYPT REPORTS PLOT TO KILL AIDES AT SADAT'S FUNERAL
abstract: Investigators interrogating suspects in the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat say that the plotters planned to kill senior Government officials at Mr. Sadat's funeral, according to today's issue of the semi-official newspaper Al Ahram.   Mr. Sadat was slain as he watched a military parade on Oct. 6. His funeral was held four days later at the same site and was attended by Egypt's top officials and by leaders from more than 80 nations.  Security was intense, and the funeral rite, from which ordinary Egyptians were barred, appeared to go smoothly.

headline: A VISIT TO A SALVADORAN VILLAGE AT WAR
abstract: Shredded strips of the blue and white Salvadoran flag flutter at the top of a 50-foot-high bamboo pole in front of the gutted shell of what was the village's municipal building.   In the shallow of a crater formed by a bomb that blew down the walls of the telephone company office, three pine wreaths and a red floral spray mark the graves of four soldiers.   At the end of a paved road high in the mountains, about 130 miles northeast of San Salvador, this village and strategic military outpost was held for nine days in August by Farabundo Marti guerrillas. They fled when the Government sent in reinforcements and began bombing.

headline: YOU THINK THERE'LL BE A GOLD STANDARD?
abstract: Y OU have a hunch that the Reagan Administration will return to the gold standard. You might be in a tiny minority, but as an investor, you know that big rewards, not to mention big losses, can go to those who put their money where their hunches are. So, allowing for your stout-hearted disposition and your belief that the nation will switch to gold, where should you put your money?   Above all, you bet against inflation. Under a gold-based system, the Government would agree to exchange a specified amount of gold for dollars at a fixed price. This linkage, say the proponents of a gold standard, would bring rigid discipline to the money supply by discouraging the Government from printing ever more dollars to pay ever-rising debts. In time, inflation and interest rates would plunge and then stabilize.   Whether gold enthusiasts will eventually prevail depends largely on the President, who can start the process by reopening the ''gold window'' for foreign central banks through an executive order.  (Congress, however, would have to enact legislation to return the country to the gold standard.) Mr. Reagan, who as a candidate urged reinstitution of the gold standard but who has been less vocal on the issue since, appointed a commission in August to study some way of linking gold to the dollar. He has indicated that he would wait for its findings - due by March 1982 - before taking any action.

headline: Conference Board Head Is Selected
abstract: At the Conference Board, the international nonprofit research organization that is financed by business, James T. Mills, a 58-yearold lawyer and businessman, has been elected to the full-time salaried position of president and chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Kenneth A. Randall, 54, who has resigned.   A spokesman for the board, Joseph L. Naar, said that ''when Mr.  Randall came in, he had an informal arrangement with the trustees that this would be for a five-year period,'' and added, ''He has been here five years.''

headline: QUAKER OATS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN NAMES STANS TO OPIC BOARD
abstract: President Reagan today announced the nomination of Maurice H. Stans, a former Nixon Administration official who was convicted of election campaign violations during the Watergate years, to be a director of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation.   Mr. Stans, who was Secretary of Commerce during Mr. Nixon's first term, is believed to be the first person with a criminal record from the Watergate scandal to be named to a Federal post. His nomination must be confirmed by the Senate. Mr. Stans, 73 years old, is now a private consultant in Los Angeles.

headline: USLIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Credit Accord Signed by AM
abstract: Financially troubled AM International Inc., a maker of engineering graphics and information processing systems, said it had signed an amended $109 million revolving credit agreement with 20 banks and has resolved its non compliance with certain covenants of the earlier agreement.   The news helped send the company's stock up 3/4 point, to 4 1/4, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: WEST COAST
abstract: The West is faring well comparatively, according to economists.  They point out that California, for instance, accounts for a quarter of the nation's job increase, though it represents only 10 to 11 percent of the nation's total wage and salary employment.   ''The West may well profit from the Reagan Administration years,'' says Werner Schink, manager of the Economic Analysis Group of the California Department of Employment Development. ''California traditionally has received 28 percent of the defense budget, so given the increase in defense spending, the impact in California should be positive.''

headline: CONRAIL HAS SECOND GAIN IN NET
abstract: The Consolidated Rail Corporation yesterday reported a thirdquarter profit of $64.9 million, or $2.56 a share, only the second quarter of profitability since Conrail was formed in 1976 by combining six bankrupt railroads.   The profitable third quarter contrasted with a loss of $88.1 million in the third quarter last year. The profit, largely achieved by cost-cutting, also came without any Federal funding -the first period that Conrail has not used Federal funds since the third quarter of 1976.

headline: 2 Die in Pretoria Jet Crash
abstract: A Lear executive jet crashed and burst into flames last night at South Africa's Waterkloof Air Force base outside Pretoria, killing the aircraft's two crewmen, the South African radio reported today. It identified the crewmen as James Burre, a Lear representative from Tucson, Ariz., and Boet Preller of Johannesburg.

headline: AUSTRIA ANGERED BY STAND OF P.L.O.
abstract: A spokesman for Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria said today that Austria might suspend its contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization or even close the P.L.O.'s office in Vienna because of the organization's outbursts of joy at the slaying of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.   Chancellor Kreisky said in a radio interview over the weekend that the jubilant reaction by leaders of the P.L.O. might have consequences for Austria's ties with the organization. In the interview, which was recorded Friday evening, Mr. Kreisky said it was ''incomprehensible that anyone could praise a murder, that anyone could by happy over a murder.''

headline: Cable News Network
abstract: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, meeting with Archbishop Luigi Poggi, Vatican envoy. Photo was made from a Polish TV broadcast. Archbishop Poggi arrived in Warsaw last Sunday, sent by Pope John Paul II.

headline: POLICY UNCHANGED, EGYPTIAN AIDE SAYS
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak's remarks reaffirming Egypt's commitment to a policy of nonalignment in foreign affairs, as well as his positive response to the Saudi peace plan, does not change Egypt's relationship to the United States or its support of the Camp David accords, according to a senior Egyptian official.   Dr. Osama el-Baz, First Under Secretary in the Foreign Ministry and a longtime adviser to Mr. Mubarak, said the concern that arose in some diplomatic circles because of the tone of Mr. Mubarak's address to the nation Sunday was unwarranted.   Mr. Baz made his remarks on the eve of the resumption here tomorrow of Egyptian-Israeli autonomy talks involving the 1.3 million Palestinian Arabs living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Renewed Attention for Saudi Plan   Mr. Mubarak, in a recent interview with the Kuwaiti press, spoke positively of the Saudi peace plan, which has been receiving renewed attention since it was introduced in August and which is opposed by Israel.

headline: Chevron Deal in India
abstract: The Indian Government intends to sign a contract with Chevron Overseas Petroleum Inc. for exploration and development of a promising offshore oilfield, the oil ministry said today. In San Francisco, an official of Chevron's parent company, the Standard Oil Company of California, said final details of the contract were being worked out and that exploration was to begin next year. The field, Saurashtra II, is in the Arabian Sea about 200 miles northwest of Bombay.

headline: A TRIBUTE TO A SPRY BREZHNEV BRINGS AN EDGY SOVIET REPLY
abstract: The state of Leonid I. Brezhnev's health created a heated dispute today between Soviet and West German spokesmen.  In what seemed intended as a compliment, Kurt Becker of West Germany said at a news conference that Bonn leaders were ''impressed with the physical stability'' with which Mr. Brezhnev followed a long program on Monday without outward signs of fatigue.   The Soviet spokesman, Leonid M. Zamyatin, responded sharply: ''I can assure you that his physical condition is good, and that he is fully capable of working. That was proven by the seven hours of talks he held yesterday with the leaders of West Germany.''

headline: Florida Savings Merger Studied
abstract: The officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank board will meet in Washington, D.C., tomorrow with officials of Miami-based Amerifirst Federal Savings in an effort to arrange a merger of that savings and loan with the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Broward County.   The Fort Lauderdale-based First Federal agreed last week to merge with the giant Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association of California in a deal that would involve financial help from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

headline: HASTINGS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: WEST, HEARING OF SADAT'S DEATH, MOURNS THE LOSS OF A FRIEND
abstract: President Anwar el-Sadat was mourned through much of the West yesterday as a man of vision and courage who had brought a frail hope of peace to the Middle East.   A solemn President Reagan appeared in the north portico of the White House to deliver a statement on the assassination, which he called an act of ''infamy, cowardly infamy, that fills us with horror.''   '' In a worl d filled with hatred, he was a man of hope,'' said the President, wh o himself survived an assassination attempt on March 30 and was host to President Sadat in Washington in early August. ''He helped improv e a world tormented by malice and pettiness. Most important, he was a humanitarian unafraid to make peace. America has lost a close friend, the world has lost a great statesman, mankind has lost a ch ampion of peace.''

headline: Indian Express Closes Its Bombay Edition
abstract: The Indian Express, the country's largest English-language newspaper, announced today that it was closing its edition in Bombay and seven allied publications. It blamed political pressure and labor and financial troubles,   The announcement by Saroj Goenka, a director of The Express, followed a campaign by the newspaper in which it accused A.R.  Antulay, chief minister of Maharashtra State, of corruption.

headline: Harvester Sets Layoffs in Illinois
abstract: Financial troubles plaguing the International Harvester Company will result in the temporary or indefinite layoff of about 2,500 workers at three Illinois plants, the company announced.   The layoffs, the result of high interest rates, will last until the tractor market improves, officials said.  As previously announced, about 300 employees at the company's Farmall plant will be placed on indefinite layoff.

headline: Nigerian Troops Reach Chad
abstract: An advance contingent of 400 Nigerian troops flew to Ndjamena today to join a peacekeeping force of the Organization of African Unity in Chad. The Nigerian commander of the peace force, Maj. Gen. Geoffrey Ejiga, said last week that Nigeria's contingent would eventually total 2,000 troops.

headline: MACMILLAN AFFIRMS GIBBS SCHOOL POST
abstract: Six months ago Eleanor P. Vreeland was named acting president of the Katharine Gibbs School, the business training organization owned by Macmillan Inc., following the sudden resignation of Lynn D.  Salvage. Now the ''acting'' has been dropped, and Mrs. Vreeland is the full-fledged president and chief executive officer of the sevenbranch, 4,000-student operation.   ''I had been pegged for another slot at Macmillan Publishing,'' Mrs. Vreeland said yesterday, when asked about being thrust into the acting presidency. ''As it turned out, I had a good relationship with the school, and I enjoyed it.''

headline: FOR BRITAIN'S SOCIAL DEMOCRATS, HEADY DAYS
abstract: Britain's new Social Democratic Party has spent the first days since its momentous by-election victory in a euphoric mood, its prospects brighter than ever.   Almost every day this week, there has been news of more defections to it from the ranks of Labor Party politicians. From the public, membership applications are flooding in at the rate of more than 1,000 a week.

headline: Armenian Group Says It Set Two Bombs in Central Geneva
abstract: Two bombs went off in the center of Geneva yesterday, and today Armenian extremists claimed responsibility.

headline: SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Times Square East
abstract: To the Business Editor: I read with interest ''Forecast for New Year's Eve: A Rising Sun'' (Nov. 8), which remarked on the recent transformation of Times Square, that showcase of Madison Avenue's electronic pageantry, into a veritable ''Ginza West'' of Japanese advertising.   In analyzing the remarkable success of Japanese consumer products in penetrating the United States market, perhaps too much attention has been paid to such products' vaunted technological superiority as against the consummate marketing skill of the Japanese in enhancing American consumers' awareness of their products through advertising and other channels.   Short of turning the Ginza into Times Square East, American companies seeking to increase their share of the huge Japanese consumerproducts market might do well to learn from some for the marketing tactics of their Japanese competitors abroad.  THOMAS H. MAHONEY 4th    New York, Nov. 19, 1981

headline: Allied Out Of Chapter 11
abstract: Allied Supermarkets Inc., Detroit, said yesterday that it had emerged from Chapter 11 proceedings under the Federal Bankruptcy Act after almost three years.   Allied, with its Great Scott Supermarkets subsidiary, had filed for court relief under the bankruptcy statute on Nov. 6, 1978, after suffering substantial losses.

headline: POLISH UNION WILL DECIDE IN 10 DAYS HOW TO PROTEST THE PRICE RISES
abstract: The Solidarity union said today that it would decide in 10 days whether to call some sort of strike or national protest unless there were talks with the Government over fixing prices and improving the food supply in Poland.   Meanwhile, the Communist Party newspaper, Trybuna Ludu, attacked the union's political and economic platform, drawn up at its national convention last week in Gdansk.   The two moves suggested a quickening in the political situation with both the union and the authorities squaring off for a possible confrontation.

headline: Soviet Exile a French Citizen
abstract: Leonid Plyoushch, a mathematician who spent three years in a Soviet psychiatric hospital before being expelled to the West in 1976, has been granted French citizenship, the Government journal said today. Mr. Plyoushch, a human rights activist until his arrest, has lived in France since being expelled.

headline: Dome Trading Volume Heavy
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd. led the most active list on the Toronto Stock Exchange today amid intense investor speculation that it would report significant Beaufort Sea exploration results later this week. The company's stock has been depressed lately by uncertainty over Dome's ability to finance its Beaufort exploration program,   Dome stock rose 1/2, to 14 1/2 (Canadian), and turned over 516,754 shares.

headline: Emirates Leader Re-elected
abstract: Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahiyan, the ruler of Abu Dhabi, was re-elected unanimously today to a second five-year term as President of the United Arab Emirates, according to the official Emirates press agency.

headline: Zimbabwe Arrests Nurses and Teachers
abstract: Policemen in armored vehicles, breaking up demonstrations in central Salisbury, arrested about 750 striking nurses and teachers today, officials said.

headline: No Headline
abstract: SMUGGLED POLISH LETTER DEPICTS A STREET BATTLE IN THE PORT OF GDANSK   STOCKHOLM, Dec. 23 (Reuters) - A letter purporting to be the account of a witness says up to 40,000 people were involved last week in a street battle with troops and tanks in the Polish port of Gdansk.   The letter, circulating in Sweden, was typewritten in Polish. It said hundreds of people, ''maybe 400, maybe 500,'' were wounded on Dec. 16 when tanks were driven into a crowd that had fought troops with umbrellas and handbags.   The three-page letter was signed ''Pawel Bozyka'' and was addressed to Reuters and Swedish television. The letter was posted in Nynashamn, the port near Stockholm used by the ferry from Gdansk.  Two Polish translators who examined the text said they believed it had been written in Poland and smuggled out. An account of the letter was distributed by the Swedish news agency.

headline: MOSLEM MILITANTS WORRYING TUNISIA
abstract: President Habib Bourguiba is reportedly concerned over apparent gains in popularity made by Islamic fundamentalists with attacks on the Tunisian Government's policies of modernization and secularization.   The President, who has prided himself as a leader of secularization in the Islamic world, is described by aides as worried over the impact of increasing fundamentalist charges that he has steered this Western-oriented North African country out of the Arab mainstream. He is said to be concerned that the fundamentalists may succeed in shaking the political stability that has prevailed in Tunisia since its independence from France 25 years ago.   No one appears to know how widespread the fundamentalist movement is, but the Government cracked down on it in September after militants made anti-Bourguiba speeches in mosques. Sixty-eight fundamentalist leaders were tried and found guilty of defaming the 80-year-old President and were sentenced up to 12 years in prison.

headline: U.S. CANDLES LIGHTED FOR POLES
abstract: By United Press International   Millions of Americans placed solitary candles in their windows to show support for Solidarity, the independent labor union in Poland, and Christmas churchgoers bowed their heads in silent prayer for the beleaguered nation.   In several cities around the country, rallies were held to protest the imposition of martial law in Poland.

headline: THE NEW POTENTIAL AT CROCKER
abstract: The Crocker National Corporation, by all accounts, is bursting with potential.  A $500 million investment by Midland Bank Ltd. of Britain for a 51 percent stake in Crocker could catapult California's fifth-largest bank holding company, with current assets of $20.8 billion, into a banking giant with assets of more than $30 billion.   Industry analysts also believe that Crocker, now the nation's 13thlargest bank holding company, could join the top 10 within two or three years.   But there are nagging doubts about whether Crocker's eclectic management will be able to turn its rich potential into hard profits.  ''The big question is whether managerially they can pull it off,'' said James J. McDermott, vice president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a securities firm that closely follows the banking industry.

headline: Sabbaticals
abstract: To the Business Editor: I would like to clarify something you said in ''Capital Sabbatical'' (Oct. 25), about the President's Commission on Executive Exchange. I refer to the statement that ''private sector employers, however, often make up the difference'' when a business executive, participating in the program, takes a loss in salary.

headline: Tonka Tenders For Its Shares
abstract: The Tonka Corporation, a leading Minnesota-based manufacturer best known for its lines of metal toy trucks, announced that it would make a cash tender offer for up to 600,000 shares of its common stock at $34.50 a share.

headline: Patents; Data to Aid Unaffiliated Inventors
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Patent and Trademark Office has arranged for the transmission to its 37 depository libraries of information that should be advantageous to independent inventors. A contract was awarded this week to the ABA Corporation, Arlington, Va., to conduct a classification and search support information system.

headline: INTEREST RATES SLIGHTLY HIGHER
abstract: Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday.  Although the consensus forecast is for lower interest rates in the next few weeks, dealers said yesterday's move to lower prices and higher yields was not too surprising since it followed a week when prices rose rapidly.   ''It was a classic pattern we've seen many times,'' one Government securities dealer said, in which the market rallies after the money supply numbers come out on Friday and then subsequently retreats.   Other market participants observed that the decline in prices started in the morning when some investors and traders decided to sell notes and bonds to lock in profits from the rally of the last two weeks.

headline: MADRID TALKS ADJOURN WITH WRANGLING OVER POLAND
abstract: In its last session before adjourning for two months, the Madrid conference on detente and human rights today broke out in sharp exchanges over Poland.   The United States and other Western nations called the imposition of martial law in Poland a violation of the 1975 Helsinki agreements that have been under review here for more than a year.   ''Poland has been a living demonstration for the world of the vitality of the process launched at Helsinki which is embodied at this meeting today,'' said Max M. Kampelman, the head of the American delegation.
